fields.headline: Neville faces misconduct charge
fields.trailText: The fallout from Manchester United's FA Cup exit is likely to have serious repercussions for Gary Neville after the Football Association charged him with misconduct yesterday for his behaviour at the end of Sunday's fourth-round defeat by West Ham.
fields.body:
The fallout from Manchester United's FA Cup exit is likely to have serious repercussions for Gary Neville after the Football Association charged him with misconduct yesterday for his behaviour at the end of Sunday's fourth-round defeat by West Ham.

Neville has 14 days to request a private hearing into allegations that he tried to confront one of the assistant referees and used insulting and aggressive behaviour to the match officials.

The England defender is thought to have been incensed that Paolo di Canio's winning goal had not been ruled out for offside and that no more than four minutes of stoppage-time had been added.

According to reports, he ran towards one of the linesmen at the final whistle and the referee Paul Durkin appeared to bodycheck him out of the way before gesturing to him to leave the pitch.

"I've reported Gary Neville to the FA for an incident that happened on the pitch after the final whistle," Durkin said last night. "Now it is up to the FA's disciplinary department what action they take."

If Neville is found guilty, the FA has the power to suspend him for as many games as it feels the offence deserves. But the 25-year-old will be able to cite a near-perfect disciplinary record; this is the first time he has run into trouble with the authorities.

The United manager Sir Alex Ferguson discussed the incident with Neville yesterday and the defender has been told not to make any comment until the case is heard, probably in the next three weeks.

Ferguson had attempted to play down the incident immediately after the match and appeared to sympathise with Neville's frustration. "He [Durkin] added four minutes on but I felt there should have been a lot more," the manager said. "They don't take the time, they just guess it."

Though those comments are understood to have irked senior figures in the FA, it is unlikely they will be asking Ferguson for an explanation.

United, meanwhile, are set to offer Teddy Sheringham a new one-year deal believed to be worth £35,000 a week. His present 12-month agreement expires this summer and Ferguson is keen for him to stay at Old Trafford.

Ferguson feels the striker, who turns 35 in April, deserves a new contract and he reckons he could get another one in 12 months' time. He is the club's top scorer this season with 18 goals. "He's been phenomenal," said Ferguson.

fields.headline: Spurs chase Booth in emergency
fields.trailText: Tottenham fans pleading with the club to buy quality players capable of returning the glory, glory years to White Hart Lane must have sighed in despair yesterday. Spurs's latest recruit is Andy Booth, a 27-year-old journeyman striker who is due to join on a month's loan from the First Division strugglers Sheffield Wednesday.
fields.body:
Tottenham fans pleading with the club to buy quality players capable of returning the glory, glory years to White Hart Lane must have sighed in despair yesterday. Spurs's latest recruit is Andy Booth, a 27-year-old journeyman striker who is due to join on a month's loan from the First Division strugglers Sheffield Wednesday.

The once mighty Spurs have been reduced to such desperate measures because injuries to three strikers - Les Ferdinand, Steffen Iversen and Les Ferdinand - have left them without a partner for their £11m star Sergei Rebrov.

Money for permanent signings at Tottenham will be made available only once Enic's takeover of the club is completed in the next few weeks. And even then the size of the transfer kitty is not expected to be large.

Tottenham's director of football David Pleat, who signed Booth at Wednesday, admitted the deal was "somewhat unusual". After scoring 54 goals in 123 League appearances for Huddersfield and earning a £2.7m switch to Hillsborough in August 1996, Booth has managed 27 goals in 130 league games.

"He's strong in the air, very wholehearted, very genuine and will give us a bit more power," said Pleat.

"It's an opportunity for him to show himself and, who knows, if he does exceptionally well, he may prove a real point."

Spurs hope the deal will go through today and Booth will be available for Wednesday's game at West Ham, though the player admits: "There are no plans for a permanent move."

Sven-Goran Eriksson has given his biggest hint yet that West Ham's Joe Cole is not far away from a full international debut. After watching him help beat Manchester United on Sunday, England's new coach labelled the midfielder "one of the biggest young talents I've seen in this country".

Meanwhile Cole's manager at Upton Park, Harry Redknapp, is hoping to turn the loan signings of Hannu Tihinen and Sébastien Schemmel into permanent deals.

The FA has played down speculation that England will meet Trinidad and Tobago in a Caribbean friendly this year. It says that 2002 would offer the earliest date.

fields.headline: French referees say 'non'
fields.trailText: French referees will refuse to officiate at a replay of a French league first division match between Racing Strasbourg and Metz after violence during recent games, their union said yesterday.
fields.body:
French referees will refuse to officiate at a replay of a French league first division match between Racing Strasbourg and Metz after violence during recent games, their union said yesterday.

In the most serious incident, a match between Strasbourg and Metz in December was abandoned after the female assistant referee Nelly Viennot was hit by a firecracker.

The French National League disciplinary committee has ordered the match to be replayed behind closed doors but referees said they would not take part. "This match was a much too bitter pill to swallow and we won't swallow it," Bernard Saules, the head of the referees' union, said. "We won't referee it."

Last weekend, referees staged a protest against the recent violence with officials holding up the kick-off at one match and handing out leaflets to players at another. The French Football Federation yesterday met referees to discuss the problem.

 The Coventry City chairman Bryan Richardson is to impose life bans on supporters found responsible for the violence at Maine Road on Saturday. Shaun Goater's injury-time winner for Manchester City in the FA Cup led to fighting in the main stand.

fields.headline: Rovers dismiss Holloway
fields.trailText: Ian Holloway was last night sacked as manager of Bristol Rovers, the club he previously played for and pledged to remain with for the rest of his football career.
fields.body:
Ian Holloway was last night sacked as manager of Bristol Rovers, the club he previously played for and pledged to remain with for the rest of his football career.

The 37-year-old Bristolian, away from the ground this week with what was described as a virus, has struggled this season to find a settled or successful side and they are only one place off the Second Division relegation zone.

The Rovers vice-chairman Geoff Dunford said: "We feel Ian has taken us as far as he can." But the shock news will bring an angry reaction from many supporters at the Memorial stadium. Despite Rovers' poor playing record Holloway has remained immensely popular, seemingly the ideal local-boy boss of a homely club.

"I'm very disappointed," said Holloway, Rovers' manager since 1996. "But the foundations are strong."

His anxiety was revealed recently when he was briefly involved in an altercation with fans near the dug-out. Rovers have still not won a home league game this season.

fields.headline: Prisons: the best and worst
fields.standfirst: Esther Addley finds shining examples and appalling conditions in Britain' jails
fields.trailText: Esther Addley finds shining examples and appalling conditions in Britain's jails
fields.body:
Most overcrowded

Birmingham prison, a Victorian monster three miles from the city centre, tops the Prison Reform Trust's roll of dishonour on overcrowding. More than 750 of the 1,083 inmates are crammed two to a one-person cell, in a facility built for 732. In November, the prison's board of visitors observed hundreds of inmates having to eat in cells beside open lavatories. Dishonourable mentions also to Leeds (600 doubling up), Preston and Durham (500 each) and Liverpool (400+).

Most violent

The Prison Reform Trust has calculated the overall risk of being assaulted while in prison at 9.9%. At Brinsford young offenders' institute, outside Wolverhampton, this soars to a shocking 67.5%. Youth prisons occupied the worst four positions for prison violence, all with an assault rate of over 45%. In contrast, assault rates in male open prisons average only 2.5%. At least 10 had no recorded assaults last year.

Least time locked up

Latchmere House, a former borstal, has been a resettlement prison since 1991, and works vigorously to integrate inmates into the local community in preparation for their release. More than 70 do real jobs in the community, and the Prison Reform Trust found that inmates spent an average of 74.1 hours a week in "purposeful activity", compared to the national average of 23.3 hours.

Most time locked up

Bottom was Brixton, with only 11.1 hours per week, less than two hours per day, spent doing anything worthwhile.

Worst for visiting

Despite a strong challenge by Portland young offenders' institution, situated on a remote Devon peninsula to which visitors must walk a mile from the nearest bus stop, Dartmoor prison just nicks the booby prize for least accessible facility. In 1979, Lord Justice May called it "simply against nature" that the prison was still in use. Visitors must get a train to Plymouth, followed by a bus to Yelverton and a six-mile taxi journey. Buses run only every two hours on Sundays. Some 25,000 prisoners, over a third of the total population, are held more than 50 miles from their committal court town.

Most drug-ridden

Much of the blame for the problems at Featherstone, on Wolverhampton's outskirts, has been attributed to its design. The "hotel principle" of locating cells along short cul-de-sacs off a central open area created a claustrophobic space, difficult for staff to police. Until recently, gangs carried out muggings along the corridors, though restricting movement has reduced this. None the less, Featherstone's drugs problem is the worst in the prison service: 35.8% of inmates had positive results for drugs in random tests.

Least drug-ridden

Albany prison on the Isle of Wight, 85% of whose inmates are sex offenders, had the best record on drugs last year, no inmate testing positively. The overall rate of drug use last year was 14.4%, a marked reduction on previous years, and lower than the prison service's target of 18.5%.

Most escapes

The prison service's record on escapes has improved sharply since the early-90s, falling by 89%, despite the prison population increasing by almost a half. There have been no Category A (high-risk) escapes since 1995. During 1999-2000, there were 30 from prisons and eight from prison service escorts. This compares with 202 in 1994-5. The most recent serious breakouts were of nine high-security prisoners from Whitemoor and Parkhurst, two of the most secure prisons in England and Wales, in 1994 and 1995 respectively. The UK's biggest breakout was from the Maze in 1983, when 38 IRA prisoners commandeered a kitchen van.

Cleanest

The Prisons Handbook described Lancaster Farms YOI, on farmland outside the city, as "a shining example of commitment and care". The Chief Inspectorate of Prisons report in 1995 praised it as "very clean, with no sign of any graffiti; cells were the tidiest and cleanest we have seen; evening association was more like a first-class, well-organised boys' club than a remand centre".

Dirtiest

Birmingham was one of the very worst, again. Its own most recent CIP report (another, probably even more damning, is imminent) observed: "One part of the centre [was] the untidiest and dirtiest we have seen anywhere." The hospital block was particularly "appalling". This was a small improvement on Stephen Tumim's report while chief inspector in the early 90s, which found cockroaches, pigeons and feral cats.

Best gardens

A hotly contested category, with a number of institutions furiously trimming their box hedges each spring in a bid to land the coveted Windlesham trophy, awarded each year by the Royal Horticultural Society. The rules have recently been changed to prevent victors winning two years in a row, a move designed to curb the runaway success of Whatton prison in Notts, which won three years in a row in the mid-1990s and is the current trophy holder. Insiders tip Kingston prison in Portsmouth to land the award this year. Its pansies, apparently, are of particular note.

Best food

Stephen Tumim was particularly taken by the dinner he was served at North Sea Camp, a small open prison near Boston. His successor, Sir David Ramsbotham, was pleased to discover recently that his recommendation for a wider provision of condiments in the canteen had been acted upon. Attached to the prison is a working farm with 900 bacon pigs, 100 breeding sows and 900 sheep. The bacon is reputed to be very tasty.

Best community relations

Blantyre House was built in the 1910s as a training facility for deprived boys, but has been a Category C resettlement prison since 1991. Because it is preparing inmates for eventual release, a high proportion of them work in the local community after spending six months inside. Each year the prison hosts a "stir crazy" day for people with disabilities and their carers, with the prisoners raising funds themselves to provide food and entertainment. They also put on an annual pantomime and host a Christmas lunch for local pensioners. The reoffending rate, at 8%, is one of the lowest in the country.

webTitle: Ian Katz visits a jail for the aged

fields.headline: The jail for the aged
fields.standfirst: Many of the 1,000 elderly convicts in British prisons are so infirm that they pose little or no threat to society. So why are they still behind bars? Ian Katz visits the country's only jail for the aged
fields.trailText: Many of the 1,000 elderly convicts in British prisons are so infirm that they pose little or no threat to society. So why are they still behind bars? Ian Katz visits the country's only jail for the aged
fields.body:
No one seems to know the whole of Harry's story, but this is what they do know. He was born in Kilmarnock, worked on the railways, became an alcoholic after his parents died. They know he lived rough and that in 1991 he was sentenced to life for starting a series of fires. He is 71.

It was never easy to get through to Harry at the best of times, and a couple of years ago it began to get even harder. Depending on who you ask, he was suffering from either Alzheimer's or a form of alcohol-induced dementia. Everyone agrees that he frequently did not know where he was, that he began falling over regularly and became incontinent. Once he borrowed a lighter to light a cigarette and accidentally set his hair on fire. They put him in a cell with a CCTV camera because they were so worried he would do himself an injury.

Recently, when he could no longer walk without help, he was moved to a nearby prison hospital. Doctors there said he should be released, but to where? "It's difficult to find nursing homes that are prepared to take people like that," says Stuart McLean, who retired as governor of Portsmouth's Kingston prison last week. "The last thing they want is to have someone who may be disruptive."

Harry's case highlights one of the thorniest questions facing our penal system: when, if ever, is someone too old or infirm to be kept behind bars? It is a delicate balancing act between compassion and risk, and right now the scales are tipped heavily against compassion. "If someone has a terminal illness I will pull out all the stops to give them the dignity of dying a free man," says Mr McLean. "But apart from that there's not a lot I can do. It's difficult to get people released because everyone wants to make sure there's not going to be some sort of miraculous recovery. That can be terribly embarrassing."

Mr McLean has more experience of these grim calculations than most. Kingston is the only prison in the country with a wing dedicated to elderly prisoners. The administrative wing of the Victorian jail was converted into accommodation for around 30 older prisoners five years ago in response to the rising number of elderly inmates in the system. The numbers of old prisoners has mirrored the explosion in the prison population of the last 15 years. In 1989 there were just 345 prisoners over the age of 60; by 1999 there were 1,053. There are 250 inmates in their 70s and 21 over 80. Until now, however, the prison service has devoted little or no thought to how to handle older inmates. Individual jails do the best they can, usually housing their older inmates in so-called VP (vulnerable prisoner) wings or prison hospitals. "[The prison service] has no policy on the elderly at all," Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, says in an interview with the Guardian to be published on Friday. "When I discover an 87-year-old on a Zimmer frame with Alzheimer's in a high-security prison, I'm sorry, but I think that is a nonsense."

Built in 1877 as Portsmouth's town jail, Kingston prison is a generously proportioned, three-storey stone structure surrounded by 20-foot walls topped with a roll of barbed wire. It is renowned for its gardens - complete with aviaries, manicured hedges, water features and artificial bowling green - and its football team. (The team's position at the top of the local league could have something to do with the fact that all fixtures are played at home and visiting supporters are forbidden, admits Mr McLean.) It is also the only prison in Britain that takes only lifers, meaning that at least three-quarters of its inmates are murderers.

The idea behind H wing was to give older lifers some protection from the rest of the population, says Mr McLean. Its inmates can circulate in the prison but other prisoners cannot pass through the two heavy gates that separate it from the rest of the jail. The wing itself has many of the trappings of a care home: stairlifts, specially equipped baths and alarm buttons in each room. Its rooms, each shared by four inmates, are bright and comparatively airy and there are several spartan communal rooms that could easily be mistaken for doctors' waiting rooms. Staff appear to be patient and courteous. "The biggest problem with them is motivation," says Jim Clark, one of the officers on the wing. "We've tried to get them out to play bowls but they just won't go. About a third of them work and the rest of them don't want to move away from their TVs."

Sir David Ramsbotham has praised Kingston for its treatment of elderly prisoners, so why, I wonder, has the press been kept out until now? A prison service official offers a surprisingly candid response: "A lot of people in the service have doubts about whether these people should still be in prison."

It's easy to see why. In one room I meet Boom Boom, a man who looks to be in his 70s leaning awkwardly on a three-legged walking stick. Like many of the inmates on E wing, he is dressed in tracksuit bottoms, T-shirt and slippers. I ask him how old he is and he holds up one hand to show five fingers, while making a series of incomprehensible sounds.

"You're 60, aren't you, Boom Boom?!" bellows his room-mate, Frank. Frank explains that Boom Boom suffered a stroke before being admitted to prison: "He can't do much. When he arrived at the Scrubs all he could say was 'boom boom'. That's how he got his name." The large, high-ceilinged room is divided into four by a series of drab partitions. The floor is dirty and the cream walls are bare. A TV is flickering noiselessly in the corner and a few books are scattered on the floor. It looks just like the kind of care home you hope you'll never end up in.

Mr McLean is quick to point out that Boom Boom and Frank are among the scruffiest inmates on the wing. "They were living rough before they came in," he says. "No one else will share with them."

Upstairs the rooms are tidier and less gloomy. The furniture would not look out of place in a student accommodation block. In one room the walls are decorated with pieces of wrapping paper. In another there is an inmate who spends his time making replica Faberge eggs.

A photo of Princess Diana has pride of place by Sam's bed. He is 50, 11 years into a life sentence for murder. He's one of the youngest prisoners on the wing, admitted because he suffered a stroke. He has barely seen the two grandchildren who were born since his conviction but he thinks his age has helped him to get through his sentence: "If I was 21 or 22 at the time I wouldn't have been able to make it."

The average age of prisoners on E wing is 65, but most look older than that. "People age quicker in prison," says Gill Ripiner, the senior nurse who runs the prison dispensary. "A 55-year-old inside would be more like a 65-year-old outside. The stress levels are high, they can't do things to relieve the stress and they can't do as much exercise."

Although they are more likely to suffer medical problems, specialising in older inmates has its advantages, says Mr McLean: "The staff-to-prisoner ratio can be quite low because you're unlikely to have a serious problem [with violence]. The sort of problem I'm worried about is not an attack, it's that someone will light a cigarette and discard the match." Its not just a figure of speech. A senior officer later tells me that several cigarette burns were found on Harry's torso when he was transferred to hospital. "He'd obviously just rolled over and lain on them. Fortunately all the mattresses are flame resistant."

Mr McLean says the prison has encountered two unforeseen problems. One has been the reluctance of many older prisoners to go anywhere near E wing. "It's perceived as dead men's shoes. People think the only way out is by dying." In fact, he says, more prisoners have been released to lower-security establishments than have died.

The second problem is that many of the inmates are in a poorer condition than the unit had bargained for. "Unfortunately, fit elderly people do become progressively more frail and the problem we've got now is that we've got people who really we shouldn't be keeping any longer who need to move from residential care into a nursing home, and we are not a nursing home."

Albert, a neatly dressed 69-year-old who has served 18 years of a life sentence for murdering his wife, describes the condition of some of the E wing prisoners in more graphic terms. "Christ, we all get old, but you've got blokes pissing in the plant pots and blokes shitting themselves." He says he was grateful for a move back to the main part of the prison after he underwent a hip replacement operation. "I was in there with a chap who'd done 42 years and one night I wake up and he's pissing up against the wall. It could have been brilliant but you've got the wrong people in there. You have people who should be in a hospice."

Mr McLean acknowledges that there are at least two prisoners on the wing who have "lost it" and "others who you talk to and you think: 'I'm not really getting through here.' Dick's case illustrates the dilemma facing the prison authorities. Dick is 57 and has served 16 years of a life sentence for rape. He is suffering from motor neurone disease and wears calipers. Doctors have called for his release, the senior officer tells me, "which is all very well, but where are you going to put him? He's got to go to a care home but the fact of the matter is that these places often have a lot of young women working in them. Physically he couldn't rape anybody, but he could ravish someone - and can you risk letting that happen?"

Already, says, Alisdair Munroe, there's not much difference between E wing and many care homes on the outside "except that it's all male and we don't let them out".

Frank, however, has little time for those who point out that life for him is not very different from what it would be like if he were in a home. "They say you must like prison. Nobody likes prison. It's a stupid question, it's daft. The same people asking it don't go to the door and open it."

webTitle: Cut jail population to minimum, Blair told

fields.headline: Cut jail population to minimum, Blair told
fields.trailText: Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, is expected this week to call on the government to end prison overcrowding, arguing that it is time the jail population was reduced to "an unavoidable minimum".
fields.body:
Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, is expected this week to call on the government to end prison overcrowding, arguing that it is time the jail population was reduced to "an unavoidable minimum". This week sees the 10th anniversary of the publication of Lord Woolf's report into prison conditions in the wake of the Strangeways riot and he is expected to use the annual Prison Reform Trust lecture on Wednesday to argue that its reform agenda is as relevant today as it was a decade ago.

The prison population stood at only 45,600 when Lord Woolf first called for prison numbers to be reduced to the "unavoidable minimum" but it now stands at more than 62,000 and is projected to rise to 70,800 in the next two years. Lord Woolf is expected to revive his recommendations that prisoners should be held nearer their homes. Some 26,000 in mates are still held more than 50 miles from home, and 11,000 more than 100 miles.

The former Conservative home secretary, Lord Hurd of Westwell, in an interview with the Guardian, also warns of the corrosive impact of overcrowding. He says that it is time for inmates to be given the vote and for a prime minister to visit a prison.

"If prisoners had the vote then MPs would take a good deal more interest in conditions in prison," he said. Lord Hurd also says no serving prime minister has ever visited a prison and discloses that a plan for Tony Blair to do so was shelved because of public relations fears.

"It is one of our public services and prisons are important institutions. Prisons are not a series of wastepaper baskets into which you can simply toss somebody and not hear from them again."

fields.headline: Granada slashes jobs
fields.trailText:
5.15pm: Granada Media is cutting back on staff in Norwich, Southampton and Bristol, reports Jason Deans.
Nov 7: Granada's plans for United interests
Oct 3: Willis stays, Wall goes
fields.body:
Granada Media is axing up to 110 jobs in the Norwich, Southampton and Bristol.

The cutbacks follow its acquisition of Anglia, Meridian TV and the HTV network production businesses in the deal with United News and Media last year.

Between 25 and 35 programme-making posts will go in Anglia's Norwich base as the Survival unit is moved to Bristol.

More jobs, possibly up to 15, are expected to go in Bristol.

The Survival team will be merged with the existing natural history programme-makers who work under Tom Archer, United Productions controller of factual programmes.

In addition, 25-30 jobs are to be lost across Anglia Television's Norwich-based planning, scheduling and promotions, and studio resources operations.

In Southampton, the Meridian Broadcasting payroll is to be cut by up to 30 staff in administration and technical areas.

Granada will seek alternative employment within the group for as many as possible of the staff affected.

Earlier this month, the company revealed a further 50-60 jobs were under threat in Norwich as Anglia Multi-Media is moved to Manchester and merged with Granada Learning.

Sharon Elliott, supervisory official at union Bectu, condemned the scale of the proposed cuts.

"Our members on all sites will be shocked and hugely disappointed that this is almost the first real taste of being part of Granada Media," she said.

"It is unacceptable to us that Granada Media should want to show talented and experienced staff the door at operations that are already run efficiently."

But Granada Media executives defended the staff cuts.

"Today's announcement means Anglia is now well placed to meet the challenges of a competitive global market for programming, while remaining at the heart of the region," said Anglia TV managing director Graham Creelman.

Meridian managing director Mary McAnally added: "Meridian has always had a proud tradition of innovation and professionalism.

"As part of Granada Media we can now build on this, developing our programming, facilities and commercial operations."

fields.headline: Gloves off as BBC enters the ring
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
6.30pm update The BBC could become the main UK broadcaster for boxing with deals involving the biggest names in the sport, writes Jason Deans.
Jan 30: BBC lands Lennox Lewis fights
Jan 19: BBC clinches Olympic boxer deal
More BBC stories
fields.body:
The BBC has been unable to conclude its deal with Lennox Lewis today but hopes to announce it has signed up the heavyweight boxer at a press conference tomorrow

It is positioning itself to become the major British broadcaster for boxing with a series of deals involving the biggest names in the sport.

Today's expected announcement that BBC Sport has poached world heavyweight champion Lennox Lewis from BSkyB is a massive boost to a department that has lost several major sports contracts in recent years.

BBC executives have also held "exploratory talks" with featherweight title-holder Naseem Hamed, who has only two fights left before his current BSkyB deal ends.

And Olympic gold medallist Audley Harrison has already signed a BBC deal covering the first two years of his professional boxing career.

"You could reach a situation by the end of this year where all the major British boxers are on the BBC," said one boxing source.

The deal with Mr Lewis is believed to cover four fights involving the champion himself and 20 bouts in all.

The agreement is also thought to allow for Lion Promotions, which is run by Mr Lewis's business manager Adrian Ogun, to promote the BBC fights.

There have also been reports of a BBC approach to Frank Warren, the leading UK boxing promoter, about bringing his Sports Networks stable of fighters to the corporation.

A BBC Sport spokesman said there "hadn't been any talks" with Mr Warren.

Mr Warren also dismissed the speculation, saying all fighters contracted to Sports Network remained with Sky.

But boxing insiders have speculated that in the current climate, with the BBC getting serious about the sport again, Mr Warren may be keen to reach an agreement under which the public service broadcaster and BSkyB share rights to live boxing action and highlights.

webTitle: Alder Hey report on use of children's organs

fields.headline: Alder Hey report on use of children's organs
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText:
Why was an inquiry into the use of children's organs launched?
Former health secretary Frank Dobson launched the inquiry in October 1999 following revelations that three children's hospitals had been harvesting hearts, lungs, brains and other organs from dead babies without their parents' informed consent. Parents were distraught to find that thousands of body parts had been removed and kept in hospital storage.
fields.body:
Why was an inquiry into the use of children's organs launched?
Former health secretary Frank Dobson launched the inquiry in October 1999 following revelations that three children's hospitals had been harvesting hearts, lungs, brains and other organs from dead babies without their parents' informed consent. Parents were distraught to find that thousands of body parts had been removed and kept in hospital storage.

What has the inquiry examined?
The inquiry, led by chief medical officer Liam Donaldson, has looked at what information parents are given and what they understand by "consent" and recommended future practice across the NHS. The census coincided with the publication of the report on Liverpool's Alder Hey Children's Hospital, where 2,080 organs were removed from 800 children.

How many organs have been harvested?
The Donaldson report found that 105,000 organs are retained at hospitals and medical schools across England.

When did the scandal break?
The scandal first broke in 1999 when it emerged that the hearts and other organs of 170 children who died at Bristol Royal Infirmary had been kept without their consent. The scandal at Alder Hey emerged soon after. It became clear that organ harvesting at the hospital went back decades.

Have any other practices been criticised?
Last week it emerged that the Birmingham and Liverpool hospitals had also given thymus glands, removed during heart surgery from live children, to a pharmaceutical company for research in return for financial donations. Alder Hey also stored 1,500 foetuses that were miscarried, stillborn or aborted without consent.

Why are organs removed?
Postmortems are performed when there is doubt about the cause of death, which is especially important in young children. Organs and other tissues are removed and examined during autopsies.

How did this happen?
Doctors and scientists thought that telling parents exactly what happens during and after a postmortem was too distressing. Parents did not realise that by signing a consent form for a post mortem stating "tissues may be retained" for research that this allowed the hospital to remove or dispose of all their child's organs. Some parents of children who died at Alder Hey still do not know what body parts the hospital still has.

Has any guidance been issued already?
Prof Donaldson has issued interim guidance to hospitals, requiring them to tell parents exactly what autopsies involve and get their explicit permission if there is any need to remove organs.

What does Prof Donaldson's report recommend?
It says major changes in the law are needed to ensure parents, patients and relatives are giving "informed consent" to the removal of organs during postmortem examinations.

Who has been called to account?
The Alder Hey inquiry, chaired by Michael Redfern QC, points the finger at the "rogue" Dutch pathologist Dick van Velzen, who kept an 11-year-old's head in a jar. During his time at the hospital he systematically ordered the "unethical and illegal stripping of every organ from every child who had had a post mortem". Four NHS staff, including the current chief executive, have also been suspended. The Redfern report has been referred to Merseyside police and passed to the Director of Public Prosecutions. The General Medical Council has also begun an investigation of Prof van Velzen, and is holding an emergency meeting on Friday to consider limiting his registration.

What action will the government now take?
Health secretary Alan Milburn has announced changes in the law governing consent. The 1961 Human Tissue Act, which currently regulates organ retention, will be amended to make it illegal for staff to ignore informed consent. A new consent form will be introduced throughout the NHS, and a code of practice will be issued on the use of organs by pharmaceutical companies. A special commission will oversee the return of body parts to relatives who wish to have them.

How has the medical profession reacted?
The British Medical Association and the Royal College of Pathologists accept the "doctor knows best" attitude is no longer acceptable and relatives should be fully briefed informed in order to give informed consent. The BMA has been working with the Department of Health on new guidance. But they are concerned that the medical profession should not be demonised.

How have parents reacted?
Parents have welcomed the referral of the Redfern report to the Director of Public Prosecutions. But they called for an independent inquiry into what happened at Alder Hey before and after Prof van Velzen worked there. They also want pharmaceutical companies that received body parts from the hospital to be investigated.

Four NHS staff, including the current chief executive, have also been suspended. The Redfern report has been referred to Merseyside police and passed to the Director of Public Prosecutions. The General Medical Council has also begun an investigation of Prof van Velzen, and is holding an emergency meeting on Friday to consider limiting his registration. What action will the government now take? Health secretary Alan Milburn has announced changes in the law governing consent. The 1961 Human Tissue Act, which currently regulates organ retention, will be amended to make it illegal for staff to ignore informed consent. A new consent form will be introduced throughout the NHS, and a code of practice will be issued on the use of organs by pharmaceutical companies. A special commission will oversee the return of body parts to relatives who wish to have them. How has the medical profession reacted? The British Medical Association and the Royal College of Pathologists accept the "doctor knows best" attitude is no longer acceptable and relatives should be fully briefed informed in order to give informed consent. The BMA has been working with the Department of Health on new guidance. But they are concerned that the medical profession should not be demonised. How have parents reacted? Parents have welcomed the referral of the Redfern report to the Director of Public Prosecutions. But they called for an independent inquiry into what happened at Alder Hey before and after Prof van Velzen worked there. They also want pharmaceutical companies that received body parts from the hospital to be investigated.

fields.headline: UUP deputy to leave Westminster
fields.trailText: The Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor, is to resign from his Westminster seat at the general election, he announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor, is to resign from his Westminster seat at the general election, he announced yesterday.

The 63-year-old Strangford MP, who is also a Stormont assembly member, said he was stepping down because of his demanding workload.

Mr Taylor, who has represented the constituency for 18 years, said however that he had no intention of retiring from politics.

He was a key player in the Good Friday agreement negotiations and he has expressed his desire to increase his role at Stormont and in Northern Ireland public life. Mr Taylor is also keen to play a prominent role in the new police board.

However, his resignation comes at a critical point in efforts to save the deadlocked political process and could put the UUP leader, Mr Trimble, under more pressure from hardliners in his party.

A fierce battle for his Westminster seat is now likely to follow between the pro-Good Friday agreement wing of the UUP and the anti-agreement Democratic Unionist candidate, Iris Robinson. Mr Taylor, 63, had already been selected to defend Strangford. He won a comfortable 6,000 majority over the DUP in 1997. But Ian Paisley's party is promoting Mrs Robinson, a Stormont representative and the wife of deputy leader, Peter Robinson, as a strong contender.

One of Mr Trimble's closest Commons allies, the Fermanagh/South Tyrone MP, Ken Maginnis, is also leaving Westminster at the election and Ulster Unionists were dealt a blow at the polls last autumn when the DUP's William McCrea defeated their candidate, David Burnside, in the South Antrim byelection.

Intense talks to broker a deal between unionists, nationalists and republicans on paramilitary decommissioning are making some progress, although the new Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, cautioned against over-optimism.

Tony Blair will meet the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, in Downing Street on Wednesday and they will have to act fast if there is to be a breakthrough before election fever starts.

Ulster Unionist hardliners have warned that the party could be annihilated at the polls if Mr Trimble signed up to anything short of a strong guarantee that there would be substantial IRA disarmament.

Mr Taylor said last night: "I expect the Ulster Unionists to hold the Strangford seat and I want to contribute more to the success of the Stormont assembly. This has been a very difficult decision to make but I believe it is best for the party and myself if I am to increase my political activity on other public bodies."

fields.headline: Scotland confirms care charge divide
fields.trailText: Britain is set to have a two-tier system of care for the elderly within 15 months after the Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, confirmed yesterday that he would abolish personal care charges north of the border.
fields.body:
Britain is set to have a two-tier system of care for the elderly within 15 months after the Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, confirmed yesterday that he would abolish personal care charges north of the border.

The commitment followed a weekend of wrangling over whether the executive had really set itself on a collision course with Westminster by pledging to abandon the charges.

But yesterday Mr McLeish said he could be no more explicit. "We are embarking on a process which will have as its destination the implementation of free personal care," he said.

He later added: "There will be no backsliding."

The executive is working towards a programme which aims to ensure that as soon as April 2002 any elderly person living north of the border will be entitled to free personal care, which covers things like washing and cooking. But elsewhere in the UK this benefit will remain means tested and only nursing care will be free.

Downing Street yesterday ruled out any policy reversal for England and Wales and denied the move north of the border was an embarrassment. "The fact different decisions are made is not an accidental consequence of devolution," said a spokeswoman.

But pressure groups said yesterday's Scottish announcement would be used as ammunition to force amendments to the health and social care bill, currently on its way through Westminster.

"It is patently ridiculous that we are now going to have a situation where an elderly person living a few miles across the border will be up to £350 a week worse off in terms of paying for their care," said a spokeswoman for Age Concern England.

The abolition of personal care charges was a key recommendation of a recent royal commission, chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland. But it was initially rejected by the administrations on both sides of the border as too costly and of disproportionate benefit to better-off pensioners.

When he took over from the late Donald Dewar, Mr McLeish made it clear he wanted to implement the Sutherland proposals in full.

By the middle of last week Mr McLeish backtracked on the issue and the executive announced it planned only to make the means testing system used to calculate who is exempt from personal care charges more fair.

The move was widely interpreted as recognition that there was opposition to implementation of Sutherland not just from Westminster but within Mr McLeish's own cabinet.

But after Labour's Liberal Democrat coalition partners threatened to rebel and vote with the Scottish National party on the issue, the executive was forced to make an emergency statement to the Scottish parliament. The wording of that statement was ambiguous, however, and it was not until yesterday that Mr McLeish categorically committed the executive to Sutherland's recommendation, going further than many had predicted. "We are embracing the principles of Sutherland in full," he said.

Some analysts have predicted that the abolition of personal care charges in Scotland will lead to an influx of wealthy pensioners, anxious to protect their savings, from south of the border.

A spokesman for the Scottish executive said a committee led by the health minister, Malcolm Chisholm, would be looking at cross-border issues.

Jess Barrow, of Age Concern Scotland, dismissed the idea of a mass migration.

"This is Scotland, not Florida," she said.

fields.headline: BBC letter on plans for advertising-funded website
fields.trailText: BBC letter admitting the corporation is considering launching a website funded by adverts.
fields.body:
The BBC is clear that BBC Online is aimed solely at the needs of UK licence payers who pay for it.

"BBC Online has been regularly praised by Parliament and public for taking the BBC's traditional public service purposes into the digital age, increasing choice with a wide range of quality content to the benefit of all licence payers. It offers a new way of bringing our audiences information, news and education in a far more convenient form and at greater depth than ever before; increasing access into the creative and information resource at the heart of the BBC. It will provide new opportunities for interaction as the technology and convergence develops.

But the central conundrum remains - unlike television and radio, the key characteristic of the technology is that it is open to everybody, anywhere, anytime. Consequently, there is an impressive level of interest in BBC sites from around the world; which is good for Britain, good for the BBC. That is why the BBC World Service, through grant-in-aid funding from the Foreign Office, pay a proportion of the international distribution costs for the world news. But nonetheless, as international interest grows in sites around the UK, how do you ensure that UK licence payers are not subsidising the rest of the world's internet users attracted by the quality and integrity of the whole BBC Online offer?

The Government's review into the BBC's future funding and the comprehensive public and Parliamentary debate into the issues over some 18 months concluded that the BBC should "launch separately-branded non-UK websites aimed directly at overseas users of BBC Online. The content of these sites might be similar to BBC Online, but we have been assured that it should be possible to direct most non-UK users to the sites specified for them. There is no reason why these international websites should not be run on a commercial basis, accepting both advertising and e-commerce revenues."

This view was endorsed and encouraged by Government and Parliament, particularly the Department of Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee.

Against a background of tough Government imposed targets for savings and commercial revenue generation as part of the BBC's recent licence fee settlement, the BBC is therefore vigorously exploring all possibilities for generating commercial revenue from its international online users to plough back into its publicly funded programmes and services to the benefit of its licence payers.

The notion of commercially-funded international access points to the BBC's licence-fee funded news online services is part of this, and is at an early stage of development. If such a proposal were to come to fruition it would, of course, have to pass the BBC Governors who act independently on behalf of the public interest, would require DCMS approval, and would be subject to all the usual UK and EU competition laws.

Caroline Thomson
BBC director of public policy

fields.headline: Multicoloured swap shop
fields.standfirst: What's a sculpture of a crying child and a horrified parent doing in front of a 19th century painting of the Great Exhibition?  Adrian Searle on an exercise in juxtaposition
fields.trailText: What's a sculpture of a crying child and a horrified parent doing in front of a 19th century painting of the Great Exhibition? Adrian Searle on an exercise in juxtaposition
fields.body:
Late Saturday afternoon at the Serpentine Gallery and the German artist Hans Haacke is still tinkering, skewing the symmetries of his arrangement of more than 200 works borrowed from the Victoria and Albert Museum. Haacke is trying to disturb the obsessive-compulsive manners of modern display, messing with curatorial etiquette, making sure the vitrines don't sit square against the walls. Haacke has wrested a vast clutter of things from the lumbering, baggy, omnivorous, many-pocketed institution that is the V&A: photographs, prints, sculptures, pots, paintings, items of clothing, religious artefacts, toys and trivia. Haacke has rearranged all this, regardless of museological classification. In so doing, he has created his own system, which is at times as as tonishing as it is annoying, as subtle as often as it is blundering.

The entire Serpentine display should be read as a single work, called Mixed Messages. It is part of a larger collaboration between the Serpentine and the V&A, where 15 artists have also had works installed. Both parts of the show, called Give & Take, open to the public today, following a deal brokered between Julia Peyton-Jones, director of the Serpentine, and the soon-to-be- departing V&A director Alan Borg.

Objects, as often as they elicit curiosity, can also incite anger. Mixed Messages is a mad conversation piece, in which stories about empire, colonialism, race, sex, religion, class and cultural division collide with the things which represent them. Things have a life of their own; they have histories which refuse to submit to the categories which would contain them. They have a present, as well as a past.

Haacke has been described as a conceptual artist, and as an artist concerned with the social conditions of art. He describes his role at the Serpentine, lightly, as "social secretary", getting all these things into the building and getting them to talk to one another. The party - if it is one - begins in high Victorian drag, with wallpaper, pot plants, a gilded mirror and commemorative Great Exhibition vases. Albert and Victoria look on, but Richard Billingham's tattooed mum couldn't give a toss, and does a jigsaw in the corner. Cindy Sherman, dressed for a date at Tiffany's, is an actress in search of a role. She's in the wrong movie. Lady Wolverton's more like it, dressed-up as Brittania for an 1897 Devonshire house ball, with her shield and trident.

You laugh, but things quickly take another turn, as one would expect from Haacke. He's not really a party animal. When I heard he was showing at the Serpentine, I thought he might do something extreme; for his great work in the German Pavilion in Venice in 1993, he tore up the floor with jack-hammers, leaving us to teeter over the rubble, and to think about Germany's history. Museums can have dark histories, too. Can any such institution avoid looking at its holdings in a guilty light? The climate at the V&A might well be controlled, the air purified, the lighting kind, but all this seeks to do is to nullify, to omit and suppress, to prevent larger stories being told. In part, Haacke's show is a rescue attempt, a way of giving voice to multiple meanings, mul tiple readings.

Haacke has also gone for the grand effect, the killer conjunction. In the high-ceilinged North Gallery, the V&A's cast of Michaelangelo's Dying Slave towers queerfully between a large, pained 13th century crucifix and a tranquil Burmese carved and lacquered Buddha. Two Islamic prayer carpets hang on one wall, opposite a Jewish Torah mantle.

If this room is a kind of summit of world religions, it is also a place of rootless reverences. The Dying Slave returns us to the body, to profanities and earthly desires, from which the rest is an escape. Through an open doorway into the next gallery, Canova's Sleeping Nymph is showing us her marble bum. I turn, suddenly, to a picture of Polish soldiers having a souvenir photo taken against a sylvan painted backdrop erected by their photographer amidst the rubble of Warsaw in 1942. A second photographer, Marco Jindrich, photographed this farcical event. This little image is a lesson in the fact that, while hundreds of things ultimately dull the spirit, one thing alone can hold you, and burn a hole in your brain.

The 1851 Great Exhibition was the progenitor of the V&A. A commemorative painting of the royal opening sits behind a sculpture by Viet-Hong Lien featuring a crying child, a horrified parent and a pile of poo. The big day out always ends in tears.

Over at the V&A, amongst the tranquil shelves and cabinets of cups and jugs, plates and figurines in the British porcelain collection, the room is loud with clattering crockery, tinkling teaspoons, the hum of conversation. The roar of school dinner hour, the buzzing restaurant, someone stacking the washing-up. The ambient sound-collage is disturbing here, making the serried rows of Lowestoft, Worcester and Burslem chinaware all the more silent and static in their dust-free vitrines. Neil Cummings and Marysia Lewandowska's soundscape ends with an almighty disaster with the crockery, a great splintering crash of broken plates. "They're gonna love this," said a V&A attendant, "It's not punters you get up here, it's scholars." I have a vision of an amplified soprano amongst the glassware, shattering everything with a high note.

The work of the 15 artists placed by Serpentine curator Lisa G Corrin amidst the collections of the V&A have a much tougher time than Haacke. They have to compete. Mostly, they fail, or are merely irritating. Belgian artist Wim Delvoye's hand-carved and decorated life-sized cement mixer - lovingly detailed with florrid foliage and lions' heads by Indonesian craftsman - has almost no impact in the little vestibule where it sits. The museum subsumes it.

J Morgan Puett and Suzanne Bocanegra's new tartans - whose colourways and warp and weft are based on New York ethnic and income demographies, inserted amongst the V&A's Tartan collection - almost disappear. Their presence is furtive, which maybe is the point, but as a gesture it is as meek as it is convoluted.

Ken Aptegar's repainted details from the V&A's paintings, placed under glass etched with bits of conversations he had with focus groups, only make you want to cut the chat and look at the original.

Placing Andres Serrano's photos of suckling infants, rat poison suicides and corpses burned to death amongst the artefacts of Catholic faith seems apposite. I look at Serrano's Pieta, then over at a recumbrent knight, carved in stone. As I walk towards his photo of a head of Christ, drowned in milk and water, I see it reflected in a nearby vitrine which contains a tiny, broken, white ivory Christ crucified. Then I'm off again, worrying about the ivory trade. Serrano feels just right here: risky, yet oddly surprising and seamless. He brings the things about him to life.

Similarly, Phillip Taafe's paintings, set amongst Islamic carpets, also manage to integrate themselves succesfully, without disappearing. Taafe might be seen as a belated, urbane American abstract Orientalist, but his paintings animate our attention, get us looking again at the gorgeous carpets, at their woven abstract symbolism.

Here, dialogues work better than outright interventions, which too often are merely silly, modish, point-scoring. But looking at the new (Marc Quinn's perfectly carved, white marble sculptures of amputees, his one-armed kick-boxer battling between the busts and the Canovas, for example) makes you realise that the new, if it survives at all, will eventually be devoured by the museum. One day it will all be old, and awaiting its own resuscitation.

 Give & Take is at the Serpentine Gallery, London W2 (020-7402 6075) and the V&A, London SW7 (020-7942 2502), until April 1.

But looking at the new (Marc Quinn's perfectly carved, white marble sculptures of amputees, his one-armed kick-boxer battling between the busts and the Canovas, for example) makes you realise that the new, if it survives at all, will eventually be devoured by the museum. One day it will all be old, and awaiting its own resuscitation.  Give & Take is at the Serpentine Gallery, London W2 (020-7402 6075) and the V&A, London SW7 (020-7942 2502), until April 1.

webTitle: Milburn orders overhaul of the law in wake of organs scandal

fields.headline: Milburn orders overhaul of the law in wake of organs scandal
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, today announced a radical overhaul of the law governing consent for the removal and storage of body parts, following publication of a devastating report into the Alder Hey chidren's hospital organs scandal.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, today announced a radical overhaul of the law governing consent for the removal and storage of body parts, following publication of a devastating report into the Alder Hey chidren's hospital organs scandal.

In a Commons' statement, Mr Milburn set out a raft of measures to overhaul currently "ambiguous" consent procedures to ensure patients and their relatives are in future fully informed about what doctors intended to do during and after autopsies. It will be illegal for staff to ignore informed consent.

His pledge followed the publication of a census of organ retention in the NHS by chief medical officer Prof Liam Donaldson which revealed that more than 105,000 body parts are currently in storage in hospitals across England.

The pathologist at the centre of the Alder Hey scandal, Prof Dick van Velzen, has been referred to the General Medical Council (GMC) and four non-clinical hospital staff including the current chief executive of the hospital trust have been suspended.

The GMC is holding an emergency meeting on Friday to consider taking interim action to limit Prof van Velzen's opportunities to practice in the UK.

A separate inquiry into the hospital revealed that Prof van Velzen, a Dutch-born pathologist, systematically ordered the unethical and illegal stripping of every organ from every child who had had a post-mortem between 1988 and 1995.

The Alder Hey report has been referred to Merseyside police and the director of public prosecutions.

Mr Milburn said in his Commons statement that the 1961 Human Tissue Act, which currently regulates organ retention, would be amended. There would also be a wider review of existing laws on all aspects of taking, storing and using tissue and organs from both the living and the dead.

A new standardised consent form will be introduced throughout the NHS. A new statutory code of practice will also be issued to the NHS, covering the use of organs by the pharmaceutical industry. And a special commission will oversee the return of body parts to relatives who wish to have them.

Mr Milburn claimed the 1961 Human Tissue Act had "ill-served bereaved parents" and caused "confusion for staff".

He said: "I will bring forward measures urgently to amend the Act to clarify that informed consent must be given, that organs and tissues must be specified and to make it a criminal offence to ignore informed consent."

Mr Milburn said the report into Alder Hey had revealed "a lack of respect and a failure to appreciate the circumstances which led to the taking of human material".

He added: "The inquiry report says Professor van Velzen must never be allowed to practice again in this country.

"He ignored parent's wishes even when they told him explicitly that they did not want a full postmortem, let alone the retention of any of their child's organs.

"He lied to hospital managers. He stole medical records. He falsified statistics and reports. And he encouraged other staff to do the same."

NHS staff are bracing themselves for a public backlash over the scandal. Hospitals throughout England have apologised to parents for removing and storing the organs of their dead children without proper consent following the publication of Prof Donaldson's report.

Great Ormond Street hospital for children in London has set up a telephone counselling service for distraught parents after Prof Donaldson's report disclosed it has a "large" human organ store.

The hospital has acknowledged that it once sent the organs of living children to researchers in the US, in return for a "payment for processing". The shipment of thymus glands taken from children during heart surgery in 1993 was a "one-off", it said.

Birmingham's children's hospital, which also has an organ store, said it was making preparations to deal with questions from parents.

However, doctors' leaders have warned against "demonising" the medical profession.

Dr Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said he was concerned that Mr Milburn had described the Alder Hey report as "grotesque" prior to its publication.

"The initial comments, about shocking and gruesome, do not help the medical profession to carry on with their work. I don't think they help the parents in this particular case," Dr Bogle told BBC Radio 4's The World at One.

"Doctors are trying to carry on doing their work and helping the public and it won't help their morale and it won't help the public's confidence."

webTitle: Verona president under fire in black player row

fields.headline: Verona president under fire in black player row
fields.trailText: Verona president Giambattista Pastorello has been heavily criticised after claiming he would be unlikely to sign a black player because of his club's racist fans.
fields.body:
Verona president Giambattista Pastorello has been heavily criticised after claiming he would be unlikely to sign a black player because of his club's racist fans.

Asked on local TV about a rumour that Verona striker Emiliano Bonazzoli could be heading to Parma in exchange for African player of the year Patrick Mboma, Pastorello said such a move was unlikely as it would anger Verona's supporters.

"If we swapped Bonazzoli for a coloured player it wouldn't solve that [the problems of racism at the club]," he said. "You need to draw your own conclusions.

"If you have fans that do these things you need to have patience," he went on. "Our supporters have behaved badly, at least in regard to coloured players".

The problem of racism among Verona's supporters was evident during Sunday's match against Parma, when Lilian Thuram was booed by sections of the home crowd. Verona do not currently have a black player in their first-team squad.

Pastorelli's views immediately came under attack from the mayor of Verona, Michela Sironi Mariotti, who has threatened to close the ground to defeat the racists. "I think it is serious if a few dozen hooligans can hold president Pastorello hostage," he said.

Mariotti also pointed out that the city's other football club, Chievo, had no problem in signing black players and the local basketball team had black players "who have worn the yellow and blue shirt and lived in Verona without any problems".

Verona have issued a statement saying that Pastorello did not intend to suggest Mbomba would not be signed because of his colour, and that the club would continue to campaign against racial intolerance.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From: James
fields.trailText: If you go to Ubud when you're in Bali, go to Tutmak - a friend of mine runs it and it has some great artwork there. It's an old haunt of Monet's grandson, who lives in the area. You can't miss him; he looks like Father Christmas in a sarong.
fields.body:
Hi Milly,

I've been back in the UK for eight months after travelling in the Far East for a year and I'm seriously missing the life.

The reason for the mail is that I know that for part of your trek you're going to Bali.

Don't get sucked in by Kuta - it is a weird and wonderful place, but it isn't Bali. If you have time and get the chance, stay up in Ubud, particularly in the Gerebig Bungalows (piece of random info: 'bunga' is Indonesian for flower, and low means, well, low) in Penestanan.

The Bungalows are run by a wonderful family, who also own the paddys that they look over.They're cheap, clean and have hot water. You may even bump into my dad there, the infamous 'Mr Dick' (as in Richard), who's fairly well known as 'the kooky ex-pat with a cat' - my cat to be precise. Anyway, (blah, blah, blah) they have some amazing ceremonies in the area, and if you do bump into 'Mr Dick', I'm sure he'll be happy to take you to some of the traditional carvers and some of the family homes in the area.

Also, if you do go to Ubud, go to Tutmak - a friend of mine runs it and it has some great artwork there. It is an old haunt of Monet's grandson, who lives in the area. You can't miss him; he looks like Father Christmas in a sarong.

All the best, and happy travels!

James Collier

PS You can find some of the funny mushroom Maccy Dees in Midnight Oil, which is on Poppy 2.

fields.headline: Brent gun crime appeal
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Brent council is launching poster ads showing a man lying in a pool of blood under the words 'Young, gifted and dead', writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A hard-hitting poster campaign showing a man lying in a pool of blood under the words "Young, gifted and dead" went up in London today as part of a campaign aimed at stopping gun crime.

The poster ad forms part of a campaign by Brent Council to combat the growing number of shootings in the Harlesden area in recent years.

The "Not Another Drop" campaign is backed by the Metropolitan Police and the home office and will include radio ads featuring the voice of a mother whose son has been killed.

The council is also putting together postcards carrying details of a freepost address to which details about gun crime can be sent anonymously and an Aids-style "Not Another Drop" badge in the shape of a drop of blood.

"Harlesden's reputation has been tarnished thanks to the evil activities of a handful of people," said councillor Paul Daisley, deputy leader of Brent council.

"The time has come for us to take a stand against these gangsters and the menace they have brought to our streets. We will do all we can to work with the local community and police to force them out."

Eight people have been killed and 12 injured since 1999 as a result of shootings in the Harlesden area.

The campaign was devised in-house.

webTitle: Figures show Oxford 'favoured' state school applicants

fields.headline: Figures show Oxford 'favoured' state school applicants
fields.trailText: Oxford University discriminated in favour of pupils from comprehensive schools during the year that Tyneside student Laura Spence applied, according to an MP who has seen provisional admission figures.
fields.body:
Oxford University discriminated in favour of pupils from comprehensive schools during the year that Tyneside student Laura Spence applied, according to an MP who has seen provisional admission figures.

Criticism of the university after Ms Spence was rejected was "completely unfounded", said Evan Harris, the local Liberal Democrat MP, who has presented evidence on the latest admissions figures to the Commons select committee.

In fact, statistics showed that while the great majority of all entrants gained three A grades at A-level, 23% of comprehensive pupils were admitted with slightly lower grades, compared with 17.2% from independent schools.

For every 100 places, Oxford colleges typically make 120 offers, expecting 80 applicants to achieve their grades. It was in the 20% of places from candidates who narrowly missed three As or two As and a B that Oxford was giving comprehensive students the benefit of the doubt, Dr Harris believed.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, had said it was "an absolute scandal" that Miss Spence, who is now on a scholarship at Harvard in the US, was refused a place to study medicine at Oxford.

"If anything the bias is the other way - and rightly so", said Dr Harris.

Provisional figures from the university show comprehensive pupils with a slightly higher success rate in 1999 for the first time. He pointed out that comprehensive educated students got an identical proportion of first class degrees as former independent school pupils last summer despite getting slightly worse A-levels on average.

The university said it was committed to selecting the brightest and best candidates whatever their social or educational background. "Our admissions tutors assess the academic potential of each applicant with great care, considering factors including academic achievement, performance at interview and (in many cases) assessment of written work," said a spokesman.

"Over 800 tutors, across 30 undergraduate colleges, are involved in selecting candidates and deciding the grades at which each conditional offer is set. Every case is decided on its own academic merits and there are no university-wide policies governing the levels at which these offers are made."

A spokesman for the Independent Schools Information Service said they were in favour of the broadest cross-section of candidates entering higher education. "It is simply the method of selection that concerns us. It should be on proven merit on grades achieved as well as other factors that universities take into account."

Independent schools were concerned that selection should be a matter for universities and not for political diktat or quotas. "The process must be transparent. Candidates need to know where they stand."

Independent schools have criticised colleges like Clare College, Cambridge, which have taken steps to attract state school applications. Bristol University which makes lower offers in subjects including law to pupils from schools with a poor A-level record has also drawn fire from independent heads.

Dr Harris added: "The message for state school pupils [like me] is apply, and don't be distracted by unfounded allegations of discrimination against you."

However, these figures may have come too late. Despite a late surge in applications, official figures in October showed demand from the state sector had dropped with the share of applications from state schools and colleges slipping to 54% after rising to 56% last year. Until last summer's controversy over the rejection of Miss Spence by Magdalen College, the university had expected demand from the state sector to continue growing.

fields.headline: Trial by ordeal
fields.standfirst: Six professors have just received full marks for their teaching of economics at Warwick. So why do they believe that the whole assessment process is 'damaging and destructive'?
fields.trailText: Six professors have just received full marks for their teaching of economics at Warwick. So why do they believe that the whole assessment process is 'damaging and destructive'?
fields.body:
Imagine you've built a successful organisation based, like Warwick University's economics department, on an outstanding reputation. You are known throughout the world; you turn potential customers away by the thousand. Your reputation is supported by every external indicator of your past performance; it's never been questioned.

Then, out of the blue, someone slanders you. You have to go to court to defend yourself. The jury must absorb a hundred witnesses and 20,000 pages of documents - all inside three days - and the judge will let private opinions and hearsay count in evidence too.

The quality of your rhetoric is likely to weigh more heavily than documents and expert witnesses. The best you can hope for is that the judge will find in your favour, with no damages and no order for costs. Every penny you've spent, all the months of preparation, are gone for ever. The trial process is so flawed that you could lose your case and your reputation, and be left with nothing. There is no provision for appeal.

This is the system of teaching quality review that has been imposed throughout England's universities and is operated by the QAA - the so-called Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education. Economics at Warwick has just been reviewed, and we obtained the maximum score: 24 out of 24. This point is worth making in capital letters so that you know: we would not recognise a sour grape if we stood on one. Our economists have played this system and won.

Do we delight in a deserved vic tory? Are we pleased that other university departments in this nation will be subjected to the same rigour? No, our frank conclusion is that it is probably the most damaging and destructive system of regulation that could possibly have been devised. Before we say why, let's make it clear that we have only praise for the underpaid, overworked academics who conscientiously reviewed us on the lines laid down by the QAA. The procedures are at fault, not the people who operate them.

Let's start with this department's score. Our full marks should place us among the country's elite. The world will think that, anyway. As for ourselves, we do believe we're very, very good (though not perfect). But our belief is not based on our QAA "teaching quality" score, which does not remotely measure teaching quality in this or any other department.

There are many possible illusions about the QAA process. Get your notepads out.

Illusion 1

Warwick's perfect QAA score tells parents that our teaching quality is the best.

Wrong. QAA only measures the claims that each institution makes about its teaching quality. We made high claims for our teaching quality, and the QAA panel agreed; so we got full marks. A department that made lesser claims, and proved them, would get full marks too. So you can't compare a 24 for economics at Warwick with the score from anywhere else. These QAA numbers are virtually useless. Yet nobody explains this to parents, teachers, or newspapers.

Illusion 2 The QAA has measured teaching quality objectively at Warwick.

Wrong. The method is not scientific. We supplied the hypothesis, the evidence and the witnesses. We chose the students, the former students and employers, the samples of student work, and the internal documentation to be seen by the panel. (Without a word being said, our students grasped perfectly the incentives at work: the more they supported us, the more their degrees would be worth.)

Finally, we managed the stage. We chose the meeting rooms, the seating plans, and which of us would perform as advocates. We trained ourselves in theatre and rhetoric; we learnt to argue fluently with passion and conviction. We were barristers in our own defence.

In other words we, who had the clearest possible interest in the outcome, also had a decisive influence on the hypothesis, the evidence, and the trial process. We did it well, but it wasn't objective.

Illusion 3

QAA scores can measure the change in teaching quality at Warwick

Wrong. The QAA's methodology is so unstable that it never uses the same criteria twice. In the previous cycle the scoring system was different, and it will be different next time round as well. Each time, the criteria change. Because it's never done the same way, anyone wanting to make useful comparisons over time cannot begin to know how teaching quality is altering.

Illusion 4 The QAA aims to enhance teaching quality in universities

Wrong. The QAA aims to enhance confidence in teaching quality, not teaching quality. Read the rubric. Its mission is "to promote public confidence that quality of provision and standards of awards in higher education are being safeguarded and enhanced." It's there to "assure", not "ensure". The whole thing is a hugely expensive public relations exercise.

Illusion 5 QAA reviews are cost-effective

Almost certainly wrong. Within the QAA methodology there is no attempt to compare costs with benefits, and no limit to the costs which universities are expected to incur in order to comply with bureaucratic criteria. Yes, we have found some benefits (whoopee). But that is like finding that when you fall out of an aeroplane you get a good view on the way down.

These benefits are vastly out weighed by the process's immense costs. Our estimate is that in preparing for the review over the past year our one department has spent £150,000 to £200,000 in staff time alone (ten times this sum at business consultancy rates). Multiply by the departments reviewed annually and add the overheads, and the hidden costs of QAA regulation are of the order of a hundred million pounds a year.

A still greater cost is not reckoned here at all. Teaching quality rests at its heart on the teachers' inner motivation. We're not well paid by the standards of the business world; the reason we do university economics is because we want to. Nothing could be more destructive to this motivation than the distrust and adversarial spirit that pervades QAA methodology.

Increasingly, we are forced to do things because the QAA says so and threatens us if we don't, not because true teaching quality demands it. Enthusiasm and scholarship are being strangled by bureaucratic monitor ing and demands for paper trails.

Universities don't ask for irresponsible control over the public money that pays us. We're willing to be called to account. There is a case for regulation. But not like this.

True teaching quality is being wrecked by a self-interested lobby of regulators. John Randall, head of the QAA, was quoted last week as saying that the intensity of regulation should rise with the level of fees. The bigger the cake, the more they want to get their hands on our crumbs.

We have to stop the QAA monster or it will eat us alive.

Mark Harrison, Ben Lockwood, Marcus Miller, Andrew Oswald, Mark Stewart, Ian Walker are all professors of economics at Warwick University, and helped to prepare and present their department's case during an inspection by the nation's Quality Assurance Agency.

QAA: The true score

About 10,000 people - most of them academics - have been involved in inspecting universities and higher education colleges in the UK over the past seven years. More than 2,000 individual institutions have been reviewed for Teaching Quality Assessments. Currently they are scored on six aspects - curriculum design, teaching, student achievement, student support, resources, and quality management - out of a possible 24 points.

This year new "lighter touch" academic reviews are being introduced, initially in Scotland, in which the points system will be dropped. The period between reviews is being shortened from eight to six years.

The inspection regime (though the word "inspection" is never used) was the hotly contested outcome of the Conservative government's insistence that the higher education sector must be more accountable for the billions of public money being spent on it. Universities, and their supporters in the House of Lords, protested about threats to academic freedom and secured safeguards to prevent the education secretary or his funding councils closing down courses they disapproved of - peace studies was the example at the time.

Traditionally universities have drawn up their own degree courses and guaranteed standards themselves with the help of a fairly informal system of external examiners from other universities. The polytechnics were overseen by a central body until they gained the right to award their own degrees.

The agency audits institutions' own procedures and scrutinises the education offered in each subject, judged against their own objectives.

Donald Macleod
