The best you can hope for is that the judge will find in your favour, with no damages and no order for costs. Every penny you've spent, all the months of preparation, are gone for ever. The trial process is so flawed that you could lose your case and your reputation, and be left with nothing. There is no provision for appeal. This is the system of teaching quality review that has been imposed throughout England's universities and is operated by the QAA - the so-called Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education. Economics at Warwick has just been reviewed, and we obtained the maximum score: 24 out of 24. This point is worth making in capital letters so that you know: we would not recognise a sour grape if we stood on one. Our economists have played this system and won. Do we delight in a deserved vic tory? Are we pleased that other university departments in this nation will be subjected to the same rigour? No, our frank conclusion is that it is probably the most damaging and destructive system of regulation that could possibly have been devised. Before we say why, let's make it clear that we have only praise for the underpaid, overworked academics who conscientiously reviewed us on the lines laid down by the QAA. The procedures are at fault, not the people who operate them. Let's start with this department's score. Our full marks should place us among the country's elite. The world will think that, anyway. As for ourselves, we do believe we're very, very good (though not perfect). But our belief is not based on our QAA "teaching quality" score, which does not remotely measure teaching quality in this or any other department. There are many possible illusions about the QAA process. Get your notepads out. Illusion 1 Warwick's perfect QAA score tells parents that our teaching quality is the best. Wrong. QAA only measures the claims that each institution makes about its teaching quality. We made high claims for our teaching quality, and the QAA panel agreed; so we got full marks. A department that made lesser claims, and proved them, would get full marks too. So you can't compare a 24 for economics at Warwick with the score from anywhere else. These QAA numbers are virtually useless. Yet nobody explains this to parents, teachers, or newspapers. Illusion 2 The QAA has measured teaching quality objectively at Warwick. Wrong. The method is not scientific. We supplied the hypothesis, the evidence and the witnesses. We chose the students, the former students and employers, the samples of student work, and the internal documentation to be seen by the panel. (Without a word being said, our students grasped perfectly the incentives at work: the more they supported us, the more their degrees would be worth.) Finally, we managed the stage. We chose the meeting rooms, the seating plans, and which of us would perform as advocates. We trained ourselves in theatre and rhetoric; we learnt to argue fluently with passion and conviction. We were barristers in our own defence. In other words we, who had the clearest possible interest in the outcome, also had a decisive influence on the hypothesis, the evidence, and the trial process. We did it well, but it wasn't objective. Illusion 3 QAA scores can measure the change in teaching quality at Warwick Wrong. The QAA's methodology is so unstable that it never uses the same criteria twice. In the previous cycle the scoring system was different, and it will be different next time round as well. Each time, the criteria change. Because it's never done the same way, anyone wanting to make useful comparisons over time cannot begin to know how teaching quality is altering. Illusion 4 The QAA aims to enhance teaching quality in universities Wrong. The QAA aims to enhance confidence in teaching quality, not teaching quality. Read the rubric. Its mission is "to promote public confidence that quality of provision and standards of awards in higher education are being safeguarded and enhanced." It's there to "assure", not "ensure". The whole thing is a hugely expensive public relations exercise. Illusion 5 QAA reviews are cost-effective Almost certainly wrong. Within the QAA methodology there is no attempt to compare costs with benefits, and no limit to the costs which universities are expected to incur in order to comply with bureaucratic criteria. Yes, we have found some benefits (whoopee). But that is like finding that when you fall out of an aeroplane you get a good view on the way down. These benefits are vastly out weighed by the process's immense costs. Our estimate is that in preparing for the review over the past year our one department has spent £150,000 to £200,000 in staff time alone (ten times this sum at business consultancy rates). Multiply by the departments reviewed annually and add the overheads, and the hidden costs of QAA regulation are of the order of a hundred million pounds a year. A still greater cost is not reckoned here at all. Teaching quality rests at its heart on the teachers' inner motivation. We're not well paid by the standards of the business world; the reason we do university economics is because we want to. Nothing could be more destructive to this motivation than the distrust and adversarial spirit that pervades QAA methodology. Increasingly, we are forced to do things because the QAA says so and threatens us if we don't, not because true teaching quality demands it. Enthusiasm and scholarship are being strangled by bureaucratic monitor ing and demands for paper trails. Universities don't ask for irresponsible control over the public money that pays us. We're willing to be called to account. There is a case for regulation. But not like this. True teaching quality is being wrecked by a self-interested lobby of regulators. John Randall, head of the QAA, was quoted last week as saying that the intensity of regulation should rise with the level of fees. The bigger the cake, the more they want to get their hands on our crumbs. We have to stop the QAA monster or it will eat us alive. Mark Harrison, Ben Lockwood, Marcus Miller, Andrew Oswald, Mark Stewart, Ian Walker are all professors of economics at Warwick University, and helped to prepare and present their department's case during an inspection by the nation's Quality Assurance Agency. QAA: The true score About 10,000 people - most of them academics - have been involved in inspecting universities and higher education colleges in the UK over the past seven years. More than 2,000 individual institutions have been reviewed for Teaching Quality Assessments. Currently they are scored on six aspects - curriculum design, teaching, student achievement, student support, resources, and quality management - out of a possible 24 points. This year new "lighter touch" academic reviews are being introduced, initially in Scotland, in which the points system will be dropped. The period between reviews is being shortened from eight to six years. The inspection regime (though the word "inspection" is never used) was the hotly contested outcome of the Conservative government's insistence that the higher education sector must be more accountable for the billions of public money being spent on it. Universities, and their supporters in the House of Lords, protested about threats to academic freedom and secured safeguards to prevent the education secretary or his funding councils closing down courses they disapproved of - peace studies was the example at the time. Traditionally universities have drawn up their own degree courses and guaranteed standards themselves with the help of a fairly informal system of external examiners from other universities. The polytechnics were overseen by a central body until they gained the right to award their own degrees. The agency audits institutions' own procedures and scrutinises the education offered in each subject, judged against their own objectives. Donald Macleod

fields.headline: 'But mum, it's my vocation'
fields.standfirst: The government says its new vocational GCSEs will not be second best. But will parents, employers or kids ever believe it?
fields.trailText: The government says its new vocational GCSEs will not be second best. But will parents, employers or kids ever believe it? Dave Hill reports
fields.body:
Five years from now, if today's vexing plumber scarcity is just a painful memory and the Yellow Pages burst with ads for leisure consultants and nail technicians, David Blunkett will be looking for some credit. Last week, as part of a transformation of the secondary sector planned for the Blair government's anticipated second term, he announced "ambitious plans" to introduce a range of new Vocational GCSEs into schools.

Starting on a small scale from 2002, Year 9 pupils considering their options for the following two years will not be restricted to the narrow, overwhelmingly academic choice the national curriculum presently offers. Everyone will have to do English, maths and science, but there will also be courses starting them on the road to being electricians or engineers, caterers or keyboard jockeys, retail managers or tour organisers, often linked to workplace experience. Vocational GCSEs, Blunkett pledged, would be central to a drive to "raise the standard of vocational study and training, and draw together the worlds of education and work in ways that have never before been achieved".

So what's it all about? Precise details are sketchy, but it seems there may be a GCSE called something like Applied Technology, which will be of relevance to potential builders, joiners, mechanics and, yes, electricians and plumbers. It also appears that the new qualifications will cover many of the same subject areas as the General National Vocational Qualifications (GNVQs) they will replace. These currently include art and design, leisure and tourism, the performing arts, health and social care, hospitality and catering, and information and communications technology. Many schools already offer these (at advanced level too) to children who find the more academic disciplines difficult or boring.

GNVQs have a credibility problem, however: employers don't respect them, most schools don't prioritise them, and many pupils who study them see them as a badge of failure.

Raising the status of vocational qualifications is central to the government's plan. But how well will it work? Will an exam pass in what is conventionally thought of as a "practical" subject ever be regarded by anyone as equal to an academic counterpart? Even keen supporters of the move have spoken of a risk that some of the effects may turn out to be the opposite of what's intended: instead of "levelling up" the status of vocational courses by running them directly alongside academic ones, giving them the same name, and saying they are just as good, will the result simply be to institutionalise a two-tier system within schools, whereby the intellectual elite is confirmed as precisely that and the vocational rest, just second best?

Significantly, NUT General Secretary Doug McAvoy and the Confederation of British Industry have responded in similar ways. Both have praised the principle, but have concerns about implementation. McAvoy warns against reviving the old grammar-secondary modern divide and putting youngsters on a narrow course towards a particular trade or career too soon: "The government must take care not to create vocational ghettos instead of ensuring that all our young people benefit from a broad general education which widens their horizons."

Anne Lindsay, a policy adviser with the CBI's Learning and Skills Group, makes compatible points. For her, success hinges very much on "issues of quality". One of these is the provision of "good impartial careers advice, which is very patchy at the moment. These are very young people who will be making important decisions very early in their lives."

Peter Watts, a self-employed heating engineer from Hertfordshire in his 50s, adds to the consensus. He learned plumbing on the job and feels he was taught well, but would have welcomed the chance to learn the rudiments as a schoolboy. Even so, he can see potential difficulties. For one thing, having a qualification may not be enough to keep a youngster in his trade: "A lot of them starting off now aren't getting such a good wage as the bloke down the road who's a labourer. The government would have to look at that side too." And he, too, would be concerned about youngsters heading down a job-targeted path too soon: "Does any child know what they want to do for a living at that age?"

Anne Lindsay also stresses the need for teachers to be helped with adapting to another new set of demands, and for the Vocational GCSE itself to be -and be perceived as being -as challenging as the traditional variety. So how have schools where vocational courses are already well-established met such concerns?

Kevin Satchwell, head of Thomas Telford school, a City Technology College in Shropshire, is proud that vocational courses have been integral since the school opened 10 years ago. He believes Thomas Telford has avoided the "bear trap" of a "sheep and goats curriculum" by stressing the virtues of a balanced range of subjects to fit individual children's needs. Every Thomas Telford child does at least one vocational course at some stage. Hospitality and catering is very big. "Even the ones who will go on to do very academic things see the value of it," he says. "They'll say, 'well, I want to be able to look after myself properly, and if I go to university it'll help me to get a holiday job'." If recent exam results are any guide, Satchwell's approach seems to be working: last year, every GCSE entrant achieved at least five A-C grades, the best performance by a comprehensive in the country.

In the Knowsley area on Merseyside, meanwhile, the LEA has for some while been encouraging vocational learning, often as a means of re-engaging children who become alienated or drop out. Working with local industry and support agencies, they've made use of the "disapplication" process, whereby youngsters can be released from two curriculum subjects and use some of the time to do work-based training instead.

David Lang, head of Halewood Community Comprehensive, is keen to see the principle extended so that vocational learning is properly developed and upgraded. From a school teacher's point of view, though, he observes that in some subject areas resources could be a problem -"we're not geared to having relatively small numbers in specialised workshops, for example" -and that part of the effectiveness of vocational courses is that they require a different style of teaching. He also emphasises the continuing need for "breadth and balance - you have to find the right combination of preparing them for careers and widening their horizons as human beings."

A cynical view of the Blunkett announcement might be that it's as much about re-branding GNVQs as a drive to "strengthen and clarify the vocational pathways" through links with business and reformed Modern Apprenticeships. If delivered and presented the right way, however, there is evidence that the new courses may have some of the most desired effects.

Felicity Fletcher-Campbell was project director of an investigation into alternative educational provision at Key Stage 4, conducted for the Local Government Association at the National Foundation for Educational Research. The project, which included eight detailed case studies of individual schools, showed that if vo cational courses are taken seriously in the spirit of inclusiveness they can do great things for pupils' self-esteem. Also, learning in the "real world" helped them see the sense of learning in the classroom. She says: "If they could see why a millimetre mattered on the shop floor they could see why maths might matter too."

Such findings seem borne out by the experience of Ben Simpson, 16, from east London. He couldn't wait to leave school, and he's much happier now, combining studying an advanced GNVQ in business studies at a sixth form college with working in an electronics shop. "I was bored by the academic stuff, I couldn't see the point of sitting round in a classroom all day." His course contains modules on marketing, finance, IT and economics. "It's got everything," Ben says. What goes for Ben goes for many others too, according to his dad, Nick, a youth worker in east London. "A lot of kids I work with feel just the same as Ben," he says. "He wasn't interested in maths, but he likes learning how to draw up a set of accounts. It would help them a lot if they could do a GCSE that gave them some sense of what they might do later on. I know there is more to education than passing exams. But they can't see how finding out what Napoleon got up to is going to help them to find a job."

fields.headline: Survival Anglia shut down
fields.trailText:
Tuesday 5.45pm update: Renowned wildlife film-maker Survival Anglia has fallen victim to the rise of 'popular wildlife' programming, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 30: Granada slashes jobs
Nov 7: Granada's plans for United interests
Oct 3: Willis stays, Wall goes
fields.body:
Survival Anglia, which has produced wildlife programmes for the past 40 years, is the latest victim of the rise of "popular wildlife" programming.

The prestigious programming unit behind hit shows including Flight of the Snow Geese and the famous documentary about the flora and fauna of the Prince of Wales's residence at Highgrove, is closing due to market pressures.

Granada confirmed today it plans to close the Survival office in Norwich, and would relocate it to Bristol under Tom Archer, United's head of factual programmes.

Under the plans, between 25 and 35 of the 40 staff who work for Survival Anglia in Norwich will be made redundant, although a spokesman was unable to give any clear indication of what would happen to remaining staff.

And it is understood that a further 15 posts could be cut at United's Bristol base as the Survival staff are merged with the existing natural history programming department.

Broadcasting union Bectu reacted with anger at the proposed cuts.

Bectu supervisory official Sharon Elliott said the loss of Survival Anglia was "a major loss".

Granada attributed the move to the "changing demands of UK and international broadcasters".

It said that markets were "hungry for popular documentary techniques, the use of presenters and the inclusion of more science".

In a statement the company said: "With Bristol already acknowledged as the world capital of wildlife film making, the new department will now be in an even stronger position to expand into the international market and be fully prepared to take advantage of broadband and new media opportunities."

But insiders have condemned the decision as an attempt to be "trendy".

Presenter-led programming, with the likes of ITV's Steve Irwin and Nigel Marven, has stolen a march on more traditional wildlife programming.

Ms Elliott of Bectu continued: "It is unacceptable to us that Granada Media should want to show talented and experienced staff the door at operations which are already run efficiently."

The move is the latest fallout from the takeover by Granada of United Broadcasting.

Nov 7: Granada's plans for United interests
Oct 3: Willis stays, Wall goes

webTitle: Established stars are making too much damn money

fields.headline: Established stars are making too much damn money
fields.standfirst:
Caroline Sullivan looks at Heat's list of pop's biggest earners - and despairs

Beatles return to top of the money charts
fields.trailText: Caroline Sullivan looks at Heat's list of pop's biggest earners - and despairs.
fields.body:
So what can we infer from Heat magazine's "rich list" that charts the highest-earning British and Irish pop stars of 2000, apart from the fact that they make too damned much money?

Paul McCartney, the UK's wealthiest songwriter, won't even notice his £13m share of the Beatles' royalties ker-chinging its way into his groaning coffers - and when someone is that rich, it's time they redistributed their cash among deserving rock journalists.

Like all such surveys, the most notable thing is that it's dominated by people old enough to be Westlife's fathers, or, in Tom Jones's case, grandfather.

The combined age of the top five is 717 years, or around 51 years each (the comparatively adolescent U2 lower the average from a crumbly 57).

Secondly, and perhaps more irksomely, most of the top 10's income is derived from back-catalogue sales, with only U2, Sade, the Spice Girls and Westlife releasing new material last year.

The Beatles compilation 1, which made 2000 the Fab Three's most profitable year ever, didn't contain a song less than three decades old. In effect, most of the richest stars didn't have to lift a finger to earn their millions.

Which is nice work if you can get it, but it's another sign that the music industry is less about music than industry these days. If the top 10 was based on merit as the upcoming Brit Awards supposedly are - most of these artists wouldn't be on it.

It has been years, even decades, since the Rolling Stones or the Eltmeister made a record worth buying, while blank-eyed newcomers Westlife have yet to produce anything that convinces me they should ever be allowed near a studio again.

Last autumn, George Michael caused a stir by denouncing British pop as stale and manufactured (Mr Pot, do meet Mr Kettle). He was right, but it's interesting to note that, despite Steps and A1's deplorable pre-eminence in the singles chart, they haven't made the serious money that would boost them into the list.

Instead of railing against pipsqueaks, Yog should have attacked the likes of Phil Collins, who, in the long run, poses a greater danger. As long as he effortlessly makes millions a year, what incentive is there for record companies to invest in new talent?

The top 10 of the Heat rich list of British and Irish music stars is as follows with last year's position in brackets:
1 (3) The Beatles - £55m
2 (-) U2 - £50m
3 (2) Sir Elton John - £35m
4 (1) Rolling Stones - £27.5m
5 (-) David Bowie - £20m
6 (-) Sade - £10m
7 (-) Tom Jones - £8.5m
8 (-) Phil Collins - £6m
9 (6) Spice Girls - £5m
10 (-) Westlife - £5m

webTitle: Oah Aah BBC raps Rory McGrath

fields.headline: Oah Aah BBC raps Rory McGrath
fields.trailText: 4pm:Sports quiz They Think It's All Over has come under fire in the BBC's own complaints bulletin for crude jokes about David Beckham and Posh Spice writes Jessica Hodgson .
fields.body:
Sports quiz They Think It's All Over has come under fire in the BBC's own complaints bulletin for crude jokes about David Beckham and Posh Spice.

Viewers were shocked to see panellists repeat a popular football terrace chant about Posh Spice's sexual preferences.

The programme complaints unit upheld complaints from a viewer about a "gross and poisonous" attack on Mr and Mrs Beckham during one edition of the show.

And the remark, made by panellist Rory McGrath and others, is to be edited out of repeats of the show.

The ruling will be a victory for Mrs Beckham, who has had public slanging matches with Mr McGrath in the past.

She called him "that ugly bastard" in a magazine interview.

The BBC programme complaints unit found the programme "went beyond even the broad limits" of the programme, renowned for its bawdy humour.

"The Beckhams are no strangers to publicity and, as a couple so much in the public eye, are a legitimate target for the programme's humour. However, this edition contained a sexual suggestion about them which, by its nature and explicitness, went beyond even the broad limits which the programme has established for itself," said the BBC.

Jonathan Ross, known for his acid humour, has also been found guilty of breaching standards of taste and decency.

Complaints were upheld about explicit sexual references by a studio guest on his Radio 2 show.

And the governors have also complained about a flippant reference by Jonathan Ross to the tragedy in which 58 Chinese immigrants had died.

"The sexual references went beyond acceptable limits, despite Jonathan Ross's efforts to keep the conversation under control. His own flippant remark was a lapse in taste, for which he apologised at the time and later in the programme," said the BBC in a statement.

Two complaints about Newsnight were also upheld.

webTitle: Beatles return to top of the money charts

fields.headline: Beatles return to top of the money charts
fields.standfirst: Caroline Sullivan: Established stars are making too much damn money
fields.trailText: The pop charts are dominated by established stars and aging rockers, according to a new "rich list" in which the Beatles emerged as biggest pop earners of the past 12 months, with songs over 30 years old.
fields.body:
The pop charts are dominated by established stars and aging rockers, according to a new "rich list" in which the Beatles emerged as biggest pop earners of the past 12 months, with songs over 30 years old.

Heat magazine's survey of British and Irish music stars' earnings in the charts in the year 2000 reflected the astonishing sales for The Beatles' greatest hits package, called 1, saw each of them make £55m for re-released material.

In the magazine's first round-up a year ago, the Fab Four were thought to have made £15m in 1999, earning them third place. However that rocketed in the latest list following number ones in at least 30 countries and simultaneously topping the charts in both the UK and the US.

Heat editor Mark Frith said: "2000 was The Beatles' biggest money-making year yet - which is just incredible 30 years after they split.

"And really all they did was say yes to the release of a compilation. That was a very profitable decision."

Irish superstars U2 are runners-up and saw their comeback album rake in around £50m according to the magazine's researchers, with sales of seven million for All That You Can't Leave Behind.

And the band can look forward to further riches in 2001 with a huge north American tour, European dates to come and the knock-on effects of performing in front of millions of fans when they pick up an award at the Brits.

Other veterans in the top five include Sir Elton John at three (down a place but making around £10m more), the Rolling Stones slipping from number one and David Bowie at five.

Singer Sade's return from many years in the musical wilderness is thought to have made her around £10m. Sade's Lovers Rock album helped to fuel her millions but - like The Beatles - it was also due to the strength of her back catalogue with her Best Of album continuing to sell well.

Westlife as the highest placed newcomers, landing 10th position with a mere £5m that they are reckoned to have made in 2000.

The Spice Girls fall from grace with record buyers was underlined by their poor performance in the list. During 1999 there were no new singles but their albums and live shows continued to pull in around £9m between them. But in 2000, even with the release of third album Forever, they fell to £5m - dropping from six to ninth position.

Teenage soprano Charlotte Church continues her moneymaking with a further £4.5m - on top of the previous year's £6 million. However her split with manager Jonathan Shalit is thought to have cost in excess of £1m.

The top 10 of the Heat rich list of British and Irish music stars is as follows with last year's position in brackets:
1 (3) The Beatles - £55m
2 (-) U2 - £50m
3 (2) Sir Elton John - £35m
4 (1) Rolling Stones - £27.5m
5 (-) David Bowie - £20m
6 (-) Sade - £10m

webTitle: Met finds itself guilty of vendetta

fields.headline: Met finds itself guilty of vendetta
fields.standfirst:
Black activist should be given apology for harassment, says report that has riven police force
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An explosive report by the Metropolitan police into allegations of a vendetta by officers against a black activist has recommended he should receive a public apology.
fields.byline: Jamie Wilson, Simon Hattenstone  and Diane Taylor
fields.body:
An explosive report by the Metropolitan police into allegations of a vendetta by officers against a black activist has recommended he should receive a public apology.

Compiled by London's top Asian officer, the inquiry concludes that the force had been guilty of unlawfully arresting Delroy Lindo on three occasions and subjecting him to racial stereotyping.

Senior officers initially refused to publish the report, which criticises organisational failings in the Met , after its findings caused a row in the force. The Met finally posted the report on the internet last night and a press briefing is scheduled for today with the Metropolitan police authority.

The inquiry, which looked at why Mr Lindo had been arrested on 37 occasions and charged with 18 offences - only one of which resulted in a conviction that was overturned on appeal - was set up last year by a deputy commissioner, Ian Blair. Matters came to a head on July 2 when Mr Lindo, who is suing the Metropolitan police for £1m in damages, was arrested for "sucking his teeth" in the presence of a police officer.

The final version of the report seen by the Guardian has been toned down considerably. Comments that the police may find it difficult to defend a series of civil actions brought by the Lindo family have been excised, as have details of incidents that might identify the officers concerned.

Human rights

The report has provoked a battle in the Met, with officers complaining that the man in charge of the investigation, deputy assistant commissioner Tarique Ghaffur, did not interview any of the 49 officers who came into contact with Mr Lindo to test his allegations against their own.

Last week three of the officers accused in the report wrote to Sir John Stephens, commissioner of the Metropolitan police, complaining that their human rights had been infringed.

Perhaps the most damaging finding in the report is that three of the arrests made on Mr Lindo were unlawful. "There was insufficient evidence to arrest, charge or achieve a a successful prosecution," the report said. "A common feature in the three cases is that the arresting officers detained Mr and Mrs Lindo after a confrontation where the police officers' rationale was not supported by legislation."

The inquiry found Mr and Mrs Lindo were prosecuted on 11 occasions for a va riety of offences ranging from breach of the peace to threats to kill. On top of the three unlawful arrests a further four of the charges were not investigated to an acceptable prosecution standard

The report also criticised procedures at police stations, concluding custody sergeants "readily accepted the evidence given to them by the arresting officers, even where no prima facie evidence existed to substantiate a formal charge."

Mr Lindo has always maintained that part of the reason he was subjected to harassment was because of his friendship with Winston Silcott, the man wrongly convicted of murdering PC Keith Blakelock during the Broadwater Farm riots in north London in 1985.

The inquiry team found no evidence of an organised conspiracy to harass Mr and Mrs Lindo. "There was, however, evidence that harassment had taken place because of the negative stereotyping of the Lindo family," the report said.

"This had been caused by police officers in Haringey focusing on the fact that Mr Lindo has spent convictions, including one for rape, which "led to a disproportionate number of interactions with the Lindo family."

But the report said the Lindos were "partly instrumental in creating the spiral of deteriorating relationships and reciprocated the negative, aggressive and un professional behaviour exhibited by certain police officers."

The couple exhibited "extremes of behaviour" that led to "overreaction by the police and the punitive use of the judicial system".

However, the report concluded: "Notwithstanding this intense and at times arguably provocative behaviour by the Lindo family, the Metropolitan police is at fault in its lack of strategic response to this series of incidents, its punitive overreaction on occasions, poor supervision of events, arrests, prosecutions, complaints and mediation."

The inquiry also found the family was subjected to more than its fair share of inquiries by the police. Between 1996 and 2000, Mr Lindo was the subject of 52 intelligence reports. "The number of intelligence reports recorded by the police at Haringey is disproportionately high," the report concluded.

The report also found that inappropriate comments amounting to "stereotypical and frivolous behaviour towards the Lindo family" were also disproportionately high in the intelligence reports. One of the conclusions Mr Ghaffur made was "the need for a quality control of inappropriate language used on criminal reports".

Collective failures

Mr Ghaffur said the general conclusion was that there did not appear to be any conspiracy by individual officers or a cadre of officers within the Metropolitan police. "However, when all factors are collectively considered, including anomalies in the use of discretion, legal powers, stereotyping, disproportionality and organisational failings, then the inquiry finds that harassment of the Lindo family took place."

He said that the findings would "seriously challenge" the Met and those concerned with its good management.

The report concluded the force in the borough of Haringey lacked "the competency, or will (or both) to detect over a number of years major weaknesses".

The report added that the processes examined, such as the duty of custody sergeants to ensure there is enough evidence to substantiate a charge, had been generally ignored or incompetently performed. "Moreover, this sloppiness seems endemic to the investigative and the whole criminal justice function within the borough."

It warned that the collective failures "have put the Metropolitan police service at a serious risk of undermining the confidence of sections of minority ethnic communities within the borough of Haringey".

However, the report added that while the Lindo family had been to a large extent the victims of "unprofessional standards and management" by the Met, "this inquiry in attributing liability also feels that the Lindo family, to a much lesser extent, have contributed to some of their own misfortune."

Ian Blair told the Guardian that parts of the report made "uncomfortable reading" and that some of the findings were "concerning". "What I want is to move forwards. The priority is to achieve a situation in which levels of suspicion between the core participants in this story are reduced. To achieve that you need a transparent, accountable policing style."

Mr Blair defended the fact that none of the police officers involved were to face disciplinary action.

"The unlawful arrests have been subject to investigation already. This process is not designed to and has not thrown up any new disciplinary matters."

Commenting on the findings , Mr Lindo said: "I do have a few points that I contest as the police have a few points they contest. But in general the report is a vindication of everything we have fought for. The conclusion is that police harass people and target people, especially people with previous convictions, which has to be worrying for all those people in society who have got spent convictions."

Lee Jasper, race adviser to the Greater London Metropolitan police authority, said that even the diluted final version was "a shocking indictment of a racist and bullying police culture and has profound implications which will reinforce the Macpherson recommendations."

Evidence of harassment because of stereotyping of Mr Lindo and his family, although there is no evidence of an organised conspiracy to harass them because of their connection with the Winston Silcott campaign.

Disproportionate number of arrests of the Lindo family. Three were unlawful, while a further four were not investigated to an acceptable prosecution standard. There was also evidence of a misuse of discretion of police powers and inappropriate comments within intelligence reports and official documents.

Anomalies in file completion, management and supervision all played a part in what amounted to a collective organisational failure in the policing of these incidents in the borough of Haringey over a number of years.

Mr and Mrs Lindo were partly instrumental in creating the spiral of deteriorating relationships. At times they exhibited extremes of behaviour.

The collective failures have put the Metropolitan police at a serious risk of undermining the confidence of sections of ethnic communities in the borough of Haringey. Lessons from the inquiry should be used to improve the operational effectiveness of the Met

The Met should take matters forward , beginning with an apology to the Lindo family, followed by mediation and confidence building measures.

A fairness audit will create foundations and underpin the community race awareness training for police in the borough.

webTitle: Jewish broker told to wear Nazi uniform at work

fields.headline: Jewish broker told to wear Nazi uniform at work
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A leading city firm has admitted that a Jewish broker, whose grandmother was murdered by the Nazis at Auschwitz, was told to wear an Adolf Hitler uniform at work, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
A leading city firm has admitted that a Jewish broker, whose grandmother was murdered by the Nazis at Auschwitz, was told to wear an Adolf Hitler uniform at work, the Guardian has learned.

Laurent Weinberger, 33, is suing Tullett & Tokyo Liberty for racial discrimination and unfair dismissal claiming that he was also subjected to repeated anti-semitic abuse.

According to documents seen by the Guardian the firm admits that Mr Weinberger was handed a German uniform to wear, and that he was called "Yiddo" and "Jew boy".

Mr Weinberger resigned from his job with the money brokers two weeks after the Hitler uniform incident. He claims an attempt was made to demote him from his £125,000-a-year job after six years with the firm.

Tullett & Tokyo denies the claim, arguing that the incidents were part of the office culture Mr Weinberger joined in with, and a preliminary employment tribunal hearing is due to start tomorrow.

Tullett & Tokyo has offered to pay £50,000 to a Jewish charity if he drops the case.

In its defence, the firm says Mr Weinberger was not singled out because of his race. "It is admitted that there was a practice on the [company's] trading desks that if any employee was late in to work on Friday morning they would be given a costume to wear as a forfeit. The practice was a light-hearted one.

"The choice of costume might refer to a particular characteristic of the employee concerned, including on occasion his racial or ethnic origins. By way of example: a Welsh employee, Phil Gould, was given a Bo Peep costume to wear because of its association with sheep and, in the brokers' jestings, their association of sheep with Wales.

"A Northern Irish protestant employee, Steven Duff, was given a Pope costume to wear. The applicant was the (or certainly an) instigator of the choice of this costume. In this respect also the applicant was treated no differently from [other] employees."

The firm's own account of Mr Weinberger being handed the Hitler uniform on May 12 last year reads: "Shortly after his arrival, the applicant was handed a bag containing a second world war German army uniform costume by the third respondent [Simon Curry, a fellow broker] for the applicant to wear as his forfeit. The applicant refused to wear the costume."

The company says that a week later it decided that the new issue desk, where Mr Weinberger had been working, was performing poorly and he would have to move to another section and take a pay cut.

On May 21 Mr Weinberger resigned alleging "wrongful and unfair dismissal and racial discrimination".

In its defence Tullett&Tokyo admits that Mr Weinberger was called "Yiddo" and "Jew boy" by a manager and colleague. "The working environment on the first respondent's trading desks involved a lot of banter, including strong language, name calling and references to personal characteristics or actual (or alleged) habits much of which was in bad taste.

"The banter might be general, it might refer to a particular characteristic of an employee or it might on occasion refer to an employee's racial or ethnic origins. For example calling Welsh employees .... 'Welsh', 'Taffy Twat' and 'Sheepshagger'.

"It is specifically denied that on a continuing basis since 1997 the applicant was called 'Yiddo', 'Jew boy' and 'Jewey' by employees of the company if it is meant to suggest that the applicant was singled out for such treatment or subjected to it maliciously."

Tullett & Tokyo declined to answer questions, but released a copy of a letter sent by their lawyers to Mr Weinberger last week offering settlement.

In it they say the Hitler costume was "wholly inappropriate" but add that "we do not believe that this misguided behaviour amounted to race discrimination. Nor do we believe you held that belief at the time".

In the letter Tullett & Tokyo say that those involved in the Hitler uniform incident have received written warnings and that the Friday costumes practice has been ended: "To emphasise how inappropriate was this behaviour and to bring an end to these proceedings we are prepared to pay £50,000 to a Jewish charity (to be agreed between us) if you will withdraw your claim. We do not relish the prospect of the fight for obvious reasons, but we will not be blackmailed."

The company claims that Mr Weinberger abused colleagues of Jewish, Welsh and Scottish origin.

Neither Mr Weinberger nor his solicitors would comment ahead of tomorrow's hearing.

By way of example: a Welsh employee, Phil Gould, was given a Bo Peep costume to wear because of its association with sheep and, in the brokers' jestings, their association of sheep with Wales. "A Northern Irish protestant employee, Steven Duff, was given a Pope costume to wear. The applicant was the (or certainly an) instigator of the choice of this costume. In this respect also the applicant was treated no differently from [other] employees." The firm's own account of Mr Weinberger being handed the Hitler uniform on May 12 last year reads: "Shortly after his arrival, the applicant was handed a bag containing a second world war German army uniform costume by the third respondent [Simon Curry, a fellow broker] for the applicant to wear as his forfeit. The applicant refused to wear the costume." The company says that a week later it decided that the new issue desk, where Mr Weinberger had been working, was performing poorly and he would have to move to another section and take a pay cut. On May 21 Mr Weinberger resigned alleging "wrongful and unfair dismissal and racial discrimination". In its defence Tullett&Tokyo admits that Mr Weinberger was called "Yiddo" and "Jew boy" by a manager and colleague. "The working environment on the first respondent's trading desks involved a lot of banter, including strong language, name calling and references to personal characteristics or actual (or alleged) habits much of which was in bad taste. "The banter might be general, it might refer to a particular characteristic of an employee or it might on occasion refer to an employee's racial or ethnic origins. For example calling Welsh employees .... 'Welsh', 'Taffy Twat' and 'Sheepshagger'. "It is specifically denied that on a continuing basis since 1997 the applicant was called 'Yiddo', 'Jew boy' and 'Jewey' by employees of the company if it is meant to suggest that the applicant was singled out for such treatment or subjected to it maliciously." Tullett & Tokyo declined to answer questions, but released a copy of a letter sent by their lawyers to Mr Weinberger last week offering settlement. In it they say the Hitler costume was "wholly inappropriate" but add that "we do not believe that this misguided behaviour amounted to race discrimination. Nor do we believe you held that belief at the time". In the letter Tullett & Tokyo say that those involved in the Hitler uniform incident have received written warnings and that the Friday costumes practice has been ended: "To emphasise how inappropriate was this behaviour and to bring an end to these proceedings we are prepared to pay £50,000 to a Jewish charity (to be agreed between us) if you will withdraw your claim. We do not relish the prospect of the fight for obvious reasons, but we will not be blackmailed." The company claims that Mr Weinberger abused colleagues of Jewish, Welsh and Scottish origin. Neither Mr Weinberger nor his solicitors would comment ahead of tomorrow's hearing.

fields.headline: C4 struggles with physics
fields.trailText: 4pm: TV overnights Channel 4's physics night failed to spark a big bang in the ratings yesterday, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Channel 4's physics night failed to spark a big bang in the ratings yesterday, despite a well-received documentary on scientific genius Stephen Hawking.

The John Hurt-narrated Universe documentary and the Real Stephen Hawking gained a total of 3.2m viewers between 8pm and 10pm on Channel 4.

The profile of Mr Hawking took 1.9m and a 7% share.

But BBC2 dug deep with archaeology programmes Meet the Ancestors and Journeys to the Bottom of the Sea, which registered 5.6m between 8.30 and 10pm.

Journeys went head-to-head with the Real Stephen Hawking at 9pm and took 2.6m, with a 10% share.

Elsewhere, the Who Wants to be a Millionaire? bandwagon crushed Clive Owen vehicle Second Sight, pulling in 11.3m viewers and a 45% share at 9pm on ITV.

Second Sight drew 5.2m and a 21% share on BBC1.

The battle of the 10pm news bulletins again went the way of ITV, which drew 7.6m and achieved a 36% share.

It beat BBC1's news offering by a whopping 2.8m viewers.

Baddiel & Skinner's cheap and cheerful improvised show cleaned up in the late-night ratings, taking 4.1m and a 32% share at 10.50pm on ITV.

The comedy programme knocked the Demi Moore film Mortal Thoughts on Channel 4 into touch.

fields.headline: Motorbikes, Multiplication, and Mentalists
fields.trailText: GREG THE PEG
fields.body:
GREG THE PEG

It seems like only three days ago that John Gregory, football's Mr Live Fast, Die Young, was tearing out of Villa Park on the back of a hog on a mission to sign (another) new striker. In fact it was only three days ago, and in the middle of Villa's ultimately disappointing, nay rubbish, Cup defeat at the feet of Leicester City. Greg had pelted away from the ground in order to fly to Spain and watch Alaves striker Javi Moreno in action. Just as well it wasn't a completely wasted journey then, eh?

"Get away! I haven't had contact with anyone," Moreno said today. "I want to leave the subject closed. I wish to finish the season in Alaves and then we will see. I don't want to say too much. I can guarantee that I haven't signed anything with anyone and whoever says that I have is lying." Which is a fairly definitive statement whichever way you look at it (apart from upside down, when it simply becomes confusing).

Which leaves Greg in a right old Joachim of a situation. The man who, only 18 months ago, was trumpeting the cause of buying British, now can't land the foreign talent he so desperately wants. Another prospective deal, to bring Colombian Mauricio Serna to the club, is dependent on Gregory raising the necessary funds. Which means that, according to reports, true Brits Gareth Southgate, Dion Dublin and Julian Joachim are all up for grabs to the highest bidder. Vroom! Vroom!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MARKO DISTINCTION

Think of number between one and nine. Now multiply it by seven and add 100. Providing you have a rudimentary knowledge of the seven times table - and if you haven't, why wasn't it caned into you at school? - you should now have a large number in your mind's eye. As large as it may be, the Fiver is quietly confident that number falls short of 167, which happens to be the rather high combined age of Arsenal's first choice defence.

With Lee Dixon pushing 37, and Tony Adams and Martin Keown both 34, Arsene's Arsenal Wenger either needs to find an Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade style elixir of youth (pick the carpenter's cup, Arsene!) or bring in players that offer QVC - quality, versatility and cost-effectiveness. Which is where Hertha Berlin's Marko Rehmer comes in. At 28, Rehmer is just out of kindergarten as far as the Gunners are concerned. Better still, he can play in centre half, midfield or full-back and has 16 caps for Germany. And Rehmer even has a clause in his contract that states he can leave Hertha for 16m Deutsche marks (which is £5m at current exchange rates).

So is a deal close? According to reports in this morning's papers, Rehmer, who recently visited Arsenal's training facilities in London Colney, was practically on the plane over. But this afternoon Rehmer's agent Hans Joerg Neubauer poured a large jug of ice-cold water on such talk. "He is in talks with a number of clubs," said Neubauer. "I do not want to give a statement naming any clubs at the moment because we are in talks with some clubs. I will be able to say more in about two weeks." And with these some clubs reported to be Juventus, AC Milan and Fiorentina, Arsene may have to return to the adding board.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It's not about touting - that's monster rubbish. I just try to make clubs aware of players that are free. If I'm an actor in the West End, I want someone to find me the best play and the best deal - it's the same with footballers."

Eric Hall, who else, responds to a proposal by the FA's vice-chairman David Dein to ban agents touting players prior to transfer.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

'NAP HAND

Some children collect Dairylea triangles. Others collect, and sell, crack cocaine. But only Catalan nutters, it seems, are intent on collecting professional football players.

For the second time in two months, police have foiled the attempted kidnap of a Barcelona player. This time the target was shaven-headed midfielder Ivan de la Pena, who was assaulted in his home yesterday after being stalked all day by an unnamed 35-year-old (which rules out He Was He Is Emmanuel Petit).

Last month police arrested a 32-year-old man outside the Barca training ground - he later confessed to planning the kidnap of a member of the squad. The loon was looking for a big ransom to pay off his business debts, but because he was a non-football supporting mentalist, didn't know which one to nab.

The news comes at a bad time, with the imminent arrival of Stanley Victor Collymore on Spanish shores. Stanley, who is expected to complete his move to Real Oviedo today, would be an obvious target for any loon. No insult intended to Oviedo director general Felix Ortega.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal could sign Brazil international Ronaldinho on loan, according to reports. Ronaldinho's move from Gremio to Paris St Germain has been held up by red tape, and reports from France suggest that PSG may allow him to join the Gunners on loan while the matter is resolved.

FC Copenhagen striker David Nielsen is set for a £450,000 move to Sheffield Wednesday, according to his agent.

Sunderland are interested in signing 6ft 7ins Anderlecht striker Jan Koller for £9m.

Fulham have been linked with a move bid for Bradford City striker Benito Carbone.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Manchester United are planning to re-turf the playing surface at Old Trafford following their 1-0 FA Cup defeat to West Ham.

The club president of Serie A side Verona, Giambattista Pastorello, claims he is unlikely to sign a black player because it would prompt a backlash from his club's racist fans. Asked about a rumour that Verona striker Emiliano Bonazzoli would move to Parma, with Patrick Mboma heading the opposite way, Pastorello said it was unlikely. "If you have fans that do these things you need to have patience," he said. "Our supporters have behaved badly, at least in regard to coloured players".

Paulo Wanchope may not have played his last game for Manchester City despite being transfer-listed. "We'll get tomorrow out of the way and then we'll see," said manager Joe Royle.

Blackburn Rovers midfielder David Dunn has signed a new four-year contract.

Leicester have signed Gillingham midfielder Junior Lewis on a month's loan.

York's fixture with Carlisle will go ahead tonight after the Bootham Crescent pitch passed an afternoon inspection.

Sheffield Wednesday have signed a new three-year kit sponsorship deal with Diadora.

Sunderland have named former brewery executive Hugh Roberts as their new chief executive.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Football Extra (3.20am) "Hi, I'm Bert Bartlecek of Bogle, Bogle and Bogle Consultants (now known as Smartcasual). I'm assessing the TV and radio section for effectiveness. Don't mind me though, I'll just be in the background tapping violently on my top of the range laptop."

Channel 5: Dutch football (1am) TaptaptaptapTAPtaptaptap.

Argentine football (2.40pm) "Hi! Gwynnie! Lunch at 2.30 - 2.35! Ciao!"

Sky Sports 1: Live Scottish Football - Kilmarnock v Hibernian (7pm) TaptaptaptapTAPtaptaptap.

You're on Sky Sports! (10.30pm) [sudden absence of tapping]

World Football show (11.30pm). "Hey, Ghent! Come over here guy, I think I've got something."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on Five with Ian Payne (7pm) "You see, if we simply stop making jokes about this McCoff guy, and replace it with a picture of a monkey scratching its butt the coefficient rises exponentially!"

TalKspOrt: Football First European Special with Adrian Durham and Gerry Armstrong (7pm) "Hey, that's a great idea Bert. Sushimi?"

webTitle: BBC admits plans for advertising-funded website

fields.headline: BBC admits plans for advertising-funded website
fields.standfirst: BBC letter on website plan
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: The BBC has finally admitted it is planning an international news website to be funded by advertising, reports Amy Vickers.
BBC letter on website plan
Jan 24: BBC website ad plans condemned
fields.body:
The BBC has finally admitted it is planning an international news website that will be funded by advertising.

Caroline Thomson, director of public policy at the corporation, said the notion of a commercially-funded international online news service was "at an early stage of development".

However, she attempted to play down the significance of the move by insisting the websites would not simply be rubber-stamped by corporation bosses.

"If such a proposal were to come to fruition it would, of course, have to pass the BBC governors who act independently on behalf of the public interest, would require DCMS approval, and would be subject to all the usual UK and EU competition laws," she said.

Ms Thomson's letter follows a week of protest from commercial rivals who say the BBC should not be allowed to use public money to compete in the private setor.

Up to now the BBC has played down the initiative, which has been hatched during a series of clandestine conferences code-amed 'Hever'.

Ms Thomson's letter, written for this week's issue of internet trade magazine Industry Standard, opens up the idea of a commercially-funded public service website for public debate.

"I think this is a means of addressing the questions that have been raised around the issue of BBCNews.com, as well as an opportunity of giving the BBC point of view," said a spokesman for the BBC.

BBC critics, however, reacted angrily.

One industry source said: "The letter doesn't answer the 'taking money directly away from other UK news providers' argument and creating market distortion with licence fee funded content fuelling a commercial enterprise.

"It's a very bullish position to take, which is hardly surprising given the cosy relationship between the BBC and DCMS in the run-up to an election."

Ardent BBC Online critics, the British Internet Publishers Alliance, meets tomorrow with Gerald Kaufman, the chairman of the culture, media and sport select committee to talk about the BBC's internet role in response to the communications white paper.

webTitle: Website flies spy memoirs into Britain

fields.headline: Website flies spy memoirs into Britain
fields.trailText: The memoirs of former MI6 agent Richard Tomlinson were today released for the first time in Britain after a failed attempt to stop their publication.
fields.body:
The memoirs of former MI6 agent Richard Tomlinson were today released for the first time in Britain after a failed attempt to stop their publication.

More than 1,500 copies of the book The Big Breach were last night flown into the country from Russia by online information company 192.com, which claimed to be "defenders of the right to freedom of information".

Only 10,000 copies of the book have been printed by unknown Russian publishing house Narodny Variant. In a special arrangement with the publishers, 192.com said it had secured 5,000 copies for the British public.

Tomlinson, who worked for MI6 between 1991 to 1995, was jailed in 1997 for breaching the Official Secrets Act and now lives in Italy.

He reveals how the British intelligence services perfected a means of invisible writing using a humble Pentel pen.

British authorities have already attempted to stop publication of Tomlinson's revelations in a series of extracts in the Sunday Times.

But last week the Court of Appeal ruled that once the book was in the public domain, it could be made available in the UK.

Nuala Whelan, sales and marketing director for 192.com, said the company was committed to promoting the freedom of information and access to all data.

It has already been criticised by privacy campaigners for making it possible to find the home address of anyone registered to vote in Britain.

Ms Whelan said: "It is not that we are supporting the publication of secrets from Russia, but the book has been published.

"If the information is available to people in Russia, it should also be available to the British."

Allegations have been made by the prominent Soviet defector, Oleg Gordievsky, a former high-ranking KGB officer, that the Russian secret service has doctored the memoirs in an attempt to undermine the British secret service.

But 192.com issued a qualification with each copy of the new book stating that it made no judgment on its merits or authenticity.

It warned that the book was published in Russia "in circumstances which seem as much cloak-and-dagger as the story itself".

"We make no judgment on the merits of this book or the authenticity of the whole. Whatever the circumstances surrounding its publication, the result has certainly been to leave MI6 powerless to prevent its entering the public domain, and doubtless the KGB - or their successors in the now named SSB - regard that as one in the eye for the British secret service."

John Wadham, director of civil rights group Liberty, said: "It can't be right for the Russian people to be able to read about the escapades of the MI6, but for the people of this country - whose taxes pay for the MI6 - to be unable to read the same information."

webTitle: Hoon praises Nato but argues for EU force

fields.headline: Hoon praises Nato but argues for EU force
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, yesterday delivered a robust case in support of plans for a joint EU military force, the object of fierce criticism by the Conservatives and elements within the new Bush administration.
fields.body:
Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, yesterday delivered a robust case in support of plans for a joint EU military force, the object of fierce criticism by the Conservatives and elements within the new Bush administration.

Mr Hoon said the aim was to strengthen Europe's military capability, adding: "There must be no doubt that Nato is and will remain the cornerstone of our defence."

He told a Royal Institute for International Affairs confer ence: "We have not given away the right to say where and how British troops will be deployed. We have not placed another burden on our already stretched armed forces. We have not signed up to duplicate or independent structures that would in some way damage Nato."

The EU is committed, by 2003, to deploy within 60 days ground forces of up to 60,000 troops, with maritime and air forces. Britain has said it could contribute up to 12,500 ground troops, 18 warships and 72 combat aircraft.

webTitle: President Bush urges religion to increase sense of charity

fields.headline: President Bush urges religion to increase sense of charity
fields.trailText: In a move that will resonate with the British government's aim to embrace faith-based organisations, US president George Bush is attempting to tap religious institutions for more charitable work.
fields.body:
In a move that will resonate with the British government's aim to embrace faith-based organisations, US president George Bush is attempting to tap religious institutions for more charitable work.

On Monday, President Bush established a White House office that would distribute billions of dollars to religious groups and charities over the next 10 years. The president wants to allow such groups to compete for taxpayer's money to provide after-school programmes, prison ministries and drug treatment, among other activities.

To build support, the president will meet leaders of spiritual and charitable groups throughout this week and he plans to attend the National Prayer Breakfast on Thursday.

Earlier this month, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, acknowledged the importance of faith-based organisations in galvanising volunteers when he announced his £300m funding package for voluntary organisations over the next three years.

Critics in the US say using public money for such programmes could violate the separation between church and state. Even some churches are wary of government money that might come with strings attached. Making a preemptive strike at those critics, President Bush said religious groups must be part of the solution to society's ills.

"A compassionate society is one which recognises the great power of faith," the president said last week. "We in government must not fear faith-based programmes, we must welcome faith-based programmes."

In March, a US-based specialist in charitable activity, Robert D Putnam, will tell delegates at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations' (NCVO) third sector foresight conference how to maximise social capital and discuss if there are any lessons to be learned from America.

fields.headline: Senior staff abandon AltaVista
fields.trailText: 3pm: Two senior employees of AltaVista Europe have quit amid speculation the operation is to close, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Two senior employees of AltaVista Europe have resigned amid speculation parent company CMGI is about to close its European operations.

Pierre Paperon, president of international operations, and Vesey Crichton, international general manager, are believed to have walked out after a disagreement on strategic direction.

AltaVista Europe immediately raised the drawbridge, refusing to talk to the press or elaborate on further departures from the European office.

Instead, a statement from the US web company said Nick Humby, a finance director of CMGI, will take on the role of acting chief operating officer in Europe.

Also Kevin Eyres, an operational engineer from AltaVista Europe, will assume the role of acting general manager.

"Mr Paperon has departed the company for personal reasons and has not indicated any future plans," said Peter Mills, managing partner of CMGI and an adviser to AltaVista.

AltaVista has felt the pinch recently - it has been forced to shed around 450 staff in the past four months.

Rumours persist it is about to close its Maidenhead office and cut back to a skeleton operation based in Ireland.

It is believed just over 50 staff remain at the UK office, half the number employed last year.

CMGI now appears to be pulling all the strings at AltaVista.

All decisions affecting the European arm are coming directly from the head office in Palo Alto, California.

AltaVista created a frenzy in the UK last year when it said it would provide unmetered free internet access.

It then reneged on its word, misleading the press about having launched the service.

fields.headline: Charities face 'quiet crisis' over funding
fields.trailText: Celebrity endorsements and high-profile campaigns can provide charities with the means they need for innovative projects. Finding the funds to pay the electricity bill or upgrade a computer is a less glamorous task however, and one that is becoming increasingly difficult for all voluntary organisations.
fields.body:
Celebrity endorsements and high-profile campaigns can provide charities with the means they need for innovative projects. Finding the funds to pay the electricity bill or upgrade a computer is a less glamorous task however, and one that is becoming increasingly difficult for all voluntary organisations.

Funding for core costs continues to be a thorny issue for a voluntary sector still reeling from media accounts of misspending and high administration costs. Latest analysis of the top 500 charities' accounts by the Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) shows that state funding sources have fallen by £87m, or 6.7%, in real terms - possibly caused in part by a levelling out of contracting services to the sector.

Some new streams of statutory income, such as the New Opportunities Fund and SureStart, have yet to show up in charity accounts or may be going to smaller charities. But many organisations currently face what one charity chief executive has described as the "quiet crisis" of formerly reliable sources of income becoming harder to access or disappearing altogether.

Central and local government remain among the main sources of core funding for many organisations, and the funding guidelines stemming from the Compact call on government for "a recognition of core costs and how they can be met". They also urge voluntary organisations to prepare realistic budgets, which take into account financial changes such as salary increases or compliance costs related to new legislation.

Constant squeezes on statutory funding are compounded by the nature of the process itself. "Often you don't know whether you've got the funding until you've spent it," says one charity director.

Research by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations shows the sector wants a commitment from any future government to provide them with core funding, with 65% preferring this form to project funding (20%) and start up funding (15%). The National Lottery Charities Board does not fund core costs, but will cover start-up costs and project running costs. The board has been under pressure from the sector to reconsider its stance on core funds but has yet to change its policy. Applicants sometimes build core costs into their bids, but the board does not look kindly on this.

One organisation recently had £24,000 stripped out of its bid because it covered core management costs; another had its grant turned down because it related to posts already being funded.

Trusts and foundations often represent a more fruitful way of getting central costs covered. While some stipulate that they will only fund specific or time-limited projects, others like London's City Parochial Foundation actively encourage applicants with core funding needs. Its annual budget of £5.5m has supported salaries, training and administration costs for organisations like the Children's Express journalism project and community development group Praxis.

Clerk to the foundation Bharat Mehta says independent funders have avoided core costs as it silts up funding. But the climate is changing, he says, particularly with many trusts and foundations now run by people from charities who have a hands-on understanding of applicants' needs.

An entirely new approach to funding was set out more than a year ago in a publication from the Association of Chief Executives of Voluntary Organisations (ACEVO). Who pays for core costs? argues that contract funding is not conducive to a good funding relationship as it discourages transparency and partnership.

Instead, author and consultant Julia Unwin puts forward three alternatives for funders:
 full project funding - including necessary core costs
 development funding - supporting infrastructure of an organisation in its early stages
 strategic funding - investing in a charity to meet own objectives.

Ms Unwin said: "The argument around core funding is a dead one. The sector needs a new settlement that recognises the real costs involved in running organisations."

webTitle: Councils to win health scrutiny powers

fields.headline: Councils to win health scrutiny powers
fields.trailText: District councils are set to win new powers to scrutinise the work of local hospitals and GPs under the health and social care bill.
fields.body:
District councils are set to win new powers to scrutinise the work of local hospitals and GPs under the health and social care bill.

The legislation carries forward proposals in the NHS plan to greatly strengthen local government's role in examining the health service.

The bill originally made no mention of the role of district councils in the scrutiny process, and officials at the local government association (LGA) feared this would make it difficult or impossible for county councils to pass on scrutiny responsibilities to politicians in lower-tier authorities.

But government amendments to the bill, now in its committee stage, will allow districts to take on delegated scrutiny powers from county councils, form joint committees with them or have district councillors co-opted onto a county scrutiny panel.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is also likely to gain new powers to force reluctant counties to cooperate.

A spokeswoman for the LGA welcomed the move: "It seems mad to exclude districts when they have a contribution to make to this vital debate."

Although the amendment raises the possibility of NHS trust chief executives facing a grilling from district councillors, it is much more likely that the powers will be used to call in GPs and officials from local primary care groups and trusts.

The powers could be used to involve district councils in broader decisions, such as hospital closures that have a direct impact on the district's area.

Both the LGA and the NHS confederation backed the move. A joint discussion paper from the two organisations said: "District councils must also have a role in this process They also provide housing, leisure and environmental service which have a major impact on local health."

fields.headline: Who really owns our bodies?
fields.trailText: Comment:Beyond the questions of consent at Alder Hey are those of professional interest, commerce and, particularly, ownership, writes Jane Wildgoose
fields.body:
The findings of today's report into Alder Hey are to be welcomed. Closer examination of the issue of consent in relation to medical profession and the public is long overdue. But, additional to questions of consent at Alder Hey are those of professional interest, commerce and, particularly, ownership.

Until recently, the concept prevailed that the "only lawful possessor of the dead body is the earth". With its echoes of Christian doctrine and the words of the burial service, "earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust", this ancient principle was brought into legal argument when the artist Anthony-Noel Kelly was tried in 1998 for theft of anatomical specimens from the Royal College of Surgeons (RCS). It was at Kelly's trial that this principle was overturned, and that some of the issues under debate regarding Alder Hey were prefigured.

Kelly and an accomplice had removed anatomical specimens from a basement store at the RCS. Kelly made moulds from the specimens, which he then cast in plaster and embellished with precious metals. While not denying that he took the specimens to further his work, he pleaded not guilty to the charge of theft since, at the time he took them, there was no precedent for corpses being regarded as property, and the lesser trespass of "outraging public decency" prevailed.

In order to gain a conviction for theft, it was necessary to establish that the corpses in question had some status as property. To whom did these particular body parts belong? Unidentifiable due to the length of time they had been stored, it was impossible to tract the next of kin, or to establish rights of possession by the college under contemporary licence law.

However, Judge Rivlin did rule that the specimens were the property of the RCS: because of the "skilled work" carried out upon them by "a previous generation" of surgeons. In his summing up, Judge Rivlin asked the jury to consider whether the defendants a) took the body parts; b) intended to deprive the "owners" of the property permanently; and c) were acting dishonestly. These are all questions which might be raised with regard to Alder Hey.

His case exposed irregularities in storage of bodies donated for medial research, and also fuelled public concern about commercial interest - in this case of an artist - in dealing with the dead. The benefits of medical research are undeniable, but the use of human material by pharmaceutical companies sponsoring research is subject to commercial interests - which extend beyond what many would consider "legitimate" medical research to the cosmetic industry.

Dr Ruth Richardson, who has contributed to the Alder Hey inquiry, medical historian and author of Death, Dissection and the Destitute (a comprehensive study of the background and consequences of the 1832 Anatomy Act), submitted evidence to the recent chief medical officer's summit on organs and consent. In the new edition of her book, she discusses the "fearful symmetry" of commercial and social conditions prevailing in the late 18th and early 19th centuries (which led to sale of stolen corpses to anatomy schools for dissection) and conditions surrounding organ transplant and the research industry today.

Unless the government acts to ensure that human material will never be bought and sold, we face a return to the kind of conditions which led to the 1832 Act where unregulated trade in human corpses put the public at risk.

As Dr Richardson points out, the human corpse again has a commercial value unprecedented since the 1832 Act. Dr Richardson advises that we learn the lessons of medical history, and ensure that the human body is never bought or sold, but rather used in fully understood, consenting donation. However, this question remains: does current law sufficiently cover the question of ownership of the body under contemporary conditions for consent to be effectively protected?

To return to the Kelly case, it would appear that if the same principles were applied, Alder Hey hospital could be construed as being the legal owner of the body parts because of the "skilled" work they carried out.

At the same time, they would appear to be answerable the same questions as Kelly. Did they take the body parts? Did they intend to deprive the "owners" of the property permanently? Were they acting dishonestly? It could well be that they are open to police investigation in the same way that Kelly was.

Kelly's case has left a legal precedent which, in apparently seeking to protect the medical profession, may well have left it open to criminal investigation

 Jane Wildgoose is a visiting lecturer at Winchester School of Art. She is an artist and also writes on the status of the body in historical and contemporary art.
