fields.headline: Jobbins to head freelances's charity
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: BBC veteran Bob Jobbins has been named chairman of the Rory Peck Trust, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Bob Jobbins, a long-time BBC World Service director, is to be the new chairman of the Rory Peck Trust.

Mr Jobbins replaces Lucian Hudson, a former programme editor at BBC Worldwide, who has taken up a position at the cabinet office.

Mr Jobbins, a former foreign correspondent in the middle east and the US, has worked at the BBC for 30 years.

More recently, he was involved in setting up World Service Television (now BBC World).

Tina Carr, director of the trust, which was set up in 1992 to promote the safety and financial security of freelance camera operators, said Mr Jobbins was "ideally placed to understand the issues facing freelance camera operators working in newsgathering around the world".

It has a special focus on training for hostile environments and supporting the families of cameramen killed in action.

fields.headline: Lockerbie verdict due tomorrow
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: A verdict in the Lockerbie bombing trial will be delivered tomorrow, the presiding Scottish high court judge, Lord Ranald Sutherland, announced today.
fields.body:
A verdict in the Lockerbie bombing trial will be delivered tomorrow, the presiding Scottish high court judge, Lord Ranald Sutherland, announced today.

The decision will be issued at 10am GMT at Camp Zeist, a former US air base, where the judges have heard the case against two Libyans charged with the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103.

The two men, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, are accused of planting a bomb on the flight and which killed 270 people in December 1988. They have been on trial in the Netherlands under Scottish law for the last eight months.

There are three possible verdicts the judges could deliver tomorrow: guilty, innocent or not proven - the latter specific to Scottish law. Any verdict other than guilty will result in the immediate release of the two men.

If convicted, the men face life imprisonment in a Glasgow jail. The defence would have two weeks to appeal a guilty verdict. Any appeal would be heard by a five-judge Scottish court at Camp Zeist. The prosecution cannot appeal.

Both men have pleaded innocent, with the defence suggesting Palestinian extremists carried out the bombing, probably on behalf of Iran in revenge for the shooting down of an Iranian civilian Airbus earlier in 1988 by the US missile cruiser USS Vincennes.

Prosecution lawyers say the accused sent an unaccompanied suitcase containing a bomb on board an Air Malta flight from Luqa airport in Malta, which was later transferred to the doomed Pan Am flight.

Mr Megrahi and Mr Fhimah surrendered for trial in April 1999 under a deal settled with the Libyan leader Muammar Gadafy, who agreed to have them stand trial in a neutral country after nearly a decade of economic sanctions.

fields.bodyText: A verdict in the Lockerbie bombing trial will be delivered tomorrow, the presiding Scottish high court judge, Lord Ranald Sutherland, announced today. The decision will be issued at 10am GMT at Camp Zeist, a former US air base, where the judges have heard the case against two Libyans charged with the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. The two men, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, are accused of planting a bomb on the flight and which killed 270 people in December 1988. They have been on trial in the Netherlands under Scottish law for the last eight months. There are three possible verdicts the judges could deliver tomorrow: guilty, innocent or not proven - the latter specific to Scottish law. Any verdict other than guilty will result in the immediate release of the two men. If convicted, the men face life imprisonment in a Glasgow jail. The defence would have two weeks to appeal a guilty verdict. Any appeal would be heard by a five-judge Scottish court at Camp Zeist. The prosecution cannot appeal. Both men have pleaded innocent, with the defence suggesting Palestinian extremists carried out the bombing, probably on behalf of Iran in revenge for the shooting down of an Iranian civilian Airbus earlier in 1988 by the US missile cruiser USS Vincennes. Prosecution lawyers say the accused sent an unaccompanied suitcase containing a bomb on board an Air Malta flight from Luqa airport in Malta, which was later transferred to the doomed Pan Am flight. Mr Megrahi and Mr Fhimah surrendered for trial in April 1999 under a deal settled with the Libyan leader Muammar Gadafy, who agreed to have them stand trial in a neutral country after nearly a decade of economic sanctions. fields.headline: Telewest confident of boosting subscriber numbers
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Cable operator Telewest says it is 'on target' to reach 500,000 subscribers by March, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Cable operator Telewest is staging a comeback after a disastrous summer last year, when it lost ground to its digital rivals.

The Microsoft-backed company said it was on course to reach 500,000 subscribers by March after announcing its latest operating figures.

Telewest's shares were hammered last year when supply problems caused a shortage of digital set-top boxes and let rivals ONdigital and BSkyB race ahead.

Telewest said it had signed up 377,664 digital customers at the end of December.

It was "confident" of reaching the 500,000 mark by the end of the first quarter of the year.

"These figures show Telewest is delivering on target," said chief executive Adam Singer.

"Our focus on customer service and the launch of our digital pricing and packaging is starting to reap benefits."

Telewest is on many analysts' long-term buy lists because of the potential revenue to be gained from bundled services.

These combine television, internet and telephone, accessed through a single cable line.

The company's shares rose 2% (or 3p) to 148.75p in early trading, although they are still far behind their 12-month high of 563p.

But Telewest and close rival NTL remain far behind BSkyB, which has over 4m digital customers, and Ondigital, which has just over 1m.

It is expected Telewest and NTL, the two major UK cable companies, will merge at some point in the future in order to catch up with their competitors.

In the short term, it is likely the two parties will collaborate to cut costs.

This could involve joint purchasing of set-top boxes and a combined approach on regulatory issues.

NTL has set itself a target of 1.25m digital subscribers by the end of the year.

fields.headline: Visiting mum
fields.standfirst:
How do children cope when a parent is sent to jail? Maggie O'Kane travels to Low Newton prison with the daughter of one inmate
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: How do children cope when a parent is sent to jail?  Maggie O'Kane travels to Low Newton prison with the daughter of one inmate.
fields.body:
Lisa Peel was supposed to be smacked up, but she has been clean for a while - been through the "rattle". There can't be many worse places to go through the rattle than a housing estate outside Middlesbrough. High-gloss pink kitchen walls; cold turkey in the afternoon in the corner of the sitting room where Lovejoy leaps about the screen with Joanna Lumley.

Outside, the atmosphere on the estate is heavy with heroin. It's in the agitated gait of the young men hurrying by as if they are going to miss the last train to somewhere important. It's in the rigid, heads-down march of two women across the road hoping that if they push their prams fast enough their kids won't be infected.

Peel's life of addiction, abuse and confusion may have nothing to do with her mother's life spent in and out of prison. She certainly doesn't blame her mother, although she does wish she had been around more. "The first time my mum went into prison I was two and a half. I remember going to see her with my dad. He told me that she was in hospital but I kept asking where the bed was. Then, after the visit, she went back through a door to the cells and they said 'kids aren't allowed in there'."

This year, around 44,000 children will lose their mother, or father, to Her Majesty's prisons. Peel's mother, Julie Miller, has already served six sentences for everything from driving while banned to cheque-book fraud, and is halfway through a seventh. "I committed child abuse by leaving her," she says.

Peel is softer on her mother. "She was a heroin addict and she had mental health problems. She needed help, my mum."

Diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenic in 1991, Miller, now 37, was a regular at St Luke's psychiatric hospital in Middlesbrough. The day before her last crime, she arrived at St Luke's in an agitated state and was sent home with 60 sleeping tablets. Once home, she added diazepam (tranquillisers) and crack cocaine to the mix and went out to rob the local Spar with a kitchen knife. Her sister was behind the till; she held the knife to her throat. She got four and a half years.

She began her sentence on her daughter's 18th birthday. That was the night Peel started on the path to heroin addiction. "I'd tried it three times before, but that night I just wanted to get wasted. I'm not blaming my mum - I might have ending up doing it anyway. But that's when it really started.

"I was on my own in the house with £42 a week. Social services didn't know anything about me. The night the police arrested my mother they boarded up the doors. I said to them: 'Hey, I live here,' and they said: 'We'll give you some time to get your stuff out.' After that I always [saw] people around who were taking it. I could do what I liked, she was locked up."

Peel remembers the second time her mother went to jail. She was six or seven years old. "They told me she was 'working away'. She got 22 months for driving while banned. I had to stay with her girlfriend. I think she was jealous of the love my mum had for me and she hit me. I didn't tell my mum she was beating me then because Heather said she'd kill me if I told and I believed her.

"She went into prison for the fifth time when I was 16. She was really sick then. She was on heroin and crack. When she went inside that time, I just stayed in the house.

"I dropped out of college. I would probably have stayed on if she was around. But word got out that my ma was inside. People started saying she was a smackhead and I was living in a smack house. So I stayed at home. I really missed her then. We were close, me and my ma: there was only 17 years between us. We used to go to the pub together."

Miller is serving out her sentence in one of the country's more progressive prisons, Low Newton, near Durham, where the drug-rehabilitation programme is the only one of its kind in Britain. It is 2.45pm; visiting time. Inside the main gates a drug-sniffing spaniel is circling the 20 or so children who have been brought in to see their mothers. For the most part it seems to be the grandmothers and sisters, not the men, who have brought the kids.

The women and children sit around white Formica tables in the prison's old dining room. The walls are painted yel low, and there is a play area for children.

Tracy Lally, 32, has five children. She has been a heroin addict since she was 16 and hasn't seen her kids for over a year. "Two of my kids are up for adoption and I'm happy about that. Their foster mother is great. It's my eight-year-old, Kyle, I worry about. He was four and a half when I was taken from him and he said: 'Ma, why don't you just climb over the fence? They can't keep you in here, they are not your ma and da.' "

Low Newton's governor, Mike Kirby, surveys the scene. He has worked in some of the country's harshest prisons. One of his worst memories was of a scene in the visiting room at Warrington in Cheshire. "The father came in with the son. I think he was about five and he didn't understand that his mother was in a prison and she wasn't leaving with them. At the end of visiting time he grabbed her waist and wouldn't let her go. He started screaming that he didn't want to leave her. It was tragic, really tragic. It upset everyone."

Diana Rogan, 32, is with her two chil dren, aged 11 and 13. A former heroin addict serving five years for supplying heroin, she is due to be released at the end of 2002. Her son says: "The other kids used to come up and say, 'Your ma is in prison,' but now they've stopped. Sometimes I had to shout at them. I like coming to see my ma and I never cry because it upsets my ma."

For some children, keeping their parent's imprisonment hidden is a burden. Jill remembers taking her son to Durham prison to see his father for the first time. "I didn't know the way, so I asked someone in the street and my son, Owen, said to me after: 'Ma, why did you have to go and do that? Now everyone will know my da is in prison.'"

Owen often tried to make excuses not to go and see his father. Durham, a high-security prison, can be a traumatic place for children. "They get stressed out. They think their dad is working there and ask me: 'Do you work here with my dad, do you drive the big white van [the prison transfer van] like my dad?' " says Christine Slassor of the North-East Prison After-Care Society (Nepac). "When they go in they are searched - shoes, coats, everything. They take off their watches and belts and go through a scanner. Then they have to stand in line while sniffer dogs search them for drugs."

The biggest problem for most kids is understanding where and why their mother has gone. "When I was about seven and she went back in," says Peel, "I couldn't understand why she had just gone and left me."

Joshua was eight when his mother was sent to Low Newton. "She said she was going to her friend's. She called a taxi, and the taxi just came and drove her here."

Joanne Moss is also on the drug rehabilitation programme at the prison. "My son, who's four, took it very bad. He started taking his shoes off and hiding them to get attention. Or taking off his clothes. I went on home leave and he never left my side; he was holding on to me all the time. When he comes to see me there are tantrums and I wonder sometimes if it would be better for him not to come, but I'm desperate to see him. It's hard."

In October, Britain's prison service will offer an alternative to prison for some addicts - compulsory treatment in the community. The drugs testing and treatment order is, says the Howard League for Penal Reform, "a big step in the right direction".

Twenty years ago, such a programme might have given Lisa Peel back her mother. "I did nothing wrong. I know she had to suffer for what she did, but the kids shouldn't have to suffer as well. I have never been in trouble with the police - never had a caution, never. I don't care what anybody says, you need your mum."

Help for children of imprisoned parents is available from the Federation of Prisoners and Family Support Groups on 020-8741 4578. It has links to a national support network.

fields.headline: My time 2
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Daily life in prison.
fields.body:
Duncan Williams, 36
Time served: six months on remand Crime: arson and criminal damage (acquitted)

On arriving at HMP Wandsworth the first thing that strikes you is the dark and doom- ridden architecture. Then comes the oversized, tattered clothing. That gives the prison officers in the "reception area" a reason to yell at you to: "Tuck your fucking shirt in, fella, you look like a sack of fucking horse shit!"

The constant bullying from officers creates contempt, defiance and hatred. It is wrong to suggest that every prison officer is an uncaring, unintelligent sadist; there are many men and women working hard to do a difficult job as best they can. But thanks to underfunding, overcrowding, understaffing, poor training and old-school attitudes, there are far too few of them. By the time the majority of men are ready for release from Wandsworth they are - if they weren't before - bitter, hate-ridden individuals with little in the way of a future. Many are back within months of release.

While I was there, most of us were not engaged in any constructive activity during the day. We spent 23 hours out of 24 hours locked in a tiny 8x12ft cell, two sharing. It was mind-numbing.

I made at least three applications for educational courses within the first few days of arriving and never heard a reply. The nearest I came to education was when a group of 20 or more inmates were herded into a small holding room and issued with scraps of paper that we were told were an "educational standard" test. The pages had been photocopied so many times that the typeface was barely readable. Most people didn't care. They were grateful to get out of the cell for a few minutes.

I used to read letters out to one man who was illiterate. He never got any assistance to learn to read and write throughout his stay. He was only in for three months for some drunken crime, but surely some better use could have been made of his time there?

Drugs and addiction are the evil behind most crimes and the abuse does not stop inside. Heroin has replaced cannabis as the drug of choice because it stays in the system for less time, so it's harder to trace. Despite claims to the contrary, Wandsworth is awash with drugs. I remember sitting in a cell with one poor soul who had attempted to smuggle a large quantity of narcotics into the prison by secreting a stash up his backside; unfortunately, the condom he had packed the stash into burst. He fell into a deep coma and had to be rushed to hospital.

Suicide is also rife in prison. Six men were found dead in Wandsworth by midsummer of 2000. In July, I was moved into a cell where a Spanish inmate had attempted suicide the night before. The cellmate told me the man had been beaten by someone and was in a state of total fear. He woke to find the man choking on a noose tied to a metal hinge. He pulled the man down in the nick of time and he was rushed to hospital. In this instance the police were called, but no charges were brought and no statements made.

I left Wandsworth in December with nothing but a plastic sack, uncomfortable memories and the clothes on my back. I'd lost my flat, my job and my self-respect.

Sharon Corzon, 26
Sentence: five years Crime: GBH

This was my first sentence and I got the maximum you could get for GBH because I'm black and the girl I attacked was white. That's what I think. The three prisons I've been in have all been prejudiced against black people.

White girls can be so rude to the officers - they can swear at them, they can be really insulting and give the officer no respect, and they can get away with it. But if you just say "no" and you're black, you're in trouble.

As a black person you have to hold back. You have to pretend. You have to creep. You have to keep quiet. You have to be so humble and stupid to survive as a black person in prison, and that's just not me. That's not my personality. I wasn't going to pretend to be something I wasn't.

It's the officers rather than the inmates who are racist. Black officers are few and far between. In Holloway there are more because it's in London, but the sad thing is that because they're in the minority they don't speak out against the racism. In fact, I've found they are more prejudiced against the black people.

Racism is institutionalised. Who can you complain to? You can't complain to the officer that's being horrible to someone. She'll just make your life hell. You can't complain to the governor because it's his job to back up the officer. You can't complain to the board because it's their job to back up the governor. You're fucked.

I took my prison to court because they were trying to take my baby away from me. After about five months being pregnant in the mother and baby unit, I was told I wasn't allowed to keep my baby because they thought I would endanger other mothers because of my temper. It was insulting and they were proved wrong because I won my court case and was allowed to keep my baby. I was sure that was racist as well because the board saw three pregnant black girls in the same week as me and they all got refused permission to keep their babies.

The threat of having my baby taken away was always hanging over me from then on. It was always: "If you do that again, you have to hand your child over." Meanwhile, white girls were fighting left, right and centre, and it was ignored. A lot of the black girls just let it go because they want to get their parole and go home early. It shouldn't be like that.

Andrew Evans, 45
Sentence: life (overturned) Crime: murder (wrongly convicted)

A part of me had to die to survive in prison. When you first come in you see somebody being beaten up and the instinct is to help. In prison you realise you can't. Your normal social awareness has to be disposed of. You have to let the horrors of prison wash over you, or you go insane. It's a psychological and emotional bludgeoning that goes on every day. You hear the screams at night when you first go into prison and it terrifies you because you think: "What the hell's going on?" After a while you realise that it's people cracking up because they can't take it any more.

Occasionally the guards will be fed up with someone or will have had a bad day with the wife and want to take it out on someone. That's the way they are.

Whatever crime somebody commits isn't the problem. That's the symptom. Until society gets to grip with that there will never be a reduction in crime. The problem is why they commit the crime in the first place. People say, "Oh, it's because they're short of money." That's one reason. But the reason they are short of money is because they can't fit into what everyone considers normal society. So the only way for them to cope is to opt out of the system - into this other system called crime.

What society needs to start thinking about is how to stop all these people opting out. They come into prison after going to the boys' home, the girls' home, the foster home; they've been abused and maltreated from the day they were born. It's like a cycle - they have kids and their kids start coming in. And for the people there now there is no rehabilitation. The only thing prison does is remove the problem from society for a while - and then place it back in society worse than it was before.

There is some education in prison and it does benefit some people. But what the hell are people supposed to do when they get out? They can't get a job. It's hard enough getting a decent job without a record, let alone with.

The three prisons I've been in have all been prejudiced against black people. White girls can be so rude to the officers - they can swear at them, they can be really insulting and give the officer no respect, and they can get away with it. But if you just say "no" and you're black, you're in trouble. As a black person you have to hold back. You have to pretend. You have to creep. You have to keep quiet. You have to be so humble and stupid to survive as a black person in prison, and that's just not me. That's not my personality. I wasn't going to pretend to be something I wasn't. It's the officers rather than the inmates who are racist. Black officers are few and far between. In Holloway there are more because it's in London, but the sad thing is that because they're in the minority they don't speak out against the racism. In fact, I've found they are more prejudiced against the black people. Racism is institutionalised. Who can you complain to? You can't complain to the officer that's being horrible to someone. She'll just make your life hell. You can't complain to the governor because it's his job to back up the officer. You can't complain to the board because it's their job to back up the governor. webTitle: Ian Katz visits a jail for the aged

fields.headline: Grey area
fields.standfirst:
Many of the 1,000 elderly convicts in British prisons are so infirm that they pose little or no threat to society. So why are they still behind bars? In the second part of our week-long investigation into life inside our prisons, Ian Katz visits the country's only jail for the aged
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Many of the 1,000 elderly convicts in British prisons are so infirm that they pose little or no threat to society. So why are they still behind bars? In the second part of our week-long investigation into life inside our prisons,  Ian Katz visits the country's only jail for the aged
fields.body:
No one seems to know the whole of Harry's story, but this is what they do know. He was born in Kilmarnock, worked on the railways, became an alcoholic after his parents died. They know he lived rough and that in 1991 he was sentenced to life for starting a series of fires. He is 71.

It was never easy to get through to Harry at the best of times, and a couple of years ago it began to get even harder. Depending on who you ask, he was suffering from either Alzheimer's or a form of alcohol-induced dementia. Everyone agrees that he frequently did not know where he was, that he began falling over regularly and became incontinent. Once he borrowed a lighter to light a cigarette and accidentally set his hair on fire. They put him in a cell with a CCTV camera because they were so worried he would do himself an injury.

Recently, when he could no longer walk without help, he was moved to a nearby prison hospital. Doctors there said he should be released, but to where? "It's difficult to find nursing homes that are prepared to take people like that," says Stuart McLean, who retired as governor of Portsmouth's Kingston prison last week. "The last thing they want is to have someone who may be disruptive."

Harry's case highlights one of the thorniest questions facing our penal system: when, if ever, is someone too old or infirm to be kept behind bars? It is a delicate balancing act between compassion and risk, and right now the scales are tipped heavily against compassion. "If someone has a terminal illness I will pull out all the stops to give them the dignity of dying a free man," says McLean. "But apart from that there's not a lot I can do. It's difficult to get people released because everyone wants to make sure there's not going to be some sort of miraculous recovery. That can be terribly embarrassing."

McLean has more experience of these grim calculations than most. Kingston is the only prison in the country with a wing dedicated to elderly prisoners. The administrative wing of the Victorian jail was converted into accommodation for around 30 older prisoners five years ago in response to the rising number of elderly inmates in the system. The numbers of old prisoners has mirrored the explosion in the prison population of the last 15 years. In 1989 there were just 345 prisoners over the age of 60; by 1999 there were 1,053. There are 250 inmates in their 70s and 21 over 80. Until now, however, the prison service has devoted little or no thought to how to handle older inmates. Individual jails do the best they can, usually housing their older inmates in so-called VP (vulnerable prisoner) wings or prison hospitals. "[The prison service] has no policy on the elderly at all," Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, says in an interview with the Guardian to be published on Friday. "When I discover an 87-year-old on a Zimmer frame with Alzheimer's in a high-security prison, I'm sorry, but I think that is a nonsense."

Built in 1877 as Portsmouth's town jail, Kingston prison is a generously proportioned, three-storey stone structure surrounded by 20-foot walls topped with a roll of barbed wire. It is renowned for its gardens - complete with aviaries, manicured hedges, water features and artificial bowling green - and its football team. (The team's position at the top of the local league could have something to do with the fact that all fixtures are played at home and visiting supporters are forbidden, admits McLean.) It is also the only prison in Britain that takes only lifers, meaning that at least three-quarters of its inmates are murderers.

The idea behind H wing was to give older lifers some protection from the rest of the population, says McLean. Its inmates can circulate in the prison but other prisoners cannot pass through the two heavy gates that separate it from the rest of the jail. The wing itself has many of the trappings of a care home: stairlifts, specially equipped baths and alarm buttons in each room. Its rooms, each shared by four inmates, are bright and comparatively airy and there are several spartan communal rooms that could easily be mistaken for doctors' waiting rooms. Staff appear to be patient and courteous. "The biggest problem with them is motivation," says Jim Clark, one of the officers on the wing. "We've tried to get them out to play bowls but they just won't go. About a third of them work and the rest of them don't want to move away from their TVs."

Sir David Ramsbotham has praised Kingston for its treatment of elderly prisoners, so why, I wonder, has the press been kept out until now? A prison service official offers a surprisingly candid response: "A lot of people in the service have doubts about whether these people should still be in prison."

It's easy to see why. In one room I meet Boom Boom, a man who looks to be in his 70s leaning awkwardly on a three-legged walking stick. Like many of the inmates on E wing, he is dressed in tracksuit bottoms, T-shirt and slippers. I ask him how old he is and he holds up one hand to show five fingers, while making a series of incomprehensible sounds.

"You're 60, aren't you, Boom Boom?!" bellows his room-mate, Frank. Frank explains that Boom Boom suffered a stroke before being admitted to prison: "He can't do much. When he arrived at the Scrubs all he could say was 'boom boom'. That's how he got his name." The large, high-ceilinged room is divided into four by a series of drab partitions. The floor is dirty and the cream walls are bare. A TV is flickering noiselessly in the corner and a few books are scattered on the floor. It looks just like the kind of care home you hope you'll never end up in.

McLean is quick to point out that Boom Boom and Frank are among the scruffiest inmates on the wing. "They were living rough before they came in," he says. "No one else will share with them."

Upstairs the rooms are tidier and less gloomy. The furniture would not look out of place in a student accommodation block. In one room the walls are decorated with pieces of wrapping paper. In another there is an inmate who spends his time making replica Faberge eggs.

A photo of Princess Diana has pride of place by Sam's bed. He is 50, 11 years into a life sentence for murder. He's one of the youngest prisoners on the wing, admitted because he suffered a stroke. He has barely seen the two grandchildren who were born since his conviction but he thinks his age has helped him to get through his sentence: "If I was 21 or 22 at the time I wouldn't have been able to make it."

The average age of prisoners on E wing is 65, but most look older than that. "People age quicker in prison," says Gill Ripiner, the senior nurse who runs the prison dispensary. "A 55-year-old inside would be more like a 65-year-old outside. The stress levels are high, they can't do things to relieve the stress and they can't do as much exercise."

Although they are more likely to suffer medical problems, specialising in older inmates has its advantages, says McLean: "The staff-to-prisoner ratio can be quite low because you're unlikely to have a serious problem [with violence]. The sort of problem I'm worried about is not an attack, it's that someone will light a cigarette and discard the match." Its not just a figure of speech. A senior officer later tells me that several cigarette burns were found on Harry's torso when he was transferred to hospital. "He'd obviously just rolled over and lain on them. Fortunately all the mattresses are flame resistant."

McLean says the prison has encountered two unforeseen problems. One has been the reluctance of many older prisoners to go anywhere near E wing. "It's perceived as dead men's shoes. People think the only way out is by dying." In fact, he says, more prisoners have been released to lower-security establishments than have died.

T he second problem is that many of the inmates are in a poorer condition than the unit had bargained for. "Unfortunately, fit elderly people do become progressively more frail and the problem we've got now is that we've got people who really we shouldn't be keeping any longer who need to move from residential care into a nursing home, and we are not a nursing home."

Albert, a neatly dressed 69-year-old who has served 18 years of a life sentence for murdering his wife, describes the condition of some of the E wing prisoners in more graphic terms. "Christ, we all get old, but you've got blokes pissing in the plant pots and blokes shitting themselves." He says he was grateful for a move back to the main part of the prison after he underwent a hip replacement operation. "I was in there with a chap who'd done 42 years and one night I wake up and he's pissing up against the wall. It could have been brilliant but you've got the wrong people in there. You have people who should be in a hospice."

McLean acknowledges that there are at least two prisoners on the wing who have "lost it" and "others who you talk to and you think: 'I'm not really getting through here.' " But as another senior officer points out, senility or even extreme frailty are no guarantee that someone will not reoffend.

Dick's case illustrates the dilemma facing the prison authorities. Dick is 57 and has served 16 years of a life sentence for rape. He is suffering from motor neurone disease and wears calipers. Doctors have called for his release, the senior officer tells me, "which is all very well, but where are you going to put him? He's got to go to a care home but the fact of the matter is that these places often have a lot of young women working in them. Physically he couldn't rape anybody, but he could ravish someone - and can you risk letting that happen?"

With few signs of a more liberal approach to releasing elderly prisoners any time soon, the prison service is at last aknowleging that it will have to hold and care for older and sicker prisoners. It is spending £3m on creating facilities for elderly inmates at several prisons. "This is something that has crept up on us quite recently," said Martin Nary, director-general of the prison service. Kingston has submitted a proposal to upgrade the facilities and staffing of E wing so that it can offer equivalent care to a nursing home. Already, says, Alisdair Munroe, there's not much difference between E wing and many care homes on the outside "except that it's all male and we don't let them out".

Frank, however, has little time for those who point out that life for him is not very different from what it would be like if he were in a home. "They say you must like prison. Nobody likes prison. It's a stupid question, it's daft. The same people asking it don't go to the door and open it."

 Names of prisoners have been changed.

webTitle: Libby Brooks on our female prison population

fields.headline: A woman's place?
fields.standfirst:
Our female prison population has more than doubled in the past six years, with twice as many women as men jailed for a first offence. Yet few are dangerous, and many are vulnerable, as Libby Brooks discovers
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Our female prison population has more than doubled in the past six years, with twice as many women as men jailed for a first offence. Yet few are dangerous, and many are vulnerable, as  Libby Brooks  discovers.
fields.body:
They call them "girls". "And in Holloway they called you lassies," groans Sam. "I turned round and said: 'I'm not an old dog.'" Kathrine giggles. "I got called Fanny the other day - my mum used to call me that when I was younger." "There's one officer on this wing, because my surname is Knight, keeps calling me Gladys," Sam bats back, rolling her eyes and pressing a hand to her forehead. "If we said that to him, we'd get on report."

There are things about a prison: the smell of sour milk and detergent, the ugly-making brightness of the lights, every moment punctuated by signings, lockings, unlockings. And there are particular things about a women's prison. Aggression is subdued to bitching and pettiness and cuts on people's arms. Social exclusion is not just about the colour of your skin or the emptiness of your purse, but about who is looking after your baby. And they call them "girls". "I feel like a little kid again. You have to jump when they say jump, you have to bite your tongue when you get angry," says Sam Knight, who is 20. She is handsome, funny and articulate, and serving a four-year sentence in Bulwood Hall, near Southend - one of Britain's 16 women's prisons - for importing cocaine. It was her first offence.

"It gets me angry being in here. They're wasting my time. I know I've done a crime and I wouldn't do it again. But I'm working my butt off in here, my daughter's out there, and I could be with her. I don't know why I did it. But someone's waving a wad of money in your face and you know someone who's done it before, no probs. No one got hurt. Four years for a first offence . . . " She trails off.

The female population is the fastest- growing section of the prison estate. It has more than doubled in six years, rising to 3,392 in 1999. It is an extraordinary increase, particularly when the facts about women and prison are considered.

We know that the majority of women offenders pose a low risk to the public. We know that imprisoning mothers has a disproportionately disruptive effect on family life. We know that because the number of women in prison is relatively small, inmates are held far from home and their access to suitable regimes is restricted. We know that women react more adversely to custody than men, not least because of the higher incidence of mental-health problems among female prisoners. We know that more than half the women in prison have experienced physical or sexual abuse. So why are we locking up more of the most vulnerable people in the country?

It is difficult to tease out the reasons. Despite the recent moral panic about girl gangs, the rise in violent offences is negligible. Most women in prison are not that dangerous - the most common crimes are theft or handling stolen goods, together with fraud and forgery, although the number of women sentenced for drug offences has risen dramatically. This increase is largely the result of the courts' new emphasis on deterrence, but another factor, according to Pat Carlen, professor of sociology at Bath University, is the number of women in poverty. "Women have totally different experiences of crime: they don't mix with criminals, don't think of themselves as criminals and their criminal careers are shorter and less violent. It's personal circumstances that get women into prison."

Carlen argues that women are doubly punished for offending against stereotypical ideas of how "nice" girls behave. Twice as many women as men are imprisoned for a first offence. Such as Knight. Her three-year-old daughter is living with her father. She is one of the third of mothers in prison with a child under the age of five. It is much easier if you have support from a family, she explains. "I've got my baby's father, my mum, my dad, my brothers and sisters. I've got a lot, but it's still hard because I keep feeling like I've got to rely on them. I'm asking for things from them, but they didn't put me here."

There could never be a television series called Blokes of a Feather, says Chris Tchaikovsky of the pressure group Women in Prison. "More than 80% of women stand by their men when they are inside, compared with just 17% of men. Many don't have families to help them either because they come from state care. So there's a huge qualitative difference on a day-to-day level, in terms of getting letters, pictures and money.

"But the greatest pain is separation from children, and the ongoing concerns about housing and resettlement that stem from that. For men, losing your home doesn't necessarily mean losing your kids."

Women also feel a loss of function in prison, says Carlen, as the rules and regulations cut across their domestic domain. They find it much harder to be regimented, particularly around household issues such as eating, while the lack of hygiene and privacy affects them much more.

"I haven't sat on a toilet seat for 19 months," laughs Knight. "I can't even use the toilet paper in there, I have to bring my own from my room. It's the little things you miss, like eating with a knife and fork - we have to eat with plastic."

The quality of the food concerns her. "The chicken is all watery, it's not cooked. The rice tastes tough and it's not washed properly. At lunchtime I try and eat a little of the chips and sausage, but apart from that I buy my tuna and crackers and do my thing in my room."

Some of your pride disappears in prison, she says. "Like with strip searches, even when you're on your period . You just feel like you've got no self-respect. Because it's other women doing it to you. To have to strip when they say strip, for them to come and search your room and pull up your bed."

"It's so degrading," adds Astrid Vildgaard. "When you get strip-searched, all that day and the day after is ruined because you go so low. They do it every month."

Vildgaard, 19, is also serving a sentence for drug importation. From Denmark, she is one of the foreign nationals who make up 15% of our female prison population. Nearly three-quarters of foreigners are convicted of drug offences and serving significantly longer sentences than their British counterparts. "When I got arrested, I couldn't speak the language," says Vildgaard. She is now fluent, especially in expletives.

There are two key questions, says Chris Wilkinson of the Scarman Centre at Leicester University. "Why do certain groups of women - foreign nationals, first-time offenders, women with mental health problems - find themselves in prison? We need to focus on the factors that lead them there and then look at the alternatives offered by the probation service. Second, what are their needs once in prison, and are those needs the same as men's? Women in prison are disadvantaged, damaged and dependent. Many self-harm. All too often prison serves to exacerbate the problems that have led women to offend in the first place."

The staff of Bulwood Hall certainly appear to be trying to meet those needs, with a healthcare centre, an education block, a gym and a wing where vulnerable prisoners - first-timers who are finding it difficult to cope, self-harmers, the elderly - have more intensive care. There is a hairdressing salon where women can study for a National Vocational Qualification and a fashion studio where they learn dressmaking and put on a fashion show each year. A variety of drug treatment and counselling programmes are available, as well as the enhanced thinking skills course, a national programme that deals with "cognitive deficits".

Wilkinson is sceptical about such courses. "They individualise and pathologise women, and allow for no recognition of the structural problems of society that force them to live in awful poverty and in abusive situations. It's all about managing your anger, and not about having £2 in your pocket to feed your kids."

Kathrine Samuel says it is boring at Bulwood Hall. She is not "enhanced" - she has not yet been granted privileges - so has no television in her room. Mostly, she sleeps.

Samuel is 16 and serving six months for street robbery. She and her friends ran off with a girl's bag, she tells me, and when the police came looking for them she got caught. It was her first offence. She will be out in March. Her baby is due in May.

She is a tiny thing, with a sparkling stud in her lip. She has the softest voice. I don't doubt that she has the capacity to be a right cow. But she wants to buy things for the baby and can't.

These women are socially excluded. Imprisonment will only isolate them further."

Women like Samuel, and children like her unborn child. "I had my own flat," she says. "But they took it off me. I don't know where I'll stay when I get out. I suppose I might go to a mother and baby unit."

"I got called Fanny the other day - my mum used to call me that when I was younger." "There's one officer on this wing, because my surname is Knight, keeps calling me Gladys," Sam bats back, rolling her eyes and pressing a hand to her forehead. "If we said that to him, we'd get on report." There are things about a prison: the smell of sour milk and detergent, the ugly-making brightness of the lights, every moment punctuated by signings, lockings, unlockings. And there are particular things about a women's prison. Aggression is subdued to bitching and pettiness and cuts on people's arms. Social exclusion is not just about the colour of your skin or the emptiness of your purse, but about who is looking after your baby. And they call them "girls". "I feel like a little kid again. You have to jump when they say jump, you have to bite your tongue when you get angry," says Sam Knight, who is 20. She is handsome, funny and articulate, and serving a four-year sentence in Bulwood Hall, near Southend - one of Britain's 16 women's prisons - for importing cocaine. It was her first offence. It is difficult to tease out the reasons. Despite the recent moral panic about girl gangs, the rise in violent offences is negligible. "But the greatest pain is separation from children, and the ongoing concerns about housing and resettlement that stem from that. For men, losing your home doesn't necessarily mean losing your kids." fields.headline: Web design firm adds Mediumrare to Lateral Network
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Internet design firm Lateral has signed up broadband specialist Mediumrare to its network, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Independent web design firm Lateral has expanded its Lateral Network with the addition of broadband specialist Mediumrare.

Jon Bains, chairman of Lateral, said it was time to expand the network concept, despite the turmoil in the industry.

"We've been talking with Mediumrare about this for years, and with the birth of Lshift back in October as our proof of concept of the network model, now seemed like the right time," he said.

Lshift, a technology-focused agency, was the first company to be added to the network. The addition of Mediumrare means that Lateral can now offer clients broadband expertise.

Mediumrare is taking on staff to handle a new contract for "two digital broadband channels for a major telecoms company".

Its client base already includes BBC online, artsworld.com, easyart.com, Avalon, Kudos (for Channel 4) and the Commonwealth Secretariat.

Lateral will eventually become a significant shareholder in Mediumrare, which was set up by Christian Nouyou, a former graphic designer at Fitch, in 1997.

fields.headline: Thus cuts losses
fields.trailText: 12pm: Telecoms and internet group Thus has cut its losses with help from sales at Demon Internet, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Thus, the beleaguered telecoms and internet group, has narrowed its losses on the back of an improved performance from its Demon Internet service.

The company said its transition to a business-focused telecoms company was nearly complete, which will be a relief to a market that has had prolonged doubts about the group's future plans.

Thus said turnover between September and December last year was £59.9m, up 11% from the same period last year, with sales at its Demon internet service provider rising 6% to £20.3m.

The company added that its losses for the period had narrowed to £4.7m from £8.6m in the previous three months.

"Our transition to a national, business-focused telecommunications company is now largely complete," said Thus chief executive William Allan.

Thus confirmed it is selling its consumer interactive operation, following the lead of rivals such as Redstone Telecom and Atlantic Telecom, who have announced cutbacks in order to move into profit sooner.

The company is also pulling out of installing broadband equipment in BT's phone exchanges, after having doubts over the financial benefits of so-called local loop unbundling.

Mr Allan said the continuing focus on small businesses and the disposal of the interactive division will contribute to an even better second half of the year.

"The acceleration in sales growth achieved in the third quarter gave further confidence that the company will deliver enhanced revenues throughout the second half of the current financial year," added Mr Allan.

Shares in Thus rose 17% to 72.5p, although the results fell slightly below analysts' estimates.

Thus was the worst-performing telecoms stock last year and share have fallen 93% from its highest point last year.

Many analysts see the stock as a potential takeover target for a predator seeking to enter an underperforming sector at an attractive price.

webTitle: Hollywood film strike could boost UK

fields.headline: Hollywood film strike could boost UK
fields.standfirst: British productions may plug gap left by US studios rushing to finish movies before industrial action starts
fields.trailText: British productions may plug gap left by US studios rushing to finish movies before industrial action starts.
fields.body:
When Marx and Engels urged the workers of the world to unite, they were not to know that one day film stars - the most pampered people on the planet - would take them at their word.

That is just what is happening as Hollywood and the still larger US television industry braces itself for the double whammy of an actors' strike and a writers' stoppage which threatens to bring the industry to its knees.

Before this summer is out Los Angeles could witness the incongruous sight of Charlton Heston joining Jim Carrey - who earns in excess of $20m a film and last year demanded a chef for his pet lizard - on the barricades to protest about pay.

The prospect of strikes paralysing the studios may be worrying for the Californian economy, but it could yet be a boon for Britain, which has already had a record £750m year on the back of big-budget US films such as The Mummy Returns, Tomb Raider and Pearl Harbour being shot in the UK.

With the dollar so strong and Hollywood winding down as the strikes loom, relocating films to London - with its large and relatively low-paid pool of both acting and writing talent - has never looked so good.

Not that either the Film Council or the British Film Commission, which is responsible for tempting big "runaway" productions here, is crowing over the prospect of an exodus from Hollywood for fear of a backlash from the powerful Screen Actors Guild.

Both are officially keeping a dignified silence and stressing that they would never risk their "excellent special relationship" to cash in on a little short-term local difficulty. "No one likes to be seen as a scab or a blackleg," one source said, "stealing other people's jobs."

But a source at the Film Council said the strikes, and the gaps opening up in American film production because of the fear of action, could give new British films a boost on US multiplex circuit which has proved so hard to crack.

"There are plenty of good British films waiting to be seen in the States, and you never know, this may be the break we have been waiting for," he said.

One British producer, who has made several successful Hollywood films, was more blunt.

"Let's face it, with the studios rushing to get films finished before the summer strike deadlines, there's likely to be some terrible shit around in cinemas come the fall. It's a perfect opportunity for a couple of decent British films to make a breakthrough."

While American actors have already flexed their muscles with a successful boycott of advertisements to increase repeat fees - during which the British actress Elizabeth Hurley was fined for breaking the ban to shoot an Estee Lauder commercial - it is the writers' dispute which had the potential to wreak most havoc.

Soaps and quiz shows, the staples of US TV, will grind to a halt within weeks if, as seems likely, the Writers Guild of America calls a strike in May. Series such as ER, Friends, Frasier and even cartoon shows such as The Simpsons may soon follow.

Britain seems to be the obvious place to look for off-the-peg shows to plug the gap. Anne Robinson, of Weakest Link fame, has already been approached by NBC about bringing her highly marketable line in British nastiness to US screens.

If writers go out in pursuit of a long list of grievances including a demand to double the "ridiculous" four cents they receive for each sale of a video of DVD they have written, a follow-on actors' strike is seen as almost unavoidable.

Although the biggest stars may be commanding more than ever, a spokesman for the Screen Actors Guild claimed most of their members were having their fees squeezed and many "can't provide for their families" from acting alone.

Writers have been slipping down the Hollywood food chain for years, with studios attempting to hold down the wages, in part to pay stars whose wage demands are close to $30m a film.

However, their dispute is as much to do with what they call "self-respect" as cash. The WGA claims their members are often treated as dispensable "sausage machine hacks" who are often shut off the set at an uppity director's whim. They are equally irked by directors' annoying habit of claiming all the credit for themselves through the legend: "A film by _"

Much of the strike's effectiveness, however, will depend on the attitude taken by British actors' union.

Equity, which supported the SAG advert ban, said last night that it had not been formally approached about wider action over the summer. "Obviously, there has been quite a lot of informal contact," a spokesman said. "I think it is also worth noting that the advert ban was not broken in Britain."

A British Writers' Guild spokeswoman said they would support whatever action the Writers Guild of America took in pursuit of their claims. "We are urging writers not to take on work from American production companies if striking US writers refuse to do it."

webTitle: In brief: Rowan Atkinson turns bad for Scooby-Doo

fields.headline: Rowan Atkinson turns bad for Scooby-Doo
fields.standfirst: Plus: Mark Addy to board The Time Machine; Aaliyah snaps up choice role in Matrix sequels; Geri Halliwell's film-starring debut delayed
fields.trailText: Plus: Mark Addy to board The Time Machine; Aaliyah snaps up choice role in Matrix sequels; Geri Halliwell's film-starring debut delayed
fields.body:
 Rowan Atkinson is reportedly in negotiations to play the role of the villain Mondavarious in the forthcoming Scooby-Doo film, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The much-anticipated film (see earlier story) will star Sarah Michelle Geller as Daphne, alongside real-life boyfriend Freddie Prinze Jr who will play Fred. The production starts filming in Australia on February 13.

 Full Monty star Mark Addy has signed up to star opposite Guy Pearce in The Time Machine, based on the classic novel by HG Wells about an inventor who creates a machine that allows him to travel 800,000 years into the future. According to the Hollywood Reporter, Wells's great-grandson, Simon Wells, will direct the project from a script by Gladiator scribe John Logan. Filming begins on February 4.

 R&B singer, Aaliyah, who made her acting debut in last year's Romeo Must Die, has been added to the cast of the sequels to The Matrix, reports Variety. Aaliyah will play a character named Zee who is likely to become more prominent in The Matrix 3 which is due to be shot immediately after the second instalment. Original cast members Keanu Reeves, Carrie-Anne Moss, Laurence Fishburne and Hugo Weaving are back on board for the sequels, and Jada Pinkett Smith has been added to the cast as Niobi, the love interest for Fishburne's character.

 The solo film debut of former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell has been delayed for more than a year due to an unworkable script. Halliwell is due to earn $1.6m (£1.09m) for the lead role in Therapy, a drama about a girl who has an affair with her shrink. Filming, which was due to start in September last year, now looks unlikely to go ahead until at least 2002. A spokesman for the singer told reporters: '"The script is currently undergoing its sixth or seventh rewrite. There are usually up to 15 rewrites and movies can take up to four years from start to finish. Filming might not even start this year. We can't say for sure when filming will start as the process of script development and pre-production takes so long."

We can't say for sure when filming will start as the process of script development and pre-production takes so long."

fields.headline: Glossy mags refuse charity ads
fields.trailText: 8.30am An ad campaign for a charity has been rejected by two glossy mags because the content is "too strong", writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
An advertising campaign for the charity Medecins sans Frontieres has been rejected by two glossy magazines because the content is "too strong".

Trendy style magazine Wallpaper and high society glossy Harpers & Queen have both refused to take the magazine inserts, which carry harrowing images of the charity's work in emergency medical aid.

The stark black and white images include a photograph of a hand with two fingers missing and a young man with a severed arm alongside an explanation of the charity's work.

"Wallpaper rejected the ad without giving an explanation and Harpers & Queen said the creative work was too strong," said Medecins sans Frontieres campaigns officer Nerissa Bryden.

A Wallpaper spokeswoman said the campaign was "too explicit" for the magazine's readers. "This doesn't represent a stance on charity ads, it's just that in this specific case it was not right," she added.

A million of the hard-hitting inserts will appear in travel magazines, style magazines and national newspapers urging people to commit to a regular monthly donation to the charity.

They form part of a major marketing drive by MSF, which is also putting together its first-ever television commercial.

"The proliferation of new channels makes television advertising more appropriate for us because it means we can reach our target audience," said Ms Bryden.

webTitle: Shallow grave may solve mystery of atheist's disappearance

fields.headline: Shallow grave may solve mystery of atheist's disappearance
fields.standfirst: The mystery of the disappearance of controversial atheist Madalyn Murray O'Hair may have been solved with the discovery of some charred bones
fields.trailText: The mystery of the disappearance of controversial atheist Madalyn Murray O'Hair may have been solved with the discovery of some charred bones, writes Julian Borger.
fields.body:
A baffling five-year-old mystery appears to have been resolved this week with the discovery at an isolated Texas ranch of a shallow grave full of charred bones.

The police believe that the remains answer the nagging question of what happened to one of America's most celebrated atheists, Madalyn Murray O'Hair, who disappeared in 1995 along with her son and her adopted granddaughter.

O'Hair had been almost single-handedly responsible for forcing a supreme court decision in 1963 which banned prayer in school, and there were many Christians, unreconciled to the separation of church and state, who never forgave her.

She liked to call herself the most hated woman in America.

So when she and her family went missing, there were some who said that she had been done away with by vengeful fundamentalists, and others who speculated that she had run away with $500,000 in gold coins taken from her organisation, the United Secularists of America.

It now appears that she was forced to order the transfer of the bullion in the belief that it would save the lives of her family. Her former office manager, David Waters, is currently facing kidnapping and extortion charges in connection to O'Hair's abduction, and, as part of a plea-deal, he led them to the dusty grave on a private ranch in south Texas.

According to investigators, the two-foot grave contained the three headless skeletons, all of which had had their legs severed. Three skulls and a metal artificial hip were found nearby.

O'Hair, who was 77 when she disappeared, had had hip-replacement surgery a few years earlier. Investigators are now trying to trace the serial number on the artificial hip and check dental remains, but there is little doubt about the identity of the remains.

Waters had been convicted in 1993 for embezzling money from O'Hair's group while working as the office manager. After that - according to his ex-girlfriend, Patti Jo Steffens - Waters became obsessed with revenge on O'Hair.

A man he met in jail, Gary Karr, was convicted last August of taking part in the extortion scheme. The body of a third member of the gang, Danny Fry, was found - minus hands and head - in a Dallas river in 1995, a month after the kidnapping.

The most surprising thing about the whole case was how long it took to solve - a fact which seems linked to her generally unpopular and bullying personality and to her atheism.

Her own son, William Murray, did not report her missing for a year, even though she had disappeared with his daughter, Robin and his brother, Jon.

Even after it became clear how horrifically his relatives had died, William Murray, now an evangelical preacher and lobbyist, did not seem ready to forgive O'Hair for her lack of religious beliefs.

"I think it's a shame that my mother took anyone with her, that she led other people into circumstances that cost them their lives," he said. "My brother and daughter spent their entire years in a dysfunctional home and died horrible deaths, and that's part of my mother's legacy."

fields.headline: Hollick intervenes in Express website debacle
fields.standfirst:
Hollick's letter to union
Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Lord Hollick has expressed concern over Richard Desmond's treatment of staff, reports Amy Vickers.
Click here to read the letter
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Lord Hollick has made an extraordinary intervention in the Express website debacle that has cost 46 staff their jobs.

Two months after he offloaded Express Newspapers and its websites, the Labour peer has written to the NUJ.

In the letter, he expressed his "concern" and "surprise" at the way the new owner Richard Desmond has treated staff.

Lord Hollick revealed he has been pressing Mr Desmond since early December to honour commitments to staff left without jobs after the sites were sold to an accountancy friend for £1.

The letter comes six weeks after Express Digital Media was put into administration by Seymour Pierce, the investment company that bought the online business.

Lord Hollick said when he sold the sites to Mr Desmond he insisted on "an undertaking from the purchaser that all employee rights would be protected".

"We have contacted Northern & Shell on a number of occasions since the beginning of December to make sure that this undertaking was being honoured.

"The situation with the website employees is particularly concerning," he wrote.

"United was surprised to see the sites transferred to a third party, who apparently tried to sell them and then closed them in short order.

"We made it clear to Northern & Shell we believe there is an obligation for Express Newspapers to pay redundancy," he continued.

It is the first sign of Lord Hollick showing compassion for the fate of 46 of his former employees since he offloaded them onto Mr Desmond.

However, his late intervention has failed to impress former staff, who were left on the streets shortly before Christmas with neither pay nor redundancy money.

Staff from EDM have even said they have found Mr Desmond and administrator Seymour Pierce to be "more human and sympathetic over this whole affair" than Lord Hollick.

When MediaGuardian.co.uk called former Express.co.uk editor Michael Streeter for a reaction on the letter, he said he was more angered by Lord Hollick's "crocodile tears" than his silence.

"The letter seems like complete hypocrisy," he said.

"It sounds like he's trying to offload the blame onto others and avoid taking on any responsibility himself."

Former EDM staff are working with their unions and lawyers on a settlement to claim the unpaid salaries and redundancy money.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours stock up on the morning-after pill
fields.trailText: Arsenal are "poised" to sign German international defender Marko Rehmer, according to the Daily Star. The paper claims the 28-year-old Hertha Berlin player held talks with Arsene Wenger yesterday before flying back to Germany. Rehmer, who played against England at Wembley last year, has a clause in his contract that will allow him to move for £5m.
fields.body:
Arsenal are "poised" to sign German international defender Marko Rehmer, according to the Daily Star. The paper claims the 28-year-old Hertha Berlin player held talks with Arsene Wenger yesterday before flying back to Germany. Rehmer, who played against England at Wembley last year, has a clause in his contract that will allow him to move for £5m.

Peter Reid has offered Anderlecht £9m for Jan Koller, according to the Daily Express. The Sunderland manager wants the 6ft 7ins Czech, apparently the tallest striker in Europe, as a long-term replacement for Niall Quinn.

The Mirror believes that Fulham will sign Benito Carbone on loan until the end of the season, "to give Fulham the final push into the Premiership".

Aston Villa are set for a clearout, according to the Daily Mail, which could see Dion Dublin, Gareth Southgate, David Ginola and Julian Joachim leaving the club. John Gregory needs to raise funds if he is to engineer the signings of striker Javi Moreno and midfielder Mauricio Serna. West Ham are still believed to be interested in Southgate, while Spurs could be in for Dion Dublin.

Teamtalk reports that Villa could also face competition in their attempts to sign Moreno. The website claims that both Derby and West Ham are interested in the £6m-rated Alaves star.

AC Milan could snatch West Ham's on-loan defender Hannu Tihinen away from Upton Park. Planet Football believes the Serie A giants will make a move for the impressive Finn before their transfer window closes at the end of the day.

Trevor Francis will be out of a job at Birmingham if he doesn't get his side to the play-offs. "The manager has known right since the start of the season that we must reach the play-offs or get promotion if he is to be manager of Birmingham City next season", chairman David Sullivan told the Daily Mail.

webTitle: Giles Smith on the  new Passat

fields.headline: Adults only
fields.standfirst: The new Passat has grown up in every way, and certainly won't be doing anything as frivolous as going off-road. But it will keep your travel sweets air-conditioned
fields.trailText: The new Passat has grown up in every way, and certainly won't be doing anything as frivolous as going off-road. But it will keep your travel sweets air-conditioned.
fields.body:
The VW Passat is a road car which, in a rare twist these days, has no ambitions whatsoever to be an off-road car. Flying in the face of the contemporary fondness for vehicles that look like they could be driven across fields and through bogs - even if they couldn't and won't be - VW presents the Passat as a saloon for smooth stretches of tarmac.

"You'll want to keep it that way," goes the slogan on the advertisements for the car, in which Passat owners are witnessed preferring to lock the car and walk through safari parks or set out on foot across the highlands, rather than risk the possibility of damage to their vehicle by animals or loose chippings.

Even in its new form, the Passat comes with no big lumps of plastic to protect the paintwork from bullrushes and no additional heated towel-rails bolted to the front to see off bullying kangaroos and incautious schoolchildren. You can buy a four-wheel-drive version, but VW isn't making much of a fuss about that. This is one for the road, and only the road.

It still has the big sweeping roof and loopy wheel arches of the VW Beetle, which were borrowed as part of VW's plan to make a car which looked slightly happier than normal to be a saloon - this being a sector more usually associated with dignity and dullness.

Still, the new Passat attempts to raise a quiet smile. The front end has been radically altered - a creased bonnet sloping down to a chunky new grille and a VW badge the size of a football. The dashboard lights up in a shade of lilac unseen since the decline of the kaftan. Yet, despite these "fun" touches, the car still feels rather imposingly serious and adult. You can imagine very little take-up for it among, say, rich students - or anyone, really, under the age of about 45. In a golf club car park, it might look a slightly racy choice. Elsewhere, it's going to look safe as houses.

Things have changed in the redesign, mostly for the better. For instance, according to VW, the new Passat is "10% more torsionally rigid". It's something that happens to all of us as we grow older, though that doesn't automatically mean that we become, like the Passat, "a stiffer, safer, quieter vehicle which is more refined on the road".

The new model is taller than the outgoing one: a full three millimetres taller. I defy anyone without a doctorate in aerodynamics and their own personal wind tunnel to appreciate the consequences of this - though I guess it does allow exceptionally tall drivers up to a week's additional growth of hair before they come to feel uncomfortable in the vehicle.

The car is, however, 28mm longer, and this is an apprecia ble difference, as anyone trying to back the new model into a confined parking space will rapidly realise. In only a week of testing in densely populated urban conditions, I hit the following stationary vehicles with the rear end of my Passat: a Volvo estate, a fairly old-looking Peugeot 205 and one of those nice, sporty BMW Z3s. Apologies to all concerned. But at the same time, there was no damage done - or certainly not to the Passat, which is the important thing. Robust, then, as well as long, stiff, safe and quiet.

I drove a diesel version, which was almost certainly a big mistake. The image of diesel engines has undergone something of a makeover. At Rover and elsewhere, important work is under way on the construction of a diesel engine that doesn't sound like a Post Office van and drive like a handcart. BMW has fitted its 330 saloon with a diesel engine quiet enough and quick enough to satisfy Jenson Button, who was caught doing 147mph in it. If car manufacturing was fashion, people would be trying to say that diesel was the new petrol. Even Jeremy Clarkson has recently written approvingly of a diesel engine, which is something like the Archbishop of Canterbury converting to Catholicism.

In the Passat TDi, alas, the revolution has yet to take place. Ticking over, the engine still rattles like a crate of empty milk bottles. True, it will pin your neck to the headrest with one hearty push of the accelerator in second gear, but the noise will have you imagining you're in a fighter plane. The petrol engines are, I presume, more in keeping with the car's finish.

And the Passat is - nobody could deny - well finished. Among a number of entertaining tweaks, the cup holders, between the driver's seat and the passenger's seat, are larger than they used to be - in response, one assumes, to retailers' ever more generous assessments of what constitutes a regular coffee. If this trend continues, cars will soon have to come with a tank for beverages, much as they now come with tanks for oil and petrol.

Best of all, though, is that you can now make the air conditioning function inside the glove compartment. Never again will you need to worry whether your tinned sweets and tissues are the same temperature as you are. The road is long; these are important considerations.

webTitle: Anger as Corus rejects takeover bid

fields.headline: Anger as Corus rejects takeover bid
fields.standfirst: More business news
fields.trailText: Steel giant Corus came under attack today after rejecting a bid by the industry's main union to take over a steel plant in an effort to save thousands of threatened jobs.
fields.body:
Steel giant Corus came under attack today after rejecting a bid by the industry's main union to take over a steel plant in an effort to save thousands of threatened jobs.

Workers, unions and politicians criticised the firm - formerly known as British Steel - for turning down the attempt to secure the future of the Llanwern factory near Newport, south Wales.

Corus told the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation that it did not want competition, fuelling fears that several thousand jobs will be axed in the next few days at Llanwern and at other sites across the UK.

Rhodri Morgan, first minister of the Welsh national assembly, backed the ISTC offer, which would "guarantee the realignment of the blast furnace whose iron the plant depends on".

"There will be intense frustration at the plant that Corus does not even want to give serious consideration to this offer, which would keep Llanwern an integrated plant.

"At Llanwern they naturally fear that if they become simply a finishing plant without control over their own hot metal supply the finishing plant on its own will not last longer.

"It is not good enough for Corus simply to say they don't want another competitor in the steel production home market. Corus has to explain its strategy."

Around 20 Welsh Labour MPs met company officials last night, but they said Corus would not tell them what its decision on jobs would be, or when it would be announced.

Don Touhig, MP for Islwyn, was furious at Corus. "It's absolutely outrageous," he said. "I told Sir Brian Moffat [Corus chairman] he might still have a job but tens of thousands of our constituents might not. The workers have got to be the first to know, their lives have been put on hold.

"Ministers from the prime minister down have been engaging with Corus to find out what their proposals are - but they won't tell us."

Workers at Llanwern were sceptical about the ISTC's bid and most of those arriving for the start of their shift were resigned to the closure of a large part of the plant, and huge job losses.

Eddie Timmins was glad the union tried to save the plant. But he added: "Everyone is right to try, but Corus is determined to close it.

Darren White said: "Everyone is worried at the moment - no one knows what's happening and there are thousands of people working here with big mortgages to pay."

The ISTC has been working behind the scenes for weeks putting together an investment consortium in an effort to continue making steel at Llanwern.

The union formally wrote to Corus last Tuesday telling the company it wanted to mount a bid and asking for discussions to be opened.

It has been in close contact with government ministers and Welsh assembly leaders, who have also been pressing Corus not to axe thousands of jobs.

But Corus wrote to the union rejecting its bid. "We are deeply disappointed and urge the company to reconsider," said the union's general secretary, Michael Leahy. "We and our advisers believe that there is a market for the three million tonnes of Llanwern steel which can be sold on the world market.

The workers have got to be the first to know, their lives have been put on hold. "Ministers from the prime minister down have been engaging with Corus to find out what their proposals are - but they won't tell us." Workers at Llanwern were sceptical about the ISTC's bid and most of those arriving for the start of their shift were resigned to the closure of a large part of the plant, and huge job losses. Eddie Timmins was glad the union tried to save the plant. But he added: "Everyone is right to try, but Corus is determined to close it. Darren White said: "Everyone is worried at the moment - no one knows what's happening and there are thousands of people working here with big mortgages to pay." The ISTC has been working behind the scenes for weeks putting together an investment consortium in an effort to continue making steel at Llanwern. The union formally wrote to Corus last Tuesday telling the company it wanted to mount a bid and asking for discussions to be opened. It has been in close contact with government ministers and Welsh assembly leaders, who have also been pressing Corus not to axe thousands of jobs. But Corus wrote to the union rejecting its bid. "We are deeply disappointed and urge the company to reconsider," said the union's general secretary, Michael Leahy. "We and our advisers believe that there is a market for the three million tonnes of Llanwern steel which can be sold on the world market.
