fields.headline: Indonesian president on the ropes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia
fields.trailText: Indonesian police fired tear-gas and warning shots at thousands of protesters trying to storm parliament yesterday to vent their rage at President Abdurrahman Wahid's failure to solve the country's many crises.
fields.body:
Indonesian police fired tear-gas and warning shots at thousands of protesters trying to storm parliament yesterday to vent their rage at President Abdurrahman Wahid's failure to solve the country's many crises.

Many of the estimated 7,000 protesters demanded his immediate resignation.

"He's guilty of corruption and our country is in chaos. He's got to go now," said Firman Kusnaidi, a student at Jakarta's foreign languages academy. "We'll do whatever it takes to get him out."

MPs were debating the findings of a parliamentary investigation which is believed to implicate Mr Wahid in two financial scandals. They will decide on Friday whether to impeach him, after discussing the findings in party caucuses.

The investigation is believed to conclude that Mr Wahid was involved in the theft of £2.75m from the state logistics agency and the disappearance of a £1.2m gift from the Sultan of Brunei for social projects in the strife-torn Aceh province.

The debate was delayed by Mr Wahid's party's attempt to declare the investigation illegal.

If MPs vote to impeach him he will be given three months to rectify his errors. If he does not, he is entitled to a second warning period of 30 days.

Only then, if they consider he has still failed to address the accusations, can they call a special session of the supreme people's consultative assembly to remove him from office.

The demonstration was the biggest in Jakarta since the Muslim cleric became the first democratically-elected president, in October 1999.

It turned violent when some protesters tried to tear down the front gates of parliament. The police allowed them a little way into the grounds, but kept them well away from several hundred supporters of the president, who had been allowed in earlier.

The two groups eventually dispersed peacefully.

Increasing numbers of MPs are turning against Mr Wahid, who shows no sign of caving in to the chorus of disapproval, or changing his stubborn, often erratic style of government.

Yesterday he insisted that there was no reason for him to resign, because he had done nothing wrong.

The public anger with him is driven by more than just the graft scandals, however.

People have become disillusioned by the government's failure to institute political and economic reform, two provinces are embroiled in separatist struggles, and two more are engulfed in a sectarian conflict between Muslims and Christians.

"There are so many things wrong with this country I felt I had to demonstrate, because politicians only seem to listen when the streets are full of people," said Muchtar Sofitan, a businessman.

"Hopefully, both the government and the parliament will now wake up and realise what they should be doing."

Analysts disagree about Mr Wahid's chances of survival. Most think he will ride out the financial scandal crisis, but believe that bigger street protests could prompt his main ally, Vice-President Megawati Sukarnoputri,to desert him.

"He's definitely facing a serious threat but it's not fatal yet," the political commentator Soedjati Djiwandono said.

"If he improves his performance quickly then he should be OK. If not, anything could happen."

webTitle: Spielberg receives KBE for services to British film

fields.headline: Spielberg receives KBE for services to British film
fields.trailText: The Oscar-winning director said that the honour was a childhood dream come true after a ceremony at the British embassy in Washington
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg yesterday received one of the highest honours that can be bestowed by the Queen to those born outside the UK, when he received a KBE for services to British film.

At a ceremony at the British embassy in Washington, the British ambassador, Sir Christopher Meyer, said: "Mr Spielberg's career has had a global impact but the impact in the United Kingdom stands out. His films helped significantly in the doubling of cinema admission in the UK since the early 1980s." He also praised Spielberg for using British actors, technicians and other artists in his films, as well as bringing significant US investment to Britain by producing and directing Saving Private Ryan here.

At a private dinner for family and friends, Spielberg smiled throughout the ceremony, claiming: "The truth is, I stand before you now and I'm a knight,'' he said. "This is the stuff that all of our childhood fantasies come from. You know, courtliness, civility and honour.''

An honorary knight of the British empire, the director of Jaws, Jurassic Park, ET, Raiders of the Lost Ark and Schindler's List cannot be addressed as Sir, but should take some comfort from the fact that he joins an elite list of American honorary knights which includes Andre Previn and Bob Hope.

webTitle: Wanchope on way out of Man City

fields.headline: Wanchope on way out of City after Royle row
fields.trailText: The trials and tribulations of Manchester City continued last night when their manager Joe Royle put Paulo Wanchope on the transfer list and accused him of believing he was "bigger than the club".
fields.body:
The trials and tribulations of Manchester City continued last night when their manager Joe Royle put Paulo Wanchope on the transfer list and accused him of believing he was "bigger than the club".

Royle was furious with the striker's reaction on being substituted in Saturday's FA Cup win over Coventry and summoned him to a specially convened meeting yesterday in which it was made clear the £3.6m recruit from West Ham last summer no longer had a part to play at Maine Road.

"A team in our position needs everyone pulling in the same direction and I think this is in the best interests of both parties," said Royle.

"Let's just say this isn't the first, second or even third time it has happened and you can tolerate only so much. There have been several incidents and no one can get away with thinking they are bigger than the club.

"I'm disappointed it hasn't worked out because there are times when you can get on very well with Paulo but it's an accumulation of things and you cannot put up with this sort of behaviour. The situation now is that we will be circulating his name as being available for a transfer."

Royle is trying to lure the forward Rod Wallace away from Rangers in a possible loan deal, although Wanchope has indicated that he feels he deserves another chance.

"Paulo does not want to leave and he is extremely disappointed with the manager's decision," his agent Dennis Roach said. "He wants to stay at Manchester City and if he is given the chance he wants to turn things around."

It is Royle's second fall-out with a high-profile striker this season, the former world player of the year George Weah having left City at the start of October after several disagreements with the manager.

Stan Collymore should complete his move to the Spanish club Real Oviedo today with Bradford City's chairman Geoffrey Robinson revealing that he has abandoned the club's £500,000 valuation of the striker who is now moving on a free transfer.

The unwanted Collymore, who recently rejected a move to Germany with VfB Stuttgart, is now expected to finalise personal terms in time to beat tomorrow's Spanish transfer deadline.

Oviedo's spokesman Miguel Solis said yesterday: "We are offering Stan this year and next season. A good player makes the other players play well - and we hope he gives us a lot of goals."

Collymore, who started the season with Leicester, is now expected to make his debut for his third club this campaign at at Las Palmas on Sunday.

The 30-year-old Collymore could on Sunday confront another striker fresh out of English football. Sheffield Wednesday's Gilles de Bilde had talks last night with Las Palmas about a £900,000 move after the Belgian's hopes of a loan to Newcastle collapsed.

Bradford have also been seeking to get another high earner, Benito Carbone, off the payroll. He is believed to prefer a return to Italy, whose deadline also falls tomorrow. The best option, Bradford believe, would be a loan to a Serie A club with a permanent deal in summer.

Bradford's midfielder Gareth Whalley is set to move down a division, joining Wednesday or Huddersfield.

 Hull's midfielder Theodore Whitmore has been injured in a car accident in which one of his Jamaican international team-mates, Steve Malcolm, aged 30, was killed. Whitmore is "stable" in hospital after the accident which happened when some players were travelling to Montego Bay following Jamaica's 0-0 draw with Bulgaria. Police said a rear tyre blew out and the driver, Malcolm, lost control of the vehicle, which hit an embankment and overturned.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Marr 'guilty as charged' over Mandelson resignation
fields.trailText: 10.45am: BBC political editor Andrew Marr has defended his failure to predict Peter Mandelson's resignation, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC's political editor, Andrew Marr, has defended his failure to predict the resignation of Peter Mandelson on the grounds that it is "better to be brave than boring".

Writing in today's Notebook in the Daily Telegraph - the paper that most recently accused him of pro-Labour bias - he admits he is "guilty as charged".

But he adds: "Which other broadcast journalists or newspapers predicted that night or first thing that morning that Mandelson would go?"

And he recalls that Mr Mandelson "may have been bad for politics but he was very good for journalism".

On Friday the Daily Telegraph rounded on Mr Marr as part of an attack on the BBC's "pro Labour bias".

The paper said "The close links between the BBC and Labour have aroused concern for some time. That concern has been fully justified this week."

Mr Marr has been singled out in the past by the Daily Telegraph and the Daily Mail for bringing an alleged pro-Labour bias into his reporting.

During last year's fuel crisis, Mr Marr was lambasted by the Daily Mail, who claimed that he had understated the degree of the crisis for Tony Blair.

webTitle: 'I remain the single most important political force in the country'

fields.headline: 'I remain the single most important political force in the country'
fields.standfirst:
Former Pakistani prime minister Mohtarama Benazir Bhutto, the first woman to lead a Muslim state, was ousted from office in 1996 amid charges of widespread corruption. She was interviewed by the Guardian's south Asia correspondent, Luke Harding. This is the full transcript.

Bhutto set to take on the regime
fields.trailText: Former Pakistani prime minister Mohtarama Benazir Bhutto, the first woman to lead a Muslim state, was ousted from office in 1996 amid charges of widespread corruption. She was interviewed by the Guardian's south Asia correspondent, Luke Harding. Here is the full transcript.
fields.body:
The Guardian: There has been much speculation about your imminent return to Pakistan. In a recent interview you said you had your "bags packed" ready for departure. When do you think this might happen?

Bhutto: I'd like to return sooner than later. Pakistan is my country. My ancestors lived there before Pakistan came into being. I am the twice-elected prime minister removed twice by the intelligence apparatus, which refused to bow before the people's will. I want my fundamental rights respected. They have been systematically and brutally trampled since 1977. My family has spent a cumulative 21 years in prison since then and 30 years in exile. My family's saga reflects the history of Pakistan where forces of dictatorship have battled the forces of democracy. Popular and democratic leaders are targeted with an attempt to eliminate them through perversion of justice and a smear campaign. This must stop if Pakistan is to join the civilised nations of the world by practising values enshrined in the United Nations and its human rights declarations.

The Guardian: And what assurances would you need from General Musharraf given the outstanding corruption case against you?

Bhutto: It's a miscommunication to say there is a corruption case against me. There are trumped up non-cases in a conspiracy to pervert justice. There are five attempts to pervert justice in my case and they are based on the same set of unproven papers. Given that the papers are unproven and the regime is without a single witness to prove them, a close look shows that I am the victim rather than the villain of the piece. The same set of unproven papers against me have been made into three cases against my husband and one against my mother.

As far as Musharraf is concerned, he is an officer who has sworn to uphold the law. I expect him to do so by stopping my political victimisation and that of others. My party [the Pakistan People's Party] has called for the repeal of the NAB [National Accountability Bureau] law which violates due process, the withdrawal of politically motivated cases, the release of political prisoners and for the abandonment of the politics of select pardons. The NAB law of equity demands that the regime apply the same treatment to all those behind bars which they applied to Mr Nawaz Sharif.

There is little prospect of the Musharraf regime showing such inclination in the near future. Although the euphoria, which greeted their arrival, has evaporated and their plans of economic revival, credible accountability and new leadership are in shambles, they are still to absorb the reality. The reality is that the process of political persecution, clothed in anti-corruption, which began with my ouster in Pakistan, has damaged the country. Many are calling Pakistan a failed state. Since my ouster, democracy has been dismantled, the judiciary undermined, the economy bankrupted. The only gain has been to the clerics who openly brandish their weapons and call for the Talibanisation of Pakistani society.

The Guardian: What role do you see yourself playing once back in Pakistan?

Bhutto: I see myself playing a political role in supporting democratic revival and the strengthening of a liberal and enlightened Pakistan, which works for peace in the region and gives the federating units equal treatment. There are a large number of people in Pakistan who support me and who elected me. Irrespective of whether the regime jails me, disqualifies me or seeks to restrict me in any other way, I remain the single most important political force in the country. The Benazir-led PPP is federal in nature. It has core constituents who support its liberal policies and record in office, which saw a boom economy. I expect to play a political role in Pakistan irrespective of how the regime treats me.

The Guardian: And what prospects are there, if any, for a speedy return to democracy?

Bhutto: The prospects look better with the unity of the political forces and the public disillusionment with the regime. The regime is now trying to play a geo-strategic card to stay in power. Hence the picking up of the peace process [with India over Kashmir]. But a country internally divided and polarised is a greater threat to peace and stability than one united.

The Guardian: Your successor as prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, is now in exile in Saudi Arabia following a deal last month with Pakistan's military rulers. What do you make of his release and would you countenance a similar deal for your husband, Asif Ali Zardari, still in prison after four years on corruption charges?

Bhutto: Nawaz Sharif made his choice and there's little point in commenting on it now it's done. Nawaz had just begun his sentence. My husband is in a different boat. In Pakistan, you get bailed out on corruption charges in four months. Under statutory law, an under-trial prisoner is freed after two years in prison even if it's a murder trial. Senator Zardari is being held contrary to law due to political persecution. Ordinarily, he should be free. Four courts have given him medical bail and the regime has blocked it by obtaining a stay from the supreme court contrary to the law of consistency.

Senator Zardari's prison term is completed even before his appeal is heard. Since 1990, this is his eighth year in prison. That's the punishment a male spouse gets in an Islamic country where fundamentalists control key institutions. It's inhuman and barbaric. They've tried to take his life, his liberty, his property, reputation, right to family. Both of us have been told we'd be better off if we left each other. So they've even tried to take our marriage. By the grace of God, we have survived the test and remained loyal to each other, our family and our political commitment to our party and our people. I believe in fighting for truth and justice irrespective of the odds.

Nawaz had taken 6bn rupee loans from Pakistan state banks starting from the time when the rupee was fifteen to the dollar. He had mortgaged the property to the banks in lieu of the loans. As far as Senator Zardari is concerned, he has yet to take loans from public sector banks and therefore his properties have little to do with the state. Now if the state wishes to hold him hostage and demand a ransom, I would say they have yet to do that with Nawaz. I would also ask why they want a ransom from someone from a smaller province when they refused to take a ransom from someone from the majority province. It's wrong. The racial discrimination that has been indulged in is appalling. Senator Zardari should be freed on merit and so should the others who are being held as political pawns in a power struggle between the unelected security apparatus and the elected representatives.

The Guardian: Britain's home secretary Jack Straw last month announced that he was freezing your assets in the UK.

Bhutto: That's incorrect. The British high commissioner was quoted in the press as stating so.

The Guardian: The British government is also cooperating with the authorities in Islamabad, who are investigating money allegedly stolen by you during your time in power.

Bhutto: That's incorrect. It assumes that I have stolen money and that assumption is a slur. Moreover, Islamabad has still to make such a charge against me in any country. In England, they have sought assistance on a trumped up narcotics charge against my spouse and in Switzerland there is an investigation to see whether I influenced a contract to benefit my husband. Islamabad has been unable to provide Geneva with a single witness that I influenced the contract. Whereas I am prepared to produce witnesses who were threatened to commit perjury and pervert justice in a bid to get me in the Swiss case. I can produce them before the United Nations rapporteur on judges and the judiciary if Islamabad rakes up the courage to invite him in on the subject. Or Mary Robinson of the United Nations high commission for human rights.

The Guardian: What do you think of Mr Straw's move?

Bhutto: I wish he would review it keeping in mind Pakistan's circumstances and the pressure the judiciary is under. He is involved in a process to assist Islamabad on a request related to a trumped up narcotics charge. I believe Mr Straw should reject a request by a military dictator, a request based on torture, a patently fabricated case that carries with it the death penalty. For Mr Straw it's just a request. For my family, it's the threat of death in a country where a handful of judges previously sentenced an innocent prime minister who happened to be my father. Irrespective of the lack of evidence, a Pakistani court can get legitimacy to use British assistance to obfuscate the case and give the death sentence. Particularly when the judge happens to be the relative of the man who hanged my father. Even if Musharraf says he won't carry out a death sentence, he could change his mind tomorrow or put in on the courts. The two defendants, Arif Balauch and Shorang Khan, on whose disputed statements this charge was made, were tortured to pervert justice. Their torture marks have been recorded by the high court in Pakistan. The former interior minister is on record stating that the case was concocted.

The Guardian: There is confusion as to the extent of your assets in the UK. Could you clarify what properties you do own, and whether they include Rockwood House, a nine-bedroom mansion in Surrey allegedly bought by Mr Zardari?

Bhutto: Whatever I do own, I own legitimately through inherited, invested and earned money. My husband and I both hail from privileged families. Nothing we own is tied to any illegal activity. As far as Rockwood House is concerned, without prejudice to defence, if my husband has bought it under Pakistani and international law, which allows for transfer of money under tax free administrations, it is his legal right to do so. The Karachi house he lived in before we married is worth more than Rockwood. We have repeatedly asked for [proof of] a link to defrauding the public exchequer. The regimes have failed to give these links other than make empty declarations because they know we are innocent of wrongdoing.

The Guardian: There are reports that, given the British government's ongoing investigation, you have moved permanently from London to Dubai. Is this true and do you have plans to return to Britain in the near future?

Bhutto: This is incorrect. The British government investigation started on a request made to it in September 1997 in relation to my husband. I moved to Dubai for family reasons in 2000. I do have plans to return to Britain. I was there for a few days last August, September, October and November. I go there pretty frequently, stopping on my way to Europe or America.

The Guardian: In an interview with the Guardian in September, Mr Zardari admitted he had behaved "improperly in being extravagant" while you were prime minister but said that his only crime was to "marry Islam's first woman prime minister". Do you agree?

Bhutto: I do believe that my husband is more sinned against than sinning. He reminds me of Shakespeare's King Lear. Pakistan is a traditional male society in many ways.

The Guardian: How difficult has it been to live apart from your husband for such a long period, and how has this enforced separation affected your children?

Bhutto: I have been married for 13 years and my husband has begun his eighth year in prison. He has been tortured and was almost killed in custody. Whilst in Pakistan, I sent my children overseas for fear they saw their mother arrested, too. It saddens me when I think of how heavy a price we have paid. My children have missed out on having a father in the crucial years of their upbringing. I have missed having my husband share my life in the bloom of life. The years have taken their toll and we both suffer from hypertension. I block out what I am going through because when I think of it I become all teary eyed.

The Guardian: How, also, do you keep in touch?

Bhutto: We write to each other and send each other cards and books.

The Guardian: You recently blamed your downfall as prime minister on Osama bin Laden. Could you elaborate?

Bhutto: That is partially correct. I said that the extremist forces that fought the jihad in Afghanistan wanted to make Pakistan a base and thus targeted my government and my family. Long before the world heard of Osama Bin Laden, he was funding sitting Pakistani generals (now retired) and Mr Sharif in a bid to overthrow my government. He had worked with them during the days of General Zia. These spooks also had great credibility in the western world, which had cooperated in the Afghan jihad. In 1989 Osama paid 10m dollars to overthrow my government through a no confidence move and interfere in Pakistan's politics. In 1993, Ramzi Yusuf, the [convicted of bombing] the World Trade Center in New York, made two attempts to assassinate me to prevent my election. In 1996, I briefed my cabinet that a conspiracy was being hatched to overthrow the government to strengthen extremist forces and use religion, the sharia, to enforce a takeover.

fields.bodyText: The Guardian: There has been much speculation about your imminent return to Pakistan. In a recent interview you said you had your "bags packed" ready for departure. When do you think this might happen? Bhutto: I'd like to return sooner than later. Pakistan is my country. My ancestors lived there before Pakistan came into being. I am the twice-elected prime minister removed twice by the intelligence apparatus, which refused to bow before the people's will. I want my fundamental rights respected. They have been systematically and brutally trampled since 1977. My family has spent a cumulative 21 years in prison since then and 30 years in exile. My family's saga reflects the history of Pakistan where forces of dictatorship have battled the forces of democracy. Popular and democratic leaders are targeted with an attempt to eliminate them through perversion of justice and a smear campaign. This must stop if Pakistan is to join the civilised nations of the world by practising values enshrined in the United Nations and its human rights declarations. The Guardian: And what assurances would you need from General Musharraf given the outstanding corruption case against you? Bhutto: It's a miscommunication to say there is a corruption case against me. There are trumped up non-cases in a conspiracy to pervert justice. There are five attempts to pervert justice in my case and they are based on the same set of unproven papers. Given that the papers are unproven and the regime is without a single witness to prove them, a close look shows that I am the victim rather than the villain of the piece. The same set of unproven papers against me have been made into three cases against my husband and one against my mother. As far as Musharraf is concerned, he is an officer who has sworn to uphold the law. I expect him to do so by stopping my political victimisation and that of others. My party [the Pakistan People's Party] has called for the repeal of the NAB [National Accountability Bureau] law which violates due process, the withdrawal of politically motivated cases, the release of political prisoners and for the abandonment of the politics of select pardons. The NAB law of equity demands that the regime apply the same treatment to all those behind bars which they applied to Mr Nawaz Sharif. There is little prospect of the Musharraf regime showing such inclination in the near future. Although the euphoria, which greeted their arrival, has evaporated and their plans of economic revival, credible accountability and new leadership are in shambles, they are still to absorb the reality. The reality is that the process of political persecution, clothed in anti-corruption, which began with my ouster in Pakistan, has damaged the country. Many are calling Pakistan a failed state. Since my ouster, democracy has been dismantled, the judiciary undermined, the economy bankrupted. The only gain has been to the clerics who openly brandish their weapons and call for the Talibanisation of Pakistani society. The Guardian: What role do you see yourself playing once back in Pakistan? Bhutto: I see myself playing a political role in supporting democratic revival and the strengthening of a liberal and enlightened Pakistan, which works for peace in the region and gives the federating units equal treatment. There are a large number of people in Pakistan who support me and who elected me. Irrespective of whether the regime jails me, disqualifies me or seeks to restrict me in any other way, I remain the single most important political force in the country. The Benazir-led PPP is federal in nature. It has core constituents who support its liberal policies and record in office, which saw a boom economy. I expect to play a political role in Pakistan irrespective of how the regime treats me. The Guardian: And what prospects are there, if any, for a speedy return to democracy? Bhutto: The prospects look better with the unity of the political forces and the public disillusionment with the regime. The regime is now trying to play a geo-strategic card to stay in power. Hence the picking up of the peace process [with India over Kashmir]. But a country internally divided and polarised is a greater threat to peace and stability than one united. The Guardian: Your successor as prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, is now in exile in Saudi Arabia following a deal last month with Pakistan's military rulers. What do you make of his release and would you countenance a similar deal for your husband, Asif Ali Zardari, still in prison after four years on corruption charges? Bhutto: Nawaz Sharif made his choice and there's little point in commenting on it now it's done. Nawaz had just begun his sentence. My husband is in a different boat. In Pakistan, you get bailed out on corruption charges in four months. Under statutory law, an under-trial prisoner is freed after two years in prison even if it's a murder trial. Senator Zardari is being held contrary to law due to political persecution. Ordinarily, he should be free. Four courts have given him medical bail and the regime has blocked it by obtaining a stay from the supreme court contrary to the law of consistency. Senator Zardari's prison term is completed even before his appeal is heard. Since 1990, this is his eighth year in prison. That's the punishment a male spouse gets in an Islamic country where fundamentalists control key institutions. It's inhuman and barbaric. They've tried to take his life, his liberty, his property, reputation, right to family. Both of us have been told we'd be better off if we left each other. So they've even tried to take our marriage. By the grace of God, we have survived the test and remained loyal to each other, our family and our political commitment to our party and our people. I believe in fighting for truth and justice irrespective of the odds. Nawaz had taken 6bn rupee loans from Pakistan state banks starting from the time when the rupee was fifteen to the dollar. He had mortgaged the property to the banks in lieu of the loans. As far as Senator Zardari is concerned, he has yet to take loans from public sector banks and therefore his properties have little to do with the state. Now if the state wishes to hold him hostage and demand a ransom, I would say they have yet to do that with Nawaz. I would also ask why they want a ransom from someone from a smaller province when they refused to take a ransom from someone from the majority province. It's wrong. The racial discrimination that has been indulged in is appalling. Senator Zardari should be freed on merit and so should the others who are being held as political pawns in a power struggle between the unelected security apparatus and the elected representatives. The Guardian: Britain's home secretary Jack Straw last month announced that he was freezing your assets in the UK. Bhutto: That's incorrect. The British high commissioner was quoted in the press as stating so. The Guardian: The British government is also cooperating with the authorities in Islamabad, who are investigating money allegedly stolen by you during your time in power. Bhutto: That's incorrect. It assumes that I have stolen money and that assumption is a slur. Moreover, Islamabad has still to make such a charge against me in any country. In England, they have sought assistance on a trumped up narcotics charge against my spouse and in Switzerland there is an investigation to see whether I influenced a contract to benefit my husband. Islamabad has been unable to provide Geneva with a single witness that I influenced the contract. Whereas I am prepared to produce witnesses who were threatened to commit perjury and pervert justice in a bid to get me in the Swiss case. I can produce them before the United Nations rapporteur on judges and the judiciary if Islamabad rakes up the courage to invite him in on the subject. Or Mary Robinson of the United Nations high commission for human rights. The Guardian: What do you think of Mr Straw's move? Bhutto: I wish he would review it keeping in mind Pakistan's circumstances and the pressure the judiciary is under. He is involved in a process to assist Islamabad on a request related to a trumped up narcotics charge. I believe Mr Straw should reject a request by a military dictator, a request based on torture, a patently fabricated case that carries with it the death penalty. For Mr Straw it's just a request. For my family, it's the threat of death in a country where a handful of judges previously sentenced an innocent prime minister who happened to be my father. Irrespective of the lack of evidence, a Pakistani court can get legitimacy to use British assistance to obfuscate the case and give the death sentence. Particularly when the judge happens to be the relative of the man who hanged my father. Even if Musharraf says he won't carry out a death sentence, he could change his mind tomorrow or put in on the courts. The two defendants, Arif Balauch and Shorang Khan, on whose disputed statements this charge was made, were tortured to pervert justice. Their torture marks have been recorded by the high court in Pakistan. The former interior minister is on record stating that the case was concocted. The Guardian: There is confusion as to the extent of your assets in the UK. Could you clarify what properties you do own, and whether they include Rockwood House, a nine-bedroom mansion in Surrey allegedly bought by Mr Zardari? Bhutto: Whatever I do own, I own legitimately through inherited, invested and earned money. My husband and I both hail from privileged families. Nothing we own is tied to any illegal activity. As far as Rockwood House is concerned, without prejudice to defence, if my husband has bought it under Pakistani and international law, which allows for transfer of money under tax free administrations, it is his legal right to do so. The Karachi house he lived in before we married is worth more than Rockwood. We have repeatedly asked for [proof of] a link to defrauding the public exchequer. The regimes have failed to give these links other than make empty declarations because they know we are innocent of wrongdoing. The Guardian: There are reports that, given the British government's ongoing investigation, you have moved permanently from London to Dubai. Is this true and do you have plans to return to Britain in the near future? Bhutto: This is incorrect. The British government investigation started on a request made to it in September 1997 in relation to my husband. I moved to Dubai for family reasons in 2000. I do have plans to return to Britain. I was there for a few days last August, September, October and November. I go there pretty frequently, stopping on my way to Europe or America. The Guardian: In an interview with the Guardian in September, Mr Zardari admitted he had behaved "improperly in being extravagant" while you were prime minister but said that his only crime was to "marry Islam's first woman prime minister". Do you agree? Bhutto: I do believe that my husband is more sinned against than sinning. He reminds me of Shakespeare's King Lear. Pakistan is a traditional male society in many ways. The Guardian: How difficult has it been to live apart from your husband for such a long period, and how has this enforced separation affected your children? Bhutto: I have been married for 13 years and my husband has begun his eighth year in prison. He has been tortured and was almost killed in custody. Whilst in Pakistan, I sent my children overseas for fear they saw their mother arrested, too. It saddens me when I think of how heavy a price we have paid. My children have missed out on having a father in the crucial years of their upbringing. I have missed having my husband share my life in the bloom of life. The years have taken their toll and we both suffer from hypertension. I block out what I am going through because when I think of it I become all teary eyed. The Guardian: How, also, do you keep in touch? Bhutto: We write to each other and send each other cards and books. The Guardian: You recently blamed your downfall as prime minister on Osama bin Laden. Could you elaborate? Bhutto: That is partially correct. I said that the extremist forces that fought the jihad in Afghanistan wanted to make Pakistan a base and thus targeted my government and my family. Long before the world heard of Osama Bin Laden, he was funding sitting Pakistani generals (now retired) and Mr Sharif in a bid to overthrow my government. He had worked with them during the days of General Zia. These spooks also had great credibility in the western world, which had cooperated in the Afghan jihad. In 1989 Osama paid 10m dollars to overthrow my government through a no confidence move and interfere in Pakistan's politics. In 1993, Ramzi Yusuf, the [convicted of bombing] the World Trade Center in New York, made two attempts to assassinate me to prevent my election. In 1996, I briefed my cabinet that a conspiracy was being hatched to overthrow the government to strengthen extremist forces and use religion, the sharia, to enforce a takeover. webTitle: Bhutto set to take on the regime

fields.headline: Bhutto set to take on the regime
fields.standfirst:
Twice-sacked PM aims to defy jail sentence and lead again, denouncing Straw's support for asset investigation

Transcript of the interview
Special Report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Benazir Bhutto, Islam's first woman prime minister, has revealed plans to attempt a high-risk political comeback by returning from exile soon, putting herself on a collision course with Pakistan's ruling generals.
fields.body:
Benazir Bhutto, Islam's first woman prime minister, has revealed plans to attempt a high-risk political comeback by returning from exile soon, putting herself on a collision course with Pakistan's ruling generals.

In a telephone interview she told the Guardian that she said she intended to go home "sooner rather than later", and that she was determined to play a "political role" in Pakistan's future.

Ms Bhutto, whose two terms as prime minister both ended in her dismissal by presidents on the grounds of corruption and mismanagement, said she hoped to "revive" democracy. After governing from 1988 to 1990 and 1993 to 1996, she fled in 1999 shortly before a court sentenced her to five years in jail for taking huge kickbacks.

Last week she shrugged off the prospect of imprisonment. "I remain the single most important political force in the country," she said, adding that her family's history reflected Pakistan's own struggle with dictatorship.

Five corruption cases are pending against Ms Bhutto in Pakistan. Her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, has been charged with eight and is in jail in Karachi.

There is a warrant for her arrest. But said she would return home, even if the "regime jails me, disqualifies me, or seeks to restrict me in any way" from trying to revive Pakistan's shattered democracy.

Their critics accuse Ms Bhutto and Nawaz Sharif, twice elected prime minister after her dismissal, of driving Pakistani politics and the economy ever lower. But the euphoria which came when General Pervez Musharraf deposed Mr Sharif and assumed the title of chief executive had evaporated, Ms Bhutto said.

His plans to revive the economy and restore accountability were a "shambles". Pakistan was divided and on its way to being a "failed state". The only beneficiaries were clerics who wanted the "Talibanisation" of the country.

Ms Bhutto also bitterly condemned the recent decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to help Pakistani prosecutors who have begun investigating her overseas wealth.

In November a senior home office official went to Islamabad to meet members of Pakistan's National Accountability Bureau. They allege that Ms Bhutto and her husband embezzled huge sums during her time in power. Mr Zardari is accused of buying a nine-bedroom mansion - Rockwood House - with the proceeds of drug deals.

Ms Bhutto denied that she had done anything wrong, and said the case against her husband - instigated by her successor as prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, in September 1997 - was "trumped up". The prosecution's two key witnesses were tortured to give false evidence, she alleged.

The home secretary had failed to appreciate the pressure which martial rule put on the judiciary's handling of these cases.

"I believe Mr Straw should reject a request by a military dictator," she said. "For Mr Straw it is just a request. For my family it is the threat of death."

Her "innocent father", President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was executed in 1979 at the behest of another general, Zia ul-Haq, after being convicted by a handful of partisan judges, she said.

She would not clarify in the interview what properties she owned in Britain, but insisted that all her assets there were "legitimate".

In October prosecutors in Pakistan released details of 26 bank accounts and 14 residences allegedly owned by Ms Bhutto and Mr Zardari, with a value of $1.5bn (about £1bn). Five of them were in Britain.

They included Rockwood House, valued at£3.5m; properties in Knightsbridge, Chelsea and Hammersmith; and bank accounts with Barclays, NatWest, the Midland (now part of HSBC) and Harrods. She also allegedly owns houses in France and a stud farm in Texas.

She declined to say whether Mr Zardari was the true owner of Rockwood House, but said that "if" he had bought the property it was "his legal right to do so". His old house in Karachi, where he lived before their arranged marriage in December 1997, was much bigger, she added.

She said there was no proof that any of her foreign assets had been bought with money stolen from the Pakistani exchequer. She also denied that Jack Straw had frozen her assets in Britain, at Islamabad's request. The Home Office refused to confirm or deny this.

"We both hail from privileged families. Nothing we own is tied to any illegal activity," she insisted.

Ms Bhutto denied that her decision to move last year from London to Dubai was connected to the British government's investigation of her affairs. Foreign Office sources have hinted that she left for the Gulf because the net was closing on her, but Ms Bhutto insisted that she had left for "family reasons" and planned to return to Britain soon.

Under an agreement with the United Arab Emirates, she is prevented from making political statements. Her chief political foe, Nawaz Sharif, is under a similar ban after being sent into exile in Saudi Arabia last month from prison in Pakistan.

Both the main parties in Pakistan, Mr Sharif's Pakistan Muslim League and Ms Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party, have been left leaderless and divided.

Ms Bhutto, who is 47, said she had missed having a husband with her in the "bloom of life". "The years have taken their toll and we both suffer from hypertension," she said. She said her husband reminded her of King Lear and, in a reference to Lear's words in the storm scene, added: "I do believe my husband is more sinned against than sinning."

The couple have three children: a son, Bilawal, 11, and two daughters, Bakhtwar, nine, and Aseefa, seven. "I have been married for 13 years and my husband has begun his eighth year in prison. My children have missed out on having a father in the crucial years of their upbringing. It saddens me when I think how heavy a price we have paid."

Ms Bhutto claimed that Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born terrorist based in Afghanistan, was partly behind her downfall as prime minister. In 1989 he paid $10m to try to get her out, by lobbying for a no-confidence vote against her, she said, and in the 1980s, when he was unknown in the west, he also funded Pakistani generals and Mr Sharif to try to topple her.

Ms Bhutto claimed that "extremist forces" who fought in Afghanistan against the occupying Soviet army had wanted to get rid of her so that they could turn Pakistan into a base for Islamic extremism.

webTitle: Harvey Keitel to star in Spanish-language film

fields.headline: Harvey Keitel to star in Spanish-language film
fields.trailText: The Hollywood star is to appear in a political thriller about a revolution in South America - but he will only be required to speak English
fields.body:
Hollywood veteran Harvey Keitel's eclectic career is set to take another unusual turn this year. He has signed up to play the lead role in a Spanish-language film. Keitel, however, will only speak in English.

The 61-year-old star will play a Vietnam veteran who attempts to rescue his girlfriend after she becomes caught up in a South American coup d'etat in the film Ninguna Parte (Nowhere). The Latino cast will be led by Jorge Perugorria, Rosana Pastor, Angela Molina and Leo Sbaraglia.

The $5.6m (£3.84m) political drama will mark the directorial debut of Luis Sepulveda, the Chilean novelist whose first novel, The Old Man Who Read Love Stories, was adapted for the big screen last year, starring Richard Dreyfuss.

The seven-week shoot begins in March in Salta in northern Argentina and then moves to Barcelona. Keitel is expected to join the set in April after finishing the Manuel Pradol drama, Le Volcan, in which he co-stars with Andie MacDowell

webTitle: Danger still looms in the shadow of red dust

fields.headline: Danger still looms in the shadow of red dust
fields.standfirst: A remote village pays witness to some of the worst devastation left by the earthquake in El Salvador, as aid worker Rachel Stabb reveals in her latest diary entry from the stricken region
fields.trailText: A remote village pays witness to some of the worst devastation caused by the earthquake in El Salvador, as aid worker Rachel Stabb reveals in her latest diary entry from the stricken region.
fields.body:
Help reached a remote village in the Salvadoran province of Usulutan for the first time on January 25, some 12 days after the earthquake. I heard about it during a trip to one of the worst hit and poorest parts of El Salvador.

Even though aid couldn't get through, I was curious to know if the villagers had ventured down to the small town of Berlin. I was told it was highly likely - nothing keeps people in this coffee growing area from moving around the steep inclines.

As we climbed from the plains into the hills, it was clear that parts of the countryside are still precarious. In the distance, red dust rose silently from halfway up the hillside, the telltale sign of continuing landslides. It's hard to know what impact the rains in May will have on the loosened soil.

Meanwhile, I noticed that our driver was accelerating past every potential landslide spot, which made for rather a bumpy, but ultimately safe ride.

The earthquake is never far from one's mind when travelling around the countryside. The talk of the day was the two severe aftershocks that came at around 0400 and 0520 in the morning. While I had not noticed some of the smaller ones, these woke me up, shaking my bed backwards and forwards.

The general situation creates a nervous disposition. People are extremely fearful of sleeping inside, particularly under tiled roofs. It is easy to see why. My trip to Usulutan revealed the worst devastation I'd seen in 10 days. Much of the main hilltop town of Santiago de Maria had collapsed in the tremor. The sound of hammers and shovels came from almost every dwelling. "If the quake had been at night, many people would have died," said Maria Antonio Arget as she showed us round. It was easy to see what she meant.

Manuel, from Oxfam Belgium, was shocked by what he saw. He has lived here for 11 years and knows the villages well. But he wasn't prepared for the extent or cruelty of the destruction.

Berlin and San Augustin were equally badly damaged. In both places, people are busy clearing up or doing repairs wherever they can. But this is small comfort when so much has been snatched away. I watched Maria Isidoro Garcia look over her gutted house, where she has lived for 10 years. Carrying her four-year-old son, she surveyed the scene and then left, feeling totally bereft.

Sadly, Salvadorans can draw upon a long list of crises that they have had to overcome. It includes "civil war, economic crisis, hurricane Mitch and earthquake". As a result they've become experienced at putting their lives back together, but they long not to have to do it again.

As we climbed from the plains into the hills, it was clear that parts of the countryside are still precarious. In the distance, red dust rose silently from halfway up the hillside, the telltale sign of continuing landslides. It's hard to know what impact the rains in May will have on the loosened soil. Meanwhile, I noticed that our driver was accelerating past every potential landslide spot, which made for rather a bumpy, but ultimately safe ride. The earthquake is never far from one's mind when travelling around the countryside. The talk of the day was the two severe aftershocks that came at around 0400 and 0520 in the morning. While I had not noticed some of the smaller ones, these woke me up, shaking my bed backwards and forwards. The general situation creates a nervous disposition. People are extremely fearful of sleeping inside, particularly under tiled roofs. It is easy to see why. My trip to Usulutan revealed the worst devastation I'd seen in 10 days. Much of the main hilltop town of Santiago de Maria had collapsed in the tremor. The sound of hammers and shovels came from almost every dwelling. "If the quake had been at night, many people would have died," said Maria Antonio Arget as she showed us round. It was easy to see what she meant. Manuel, from Oxfam Belgium, was shocked by what he saw. He has lived here for 11 years and knows the villages well. But he wasn't prepared for the extent or cruelty of the destruction. Berlin and San Augustin were equally badly damaged. In both places, people are busy clearing up or doing repairs wherever they can. But this is small comfort when so much has been snatched away. I watched Maria Isidoro Garcia look over her gutted house, where she has lived for 10 years. Carrying her four-year-old son, she surveyed the scene and then left, feeling totally bereft. Sadly, Salvadorans can draw upon a long list of crises that they have had to overcome. It includes "civil war, economic crisis, hurricane Mitch and earthquake". As a result they've become experienced at putting their lives back together, but they long not to have to do it again.

webTitle: Analysis: The cost of caring for the elderly

fields.headline: Better for elders
fields.standfirst: Much is made of the Scottish move to give the elderly free personal healthcare - but is the situation in England really all that different?
fields.trailText: Much is made of the Scottish move to give the elderly free personal healthcare - but is the situation in England really all that different?
fields.body:
The Scottish executive's promise on free long-term care for the elderly is less dramatic than it seems. After all, it is only a promise. An expert group under Malcolm Chisholm, deputy health minister, is to report in August. Between then and now a general election may intervene, which would not affect the balance of power in Edinburgh but might make the equations look different in London.

Some have reacted as if this were the first social policy divergence between Scotland and England. But unit costs, especially in education, have been higher north of the border for a long time. The Barnett formula, which determines how much the Scottish executive gets, was designed in the 1970s better to align spending and need across the United Kingdom; it has not done a good job. Scottish health spending as a proportion of Scottish GDP is well above the UK's. Indeed it is already at the fabled European Union average, which the UK as a whole will only reach - if Tony Blair is lucky - by 2004 or thereabouts. That depends on the EU average staying put. It looks as if it might rise from 8% of GDP to 10%, giving Labour another mountain to climb.

On the face of it, Edinburgh has said yes to Sir Stewart Sutherland's report on long-term care* when London has so far said no. That things are not quite as simple as that is testimony to the Blair government's capacity to say one thing (usually of a rightish-wing kind) while doing another, often in a progressive direction. The fact is London has already gone a long way to meeting the Sutherland recommendations and reducing the cost of old-age incapacity.

Sutherland's majority - the Labour peer David Lipsey lodged a powerful dissent in favour of rigorous means-testing - said elderly people looked after at home or in an institution should qualify for free "bodily" care. Such attention is free if they are in a bed on an NHS hospital ward.

The chart shows how the UK's elderly will grow in number. The increase is steep after 2010 but less of a gradient than elsewhere in Europe. A working assumption is that one in three women and one in five men will need to be looked after; many will suffer from degenerative illness and dementia and require a lot of attention. Often family - if it exists - will not be able to cope and mum or dad will be accommodated in residential homes which will have to be paid for. Here is where the granny-sells-home tabloid scare starts. Under existing rules - oddly enough, the Tories were in this instance enthusiastic taxers of capital - care has to be paid for when older people have assets worth £16,000 or more.

Large proportions of health and social services budgets already go on the elderly - those over 65 account for two-thirds of hospital patients and 40% of all emergency admissions. Long-term care now costs something like £8bn. It is hard to be exact because individuals' circumstances and costs are spread unevenly between the NHS and councils.

Over the next half century costs will rise fourfold in real terms, to about £27bn a year. But the economy will also grow, its historical annual average 2.5% a year. So, if the present system continued its cost as a share of GDP would increase only fractionally, from 1% to 1.1%. Sutherland - who did not propose getting rid of the "hotel" charges levied on residents of homes - would cost £33bn by 2050 or 1.3% of GDP.

Those figures would converge if Labour's grand plan for health set out last July by Alan Milburn came to fruition. The government line is that even before the national plan kicks in it is doing a lot to make older people better able to care for themselves (free health checks on retirement, for example) and be cared for.

It has also, it says, gone a long way to meet Sutherland, for example by making nursing (an important part of personal care) free for elderly people in nursing homes. Plans are afoot to boost standards in homes, for closer liaison between the NHS and social services and prompt, sympathetic and simpler assessment of needs by social services. And there is money in the pipeline - an extra £1bn plus by 2003-04 for beds outside hospitals, home adaptations (grab rails for example) and respite for carers.

From April, the first three months of nursing in a home or at home will be subject to a means test that disregards whether an elderly person owns a home. It is a "breathing space", said Mr Milburn, to allow the possibility of a return home. Some 30,000 people a year may benefit.

Councils are being told to be more consistent in what they count as capital and some of the assessment formulae frozen at 1996's levels. The complex finance of care in and out of council coffers will be simplified and stop (the government hopes) councils pushing old people into private sector homes because they are cheaper.

As important as the emergent differences between Scotland and the rest of the UK are the similarities - the big issues unbroached in both. Should social services remain separate from the NHS? Why not a compulsory insurance scheme, pooling risks? The official line in London is that a private sector solution is being looked at, though everyone knows it is bound to leave out the many who can't or won't pay. Scotland is allegedly more collectivist than England but there, too, the radical solution of compulsory state insurance for the risks of incapacity in old age is on no one's agenda.

 With Respect to Old Age: Long Term Care - Rights and Responsibilities, A Report by The Royal Commission on Long Term Care March 1999

webTitle: Students to revive spa town's fortunes

fields.headline: Students to revive spa town's fortunes
fields.trailText: Buxton, a once fashionable spa whose waters were taken by the gentry as a remedy for a variety of ills, has found a wonder cure for its own economic strife. David Ward reports
fields.body:
Buxton, a once fashionable spa whose waters were taken by the gentry as a remedy for a variety of ills, has found a wonder cure for its own economic strife.

Local councillors, who have struggled to reverse a decline which has lasted for a century, are celebrating the imminent arrival of the University of Derby in the town centre.

The university already has an outpost on a windy hill on the edge of Buxton. But plans will be finalised this week for the university to take over two of Buxton's - and Britain's - finest buildings and import 2,500 students to a new and elegant Peak District campus.

"Students may not be rich but they spend every penny they have in their pockets - and more besides," said Andrew Uprichard, deputy leader of High Peak borough council.

The council cannot believe its luck. The economic and social impact on Buxton, a place with an ageing population and few job opportunities, has yet to be fully assessed. But the university has attracted £80m to the local economy in Derby each year since it was created in 1992.

"The university's plans have won almost universal support," added Mr Uprichard. "Everyone sees the bringing in of a significant number of students as the injection of life that Buxton needs."

Councillors dream of new bars and restaurants and the revival of fortunes of Spring Gardens, the principal shopping street now dominated by charity shops. "Many people are already making investment decisions in anticipation of the students coming to town," said Richard Tuffrey, the council's conservation manager.

This week the university will formally acquire from NHS Estates, at the knockdown price of £100,000, the former Devonshire Royal hospital, built in 1789 by John Carr of York as a circular stable block for the horses of spa visitors.

The complex became a hospital and was given a steel roof with glass cupola in 1881. Now listed grade II, it boasts a dome which is 154ft in diameter, bigger than those of the British Museum, St Peter's in Rome, the Capitol in Washington and the duomo in Florence.

It also has an amazing acoustic quality which attracts visitors who cough, snap their fingers and whisper to each other round the walls.

"One of our challenges will be to retain the dome's wow factor," said Roger Waterhouse, the university's vice-chancellor. "The challenge will be to create an atmosphere that respects the learning function but also maximises access for the public."

Present plans suggest a variant of the British Museum's reading room, a mix of learning and cafe sociability, a place to meet and exchange ideas. As part of the £8.5m scheme, former wards will be converted to lecture theatres and new uses will be found for 13 other buildings on the site. The first students should arrive in September 2002.

The university will also cure a Buxton headache and give a boost to the local tourism economy by moving into The Crescent, a Georgian range of hotels and lodging houses built by John Carr to accommodate spa visitors. It is listed grade I but has been empty for 15 years.

Following the closure of a hotel in the mid 80s, the building rapidly declined until it was jointly acquired by the High Peak and Derbyshire county councils.

Emergency repairs made the exterior wind and waterproof but the interior, including a magnificent ballroom used variously as a hospital and a library, was untouched.

But in December a trust formed by the two councils submitted a £10.9m bid to the heritage lottery fund as part of a £15.5m restoration scheme. The councils have found a preferred developer and The Crescent will become a four-star training hotel managed by the university's new international school of tourism and hospitality management: 69 guest bedrooms (with bathrooms having running Buxton spring water), 25 student bedrooms, two restaurants, conference spaces and spa and fitness centre. It should open in 2003.

"We are planning a renaissance of the core of 18th and 19th century Buxton," added Professor Waterhouse. "We know we have the ability to breathe new life into the town. Buxton will feel different. But the scheme will also have a cultural impact on the town, which should have a great future as a centre for the arts."

webTitle: Lords rejects ban on chemists selling the morning-after pill

fields.headline: Lords rejects ban on chemists selling the morning-after pill
fields.trailText: A move to ban chemists selling the morning-after pill over the counter was firmly quashed last night after the House of Lords threw out an order brought by the family values campaigner Lady Young.
fields.body:
A move to ban chemists selling the morning-after pill over the counter was firmly quashed last night after the House of Lords threw out an order brought by the family values campaigner Lady Young.

Peers voted by 177 to 95 - a majority of 82 on a free vote - to reject a procedural motion which would have seen the pill withdrawn from chemists' shelves immediately.

The pill - which would still have been available at doctors' surgeries, hospitals and family planning clinics - was made available over the counter to all women aged 16 and over from January 1 amid much controversy.

Welcoming the defeat of the motion, the health minister, Lord Hunt, said: "We are absolutely delighted at the result of this vote which is a major step forwards for women's health in the UK."

Family planning groups also applauded it. The Family Planning Association argued peers would be guilty of "an extraordinary attack on women's health" if they had backed it, and said women needed access to the pill - which can be taken up to 72 hours after sex - as swiftly as possible to ensure it was most effective.

The support for the government policy came about despite the Tories operating an unofficial whip to ensure their benches backed Lady Young, their one time leader in the Lords. But the Lib Dems, who turned out in force, redressed the balance by backing their health spokesman, who opposed the motion, Lord Clement-Jones.

Bringing the order, Lady Young, who last year spearheaded the campaign to defeat the government on lowering the gay age of consent, warned that the emergency contraception, while intended for the over 16s, was being bought by girls younger than that age.

Its sale at £20 per pill sent out the signal that unprotected sex was permissable, said Lady Young. "This is in fact exactly the opposite of what the sex education industry has been saying for at least 20 years. It is a very dangerous signal because it will increase the incidence of sexually transmitted diseases."

She also suggested it was unsafe.

"Each treatment is 50 times more powerful than the previous contraceptive pill. What adults choose to do is a matter for them but I think we have a responsibility to the young."

Her call was backed by the former Labour cabinet minister and prominent Roman Catholic Lord Longford, who argued increased accessibility to the pill would encourage "fornication and adultery."

But peers, including a gynaeocologist, teacher and two bishops, rejected her claims with the Lib Dem Lady Walmsley suggesting she wasn't living in "the real world".

She said: "In the real world, things sometimes go wrong with responsible people's normal method of contraception.

"Condoms split or come off and women forget to use the pill.

"Should we be trying to punish women by forcing them to have children they don't want? I have to say that I think it's much more of a tragedy for a 15-year-old girl to have a baby than to have a pill."

webTitle: BBC to broadcast Lennox Lewis fights

fields.headline: BBC boxes clever to land Lennox Lewis fight rights
fields.trailText: 9.30am: The BBC is today expected to win exclusive coverage of heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis' title defence, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC is today expected to confirm a deal for exclusive coverage of world heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis' defence of his title.

The fight-by-fight deal is expected to begin on April 21 when Lewis meets American Hasim Rahman.

And the deal for BBC1 and Radio 5 Live could also include Lewis's proposed showdown with Mike Tyson.

A BBC Sport spokesman said no deal had yet been signed but it hoped to conclude negotiations later today.

"We are hoping to hold a press conference this afternoon to make a major boxing announcement," he said.

The deal is a major boost for the BBC, which has suffered a string of sporting losses over the last five year including last year's loss of Premier League football highlights.

Lewis's fights have previously been broadcast by BSkyB in the UK.

It follows the signing earlier this month of Olympic boxing gold medallist Audley Harrison to a two-year BBC deal.

webTitle: Napster to charge online song swappers

fields.headline: Napster to charge online song swappers
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Napster, the controversial online music exchange service, is to charge its users for the first time this summer, reports Peter Capella.
fields.body:
Napster, the controversial online music exchange service, is to charge its users for the first time this summer.

Yesterday German music publisher Bertelsmann, which shocked rivals last year by breaking ranks and teaming up with Napster, said it was preparing to introduce a subscription-based music download service over the internet, using Napster software.

"I'm convinced we can introduce in June or July of this year a subscription model, with a real working digital rights management system," Thomas Middelhoff, Bertelsmann chief executive, said at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

Until now Napster's 57m users worldwide have been able to swap files over the internet free of charge. This has lead to music publishers, including Bertelsmann, suing the company for breach of copyright.

As part of the cooperation deal with Napster, Bertelsmann dropped its lawsuit although others are still outstanding.

News of the subscription deal had a sceptical reaction from other panelists at the Davos forum, including Sony chairman Nobuyuki Idei and Jean-Marie Messier of Vivendi-Universal, who own rival music companies. How ever, Mr Middelhoff said he was confident that a variety of subscription services would work.

Bertelsmann claimed there were signs that the music industry was preparing to move to the "new business models" advocated by Mr Middelhoff with the advent of the internet.

The head of the company's e-commerce unit, Andreas Schmidt, said Bertelsmann was in talks with other music companies, and some could join the Bertelsmann-Napster service within a matter of weeks.

Market research among 20,000 Napster users clearly indicated that they were willing to pay for the service, and there were prospects for paid file-sharing involving other types of entertainment.

"File sharing is not just about music, it is also about movies and entertainment," Mr Middelhoff said. He compared it with the survival of subscrip tion-based internet services, such as AOL, which had not suffered despite the emergence of free internet access.

Mr Middelhoff justified the decision last year to enter into a cooperation agreement with Napster by suggesting that legal moves against the service would not have succeeded.

"The publishers threatened to sue, but you can't sue 100m customers, because at the same time they are heavy buyers of music." The deal he struck with Napster was meant to protect copyrights.

Mr Middelhoff estimated that he would need only a fraction of Napster's users to subscribe to make the service worthwhile.

However, the deal continues to earn Mr Middelhoff criticism from those who do not share his vision of online subscription sales. Last November, two senior executives at BMG, Michael Dornemann and Strauss Zelnick, walked out days after Mr Middelhoff announced the Napster deal.

Others within the industry have described his breathtaking volte face as typical of Mr Middelhoff's flamboyant style and have suggested the poor quality of Napster's downloads will not justify charging for them.

Napster chief executive Hank Barry has denied the charge, saying the service was already acceptable to a large number of people.

Mr Middelhoff justified the decision last year to enter into a cooperation agreement with Napster by suggesting that legal moves against the service would not have succeeded. "The publishers threatened to sue, but you can't sue 100m customers, because at the same time they are heavy buyers of music." The deal he struck with Napster was meant to protect copyrights. Mr Middelhoff estimated that he would need only a fraction of Napster's users to subscribe to make the service worthwhile. However, the deal continues to earn Mr Middelhoff criticism from those who do not share his vision of online subscription sales. Last November, two senior executives at BMG, Michael Dornemann and Strauss Zelnick, walked out days after Mr Middelhoff announced the Napster deal. Others within the industry have described his breathtaking volte face as typical of Mr Middelhoff's flamboyant style and have suggested the poor quality of Napster's downloads will not justify charging for them. Napster chief executive Hank Barry has denied the charge, saying the service was already acceptable to a large number of people.

webTitle: Davos elite totters at the digital divide

fields.headline: Davos elite totters at the digital divide
fields.standfirst:
Gates defends PC from assault of the multi-access gizmo

More net news
fields.trailText: Even the free gift of hi-tech wireless 'personal assistants' failed to lift the gloom at the World Economic Forum. By Peter Capella.
fields.body:
Even the free gift of hi-tech wireless "personal assistants" failed to lift the gloom from the gathering of technology business leaders at the World Economic Forum.

Past years' enthusiasim for gadgets and gizmos was off the agenda at Davos, replaced this time by sober talk of "sustainable business models", reflecting the unease being felt from the tumbling value of technology stocks over the past year.

As well as falling stock prices, participants voiced their fears at the advance of the internet's "second wave," shaped by file-sharing applications such as Napster, allowing users to swap music and thereby avoid copyright payments - a model that could be extended to films and books in digital form. The trepidation was summed up by Nobuyuki Idei, the chief executive of Sony: "The internet is a kind of power shift," he said. "Now the consumer has more power than the company."

This, he said, has created a problem - how can the company be sustained in the new environment?

Only Tim Koogle, chief executive of Yahoo!, one of the more profitable internet companies, managed to present a brave face. While he admitted that his company may not continue to generate revenues of $1.1bn with a 30% profit margin, Mr Koogle felt he could manage with less. "I am confident because we have an established platform," he said.

His advice for start-ups is not only to "find ways to do it in ways that others can't do it for some time", but also to make sure that innovators quickly find a way to avoid relying on borrowed capital to reach profitability.

Consumers were expected to be at the centre of the unfolding new wave, rather than the technology itself.

But with the exception of direct sales by established brands - such as online tickets from airlines - internet e-commerce was out of favour in Davos, mainly because it has turned out to be more expensive than people had thought.

"The dot.coms failed because they ultimately had nothing tangible of their own to offer consumers - they had no assets and thus no profits," Oriet Gadiesh, a US-based business analysts told the assembled executives.

After the issues of business to business, or B2B, and business to consumers, or B2C, the talk was of what James Kelley, the chief executive of United Parcel Services, described as "B2Me".

"We see a time when we can get merchandise to our customers any time and any how, and the internet has to help us do that," Mr Kelley said.

That process may be helped by convergence - the only durable techno buzzword to emerge from the gloom.

"The PC-centric world is definitely dead. The multi-access world is here," insisted Jean-Marie Messier, the chief executive of media and entertainments corportation Vivendi.

That means wireless mobile devices - combining features of the internet, mobile phones and personal organisers - at connection speeds 40 times faster than in use at present, over a network seamlessly operating between work and home.

But Microsoft co-founder - and Davos regular - Bill Gates remained a staunch defender of the old order based around the PC.

Mr Gates told the forum that the flexibility of the PC made possible the Napster phenomenon of "peer to peer" communication. Enthusing about the "explosion" of young people using PCs, Gates pointed out that the necessary software for Napster came from a previously unknown developer, and could be adopted so quickly because of the widespread availability and flexibility of the standard PC.

However, there were signs that a large proportion of the world's populations will not have access to the internet's first wave, let alone its second.

The Davos elite made few steps in the direction of one of the forum's slogans: Bridging the Digital Divide.

"We have spoken a lot about it, but we have not yet reached the point where we have acted against the digital divide," Vivendi's Mr Messier admitted.

Few of his colleagues attempted to answer a Nigerian delegate who asked for less complex software that was better adapted for the needs of small businesses located in developing countries with access to computers.

Privately, executives felt there would be little bridge building from their side because of the economic slowdown.

With the internet established as a powerful tool, only about half the world's population has access to the electricity and phone lines necessary to enable them to adapt the technology.

Only a week before the forum started in Davos, the International Labour Organisation estimated that up to a third of the world's population was "technologically disconnected" - and that less than 5% used the internet.

The digital divide, the ILO's employment report found, also exists within developing nations, with access to technology being more common among the young, urban males who have high levels of income and education.

A similar divide was also evident at Davos. A spontaneous poll among the audience about the value of their wireless freebie, which tapped into the forum's computer information system, saw lots of hands go up when asked if it was useful. A few thought it was fun. But only one person claimed to understand how to use the device properly.

webTitle: 400 jobs lost as Disney pulls the plug on Go.com

fields.headline: 400 jobs lost as Disney pulls the plug on Go.com
fields.trailText: Walt Disney has announced the closure of internet portal Go.com with the loss of 400 jobs, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Walt Disney became the latest large media company to scale back its internet ambitions yesterday when it announced the closure of portal Go.com and the loss of 400 jobs.

The entertainment group is to take a $790m (£542m) charge in the second quarter to pay for the restructuring, as well as an estimated charge of between $25m and $50m for severance and other costs.

Several traditional media companies have cut jobs and reorganised their online operations in recent months.

In separate announcements, News Corporation, AOL Time Warner and the New York Times have all blamed a changing market or internal rationalisation for their decisions to retrench.

Michael Eisner, chairman and chief executive of Walt Disney, denied that yesterday's decision was a reversal of group strategy. "The internet continues to be a central focus of our company's business strategy. We believe this action should help us gain greater competitive advantage as we leverage Disney's creative content, brands and other assets."

The company has enjoyed greater success with its branded, niche sites than with Go.com, which was launched as a general search portal in November 1999 and focused on the entertainment and leisure industries only last October.

Charlene Li, analyst with Forrester Research, the US consultancy, said that over the past 18 months Go.com has grown at less than 20% in terms of page views and users, while Disney's other content sites such as ESPN, the leading sports site, and ABCnews.com, have grown between 50% and 75%. Go.com never managed to affect the popularity of all-purpose search services provided by Yahoo! and AOL.

Disney's decision to close Go.com and dissolve its internet tracking stock further underlines the changing fortunes of the web in the past few months. Mr Eisner has frequently reiterated his faith in the medium and, more significantly, Disney had more committed resources to building an online presence than any other large media company.

Wall Street analysts yesterday expressed only mild surprise that the California-based company had decided to abandon the web after spending so much money. Jessica Reif Cohen, media analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "Disney's internet spending is significantly more than anybody else in the industry. But, today, they are all rethinking their strategy."
