webTitle: Pay new parents to stay at home - Harman

fields.headline: Pay new parents to stay at home - Harman
fields.trailText: Pressure for parents to be paid to stay at home with their young children intensified last night after a new report called for "generous financial support" to be offered to those who do for the first three years of their child's life. Sarah Hall reports
fields.body:
Pressure for parents to be paid to stay at home with their young children intensified last night after a new report called for "generous financial support" to be offered to those who do for the first three years of their child's life.

The independent childcare commission - set up to advise the government - suggested that increased child benefit or a "toddler tax credit" should be offered to all but the highest earners to enable them to pay for childcare, or to ensure they could afford to stay at home. The report is being scrutinised by the Treasury.

While the commission - chaired by the former social security secretary, Harriet Harman, - failed to come up with a recommended figure, family groups believe it should be at least £150, nearly half women's average weekly income of £337. The move would cost the Treasury around £3bn a year, but advocates argue that the cost is justified if childcare is recognised as a crucial area of public funding, alongside transport, hospitals and schools.

The proposals were welcomed by the government, but described by the employment minister, Margaret Hodge, and Treasury officials as "extremely expensive".

The report also called for a children's centre, providing high quality nursery and after-school care, to be set up in every area. Only 2,000 such centres exist and increasing the number to the required 10,000 would cost up to £8bn, says the Treasury.

Parents, who on average spend £5,000 a year on child care, should also be helped by being granted tax relief to the basic rate on up to £2,000 of childcare expenses per year, it says - a move that would cost an extra £1bn a year.

Employers should be offered tax breaks to encourage, rather than deter, them from improving childcare provision. They should also do more to improve flexibility for parents.

But the commission stopped short of calling for legislation to make employers responsible for the provision or payment of childcare, and failed to suggest parents who remain at home for three years should have their jobs kept open.

The commission, whose 12-month research covered parents, children and employers across the country, also proposes a government department of work and family services to drive through childcare policy. The move, which would ensure childcare was no longer handled in a piecemeal way by different departments, would signal the government's commitment to solving a problem affecting at least 6m mothers.

Last night Ms Harman stressed: "This needs to move up the agenda of public policy and needs to be recognised as a priority alongside transport and schools. Children are not a lifestyle choice - they are the future of this country. We depend on them."

Family groups also welcomed the study. The Maternity Alliance, which campaigns for young parents' rights, said that implementing the report would cost peanuts in comparison with the costs borne by 700,000 couples who become new parents each year. "At present, women are returning to work before they want to because they can't afford not to," said its director, Christine Gowdridge.

The Tories also backed the recommendations, with the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, claiming they revealed a welcome shift away from penalising mothers who stay at home.

"No one's saying women must stay at home, but this shows a neutrality," he said. "This government has constructed a set of pressures in the tax and benefits system to favour parents to go out to work, but if you're at home you need assistance and support as well and this recognises that."

But the report drew criticism from some employers, who feared its recommendations would be too costly.

"This will fall on taxpayers whether they are individuals or businesses," said Ruth Lea, of the Institute of Directors. "I think there could be some resentment because they will be saying to themselves, 'I will be financing someone else's lifestyle choice'."

Margaret Hodge described the report as "a serious contribution to the development of childcare in this country".

She said: "We are doing a lot of what the report is recommending. We have already created the largest ever expansion of childcare, we have created places for over half a million children and the working families tax credit offers generous support with childcare costs for lower income families.

"It is important not to rule anything out prior to a budget, but clearly some of these proposals would be extremely expensive."

New deal for young: the main points

 A children's centre should be set up in every area to provide high-quality nursery and after school care. With one centre catering for two to three schools, up to 10,000 should be built. Would be funded by a combination of state and parental support

 Parents and other relatives should be offered "generous financial support for family care" for the first three years of the child's life.

The money would be spent on childcare - either formal care, a nursery or childminder; or family care - parents or other relatives.

Different options are mooted: an increase in child benefit for children up to three; a toddler tax credit for the first three years - available to all but those on the top rate of tax; or transferable tax allowance - available when one parent works and pays tax and the other stays at home - for the first three years

 Tax relief for childcare on the basic rate of up to £2,000 of childcare expenses per year

 Increased flexibility and a change in the tax system to encourage family friendly employment patterns at work

 A new government department of work and family services, which would be responsible for policy on childcare

Parents, who on average spend £5,000 a year on child care, should also be helped by being granted tax relief to the basic rate on up to £2,000 of childcare expenses per year, it says - a move that would cost an extra £1bn a year. Employers should be offered tax breaks to encourage, rather than deter, them from improving childcare provision. They should also do more to improve flexibility for parents. But the commission stopped short of calling for legislation to make employers responsible for the provision or payment of childcare, and failed to suggest parents who remain at home for three years should have their jobs kept open. The commission, whose 12-month research covered parents, children and employers across the country, also proposes a government department of work and family services to drive through childcare policy. The move, which would ensure childcare was no longer handled in a piecemeal way by different departments, would signal the government's commitment to solving a problem affecting at least 6m mothers. Last night Ms Harman stressed: "This needs to move up the agenda of public policy and needs to be recognised as a priority alongside transport and schools. Children are not a lifestyle choice - they are the future of this country. We depend on them." Family groups also welcomed the study. The Maternity Alliance, which campaigns for young parents' rights, said that implementing the report would cost peanuts in comparison with the costs borne by 700,000 couples who become new parents each year. "At present, women are returning to work before they want to because they can't afford not to," said its director, Christine Gowdridge. The Tories also backed the recommendations, with the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, claiming they revealed a welcome shift away from penalising mothers who stay at home. "No one's saying women must stay at home, but this shows a neutrality," he said. "This government has constructed a set of pressures in the tax and benefits system to favour parents to go out to work, but if you're at home you need assistance and support as well and this recognises that." But the report drew criticism from some employers, who feared its recommendations would be too costly. "This will fall on taxpayers whether they are individuals or businesses," said Ruth Lea, of the Institute of Directors. "I think there could be some resentment because they will be saying to themselves, 'I will be financing someone else's lifestyle choice'." Margaret Hodge described the report as "a serious contribution to the development of childcare in this country". She said: "We are doing a lot of what the report is recommending. We have already created the largest ever expansion of childcare, we have created places for over half a million children and the working families tax credit offers generous support with childcare costs for lower income families. "It is important not to rule anything out prior to a budget, but clearly some of these proposals would be extremely expensive." New deal for young: the main points  A children's centre should be set up in every area to provide high-quality nursery and after school care. With one centre catering for two to three schools, up to 10,000 should be built. Would be funded by a combination of state and parental support  Parents and other relatives should be offered "generous financial support for family care" for the first three years of the child's life. The money would be spent on childcare - either formal care, a nursery or childminder; or family care - parents or other relatives. Different options are mooted: an increase in child benefit for children up to three; a toddler tax credit for the first three years - available to all but those on the top rate of tax; or transferable tax allowance - available when one parent works and pays tax and the other stays at home - for the first three years  Tax relief for childcare on the basic rate of up to £2,000 of childcare expenses per year  Increased flexibility and a change in the tax system to encourage family friendly employment patterns at work  A new government department of work and family services, which would be responsible for policy on childcare

fields.headline: A Whitehall farce
fields.standfirst:
Broadcasters should call the lobby's bluff

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Broadcasters should call the lobby's bluff
fields.body:
"People were talking at cross-purposes, allowing imprecise language to convey uncertainty about the facts. Something of a Whitehall farce was unfolding " - Peter Mandelson's valedictory article in the Sunday Times.

On this, if nothing else, Peter Mandelson was surely right. The main act of the farce was played out last Friday afternoon at the regular gathering of that strange British institution known as the Sunday lobby.

The secretive little weekly ritual by which the prime minister's surrogate tries to influence the agenda of the Sunday newspapers was already falling into disrepair in the bad old days of Sir Bernard Ingham. According to the 1985 biography of Sir Bernard by Robert Harris (himself a member of the Sunday lobby for a while): "It was often impossible ... to work out which were Ingham's opinions and which were Mrs Thatcher's. This enabled him to plant stories which were neither true nor false, but inhabited some grey area in between ... The potential for error, for misinterpretation, for reading too much into too little or for missing something altogether, was obviously immense ... But this, as (Sir Edward Heath's former press secretary) Donald Maitland concluded 20 years ago, is precisely what the lobby system is all about. Nods and winks, kite-flying and speculation are the stock in trade of a system which is non-attributable."

Here were are, 30 years on from Maitland and 15 years on from Ingham, still trapped in that grey area between truth and falsity. Many of the journalists who attended the Friday afternoon lobby had not a shred of doubt that the prime minister's press secretary had ruthlessly and pre-emptively acted to knife Peter Mandelson in the knowledge that he was penning an article in the Sunday Times that threatened to reignite a story that might otherwise have been stuttering. Mr Campbell, meanwhile, insists that he has been drastically misunderstood. A transcript of his remarks would show that he was merely seeking to explain how Mr Mandelson - under intense pressure negotiating a peace in Northern Ireland - had not been able properly to focus on the detail of questions about the Hinduja affair.

But, as of last night, there was no publicly available transcript. The summarised lobby briefings which now appear on the Downing Street website are frozen in time at Friday morning. It is possible that this continued lack of clarity about what precisely was said, how it was said and in response to what promptings, suits Mr Campbell. It is difficult to understand why else he should have chosen to speak partly on the record and partly off. This had the risible consequence that some papers attributed some of his remarks directly to him and others to "Downing Street sources."

This farce cannot run much longer. The broadcasters - BBC, ITN and Sky - should call Mr Campbell's bluff and simply arrive at the next lobby briefing armed with cameras and tape recorders. Would Mr Campbell - who has already invited cameras in for a one-off film - dare to boycott the meeting? Would the print journalists (traditionally and ironically, the forces of unattributable conservatism) have the nerve to protest? Let daylight in. Let the briefers do what they do in Washington and most other open societies these days: speak on the record and on camera. There can be no value in a system when even after four days no one - the briefer, the briefed, the victim and the voters - has the remotest idea what was said or intended to be said in the name of the prime minister.

fields.headline: Teen girl website sponsors Buffy in £250,000 deal
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Teen girl web portal mykindaplace.com is to sponsor the new series of Buffy the Vampire Slayer on Sky One, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Teen girl web portal mykindaplace.com is to sponsor the new series of Buffy the Vampire Slayer on Sky One in a £250,000 deal.

The portal, backed by BSkyB, Freeserve and ThinkVentures, will have exclusive sponsorship of the 18-episode series, which runs from February 2 until June 1 in the primetime Friday 8pm slot.

Repeats of the first series will be shown on Tuesdays at 8pm.

Mykindaplace commercial and marketing director Charlie Redmayne said the sponsorship deal aimed to attract the portal's target audience of 12 to 18-year-old girls.

"In addition to our advertising campaign on Sky One and the Sky movie channels, this deal will further drive traffic and develop our brand awareness," he said.

The deal is mykindaplaces second foray in to TV sponsorship  last year it sponsored US high school series Popular.

The deal was put together by BSkyB sponsorship manager Lisa Christodoulou and Oliver Croom-Johnson of RCL Communications.

webTitle: Tragedy of UK doctor who died

fields.headline: Tragedy of UK doctor who died
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: In the early hours of yesterday, Ashok Nathwani (above) should have been getting on a flight back to the UK. A senior paediatrician from Hampshire, he had decided to pop in on relatives in Ahmedabad on his way back from a lecture tour through India. He was only going to stay one night.
fields.body:
In the early hours of yesterday, Ashok Nathwani (above) should have been getting on a flight back to the UK. A senior paediatrician from Hampshire, he had decided to pop in on relatives in Ahmedabad on his way back from a lecture tour through India. He was only going to stay one night.

But after breakfast the following morning, as he sat on a bed in the third floor of Akshardeep apartments, the ground started to heave. Dr Nathwani rushed to the door. He did not make it. "A beam fell on his head. It was an instant death," his brother-in-law Narendra Mirani said yesterday.

And yet the earthquake that ripped through the four-storey apartment block last Friday spared everyone else in the flat. Its haphazard impact flung Hardik, a 15-year-old relative who had been sitting next to Dr Nathwani, through the window and into a tree. Another relative, Pallavi, was having a bath when the tremors began. She plunged three storeys, but was rescued.

Dr Nathwani's host, Kishor, also survived. "He was in the lobby talking to neighbours. He ran towards the staircase. The staircase with everyone on it totally collapsed. Though the debris fell on him, he was visible so they pulled him out," Mr Mirani said.

Not everyone in the building was so fortunate. Four people, including Dr Nathwani, died. Yesterday rescuers were still trying to dig one 16-year-old boy out from what used to be the parking bay. They know he is in there because one of his friends bumped into him as they fled in different directions.

A Swiss rescue team that arrived over the weekend spent the morning combing the rubble with labrador sniffer dogs but found no sign of life.

Last night Dr Nathwani's widow, Chhaya, flew to India with their two children, Ketul, 16, and Vivek, seven, from their home in Fareham.

webTitle: India: a baby saved from a concrete tomb

fields.headline: After the devastation, the miracle of a baby saved from a concrete tomb
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Rescuers pulled an eight- month-old baby from the lap of his dead mother yesterday, more than 72 hours after they were buried alive under rubble by the earthquake which has devastated Gujarat state.
fields.body:
Rescuers pulled an eight- month-old baby from the lap of his dead mother yesterday, more than 72 hours after they were buried alive under rubble by the earthquake which has devastated Gujarat state.

With estimates of the death toll now exceeding 20,000, the fear of more earthquakes has intensified and spread across India. In Bangalore, the hi-tech capital of the southern state of Karnataka, an aftershock of 4.4 on the Richter scale shortly after 8am yesterday sent office workers spilling out into the streets in panic; they stayed out all day.

The rescue of the baby boy was one of the increasingly rare dramatic rescues in the devastated town of Bhuj where funeral pyres have been burning around the clock in the wake of Friday's earthquake. "It was just miraculous," said RK Thakur, a Border Security Forces assistant commandant, who was among the rescue workers who found the baby, Murtza Ali, under a collapsed building in Kansara Market in the old city of Bhuj, the town nearest the centre of Friday's huge quake.

His team was trying to recover the body of a woman from the rubble when they realised the blood-covered baby in her lap was alive.

"We saw the baby in the mother's lap, we saw some movement from the baby. I took the baby in my hand and I found it was alive," Mr Thakur said.

The boy was rushed to a medical centre, where doctors later said he was conscious and smiling. Doctors said it was the warmth of the mother's body and the protection it offered that helped the baby survive during nights when temperatures dropped to 6C (44F)

In Bhachau, a town east of Bhuj, a seven-month-old girl was rescued from the rubble of her home, and hours later was being passed around the arms of her joyous mother and relatives.

But such rescues were the exception as time ran out for those pinioned under collapsed concrete walls and tangled girders.

Even in Ahmedabad, which fared much better than Bhuj and Kutch, the district flattened by the earthquake, the rescue operation has been erratic and slow.

Across the city where 40 buildings collapsed last Friday, killing 500, more bodies were still being dug out.

Twenty victims were pulled out yesterday from the staircase of Chandrama apartments, a middle-class residential block. They had been trying to flee when the block's water tank fell on top of them.

"We managed to rescue one 21-year-old youth two days ago," Colonel Gopi Menon of the Indian army said. "It took us 10 hours. Finally we got ropes around him and pulled him out. There are still five bodies left inside."

Hundreds of people survived the initial impact only to die entombed on Friday and Saturday, while the authorities dawdled.

The living, meanwhile, are already making the best of things. Looting has begun. In Bhachau, the town worst affected by the earthquake, survivors have started combing through the market, removing - among other things - odd shoes. Since almost everyone died here, there is no one around to complain.

Shattered

In Bhuj, 188 prisoners have escaped from the shattered jail. And in Ahmedabad, householders were yesterday busy retrieving jewellery and other valuables from teeteringly unsafe buildings.

"There is a psychological panic," MH Hakwana, director of VS Hospital, said. "There is a fear of another bout of earthquakes. Many of our patients are now in the garden because they are constantly afraid. We have erected big tents for them."

Upstairs in the wards it is clear that the injured, like the dead, are mainly children and the elderly, those unable to escape quickly enough. Clearly overwhelmed, the government said it would ask for a £1bn loan from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank for reconstruction.

The Indian prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, touring the devastation in Gujarat yesterday, announced a federal relief grant of £76m and an extra £2.11m from the prime minister's relief fund.

He added that he was creating a national disaster agency to ensure immediate response to emergencies. "The country is not ready to face such disasters."

Survivors complained yesterday that confusion and a lack of equipment was hampering search efforts. Rescuers lacked cranes, bulldozers and generators for lights. Soldiers were beginning searches at first light and stopping at sunset.

"They work from 10am to 6pm only. This is emergency duty. They should work round the clock," said Pradeep Sheth, 46, who was rescued from under the rubble after seven hours.

Mr Sheth, whose wife, mother and two daughters were still trapped in the debris, wondered how soldiers would clear the rubble. "There are live people trapped inside. We can hear their sounds," he said.

Jayesh Shah, a teacher, arrived at the hospital in Ahmedabad with his badly injured wife Deepti after a 10-hour bus journey from Bhuj. "My son and I managed to get out of the house. But my wife was next door. She jumped out of the first floor. She was OK - but then a big stone hit her on the head. Blood keeps coming from her ears," he said.

As dusk fell yesterday, members of the Ashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, a rightwing Hindu group, were doling out puris and potato curry to the injured who were camped outside the hospital.

Nearby, a group of Muslims were praying to Mecca on a white sheet. Others were rolling out bedsheets. This part of India is still not yet ready to go indoors.

Clearly overwhelmed, the government said it would ask for a £1bn loan from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank for reconstruction. The Indian prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee, touring the devastation in Gujarat yesterday, announced a federal relief grant of £76m and an extra £2.11m from the prime minister's relief fund. He added that he was creating a national disaster agency to ensure immediate response to emergencies. "The country is not ready to face such disasters." Survivors complained yesterday that confusion and a lack of equipment was hampering search efforts. Rescuers lacked cranes, bulldozers and generators for lights. Soldiers were beginning searches at first light and stopping at sunset. "They work from 10am to 6pm only. This is emergency duty. They should work round the clock," said Pradeep Sheth, 46, who was rescued from under the rubble after seven hours. Mr Sheth, whose wife, mother and two daughters were still trapped in the debris, wondered how soldiers would clear the rubble. "There are live people trapped inside. We can hear their sounds," he said. Jayesh Shah, a teacher, arrived at the hospital in Ahmedabad with his badly injured wife Deepti after a 10-hour bus journey from Bhuj. "My son and I managed to get out of the house. But my wife was next door. She jumped out of the first floor. She was OK - but then a big stone hit her on the head. Blood keeps coming from her ears," he said. As dusk fell yesterday, members of the Ashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, a rightwing Hindu group, were doling out puris and potato curry to the injured who were camped outside the hospital. Nearby, a group of Muslims were praying to Mecca on a white sheet. Others were rolling out bedsheets. This part of India is still not yet ready to go indoors. webTitle: eLance shuts up shop in Europe and Australia

fields.headline: eLance shuts up shop in Europe and Australia
fields.trailText: 8am: Freelance website eLance is closing its European and Australian offices and will run its business from California. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
eLance, the global website for freelance workers, is closing its European and Australian offices and will instead run its business from its remaining office in California.

Little more than nine months after eLance opened in London, it has taken the strategic decision that local offices are too much of a drain on cash reserves.

Sonny Ajmani, eLance's vice-president of international, said the company needed to be more prudent in its spending.

"It's more cost-effective to run the business out of California. We have a strong global network of partnerships and don't necessarily have to have offices in those countries."

The European managing director, James Fulton, a former management consultant, was not available for comment.

Mr Ajmani said there was also a drive to cut the number of partnerships from 40 to a "handful" of larger, global partners.

"We concluded that not all partnerships are profitable. Many take a lot of effort to produce significant business returns," he said.

The moves come less than four months after eLance raised $50m in funding, adding to $12m in first round funding raised to build up the business.

Mr Ajmani said funding wasn't an issue and that there was still $45m left in the bank to take the business through to profit in the second quarter of next year.

ELance brings buyers and sellers together to fill freelance vacancies across sectors such as marketing, creative and web design.

fields.headline: Sky gets to work on interactive movie service
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BSkyB has started development on Sky Movies Active, its third enhanced TV product, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
BSkyB has started development on Sky Movies Active, its third enhanced TV product.

It is thought the interactive service will be launched before the summer and like Sky Sports Active and Sky News Active, be offered as a free additional service for Sky Digital subscribers.

Viewers will be able to use their remote controls to go behind the movie channels - Sky Premier, Sky MovieMax and Sky Cinema - and find out more information about films.

Sky Movies Active will carry basic information about what's on, competitions, news and previews.

The launch of the movies interactive service will be accompanied by a new film website, located at Sky.com/movies.

The intention is to develop more of a community around Sky Movies, building up the brand both online and on interactive TV.

A spokesman at BSkyB confirmed it was looking at an enhanced TV product for movies but declined to give further details.

fields.headline: Macdonell quits Scottish Daily Mail for Scotsman
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Hamish Macdonell has been appointed Scottish political editor of the Scotsman, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Hamish Macdonell has been appointed Scottish political editor of the Scotsman.

Mr Macdonell, currently political editor of the Scottish Daily Mail, will join the paper in April.

He takes the role vacated by Iain Martin, who left the Scotsman before Christmas to be deputy editor of Scotland on Sunday.

Mr Macdonell told MediaGuardian.co.uk he was "delighted to be joining Scotland's flagship paper in time for the general election".

He said he was looking forward to covering the "increasing difficulties emerging between the Scottish executive and Westminster".

Mr Macdonell has been at the Scottish Daily Mail for three years.

fields.headline: Castaway hunk could front Scotland ad campaign
fields.trailText: 8.30am The Scottish Tourist Board wants Castaway heartthrob Ben Fogle to promote Scotland around the world, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Move over Rabbie Burns, the new face of Scotland is to be younger and better looking.

The Scottish Tourist Board wants to recruit Castaway heartthrob Ben Fogle to promote Scotland around the world.

Mr Fogle won the hearts of female viewers all over the UK when he appeared on the BBC's reality TV show Castaway.

His good looks and easygoing manner secured him huge sacks of fan mail during the series, set on the remote Scottish island of Taransay.

And the 27-year-old has already made a big splash in the US, where Castaway pulled in nearly 20m viewers.

The Scottish Tourist Board is to invite him to help it bring more visitors to Scotland.

And Mr Fogle's affection for the country makes the organisation confident he'll accept. Only a few days after leaving Taransay, the former Tatler picture editor said he wanted to return.

The Scottish Tourist Board has a history of using celebrities' affection for Scotland to promote the country.

When Madonna married Guy Ritchie in Durnoch, the board acted quickly to launch a website promoting Scotland as the perfect place to get hitched.

It then launched a witty ad campaign that transformed the material girl's famous Gaultier cone bra into a Scottish mountain range.

webTitle: BSkyB rattles ITN with perfect timing

fields.headline: BSkyB rattles ITN with perfect timing
fields.standfirst:
Murdoch bids for Channel Four and Five news contracts were stalking horses for his real target
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Murdoch bids for Channel 4 and 5 news contracts were stalking horses for his real target, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
A week ago ITN was celebrating. The largest supplier of news to commercial television and radio in Britain had won the hugely-hyped battle of the bongs. The return of News at Ten on ITV had beaten the BBC by a margin of almost two to one the previous evening.

By the end of the day, ITN was fighting a rearguard action. While its bulletin had won the contest against the BBC, it now faced a potentially greater threat. With a typically bloodyminded sense of timing, Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB announced the formation of a consortium aiming to wrest the ITV news contract from ITN's hands. The present contract, which expires at the end of next year, is worth £200m.

ITN was dismissive, but with an unusual venom, which suggested that BSkyB's hastily pulled together consortium had rattled the company. The consortium, which included US broadcaster CBS, Bloomberg, Chrysalis and Ulster TV, was, an ITN spokesman spat, "a ragbag partnership crafted of desperation". The ITV network was more diplomatic and welcomed the competition.

This will be the fourth time that Mr Murdoch has challenged ITN's monopoly on the supply of news to commercial free-to-air TV. The first time, in 1996, BSkyB did not clear the starting blocks. Intending to bid alone, it was blocked because no shareholder in the news supplier to ITV can hold more than 20% of the company.

More recently it has challenged for the Channel 4 and Channel 5 contracts, and lost both. Insiders at BSkyB believe it was used as a stalking horse.

This is, then, the first time that ITN has faced genuine competition for a contract which accounts for about 45% of its revenues. It also comes at a sensitive time as shareholders in ITN contemplate a stockmarket flotation of the business which would be devastated if it lost its largest contract.

When the network went on air in 1955, ITN was wholly owned by the ITV companies. That changed after the Broadcasting Act of 1990 through which, in typical Thatcherite style, ITN was granted greater independence with the quid pro quo of being forced to bid for the ITV contract.

Reuters and the Daily Mail & General Trust climbed on board as shareholders alongside the larger ITV companies, Granada Media, Carlton Communications and the then United News & Media.

The Murdoch alliance, which remains unnamed, has written to ITV outlining its intent to bid for the next contract. The present five-year deal is worth some £40m a year. The consortium has also applied to the independent television commission for "nominated news provider" status. Any company hoping to bid for the ITV news contract must meet criteria designed to ensure quality.

The BSkyB public relations machine has tellingly declined to put forward any of its own executives for interviews and, instead, has been encouraging other members of the consortium to talk. The company seems keen to play down its own, and thus Mr Murdoch's role, in the bid - no doubt in full knowledge of the press and politicians' tendency to demonise the media tycoon. For the moment, however, efforts are clearly being co-ordinated by the head of Sky News, Nick Pollard.

BSkyB is keen to leverage the considerable resource of Sky News and to turn greater revenues from the channel. It has a budget of between £30m and £40m, depending on who you listen to, and is profitmaking or not, on the same basis. What is clear is that the channel faces increasing competition from ITN and BBC News 24 which, to BSkyB's chagrin, is given to cable companies free of charge. Sky News was forced off some cable channels when the BBC offered its cheaper alternative.

BSkyB's chances will depend on the ITV club's solidarity. The ITV network maintains that the award of the next contract will be made on an impartial basis, but could Carlton and Granada stomach giving the contract away to their biggest rival? They might save money by awarding the deal to a BSkyB consortium but that would also undermine the value of their stakes in ITN.

John Hardie, ITV's marketing and commercial director, will handle negotiations but the vote on the competing bids will be taken by the ITV council. This has representatives from the programme companies: Granada, Carlton, Ulster, Border and SMG, owner of the Scottish, Grampian and Channel franchises. ITV chairman Leslie Hill has the casting vote.

It should be easy enough to guess which way Granada, Carlton and Ulster will vote. Others might be reluctant to risk change, though there is a suggestion that some in ITV are irked by their subsidy of ITN's loss-making cable channel. The smaller companies might be more cost-conscious and willing to try a new supplier.

'It is bizarre'
The BSkyB consortium is adopting a confident air. "We are not afraid of competition or of what is perceived to be ITN's strong position," said Richard Huntingford, chief executive of Chrysalis. "We firmly believe we can come up with a proposal with much more relevance to ITV."

ITN is expected to attack the consortium on the spectre not only of Mr Murdoch, but the presence also of more than one US shareholder. One source said: "In trying to disguise Murdoch's influence Sky News has put together a consortium which is essentially north American. It is bizarre. Parliament and press will have a field day."

BSkyB's hasty announcement would appear to have been sparked by talk that ITN was pressing ITV for an early renewal of its contract ahead of a flotation. The prospect of an ITN flotation in the short term is fading but the urgency for BSkyB remains. Carlton and Granada are also lobbying the government to let them increase their interests in ITN over the set 20% after the sympathetic communications white paper.

If the two largest ITV companies are allowed to bring ITN under the same roof, ending what many see as an anachronistic structure, this could be BSkyB's last chance to steal in.

webTitle: Lords rejects ban on chemists selling the morning-after pill

fields.headline: Lords rejects ban on chemists selling the morning-after pill
fields.trailText: A move to ban chemists selling the morning-after pill over the counter was firmly quashed last night after the House of Lords threw out an order brought by the family values campaigner Lady Young.
fields.body:
A move to ban chemists selling the morning-after pill over the counter was firmly quashed last night after the House of Lords threw out an order brought by the family values campaigner Lady Young.

Peers voted by 177 to 95 - a majority of 82 on a free vote - to reject a procedural motion which would have seen the pill withdrawn from chemists' shelves immediately.

The pill - which would still have been available at doctors' surgeries, hospitals and family planning clinics - was made available over the counter to all women aged 16 and over from January 1 amid much controversy.

Welcoming the defeat of the motion, the health minister, Lord Hunt, said: "We are absolutely delighted at the result of this vote which is a major step forwards for women's health in the UK."

Family planning groups also applauded it. The Family Planning Association argued peers would be guilty of "an extraordinary attack on women's health" if they had backed it, and said women needed access to the pill - which can be taken up to 72 hours after sex - as swiftly as possible to ensure it was most effective.

The support for the government policy came about despite the Tories operating an unofficial whip to ensure their benches backed Lady Young, their one time leader in the Lords. But the Lib Dems, who turned out in force, redressed the balance by backing their health spokesman, who opposed the motion, Lord Clement-Jones.

Bringing the order, Lady Young, who last year spearheaded the campaign to defeat the government on lowering the gay age of consent, warned that the emergency contraception, while intended for the over 16s, was being bought by girls younger than that age.

Its sale at £20 per pill sent out the signal that unprotected sex was permissable, said Lady Young. "This is in fact exactly the opposite of what the sex education industry has been saying for at least 20 years. It is a very dangerous signal because it will increase the incidence of sexually transmitted diseases."

She also suggested it was unsafe.

"Each treatment is 50 times more powerful than the previous contraceptive pill. What adults choose to do is a matter for them but I think we have a responsibility to the young."

Her call was backed by the former Labour cabinet minister and prominent Roman Catholic Lord Longford, who argued increased accessibility to the pill would encourage "fornication and adultery."

But peers, including a gynaeocologist, teacher and two bishops, rejected her claims with the Lib Dem Lady Walmsley suggesting she wasn't living in "the real world".

She said: "In the real world, things sometimes go wrong with responsible people's normal method of contraception.

"Condoms split or come off and women forget to use the pill.

"Should we be trying to punish women by forcing them to have children they don't want? I have to say that I think it's much more of a tragedy for a 15-year-old girl to have a baby than to have a pill."

webTitle: MEPs can claim £142 allowance for 'day off'

fields.headline: MEPs can claim £142 allowance for 'day off'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText: Members of the European parliament in Strasbourg have been told that they can claim a £142 tax free attendance allowance on Fridays, even though no sessions are held.
fields.body:
Members of the European parliament in Strasbourg have been told that they can claim a £142 tax free attendance allowance on Fridays, even though no sessions are held.

Friday meetings were abolished during the week each month when MEPs go to Strasbourg for full sessions of the parliament.

But the 626 MEPs have been told they should nevertheless continue to claim the full allowance - intended to pay for overnight accommodation - for Fridays. Eluned Morgan, the spokeswoman on budgetary control for the Labour group, last night described the decision as "scandalous".

MEPs qualify for their daily tax free £142 by signing a register of attendance at the par liament. In the past there were accusations that some members were claiming the cash but failing to put in a full day's work, particularly at the end of the week.

"We were jubilant when we got rid of Fridays and on top of that there was a vote which said that if there were to be any payments they would have to be within strict guidelines," said Ms Morgan.

"But the problem is that they haven't been written, so anyone can just sign in. The system needs a more thorough overhaul. To allow MEPs to claim a full parliamentary allowance for a day on which no work is done is nothing short of scandalous."

Simon Murphy, leader of the Labour group, pledged last night to fight to ensure the situation was rectified.

fields.headline: BM 'serious' about legal action
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: British Midland is threatening legal action against the British and American governments over a treaty that prevents it flying to the United States from Heathrow.
fields.body:
British Midland is threatening legal action against the British and American governments over a treaty that prevents it flying to the United States from Heathrow.

The company confirmed yesterday that it was "seriously considering" a challenge to the European courts to overturn the so-called Bermuda 11 accord, which BM insists is anti-competitive.

Under the agreement only four airlines - British Airways, Virgin Atlantic, United Airlines and American Airlines - are allowed to fly across the north Atlantic from Heathrow airport.

Both governments have been trying to negotiate a new "open skies" agreement for the past five years. But a consider able stumbling block has been the reluctance of BA to give up many slots and a refusal by the Americans to allow British carriers to continue flying to other destinations once they are within the US.

Sir Michael Bishop, BM's chairman, is likely to reveal its plans later this week when BM launches its new livery and services from Manchester to Washington DC and Chicago, due to start in April. webTitle: Comment: Peter Preston. The internet is a friend of freedom

fields.headline: The internet is a friend of freedom
fields.standfirst:
Politicians will say something must be done about the world wide web. They'll be wrong

More net news
fields.trailText: It is the ancestral cry of politics. Something must be done! And thus our jumpy leaders spring into action - cancelling their last announcement or, in the case of MMR immunisation, spending an extra £3m to defend it. But what if - as so often in life, and even more frequently on the internet - there is nothing sensible to be done?
fields.body:
It is the ancestral cry of politics. Something must be done! And thus our jumpy leaders spring into action - cancelling their last announcement or, in the case of MMR immunisation, spending an extra £3m to defend it. But what if - as so often in life, and even more frequently on the internet - there is nothing sensible to be done?

We can talk child pornography and adoption and the killers of James Bulger in a moment, though. This story begins almost six years ago when Steven Gan, an investigative reporter for the Sun, a Malaysian paper, wrote an exposé of the evil conditions at Semenyih immigration detention camp in Selangor. Evil? Try brutality and squalor and rampant sickness - like typhoid - behind closed doors. Try 59 seekers of asylum dying in secret, unmourned and unmarked. Even Ann Widdecombe would find that a scandal.

But Gan's story wasn't published. The Malaysian press is not free. It exists, amid some chafing misery, in the long, dark shadow of prime minister Mahathir Mohamad. Instead, in the end, Gan turned over his findings to a battling women's rights activist, Irene Fernandez, and she distributed the Semenyih dossiers at one of her rallies. At least, then, a tale that had to be told began to break surface.

What happened next? Irene Fernandez was charged with "criminal defamation". Her trial - already the longest in Malaysian history- still continues. Translators for Bangladeshi defence witnesses from the camp seem to be in amazingly short supply. There have been 47 adjournments - yes, count them, 47 - for lack of a translator. And curiously, when one is available (as last week), the witness himself goes missing. If this shambles ever ends, Fernandez faces three years in prison.

And Steven Gan? He had his farcical moment earlier: arrested, locked up, an Amnesty prisoner of conscience. But then he went on, just over a year ago, to found malayasiakini.com. You, like millions of Malaysians, can find it easily enough on the net. It is a paperless newspaper - and yesterday it won the Media Pioneer award (for valour) presented every year by the International Press Institute and Freedom Forum.

The wonder of malayasiakini is how straightforward and solid it is. No hysteria, no vituperation: Gan and a dedicated team of professionals believe in news you can trust and measured comment. Their strength is that they cover the things the country's print papers have to bury or set to one side: the appointment of grotesquely unsuitable judges, the views of the opposition, the illness of Anwar Ibrahim, the ordeal of Irene Fernandez. They are measured and responsible: they are also virtually alone, the carriers of a torch.

Why, you may wonder, doesn't Dr Mahathir do to them what he's done to Malaysia's conventional press? License it, with licences which can be (and are) summarily withdrawn? Or find a way, through party backwaters, of owning the journals which are supposed to call him to account? Here's the unique strength of the internet.

A country like Malaysia, which has to be open for business, must also be open to the net. You can't have one without the other. Shut down or censor or try to block, and business gets a dire message. Opting out of the world wide web is opting out of your country's future. That is a step too far for Mahathir. He must grin and bear at least one outlet he can't control or intimidate.

I could replicate the essential story of malasiakini.com many times over. The web site of the Mail and Guardian in Johannesburg (which this paper owns) has its own proud record for bringing news to the countries north of South Africa where a free press perennially struggles to survive. Later today (when I log on again) I'll find emails from all over the world from distant readers of Guardian Unlimited. There's a power here which is an immense force for good. It makes us one world not merely in the flashing of share prices and bid offers, but in the challenging of oppression and the exposure of devious dictatorship.

But blessings, of course, are rarely unmitigated. Look at the headlines of the past few days. Police break up a (global) child pornography ring which grew on the net. The Kilshaws found their babies on the net. And something must be done. Ministers chafe and mutter, then duly warn web service providers that they face prosecution (under a 1971 act). Leave adoption to local authorities. Chris Smith's proposed Ofcom, most amorphous of future regulators, will have more of an e-role. We await, without eagerness, the first website to reveal the new identities and whereabouts of Venables and Thompson, who murdered James Bulger.

Here, though, is the rub. Just like Dr Mahathir, we can't have one thing without the other. There's no choosing the good things about the net and conveniently banning the things we find bad. It is what is. Seek to constrict, to limit here or censor there, and the force is no longer with it. Imagine, as the line of principle bends and breaks, how Malaysia - and so many other dusty regimes - will rejoice. Imagine what will happen to Steven Gan and Irene Fernandez and the inmates of the camps.

Do we shoot the messenger? That's the easy bit for politicians - though child porn and foreign adoption agencies can arrive by fax or phone or stamped, addressed envelope. But some of the choices are truly hard. I agree with Judge Elizabeth Butler Sloss that Venables and Thompson should be left alone to find a new life; I don't want vengeful mobs or crowds of reporters on their doorsteps. But how do you wrap them in a permanent blanket of silence? How do you seal them off for ever from the world? Judges may order these thing with the full authority of the law, yet they are still, coldly considered, impossible to sustain. These orders cannot hold through a lifetime. Some flickering screen, one day, will blow them to smithereens. And what do we do then?

You need no gift of prophesy. Something will have to be done! And it won't necessarily be the politicians of the right who clamour loudest for action. That could just as easily come from the centre or left, making a case that Guardian readers can embrace. Tony Blair and Charlie Kennedy are always keen on doing something. They will have the best of short-term justifications and nobody will say a prayer for the long-term, nobody will remember that "good" interference - in logic and reality - admits the possibility of bad interference as well.

Try to remember Steven Gan when that moment comes. Try to remember what he, and we, have to lose. Try to remember the nature of freedom - and the times when something mustn't be done.

webTitle: Sega strikes deal to send games straight to TV

fields.headline: Sega strikes deal to send games straight to TV
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Sega, the Japanese electronic games group behind Sonic the Hedgehog, has agreed a deal with the British set top box manufacturer, Pace Micro Technology, to download its games for playing on television.
fields.body:
Sega, the Japanese electronic games group behind Sonic the Hedgehog, has agreed a deal with the British set top box manufacturer, Pace Micro Technology, to download its games for playing on television.

The alliance incorporates the Sega architecture into digital boxes used to receive multi-channel TV.

With the deal the games group is seen as striking back, after reports that it could abandon the manufacture of its Dreamcast console in the face of intense competitive pressures from rivals Sony and Nintendo.

The collaboration is also a key development in the move to eliminate the growing stack of set top boxes and consoles competing for space in the home.

Media analysts believe it is vital for the viability of marginal services, such as video-on-demand, that they are in corporated into a single digital box. "The new concept of accessing information from a single device in the living room will become increasingly popular," said Sega vice president Hideki Sato.

Pace has extended the capabilities of its boxes by installing a hard drive, allowing games to be downloaded to televisions without discs or game cartridges. Shares in Pace yesterday climbed almost 11% to 675p.

The company is in discussions with all the main pay-TV groups in Britain to market the box to their customers. It already supplies BSkyB, Telewest and ONdigital, and claims to have boxes in 5m homes. Pace has also developed a system incorporating a personal video recorder.

Andrew Wallace, marketing director of Pace, said he expected the market to evolve like the mobile phone industry. "You will have the basic entry boxes supplied for free or heavily subsidised, and then higher specification boxes at an extra cost."

Gamers will be able to choose from 60 titles on demand with a further back catalogue which will download in around three minutes. Users will be charged per game or for a fixed 'hire' period. The box can also transmit games to wireless handheld devices.

Mr Wallace said the service would broaden the games market by bringing in more casual players.

Sega said last week that it is refocusing its business and is in talks to supply games to its main rivals, Sony and Nintendo.

A final decision on the future of Dreamcast is expected by the end of the month although Sega has said it will continue to support existing console owners with new game releases and customer services whatever the decision.

Sony recently launched PlayStation 2 and Microsoft's entry into the console market is looming with the X-box.

fields.headline: Psion launch scuppered
fields.standfirst:
Blow for UK tech firm as Motorola pulls out of internet-in-your-pocket venture

More net news
fields.trailText: Psion yesterday lost a fifth of its stock market value after it was forced to admit that US partner Motorola had pulled out of an eagerly awaited joint venture aiming to "bring the internet to your pocket".
fields.body:
Psion yesterday lost a fifth of its stock market value after it was forced to admit that US partner Motorola had pulled out of an eagerly awaited joint venture aiming to "bring the internet to your pocket".

The British handheld computer manufacturer claimed that it was a victim of internal upheaval at Motorola which, it said, had moved around its senior management and cancelled more than 30 projects in the past three months.

Psion, which issued a profits warning three months ago, warned that pretax profits for 2001 would now be £12m less than expected.

The palm sized gadget, which was to have been a cross between a Psion personal organiser, a mobile phone and a unit for accessing the internet at high speed, was to have been one of Psion's flagship products launched this year.

By piggybacking on the Motorola network in the US, analysts believed Psion had a reasonable chance of taking a market share from dominant players Palm and Microsoft.

"This is a body blow for Psion," said Keith Woolcock, an analyst at Nomura. "Motorola was going to sell this device in big volumes in the US, and it was going to be Psion's big breakthrough over here."

Confirmation that the Motorola joint venture was being discontinued capped a miserable day for Psion.

Separately, it said it would shed 100 jobs at its plant in Didcot, Oxfordshire, as part of an unrelated restructuring, warned that the integration of a company it had acquired last year had resulted in "slower than anticipated sales", and was forced to deny a report from an independent consultancy that its share of the European-handheld computer market declined last year.

Psion shares - which climbed more than 5% in early trading on the back of rumours of a link-up with rival Palm - eventually closed down 51p at 213p. In March last year they were at £15.

Chief executive David Levin tried to put a brave face on the situation, and insisted that other collaborative projects with Motorola, such as the Symbian consortium with the world's leading mobile phone companies, were unaffected by yesterday's developments.

"It leaves us with a bit of a challenge because we were very excited about being first to the market with this sort of product," Mr Levin said. "But we're hopeful we can find a new partner that will enable us to still get the product to market in 2002.

"We have some hard choices to make, but we plan to update investors when we report interim results on March 1st."

The cost of the project to Psion had been around £11m, Mr Levin added.

Analysts are now expecting the company to report a pretax loss of around £6m for 2001, compared to earlier forecasts of a pretax profit of £6m.

Sales of Psion's computers climbed 65% in 2000 as the company shipped more than 500,000 units - despite reports of declining market share. Mr Levin denied allegations made by consultancy Canalys.com that Palm, HP, Compaq and Handspring were taking market share from Psion in Europe.

webTitle: Hothouse debts deal blow to 'Edison of the net'

fields.headline: Hothouse debts deal blow to 'Edison of the net'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Walker Digital, the internet think tank set up by multimillionaire entrepreneur Jay Walker, is in talks to sell assets to pay off its heavy debt burden.
fields.body:
Walker Digital, the internet think tank set up by multimillionaire entrepreneur Jay Walker, is in talks to sell assets to pay off its heavy debt burden.

Difficulties at the think tank offer further evidence of the declining fortunes of Mr Walker, once hailed as the "Thomas Edison of the internet", with a fortune of more than $10bn.

Mr Walker, 44, suffered the closure of two of his businesses last year as well as a collapse in the share price of his best known company, Priceline.com, the "name your price" ticketing group.

Walker Digital, which was founded as a hothouse for new business ideas six years ago, has told creditors that it is in talks to sell parts of the business to pay what it owes them.

In a letter seen by the Guardian, lawyer Michael Nugent tells former employees waiting for severance pay that "a third party has begun serious due diligence with respect to its possible acquisition of certain Walker Digital assets, the proceeds of which would provide the cash it needs to settle creditor claims".

The letter, first published on the Redherring.com website yesterday, goes on to warn that any settlement would become null and void in the event of the firm being unable to raise enough money from the sale, or if Walker Digital "voluntarily or non-voluntarily enters into bankruptcy proceedings".

The privately held company, which is controlled by Mr Walker, refused to discuss the letter or its finances yesterday. Kevin Goldman, a company spokesman, said: "Walker Digital continues to work hard to restructure the company to everybody's benefit."

Last November, Walker Digital sacked 106 of its 120 workers without notice. The state of Connecticut immediately filed a legal action against the business, claiming that it should pay about $1m for its failure to give 60 days' notice.

Walker Digital claimed it had been forced to lay off staff after finding itself unable to complete a round of financing.

This lawsuit could be jeopardised if the company files for bankruptcy protection.

Mr Walker was not returning calls yesterday.

He returned to head Walker Digital fulltime last month after stepping down from the board of Priceline.com. The ticketingfirm's stock had fallen from a 52-week high of $104.25 to less than $3, taking much of Mr Walker's fortune with it.

The entrepreneur, who joined the ranks of America's 400 wealthiest men drawn up by Forbes magazine in 1999, still owns 37% of Priceline, a stake valued at almost $180m.

Both Mr Walker and Walker Digital also realised several million dollars from their investment in Priceline throughout last year, according to filings at the securities and exchange commission.

In the letter to claimants, Mr Nugent says he has reached tentative agreements with 20 out of 23 employees and five of the top 30 creditors.

fields.headline: Bogus points of order flooding into the country
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: MPs wanted to talk in the chamber about the only subject any of them is talking about outside - the Mandelson affair. Unfortunately for them, it was not on the order paper. The principal issue of the day rarely is.
fields.body:
MPs wanted to talk in the chamber about the only subject any of them is talking about outside - the Mandelson affair. Unfortunately for them, it was not on the order paper. The principal issue of the day rarely is.

Instead they had to resort to that old standby, the bogus point of order. This is done by pretending that the delightful scandal involves some thunderous point of parliamentary procedure. Thus the term "bogus" is used in the same way as in "bogus asylum seeker". It means nothing, but serves an important political purpose.

Bogus points of order have to be smuggled into the Commons. You sense that they've been discovered by customs officers at Dover, skulking in the back of a truck behind 800 cases of smuggled cigarettes. Stena Sealink will be fined thousands of pounds for every one detected.

Andrew Lansley wanted to know why Jack Straw had refused to answer MPs' Mandy questions on Friday, then turned up on Breakfast with Frost two days later, giving full answers to the very same questions.

David Heathcoat-Amory wanted the Speaker to stop ministers using the proposed inquiry as a means of stalling embarrassing questions.

Dale Campbell-Savours, a Labour MP and former poacher turned game-dog, decided it was time to lick Tony Blair's face. He declared that both the previous interventions were "bogus points of order". The Speaker said that his was a "bogus point of order" itself.

They are flooding into the country, along with a small minority of perfectly valid points of order whose cases will be dealt with as expeditiously as possible. Soon bo gus points of order will have to be bussed to council estates in Kirkcudbright and given 75p vouchers to live on.

Nothing whatever having been decided, we moved onto the criminal justice and police bill. This is the kind of behaviour that could cer tainly earn a fixed penalty ticket under the new law.

Now and again she yawned with ostentatious boredom, or else waved regally, as if the Queen Mum had formed unexpectedly strong views on the topic. He now responds in a faintly camp manner. "I know how eager she is to get up and start ranting," he said, with something close to affection.

webTitle: Treasury injects cash to soften council taxes blow council tax rises

fields.headline: Treasury injects cash to soften council taxes blow council tax rises
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Labour is to go into the next election defending council tax rises set at double the rate of inflation, but with the impact softened by a last minute injection of Treasury cash.
fields.body:
Labour is to go into the next election defending council tax rises set at double the rate of inflation, but with the impact softened by a last minute injection of Treasury cash.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has released nearly £200m for local government, and the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong, yesterday predicted the average council tax rise would be below last year's rise of 6.1%.

Some local government finance officials predicted last night this projection would prove optimistic.

The extra central government cash in four earmarked revenue streams was agreed after Labour local government leaders warned some council tax rises would be closer to treble the rate of inflation, so threatening many Labour marginal seats.

The money is on top of the provisional grant announced to councils in December and follows intense negotiations between the Treasury and the Department of Environment.

The extra cash comes in the form of £100m for neighbourhood renewal in 2001-02, an extra £52m for education, £11.5m to cover the cost of the floods and £25m for the costs of housing asylum seekers, mainly in London. The extra cash means no council will receive more than 6.5% in general grant increase from central government and no council will receive less than 3.2%.

The Conservatives claimed that Labour was targeting the cash at key marginal seats. The money would also help cushion the impact of changes to the local government funding formula which have hurt northern councils. Council tax rose by 8.6% in 1998-99, 6.8% in 1999-00 and 6.1% in 2000-01.

Yesterday's announcements prompted the Conservatives to claim that council tax in England had risen by three times the rate of inflation since the election.

Their local government spokesman, Nigel Waterson, said: "After four years of a Labour government the aver age household is likely to be paying an extra £200 per year in council tax. This is the ultimate stealth tax levied by Gordon Brown, but with local councils having to take the blame."

Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, said the extra cash was welcome, but he would continue to press for extra funding for personal social services.

webTitle: MI6 drawn into Hinduja passport row

fields.headline: MI6 drawn into Hinduja passport row
fields.standfirst:
Did MI6 recommend that SP Hinduja's passport application should be refused?
Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Did MI6 recommend that SP Hinduja's passport application should be refused?
fields.body:
The Conservatives last night twisted the knife over the passport row that cost Peter Mandelson his cabinet career when they claimed that an MI6 investigation into the background of the Indian tycoon SP Hinduja recommended that his application for British nationality be refused.

As Tony Blair promised MPs that Sir Anthony Hammond's official investigation would be published as soon as possible - probably in early March - security sources denied that intelligence agencies would make such a recommendation to ministers on a passport application, even from a multimillionaire suspected of kickbacks over arms dealing.

But they did admit that it was likely, as Ann Widdecombe suggested, that - if asked by Whitehall - immigration, military and intelligence staff at the British high commission in Delhi would have been "involved in the gathering of information from their Indian counterparts".

Miss Widdecombe's letter asks Sir Anthony to consider if intelligence staff at the high commission gathered infor mation from the Indian central intelligence bureau on the suitability of SP Hinduja's October passport application in 1998; if the high commissioner was privy to these investigations; whether these officials reported to the Foreign Office, and whether their findings were passed to the Home Office and the Cabinet Office; what the dates of the reports were; and whether one recommended that the passport request be turned down.

Miss Widdecombe's claim that "SIS [M16] opposed the application for citizenship" is based on a highly placed tip-off to Conservative HQ. The Tories feel smug about the affair because they turned down both SP and GP Hinduja for naturalisation in 1990.

Last night well-placed Whitehall sources said that it would be extremely surprising if UK diplomats in Delhi had not kept London fully informed about investigations of alleged corruption in India.

M16's role is to collect and circulate information, but not to make recommendations. However, the tenor of such intelligence reports and the nature of the information contained in them can influence Whitehall policy, sources said.

Such a high-profile case and individuals as the Hinduja brothers, residents of Britain, would be likely to be the subject of reports by the intelligence services as well as other government agencies, including the Home Office, the police and the Department of Trade and Industry.

William Hague yesterday challenged the prime minister to "end the open civil war between senior members of the Labour party by insisting that senior members of the Labour party, starting with his own press secretary, stop the spinning, the secret briefings, the backstabbing and the smearing that is now paralysing government".

Mr Mandelson, who is still hoping to stay on as MP for Hartlepool, went to ground, and was said to be on holiday for the rest of the week. But the novelist Robert Harris, who is also a friend of the Blair family, gave media interviews backing what has become the key Mandelson defence: that he did not lie to Alastair Campbell or Mr Blair about his "two-minute phone call" to the then immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, over the Hinduja passport in June 1998 because it may never have taken place.

Mr Harris, writing in the Independent, said Mr Blair, Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, and Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, acted like a "hanging bench", taking a "decisive and ruthless" decision that Mr Mandelson had to go.

He describes the dismissal as a "contemporary Dreyfus affair", a reference to the French officer who was court-martialled in the 19th century for betraying secrets, but later pardoned.

The Mandelson camp says two senior officials then in the Cabinet Office, believed to be Rupert Huxter and Emma Scott, have come forward to confirm that officials handled the inquiry about the prospects of a UK passport for SJ Hinduja. They tried to alert No 10 last week, but could not get through.

SP's brother, GP Hinduja, had already got a passport. Both are being investigated for their role in the Bofors Howitzer arms deal in the 1980s.

fields.headline: Pinochet put under house arrest
fields.standfirst:
Ex-dictator indicted for his role in hit squad murders

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Attempts to put Augusto Pinochet on trial for alleged human rights abuses took a dramatic turn yesterday when the 85-year-old former Chilean leader was placed under house arrest for his role in 57 murders and 18 kidnappings.
fields.body:
Attempts to put Augusto Pinochet on trial for alleged human rights abuses took a dramatic turn yesterday when the 85-year-old former Chilean leader was placed under house arrest for his role in 57 murders and 18 kidnappings.

The criminal indictment refers to the "Caravan of Death", a roving helicopter hit squad that toured Chile in 1973 stopping frequently to execute and mutilate civilian prisoners - and in his decision, Judge Juan Guzman indicts Gen Pinochet for his role as author of the executions.

The judge's decision is a stunning defeat for the Pinochet legal team, which had sought to have all charges dismissed based on the alleged ailments of the retired general.

Not only is Gen Pinochet charged with kidnappings, but the murder charges filed againt him indicate that the self-imposed amnesty he enacted in 1978 may also be challenged by Chilean courts.

Human rights activists inside the courthouse cried and hugged one another as the information was leaked to the press early yesterday morning.

"The atrocious crimes against humanity that were committed during the military dictatorship now have an intellectual author - Augusto Pinochet," screamed Carmen Hertz, whose husband was murdered by Pinochet security forces. "This is a profound 'no' to the impunity that they have tried for years to impose on this country."

"This is a great victory for Pinochet's thousands of victims, for the rule of law and for the principle that the perpetrators of atrocities should be brought to justice," said Reed Brody, advocacy director for Human Rights Watch in New York. "None of this would have happened had Pinochet not been arrested in England. That arrest broke the spell of his impunity."

Gen Pinochet, who remained at his seaside home south-west of Santiago, issued no immediate response to the indictment. His legal team met in Santiago to study the decision and plan appeals.

Chilean judges go on holiday for the month of February so the appeals could be delayed until March.

Judge Guzman's first arrest of Gen Pinochet, on December 1, was overruled by a supreme court decision that the former dictator must first be questioned. After that interrogation last week, the judge as sembled further evidence to move forward with his investigation. During questioning a defiant Gen Pinochet rejected advice from his own lawyers to remain silent. Instead, he answered all the questions and declared to Judge Guzman: "I am not a criminal."

Then, in an attempt to blame lower ranking officers, Gen Pinochet told the judge: "The commanders of the regional divisions were in charge of the detained prisoners."

Gen Joaquin Lagos, who commanded the northern army division - where many of the executions took place - then launched a blistering media campaign, calling Gen Pinochet a coward and showing secret documents on television that he said proved Gen Pinochet's direct responsibility for the executions.

"He [Gen Pinochet] told me to make one list of the executed and to sign it _ With that, I became the person responsible for all the crimes committed in my jurisdiction," said Gen Lagos in an interview with the Spanish newspaper El Pais. He also announced that after the massacres in Oc tober 1973 he had warned the newly empowered president: "Watch out, sooner or later we are going to be judged for this. Especially you, the commander-in-chief of the army."

Gen Pinochet's unofficial spokesman, Luis Cortes Villa, retreated from previous claims that the ex-dictator was innocent and instead emphasised: "Augusto Pinochet didn't look for this situation [the coup]. Society obliged him to take it."

Judge Guzman yesterday rejected the defence's petition to have Gen Pinochet declared medically unfit for trial.

After spending three days studying the results of extensive neurological and psychological tests, the judge pronounced the general "extraordinarily normal" - a statement that was widely interpreted to mean that he would continue with the investigation.

webTitle: Standards watchdog rebukes Labour officials over Vaz inquiry

fields.headline: Standards watchdog rebukes Labour officials over Vaz inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, has reprimanded officials in Keith Vaz's constituency Labour party for seeking to interfere in her inquiry into the minister's finances.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, David Hencke  and  Kevin Maguire
fields.body:
Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, has reprimanded officials in Keith Vaz's constituency Labour party for seeking to interfere in her inquiry into the minister's finances.

Ms Filkin's completed report on Mr Vaz, the minister for Europe, is on the agenda for today's meeting of the select committee on standards and privileges.

Ms Filkin issued her reprimand after receiving a complaint from Mustafa Kamal, a Labour councillor in the minister's Leicester East constituency.

Within weeks of lodging the allegations on April 17 with Ms Filkin in the form of four detailed points about Ms Vaz's finances, Mr Kamal received a letter from the Leicester East constituency party chairman, Colin Hall. Mr Kamal was ordered within seven days to prove his claims, or face the possibility of either party disciplinary action, or even legal action.

Mr Kamal was startled to receive the threat since he has insisted he only sent one letter to Ms Filkin and had himself failed to keep a copy. As a matter of course, such allegations are passed to the MP subject to the complaint by Ms Filkin.

Following the warning from Mr Hall, Mr Kamal wrote to Ms Filkin, as well as the regional director of the Labour party, Roy Kennedy, and the national Labour party for its comments.

Mr Kamal felt the apparent leaking of his complaint was a breach of parliamentary privilege. He subsequently received a letter from Ms Filkin reassuring him that the threatened action against him by his local party would not be proceeding.

Mr Kamal also subsequently wrote to Mr Hall asking for de tails of when local party officials had decided to threaten him with disciplinary action. He also asked to know how local party officials had received a copy of his initial letter of complaint to Ms Filkin. Mr Kamal had also wanted to find out whether Mr Vaz's mother, a local party official, had been present at the meeting which decided to warn him.

It is expected that Ms Filkin's inquiry has largely cleared Mr Vaz of the substantive allegations of failing to register a financial interest.

However, members of the select committee are increas ingly concerned at the way in which Ms Filkin is obliged to publish almost all aspects of her inquiry, including what emerge to be inaccurate allegations.

Some MPs believe it is a breach of the Human Rights Act for false allegations, or unrelated unproven allegations, to be published under the cloak of privilege.

Mr Vaz is also facing separate pressure over his close relationship with the Hinduja brothers. The depth of relationship was underlined last night by the disclosure he was the billionaire brothers' guest of honour at the Millennium Dome's opening party.

In return for a £1m donation for the faith zone, the brothers had pressed in return for Tony Blair to sit side by side with them at a press conference to announce the sponsorship.

When millennium organisers said that was impossible, the Hindujas accepted the offer of an appearance with the dome minister, Lord Falconer.

Government officials who dealt with the Hindujas said the brothers always wanted to "rub shoulders" with prominent politicians.

Tory attacks are undermined by the disclosure the party sought donations from guests after a Hinduja party in their HQ attended by William Hague on March 8, 1999, at which SP Hinduja spoke.

"I am delighted that you agreed to attend the reception at New Zealand House on March 8, 1999 at which William Hague was the guest of honour," wrote Jane Kenne, Conservative central office's director of income generation and marketing.

webTitle: Public urged to ask for data

fields.headline: Public urged to ask for data
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The public was urged yesterday by Elizabeth France, the information commissioner, to obtain all files held on them by government in the advance of new "right to know" legislation.
fields.body:
The public was urged yesterday by Elizabeth France, the information commissioner, to obtain all files held on them by government in the advance of new "right to know" legislation.

Ms France - in a briefing to mark her new dual role as data registration registrar and information commissioner - said too many people did not realise they had rights to ask for all files, records and email held on them by civil servants while they were dealing with government departments, agencies or local government.

"While the new Freedom of Information Act will not come into force in Whitehall until next year, people do not realise they already have rights under the Data Protection Act to request all this information about themselves, if it is held electronically. From October they will also have the right to any information held on them in manual files," she said.

Members of the public could request a wide variety of information under the data protection laws, including how their passport, benefits and tax affairs had been processed by Whitehall, as well as data held by civil servants on any complaints they had made.

She disclosed that Jack Straw, the home secretary, who steered the freedom of information bill through parliament, had volunteered the Home Office as a "guinea pig" for implementing the new law.
