fields.headline: Railtrack warned on repairs schedule
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was last night told by the rail regulator that its plans to restore the network to normal working were inadequate and to produce a new strategy within 14 days.
fields.body:
Railtrack was last night told by the rail regulator that its plans to restore the network to normal working were inadequate and to produce a new strategy within 14 days.

Following complaints from the main inter-city operators like Virgin and Great North Eastern Railway, that the railways would not be back to normal by Easter, the regulator, Tom Winsor, issued instructions to Railrack to have "urgent and detailed discussions" with the companies.

After a two hour meeting with Railtrack and the train operators, Mr Winsor said that there were "significant areas" where Railtrack had failed to meet the companies' requirements.

The statement reflected the regulator's continuing concern that Railtrack will be unable to deliver the network to the position which existed before the Hatfield rail crash last October.

Railtrack has issued a series of mixed messages. It began by saying that the network might not be back to normal until the middle of the year, which could be after the election.

But pressed by ministers anxious for a good news story, it has put on a sunnier face and promised to restore services by Easter. Railtrack's operations director, Johnson Cox, said yesterday that Railtrack was on target to achieve this aim.

But Mr Winsor's meeting yesterday has put the company on the back foot again. The worst affected services are those up and down the west and east coast main lines between London and the north.

The 25 train companies yesterday issued figures for November and December last year. These show that inter-city journeys fell by 20% and that revenue had fallen by 10%. London commuting services fell by almost 3%.

fields.headline: UUP deputy to leave Westminster
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor, is to resign from his Westminster seat at the general election, he announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The Ulster Unionist deputy leader, John Taylor, is to resign from his Westminster seat at the general election, he announced yesterday.

The 63-year-old Strangford MP, who is also a Stormont assembly member, said he was stepping down because of his demanding workload.

Mr Taylor, who has represented the constituency for 18 years, said however that he had no intention of retiring from politics.

He was a key player in the Good Friday agreement negotiations and he has expressed his desire to increase his role at Stormont and in Northern Ireland public life. Mr Taylor is also keen to play a prominent role in the new police board.

However, his resignation comes at a critical point in efforts to save the deadlocked political process and could put the UUP leader, Mr Trimble, under more pressure from hardliners in his party.

A fierce battle for his Westminster seat is now likely to follow between the pro-Good Friday agreement wing of the UUP and the anti-agreement Democratic Unionist candidate, Iris Robinson. Mr Taylor, 63, had already been selected to defend Strangford. He won a comfortable 6,000 majority over the DUP in 1997. But Ian Paisley's party is promoting Mrs Robinson, a Stormont representative and the wife of deputy leader, Peter Robinson, as a strong contender.

One of Mr Trimble's closest Commons allies, the Fermanagh/South Tyrone MP, Ken Maginnis, is also leaving Westminster at the election and Ulster Unionists were dealt a blow at the polls last autumn when the DUP's William McCrea defeated their candidate, David Burnside, in the South Antrim byelection.

Intense talks to broker a deal between unionists, nationalists and republicans on paramilitary decommissioning are making some progress, although the new Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, cautioned against over-optimism.

Tony Blair will meet the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, in Downing Street on Wednesday and they will have to act fast if there is to be a breakthrough before election fever starts.

Ulster Unionist hardliners have warned that the party could be annihilated at the polls if Mr Trimble signed up to anything short of a strong guarantee that there would be substantial IRA disarmament.

Mr Taylor said last night: "I expect the Ulster Unionists to hold the Strangford seat and I want to contribute more to the success of the Stormont assembly. This has been a very difficult decision to make but I believe it is best for the party and myself if I am to increase my political activity on other public bodies."

webTitle: Lib Dem MP challenges refusal to open MI5 files

fields.headline: Lib Dem MP challenges refusal to open MI5 files
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Jack Straw is being challenged for the first time under the Data Protection Act to reveal whether MI5 holds a personal file on an individual it may have once considered subversive.
fields.body:
Jack Straw is being challenged for the first time under the Data Protection Act to reveal whether MI5 holds a personal file on an individual it may have once considered subversive.

Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, is taking a case before the national security appeals panel set up by last year's act.

He said he had reason to believe MI5 held files on him as a result of his "ecological activities", including involvement in Greenpeace in the 1980s. Last year he received a letter from someone calling himself "the Mechanic" who claimed to be a serving MI5 officer.

The letter said: "There were reports [on you] forwarded to the security service by Special Branch officers in East Sussex in 1988. They were from a SB source within the South Downs Earth First group."

Mr Straw has responded with a blanket ban on the disclosure of personal files."If the security service were to confirm it held records about an individual, he would be able to take measures to frustrate the security service investigation on him," said the home secretary.

Mr Straw added that if the security service confirmed that it held no information about an individual and that individual's activities threatened national security or involved serious criminal offences, "he would be able to pursue those activities freely knowing that he was not the subject of security service interest".

MI5 is concerned about opening the floodgates if it confirmed or denied it had a file on Mr Baker. The agency has 290,000 files on individuals. The first hearing on the case was on Friday when a ban was imposed on reporting anything that was discussed.

Liberty, the civil rights group acting for Mr Baker, argues that the blanket ban is incompatible with the Human Rights Act.

It says Mr Straw is acting unreasonably by claiming a "disproportionate interference in the rights of privacy" of an individual.

webTitle: MacArthur makes history in round-the-world race

fields.headline: MacArthur makes history in round-the-world race
fields.trailText: The middle of the Atlantic was the lonely stage for a piece of yachting history yesterday when the 24-year-old English sailor Ellen MacArthur became the first woman ever to hold the lead in a single-handed round-the-world race.
fields.body:
The middle of the Atlantic was the lonely stage for a piece of yachting history yesterday when the 24-year-old English sailor Ellen MacArthur became the first woman ever to hold the lead in a single-handed round-the-world race.

Soon after dawn MacArthur and her 60-footer Kingfisher were just north of the equator, five miles ahead of the previous leader in the Vendée Globe race, Michel Desjoyeaux of France, with 3,000 miles still to go.

Such close running after 23,000 miles and 81 days at sea promises to make for a dramatic race to the start-and-finish line at Les Sables d'Olonne, near Nantes on the Atlantic coast of France. They are expected to arrive there on February 10, after having sailed around the Antarctic.

The record comes after a remarkable fortnight of hot pur suit by the Englishwoman, who has made up 640 miles on the long-time leader Desjoyeaux since they rounded Cape Horn earlier this month.

At present, MacArthur and Desjoyeaux are desperately seeking a way through the windless calms of the Doldrums in the south Atlantic, knowing that the 14-strong chasing pack is eating into what was once a huge lead.

MacArthur, 5ft 2in tall and the youngest competitor in the race, is defying the punishing physical demands of continuoussailing but at the weekend she confessed she felt "as exhausted as I ever have been in this race".

Yesterday, she was not allowing herself to get too carried away with her niche in maritime history. "Maybe leading will feel good but I am so tired with trying to keep the boat sailing," she said. "Mich and I have done 64 miles in the past 24 hours and the boats behind are doing that every five hours."

As if to underline the stop-go dangers of the Doldrums, by midday yesterday Desjoyeaux had drifted back into the slenderest of leads.

MacArthur, now based in France but raised in Whatstandwell in the Peak district, caught the sailing bug on a day-trip to the seaside.

Last year she became the first woman to win the Single-handed Trans-Atlantic Race.

fields.headline: Chancellor backs English devolution
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Britain
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday paved the way for full blown devolution in some English regions in a second Labour term by calling for strengthened institutions capable of breaking down Whitehall bureaucracy and creating a new provincial dynamism.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday paved the way for full blown devolution in some English regions in a second Labour term by calling for strengthened institutions capable of breaking down Whitehall bureaucracy and creating a new provincial dynamism.

The chancellor sided with Labour backbenchers and some ministers, led by John Prescott, who are pressing for a strong commitment to begin creating a network of eight regional assemblies after the election.

Addressing business people in Manchester, Mr Brown, one of the architects of a Scottish parliament, outlined a gradualist approach with a strengthened role for regional chambers, comprising councillors and business interests, and a new English regional committee in the House of Commons.

The government has already promised eight regional development agencies - seen as the building blocks to devolution - an extra £500m by 2003-04 bringing their annual budgets to £1.7bn.

With Tony Blair cooler towards English devolution, Mr Prescott has appeared a lone voice in the cabinet calling for a new tier of English democracy to match devolution in Scotland, Wales and Greater London.

Now the chancellor is backing the call for a strong commitment in Labour's forthcoming manifesto for a series of referendums to test the case for constitutional change.

Outlining his new enthusiasm for English devolution and a rapidly evolving constitution, Mr Brown spoke of the UK becoming a "Britain of regions and nations with a new dynamism".

He added: "We are moving from the old Britain of subjects where people had to look upwards to a Whitehall bureaucracy for their solutions, to a Britain of citizens where, region to region ... we are ourselves in charge."

The Tories were unimpressed. The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, said: "Gordon Brown is calling for yet more taxpayers' money to be wasted on unwanted and unpopular regional bureaucracy. We do not need another tier of government."

fields.headline: Waiting for the Fed's word
fields.trailText: If the big question confronting the London market this week is how big an interest rate cut will be made at tomorrow's US Federal Reserve meeting, then the other big question is what to do in the interim.
fields.body:
If the big question confronting the London market this week is how big an interest rate cut will be made at tomorrow's US Federal Reserve meeting, then the other big question is what to do in the interim.

With the Fed not scheduled to reveal its decision until after the close of play in London time, traders are expecting a couple more sessions like yesterday's mind numbing affair.

It was very predictable stuff. The rate sensitive banking sector was chased higher as investors anticipated a reduction of at least 25 basis points from the Fed.

Tech stocks followed the fortunes of the Nasdaq composite index in New York and the recent outperformers were hit by profit-taking.

The upshot of it all was that the FTSE 100 index ended the day 22.7 points higher at 6,317 - a seven-week closing high - thanks to strength in compa nies such as Barclays, 67p better at £22.44, and Abbey National, 19p stronger at £12.29p.

A good showing from the telecommunications heavyweight, BT - up 23p to 692p after admitting it might demerge its Yellow Pages division, Yell - also helped the cause.

Meanwhile, the FTSE Techmark 100 ended the day in much the same position as the Nasdaq composite shortly after the start of business in New York - that is, little changed, up just 2.67 points to 2,782.93.

Market turnover was pitiful, just topping 1.5bn by 6.15pm - compared to post-Christmas volumes of over 2bn. Traders said the City's big institutions were refusing to commit fresh money to the market ahead of the Fed meeting.

Psion was one of the day's biggest losers, falling 51p, or 9.32%, to 213p after the US electronics group Motorola pulled the plug on a product development deal.

The FTSE 100's wooden spoon went to mining group Billiton, which lost 15.75p to 289.75p after stockbroker Merrill Lynch advised clients to take some "quick profits" following what it called recent "strong outperformance".

Before yesterday's decline, Billiton had risen 18% since the start of the year. A downgrade from ING Charterhouse left Lattice 6p weaker at 134p. Citing concerns about gas regulator Ofgem's forthcoming review, ING lowered its investment rating on the gas network operator to "reduce" from "hold".

Ofgem's next price review consultation paper is due out at the end of February, and traders expect it to contain details of an alternative approach to setting Transco's regulatory asset value. Put simply, Transco's regulatory asset value is the figure that dictates how much money Lattice can make and a reduced rate, which will mean lower profits for Lattice, is said to be under consideration.

Jitters ahead of tomorrow's full-year figures got the better of chip designer ARM Holdings, down 18p to 515p, while engineering group GKN slid 22p to 821p, unsettled by unconfirmed reports that its highly rated chief executive CK Chow might step down as part of its restructuring plan.

On the speculative front things were pretty quiet.

A few brave punters decided to short telecoms group Thus, off 4p to 62p, ahead of its third quarter figures today, while others were having a nibble at Alliance & Leicester, up 14p to 714p, on the back of reports that National Australia Bank is casting its eye over the mortgage bank.

Elsewhere, drinks group Allied Domecq ended 19p stronger at 421p after confounding the sceptics with an upbeat trading statement.

Among second line companies, holders of shares in frozen food retailer Iceland, 12p weaker at 192.5p, had to endure more pain.

Its new chief executive, Bill Grimsey, is expected to deliver a report on the integration of cash and carry group Booker tomorrow, and many feel it will make grim reading.

Fears are growing that the £20m of benefits promised at the time of the deal last year are taking longer than expected to come through.

On AIM, hi-tech fund Eurovestech ended 0.5p higher at 23.5p after announcing solid interim figures.

Jitters ahead of tomorrow's full-year figures got the better of chip designer ARM Holdings, down 18p to 515p, while engineering group GKN slid 22p to 821p, unsettled by unconfirmed reports that its highly rated chief executive CK Chow might step down as part of its restructuring plan. On the speculative front things were pretty quiet. A few brave punters decided to short telecoms group Thus, off 4p to 62p, ahead of its third quarter figures today, while others were having a nibble at Alliance & Leicester, up 14p to 714p, on the back of reports that National Australia Bank is casting its eye over the mortgage bank. Elsewhere, drinks group Allied Domecq ended 19p stronger at 421p after confounding the sceptics with an upbeat trading statement. Among second line companies, holders of shares in frozen food retailer Iceland, 12p weaker at 192.5p, had to endure more pain. Its new chief executive, Bill Grimsey, is expected to deliver a report on the integration of cash and carry group Booker tomorrow, and many feel it will make grim reading. Fears are growing that the £20m of benefits promised at the time of the deal last year are taking longer than expected to come through. On AIM, hi-tech fund Eurovestech ended 0.5p higher at 23.5p after announcing solid interim figures.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: Pifco
fields.trailText: Pifco
fields.body:
Pifco, the maker of Russell Hobbs toasters and kettles, has announced its factory in Lichfield, Staffordshire, will close down tomorrow, with the loss of 150 jobs.

Chairman Michael Webber yesterday said the manufacture of the group's DH Haden branded products would move to its Wolverhampton plant, marking the end of the integration process for the budget appliances business, bought for £3.2m in May last year. Yesterday, the market remained unimpressed by the cost-cutting closure, and shares in Pifco closed up just 0.5p at 158p.

Despite the group's well established position as the market leader in toaster and kettle sales in the UK, its mature customer base has shown little prospect for growth. As a result, some now think the group should no longer remain a publicly quoted company.

Efforts to spice up the product range - from the relaunch of older "classic" designs, to the new Thermocolour kettle (it changes colour as it boils) - look desperate. Pifco's smaller interests are faring no better - Carmen, its hair and skincare brand, showed a notable drop in turnover.

Mr Webber argues that the group has had some roll-out success, particularly with food preparation products, but yesterday's interim results did not give much cause for optimism. In the six months to November profits rose just over 5% to £2.24m and, without Haden's contribution, revenue was up 5%.

Mr Webber described this as a good achievement for the six months, promising "a satisfactory result for the year".

Perhaps the best news for Pifco's share price, however, are the takeover and merger rumours that continue to circle the group. Talks about a merger with Kenwood kept investors interested last year until Kenwood announced it had received a bid approach last month. There remains a chance that a larger European company could step in if the price is right. But, failing that, the prospects for Pifco are poor.

webTitle: BT confirms Yell sale to reduce debt

fields.headline: BT confirms Yell sale to reduce debt
fields.trailText: BT yesterday confirmed it is considering a sale of its directories' business, Yell, to help reduce its £30bn debt.
fields.body:
BT yesterday confirmed it is considering a sale of its directories' business, Yell, to help reduce its £30bn debt.

The news came ahead of a crucial meeting between the company and its major shareholders last night. BT has been under pressure to consider ways of reducing its huge debts to regain the confidence of investors, who have seen its share price slump.

Shareholders want the company to accelerate the pace of its planned demerger and look for a merger partner for its mobile phone arm, BT Wireless.

The company hoped to raise £1bn by floating 25% of Yell. But that move has been hampered by an ongoing office of fair trading investigation.

The OFT is considering whether Yell has a monopolistic advantage because of its association with BT.

BT had expected the review, which began last May, to conclude before Christmas, leaving plenty of time for a March flotation. An OFT spokesman said the findings would be released "in the near future".

"We were aware of BT's aim to float by the end of the fi nancial year. But we can't jeopardise our review."

At the heart of the argument between OFT and Yell is whether the company should be regulated as a monopoly in its market.

The OFT considers Yell's directories to be part of the "classified directories" market in which the only significant players are Yellow Pages and Thomson Directories.

fields.headline: Automatic choke
fields.trailText: From Detroit to Dagenham, Seoul to Stuttgart, carmakers are in trouble. General Motors and Ford started 2001 with production cutbacks in the US. The Chrysler side of DaimlerChrysler began guzzling cash and is now haemorrhaging jobs. Figures from component makers show the downturn is hitting the supply chain.
fields.body:
From Detroit to Dagenham, Seoul to Stuttgart, carmakers are in trouble. General Motors and Ford started 2001 with production cutbacks in the US. The Chrysler side of DaimlerChrysler began guzzling cash and is now haemorrhaging jobs. Figures from component makers show the downturn is hitting the supply chain.

The Americans are stuck in reverse in Europe. Ford and GM's share of the European market and the number of cars sold shrank in 2000. GM has ordered the closure of Vauxhall's Luton plant and Ford the phasing out of car production at Dagenham in 2002 - with severe consequences for the workers but little impact on overcapacity.

Pain is not confined to production lines. Once the corridors of corporate power might have been the golden mile, now they are more blood alley. Daimler has despatched Deiter Zetsche and Wolfgang Bernhard to Auburn Hills to build a new team at Chrysler after top level departures. Robert Hendry, the chairman of Opel, GM's European arm, asked to be relieved of his responsibilities after losses of €500m in 2000.

Asia, too, is struggling. With a domestic market still coming to terms with prolonged recession, Japanese carmakers are understandably concerned by the US outlook. Daewoo of Korea is in receivership, with talks about a possible GM takeover dragging on.

Not everyone in Europe is in the same mess.

A decade ago, French carmakers Renault and PSA Peugeot Citroen were thought most likely to suffer in the face of increasing Japanese competition via UK-based "transplants" and among the most likely candidates for "consolidation". Last year the two companies accounted for nearly 25% of the western European car market, with the two PSA marques collectively outselling the Japanese.

Nevertheless the European market is, like the US and Japan, a mature one. To compensate, manufacturers aim to offer customers more choice and build a greater degree of commonality across their ranges. More bodyshells in more colours riding on fewer platforms. Built to order has become the manufacturers' mantra.

As manufacturing times fall, the prospect of customers ordering online to their own specifications and still taking delivery quickly becomes more likely. If the makers can tailor production more exactly to demand they will save huge amounts on inventories of unsold cars.

While the carmakers are toe-to-toe in the volume battle, they are still looking towards niche markets. Sports cars and multi- purpose vehicles are all the rage.

Brands are increasingly important. In Europe, Ford has snapped up Volvo, Land Rover and Jaguar. General Motors bought Saab.

VW's line-up includes Audi, Bentley, Bugatti and, until the end of 2002, Rolls-Royce. The Fiat stable encompasses Alfa Romeo, Lancia, Ferrari and Maserati.

If last year's speculation - at the height of the Rover debacle - that the Quandt family was prepared to sell its shares in BMW had been true, Munich would have been crammed with potential buyers.

The big carmakers are casting their eyes towards markets where they see real growth and not simply replacement - such as Argentina, Russia, China, India, Poland and Turkey.

True the Brazilian market has its ups and down - it fell by nearly a fifth in 1999 - but it can boast a growing band of producers.

The latest entrant, PSA, will have its work cut out to dent the market shares of incumbents like Fiat and VW.

As demand in the mature markets weakens with the economic cycle, manufacturers are having to become increasingly flexible in their operations and the markets in which they are prepared to operate. The alternative is a balance sheet in any colour - as long as it's red.

fields.headline: DaimlerChrysler to axe 26,000 US jobs
fields.standfirst: Ailing division's survival depends on rescue plan
fields.trailText: DaimlerChrysler, the troubled car group, is to cut 26,000 jobs over the next three years - 20% of its total US workforce - in an attempt to improve its ailing Chrysler division.
fields.body:
DaimlerChrysler, the troubled car group, is to cut 26,000 jobs over the next three years - 20% of its total US workforce - in an attempt to improve its ailing Chrysler division.

Two thirds of the dismissals, which will include compulsory redundancies as well as early retirement, will come into force before the end of this year.

Dieter Zetsche, the German executive brought in to restructure the American division last year, said that Chrysler's very survival depended on the rescue plan.

Chrysler has previously struggled to avoid bankruptcy in 1980 and the early 1990s.

The cuts were necessary to turn the loss making company around.

"To be truly competitive in today's auto industry environment, we need to be a more nimble company," he said.

The financial impact of the cuts is to be announced next month with the Stuttgart-based company's quarterly results.

Analysts expect the world's third largest car company to report a loss of some $1.25bn in the fourth quarter, largely because of the problems in the US.

Performance at the once profitable Chrysler has declined sharply since it merged with Germany's Daimler-Benz in 1998 following management upheavals and fierce competition.

At the time of the unprecedented $36bn deal, Jürgen Schrempp, Daimler's chief executive, described the partnership as a "marriage made in heaven".

But its performance has not matched the company's expectations. It had assumed growth in prices and sales which never came, and also had to spend millions of dollare on sales incentives.

On top of that there were production problems with its new PT Cruiser model.

Analysts said Daimler and Chrysler have been reluctant to share parts to cut costs, but this may now change.

Yesterday, Mr Schrempp expressed his confidence in the new German leadership of the US division and said: "These measures will help substantially to turn around the Chrysler unit."

The latest sign of restructuring failed to cheer investors, however. Shares in the company edged up only slightly in Germany and fell in New York after reaching a four year low last month.

Arndt Ellinghorst, an analyst at WestLB Panmure, described the job cuts as "a necessary step" but said "they're not out of the woods yet".

Many Wall Street analysts were particuarly concerned about the as yet unquantified cost of the restructuring.

Some believe DaimlerChrysler could end with a one-off charge of between $2bn-$3bn to pay for the redundancies and other changes. The company has indicated that it expects to make a loss for the whole of 2001.

Yesterday's job losses had been on the cards since the company announced a significant restructuring last November following the departure of many former Chrysler executives.

As part of the restructuring, six manufacturing plants in the US will fall idle before the end of 2002.

In an earlier move, the German company ordered its suppliers to cut prices by 5% from the beginning of this year, a move which is being vehemently opposed.

The problems have led to suggestions that the group could face attempts to break it up.

Leading manufacturers such as General Motors are said to be interested in parts of the business if Mr Schrempp's programme fails. Ford, Honda and Volkswagen would also be keen to pick over any DaimlerChrysler assets that were on the market.

fields.headline: Rescued chip factory for sale
fields.trailText: Wireless components maker Filtronic yesterday hung up a "for sale" sign at its manufacturing plant in Newton Aycliffe, in County Durham.
fields.body:
Wireless components maker Filtronic yesterday hung up a "for sale" sign at its manufacturing plant in Newton Aycliffe, in County Durham.

Filtronic's decision to sell or seek new financing for the unit comes 15 months after it responded to a government call to buy the former Fujitsu factory which had many employees from the prime minister's constituency.

Finance director John Samuel said that the factory, which manufactures semiconductors, was sapping resources from its core business of providing infrastructure for mobile phone companies.

Mr Samuel said he hoped to negotiate a deal where Filtronic would guarantee to buy a fixed quantity of semiconductors if a financial or strategic partner was prepared to take on the bulk of the plant's continuing investment requirements.

The Newton Aycliffe site had been mothballed when Filtronic bought it in September 1999 but has been transformed into a state of the art manufacturing facility after an investment of £50m.

Toby Thorrington, an analyst at ABN Amro, said: "It's a positive move but a contract needs to be signed before we can ascertain the ongoing risks."

Filtronic said that in the six months to November group sales climbed 57% to £147.6m, as pretax losses remained flat at £1.5m.

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at In My Hands: Memories of a Holocaust Rescuer, by Irene Gut Opdyke with Jennifer Armstrong; and Horrible Geography: Raging Rivers, by Anita Ganeri
fields.body:
In My Hands: Memories of a Holocaust Rescuer, by Irene Gut Opdyke with Jennifer Armstrong (Corgi, £4.99) Age 11+

The second world war is "done" by students at least once at school. These particular memories were determinedly relegated to the past until Holocaust denial stories horrified Opdyke to such an extent that she resolved to make her story public. The result is at once fascinating, engaging and riveting, the story of a girl's wily courage in saving lives while risking her own. She was utterly selfless and never reneged on her responsibility, an example of heroism illuminating the humanity behind the dates, maps and battles. I couldn't help but wonder - what would I have done?

Horrible Geography: Raging Rivers, by Anita Ganeri (Scholastic, £3.99) Age 7-12 yrs

As often happens, the outstanding success of Terry Deary's Horrible History series has distracted us from its merits as a means of informing children about the past, and of encouraging them to find out by reading books. These - and the Horrible Geography series - don't pretend to be school text books, but they sow seeds to make the teacher's job all the more enjoyable. By cajoling readers into thinking through factual narrative and cartoons, often relating them to the familiar, the author includes children in her voyage of discovery. Don't expect glossaries or indexes -these books don't work like that.

webTitle: Increasing numbers of students excluded over fees non-payment

fields.headline: Increasing numbers of students excluded over fees non-payment
fields.trailText: Thousands of students are being excluded from universities because they are unable to pay tuition fees, a university vice-chancellor said yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of students are being excluded from universities because they are unable to pay tuition fees, a university vice-chancellor said yesterday.

Peter Knight, vice-chancellor of the University of Central England in Birmingham, told a conference of university heads that they faced a serious problem of student debt, with increasing numbers of students dropping out of courses at universities.

"I estimate that several thousand students are not completing courses because they can't pay fees," he said. Dr Knight added that the loss of maintenance grants for living costs was the biggest factor leading to increasing student dropout rates. Many students were using loans to pay fees when they were intended for food and rent.

The clearest sign yet of the deepening levels of debt faced by students was a 15% drop in the revenue from university student bars at UCE over the last year, Dr Knight said. He said that a total of 197 students had been excluded from UCE last year.

The comments came at the annual meeting of the higher education funding council for England, the government body which allocates teaching and research grants to universities.

Dr Knight is the second university head in a week to warn that student debt has risen sharply since the government introduced fees and scrapped maintenance grants three years ago.

Diana Green, vice-chancellor of Sheffield Hallam University, told MPs on the House of Commons education committee that the number of students dropping out of university because of debt is increasing every year.

A report for university heads last July estimated that £21m in fee payments from students was outstanding. Students graduating last year were the first to be charged the £1,050 annual fee for their degree courses.

Dr Knight said that universities were witnessing a new underclass of students "who didn't know where the next meal was coming from". He said that some students now face "grinding poverty". Students from households with an annual income of between £15,000 and £30,000 were struggling the most, according to Dr Knight. These students have to pay contributions to fees, but also find it hard to get any extra money from parents to help them through their university careers.

webTitle: Pay new parents to stay at home - Harman

fields.headline: Pay new parents to stay at home - Harman
fields.standfirst: Commission calls for children's centres for every area  Family campaigners welcome proposals  Employers fear costs
fields.trailText: Pressure for parents to be paid to stay at home with their young children intensified last night after a new report called for "generous financial support" to be offered to those who do for the first three years of their child's life.
fields.body:
Pressure for parents to be paid to stay at home with their young children intensified last night after a new report called for "generous financial support" to be offered to those who do for the first three years of their child's life.

The independent childcare commission - set up to advise the government - suggested that increased child benefit or a "toddler tax credit" should be offered to all but the highest earners to enable them to pay for childcare, or to ensure they could afford to stay at home. The report is being scrutinised by the Treasury.

While the commission - chaired by the former social security secretary, Harriet Harman, - failed to come up with a recommended figure, family groups believe it should be at least £150, nearly half women's average weekly income of £337. The move would cost the Treasury around £3bn a year, but advocates argue that the cost is justified if childcare is recognised as a crucial area of public funding, alongside transport, hospitals and schools.

The proposals were welcomed by the government, but described by the employment minister, Margaret Hodge, and Treasury officials as "extremely expensive".

The report also called for a children's centre, providing high quality nursery and after-school care, to be set up in every area. Only 2,000 such centres exist and increasing the number to the required 10,000 would cost up to £8bn, says the Treasury.

The move, which would ensure childcare was no longer handled in a piecemeal way by different departments, would signal the government's commitment to solving a problem affecting at least 6m mothers.

The Maternity Alliance, which campaigns for young parents' rights, said that implementing the report would cost peanuts in comparison with the costs borne by 700,000 couples who become new parents each year. "At present, women are returning to work before they want to because they can't afford not to," said its director, Christine Gowdridge.

The Tories also backed the recommendations, with the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts, claiming they revealed a welcome shift away from penalising mothers who stay at home.

"No one's saying women must stay at home, but this shows a neutrality," he said. "This government has constructed a set of pressures in the tax and benefits system to favour parents to go out to work, but if you're at home you need assistance and support as well and this recognises that."

"This will fall on taxpayers whether they are individuals or businesses," said Ruth Lea, of the Institute of Directors. "I think there could be some resentment because they will be saying to themselves, 'I will be financing someone else's lifestyle choice'."

"It is important not to rule anything out prior to a budget, but clearly some of these proposals would be extremely expensive."

 A children's centre should be set up in every area to provide high-quality nursery and after school care. With one centre catering for two to three schools, up to 10,000 should be built. Would be funded by a combination of state and parental support

The money would be spent on childcare - either formal care, a nursery or childminder; or family care - parents or other relatives.

fields.headline: Germany flouts BSE rules again
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Britain was last night involved in a row with Germany over the effectiveness of Berlin's anti-BSE measures following the discovery of a consignment of imported beef breaching EU safety rules, the third within a fortnight.
fields.byline: James Meikle,  Andrew Osborn in Brussels, and Kate Connolly in Berlin
fields.body:
Britain was last night involved in a row with Germany over the effectiveness of Berlin's anti-BSE measures following the discovery of a consignment of imported beef breaching EU safety rules, the third within a fortnight.

Two inches of spinal column, potentially one of the most infected parts of a cow not displaying obvious signs of the disease, were found in a quarter of beef at a cutting plant in Eastbourne, Sussex.

Every carcass imported from Germany will now be checked by British officials before being allowed into the food chain. Sir John Krebs, chairman of the food standards agency, said the further breach "is totally unacceptable and raises questions as to how effectively the EU-wide controls are being enforced".

The agency has already asked the commission to read the riot act to Germany and any further discoveries could signal pressure for a ban on German imports.

Last year they totalled more than 4,000 tonnes, a third in carcass form, but there are growing suspicions that German producers are trying to dump surplus stocks. Con sumption in Germany may have dropped by as much as 50% in recent months.

The latest discovery, among 216 quarters of beef originating from Oldenburg, in Lower Saxony, follows the seizure of two consignments totalling 40 tonnes at Newry, County Down, on January 17 after remnants of spinal cord were found in two beef quarters originating from different German states.

German officials, told by the Guardian of the latest breach, said they had already pleaded with the states to be more careful. A spokeswoman for the federal ministry for consumer protection, nutrition and agriculture, said: "There is, as far as we are concerned , nothing wrong with the safety regulations we set for the meat itself.

"The problem is that one cannot check how each animal is examined before being loaded." The spokeswoman added that central government might have to take more control of meat inspection.

The consequences of the mounting crisis were spelled out by the EU agriculture commisssioner, Franz Fischler, to a meeting of farm ministers in Brussels yesterday. He warned the commission could not afford to support farmers by buying up the excess stocks expected from a 10% fall in con sumption across the EU this year, on top of an overall 27% plunge during recent months. Bans on imports by non-EU countries meant there were fewer outlets abroad and the decline in consumption may yet be far greater, despite an actual 3% rise in consumption in Britain where consumers are used to the BSE fears.

Instead all EU governments should make use of the cheaper six-month programme, introduced in earlier this month, to help farmers destroy older cattle. "It disposes of the lowest quality beef at the lowest price," said Mr Fischler. "The situation is more dramatic than we could have estimated before Christmas."

The programme has been organised following the EU's order that all animals over 30 months must be tested for BSE before they can be allowed as food. Germans have been reluctant to use the scheme, and have been given dispensation to reduce their testing age to 24 months, following the discovery of a 28-month old infected cow.

Britain has banned all beef from animals over 30 months old for nearly four years and has been reluctant to use any tests on younger animals since it says there are doubts about their ability to identify all cases of BSE before it is obvious.

webTitle: Canadian writers rally to angry teenage author

fields.headline: Canadian writers rally to angry teenage author
fields.standfirst: Boy jailed for reading story about blowing up his school
fields.trailText: The prize-winning novelists Margaret Atwood and Michael Ondaatje, and other Canadian writers, have rallied behind a 16-year-old boy who was held in jail for a month over Christmas after reading aloud a short story he had written about blowing up his school.
fields.body:
The prize-winning novelists Margaret Atwood and Michael Ondaatje, and other Canadian writers, have rallied behind a 16-year-old boy who was held in jail for a month over Christmas after reading aloud a short story he had written about blowing up his school.

The cream of the Canadian literary establishment made speeches in defence of freedom of expression and gave readings in the capital, Ottawa, at the weekend as the grateful teenager, wearing a pink panther tie, gloried in their attention and support.

The case became a cause célèbre after the boy, who is still a juvenile and cannot be named under Canadian law, was thrown in jail for writing a short story called Twisted, about a young man seeking revenge for the cruelty he had endured at the hands of his classmates.

His lawyer, Frank Horn, said the boy was taken into custody shortly after reading it aloud in drama class. But in the weeks since his release, it has become clear that he may be charged with more than simply writing a story with a violent ending.

Many of the authors at the rally were careful to say they did not know the full story of his detention. The court banned publication of the details of his arrest and the charges against him.

He has been charged with four counts of uttering death threats, only one of which is related to his short story. His younger brother was also in jail for several weeks over Christmas, accused of threatening to blow up two schools.

The writers have been criticised by the local teacher's union for turning the youth into a poster boy for free speech without knowing the facts.

The readings, poems and speeches, though, seemed to be intended to show support for a troubled young man rather than to turn him into a hero.

"Childhood can be hell," Ms Atwood said, opening the rally.

"One reason childhood can be hell is that as a child you can have no power, you can have no recourse and nobody who will actually believe you if you did go so far as to express, in one way or another, something that happened to you," she said, quoting from The Untouched Key, a book by the psychologist Alice Miller.

Ms Atwood, who won the Booker Prize last year for her 10th novel, The Blind Assassin, presented the young man with First Words, a collection of early writings by authors who went on to become famous.

Michael Ondaatje, author of The English Patient and Anil's Ghost, told the audience that writing about strong emotions such as anger could be therapeutic.

"I see myself as someone who has been saved by writing," he said.

"God knows what I would have been, become or how I would have ended up without it."

The boy, who lives near Cornwall, in south-eastern Ontario, said the rally was one of the best moments of his life. He vowed he would keep on saying thank-you until he was dead.

webTitle: Sorry world, I'm going under cover

fields.headline: Sorry world, I'm going under cover
fields.standfirst:
If Sharon really is elected next week, I'll employ the duvet defence

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Middle East usually only gets to the top of UK news bulletins if stone-throwers can be caught on camera in front of ancient monuments or if tracer bullets fly picturesquely against the night sky.
fields.body:
The Middle East usually only gets to the top of UK news bulletins if stone-throwers can be caught on camera in front of ancient monuments or if tracer bullets fly picturesquely against the night sky. So you may not have fully grasped what is going on in Israel. Unless the polls are proved spectacularly wrong, Ariel Sharon will be elected prime minister of Israel next Tuesday in place of Ehud Barak.

This is not just the routine of democracy: out with a failed government, in with the other lot. Ariel Sharon is a figure of the very far right: a man whose political life has been conducted so far out of the mainstream that it is hard to think of a sensible analogy - imagine Pat Buchanan going to the White House, or the Rev Ian Paisley, perhaps, on the steps of No. 10.

Furthermore, Sharon would assume office two weeks after a new American president, who is widely believed to have trouble locating the Middle East on a map; and at a time when Saddam Hussain has reached a level of prestige and popularity he never achieved even before the Gulf war. Israel has had bellicose governments before now; there have been callow US presidents; Saddam has been in full cry. But the three at once? There are moments to snuggle under the duvet and hope the world goes away.

The cheerful way of looking at this situation is the Nixon-in-China theory. Sometimes only rightwing leaders can achieve historic breakthroughs. Only Richard Nixon could have visited China in 1971 because any other president would have had Nixon screaming "betrayal". General de Gaulle broke the deadlock between France and Algeria on the same principle. It even happened in Israel, when Menahem Begin, the first Likud prime minister, signed the original Camp David deal with Egypt.

But that is one hell of a slender straw to cling to. The putative Israeli leader will certainly be a rare player on the modern world stage amidst leaders like our own, whose main experience of the sound of gunfire is mediating between Mandelson and Brown. Sharon looks like a bear and reputedly has the appetite of a gannet. He has been in the thick of all Israel's major wars, and the battles in between as well. He was, at times, a brilliantly successful commander (though there are undercurrents suggesting he was more inclined to be reckless with other lives than his own). In the 1950s, he ran a commando squad attacking Palestinian communities suspected of harbouring guerrillas (69 dead, including women and children, in the village of Qibbiya). As a minister, he was the chief begetter of the settlements, the Lebanon war and the current intifada, which would have happened anyway but was actually precipitated by his provocative visit to the Temple Mount last September. A state inquiry once found him unfit to serve as defence minister.

It is said that, at 72, he is getting forgetful, which would be a mercy because up to now he has forgotten nothing. Peace, he told the New Yorker recently, "cannot be achieved". Palestinian violence, he said, would be defeated by "creative" military action. Arafat is "a murderer and a liar". "The Arabs know me," he added ominously, "and I know them."

Amid all this, where is the Israeli leftwing? They have apparently surrendered and been re-educated. The writer of the New Yorker piece, Jeffrey Goldberg, went to see the author Amos Oz and found him in despair about Arafat's refusal to take the peace deal offered by Barak last July. "I suspect now that they prefer to give birth to Palestine on the battlefield," said Oz, "not the negotiating table. The battlefield is more heroic, more macho, perhaps - more Muslim, I don't know."

One hesitates to argue with Amos Oz about the Middle East, but I think he ignores the way public opinion works even in societies, like Palestine, where democracy is imperfect. A year earlier Barak's offer might have been snapped up. By July, the casual day-to-day brutality of the Israeli imperium, even under a supposedly liberal government, had infuriated the Palestinians again to the point where Arafat could have been outflanked by his own hard-liners - just like Barak. A deal would not have stuck.

You have to fear now that both sides yearn for the heroism of the battlefield, and war is an itch that simply has to be scratched. Both sides want to believe the worst of each other and, for their part, the Israelis want to prove it by electing a warmonger. Arafat has lately been calling Barak a fascist. The message from Sharon to him comes from 1 Kings: "My father hath chastised you with whips, but I will chastise you with scorpions."

(Notice to correspondents: emails on Mr Sharon welcome; no more on who did what to whom in 1000 BC, thank you.)

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Secrets Of Maps | File On 4 | Radio 1 Rock Show
fields.body:
Peter Barber, who runs the British Museum's map collection, offers a series of insights into The Secrets Of Maps (9.30am, Radio 4). His opening example comes from 1564, when the first really accurate map of Britain appeared. Gerard Mercator, ace cartographer of the period, denied responsibility and attributed it to "a friend". Though the map was hazy about Henry VIII's new ecclesiastical boundaries, it showed Britain's coastal areas in remarkable detail. There's a strong suspicion it was designed to help a planned Spanish invasion.

Julian O'Halloran looks at the environmental record of British farmers in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). Most current rows swirl around genetically modified crops. However, this programme deals with a far longer record of failing to safeguard our countryside and its resident wildlife. For decades both the government and the agricultural industry have ignored a series of European environmental initiatives. The inevitable consequence is that our farmers are now among the nation's worst polluters.

The Radio 1 Rock Show (12 midnight, Radio 1) features live music from Marilyn Manson (pictured). When he started his band in 1989 it was with the declared intention of affronting the bourgeoisie. His bizarre outfits and offensive stage antics saw him succeed beyond his wildest dreams. But the act doesn't come across quite as dramatically on unadorned sound waves.

fields.standfirst: River Nairn
fields.trailText: River Nairn
fields.body: My route to the river took me across a field and then to the narrowest part of a burn where not only I jump but also badger, pine marten, brown hare and rabbit at various times of the year. There was still some ice on the burn but the melt water from snow on the hills flanking the strath could not be denied, and there was plenty of open fast flowing water. Just before the river I passed under a group of ageing silver birch, and I wondered at their future, as they could well have been 60 years old, perhaps more, and overgrazing by sheep meant there were no young trees to take their place.At the edge of the birch trees a wet hollow had a dead iris bed, but there were signs of things to come as, despite the still present ice, there were bright green leaves about six inches high. I knew that this water would have frogs spawn in the middle of February, so not long to go! The river could be heard some distance away as a spate had started to form, and I approached cautiously as there is always the chance of seeing an otter. There were icicles on the very low alder branches where the rising water had splashed. After a bank fall on the far side, last summer three pairs of sand martins had dug out nest holes. In this section of the river the birds have a hit-or-miss chance, as even in the summer the spates can be high enough to wash out eggs or chicks. I headed upstream to my favourite part of the river where an oxbow had started to form; on the small sandy beach I knew there would be otter tracks. The otter's holt is a little way upstream under the roots of a large alder, and it is here that one day I will see Ratty, Mole and Toad rowing upstream with their picnic.

fields.headline: Pinkos and patriots
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: In most of the circles I move in, the Guardian is regarded as something of a red under the bed. The feeling is that if this country was left in the hands of its editors we would be governed from Bonn, overrun by asylum seekers and buggered on Sundays. My friends wouldn't buy it if you paid them.
fields.body:
In most of the circles I move in, the Guardian is regarded as something of a red under the bed. The feeling is that if this country was left in the hands of its editors we would be governed from Bonn, overrun by asylum seekers and buggered on Sundays. My friends wouldn't buy it if you paid them.

But they do read the Sunday Times. Well, if they haven't noticed yet, I have news for them. The Sunday Times supports traitors, while this paper is a pillar of patriotic rectitude. I know which I'd rather read.

The traitor the Sunday Times is supporting is, of course, Richard Tomlinson, the lying inadequate who was sacked by MI6 and wrote a book designed to inflict maximum damage, which they are now serialising.

But he didn't go to them first. He came here. A couple of years ago, before his book found a publisher that appears to be a front for the brutish Russian intelligence service the FSB, it was offered to the Guardian. Doubtless Mr Tomlinson took the Colonel Walrus Moustache view that this paper is staffed by people who want nothing more than to do Britain down.

But, according to my moles in the office, the Guardian did his book down instead and informed him that they didn't want it. The editorial view was that publishing Tomlinson's entire exposé would not be in the public interest and, unlike the Sunday Times, they gave that a higher priority than making a fast buck. Good for them. It makes me proud to work for this paper, pinko lefties and all.

It's not that I think MI6 should be a no-go area for newspapers. Last year I described to readers how I was interviewed by MI6 when I was a student. I broke the Official Secrets Act. I'm not an angel. I'm a journalist. But while I have teased people at MI6 and, I'm told, earned their disapproval, I would never do anything that I suspected would harm them or their work (and that kind of information has come my way over the years, quite unsolicited).

I appreciate that we pay for MI6 out of our taxes, that their job is to protect our freedom and if their job is made more difficult it threatens us all. To my mind British spies and British journalists are on the same side (or should be) and while I have never met the editor of this newspaper, he seems to thinks the same thing.

Being on the same side does not, however, mean doing the same job. Tomlinson's stories included the claim that Dominic Lawson, currently editor of the Sunday Telegraph, was used - unknowingly, he says - in his former position as editor of the Spectator to help out MI6 by providing journalistic cover for MI6 agents. The Guardian wrote that such MI6 behaviour is irresponsible and would risk lives. I think that is right. Just as British journalists have duties to MI6 operatives, so they have duties to us. Foreign correspondents, like double agents, are not protected by diplomatic cover. To expose them to the accusation that they are spies would be to put them in very real danger.

But there are other duties too. British newspapers are renowned for their nastiness to celebrities. But they are equally renowned for their freedom from government interference. MI6 officers may despise journalists, just as some hack writers buzzing with conspiracy theories despise them. But to compromise the integrity of British journalism is to compromise our standing in the world. In short, the reputation of its journalism is as important to British interests as that of MI6.

The Sunday Times, unfortunately, has damaged both. Tomlinson's' book tells us nothing new we need to know. It is a mixture of fact and fantasy, the facts centering on the detail of training and operational procedures. But its effect will be far from trivial.

According to Oleg Gordievsky, the highest ranking KGB officer ever to have defected to MI6, the book undermines "MI6's most potent weapon: its reputation for being able to keep secrets". It was, he says, "that reputation which persuaded me to take the gigantic risk of working for the organisation. Now that reputation has been seriously damaged." No wonder the FSB's employees have been grinning with delight over Tomlinson's book. "The (Sunday Times) has always insisted that it is loyal and patriotic," Gordievsky notes, "But in its obsession with mere sensation, which led the paper to publish Tomlinson's shameful story, it seems to have forgotten those two words."

I have cancelled my order for the Sunday Times. I hope others will do likewise until its editor, John Witherow, goes the way of other journalists used by the Russian intelligence services and is sacked. His paper is now mere bumph, not to be compared to this upstanding, patriotic journal, our Guardian.

fields.headline: Kennedy rules out deals withLabour
fields.standfirst: Electoral pact rejected as 'illiberal' government is condemned
fields.trailText: Electoral pact rejected as 'illiberal' government is condemned.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, yesterday buried his party's links with Labour when he ruled out the "preposterous" idea of an electoral pact because of Tony Blair's "illiberal" record on civil liberties.

In a speech to the rightwing Social Market Foundation, Mr Kennedy pledged to fight Labour up and down the country to woo voters who have been disillusioned with Labour's tilt to the right.

Mr Kennedy singled out the home secretary, Jack Straw, who has denounced "woolly Hampstead liberals", for particular criticism. "I wonder what Jack Straw will come up with next," Mr Kennedy said. "I have no doubt that if he'd been home secretary in Bethlehem he'd have arrested the three wise men for travelling with suspicious substances."

The Lib Dem leader cited a series of government initiatives, including plans to snoop on private e-mails and the removal of benefits from offenders, as reasons why he could no longer co-operate with Labour. Rounding on Mr Straw's child curfews, Mr Kennedy said: "That's just a hammer to crack a nut - the kind of policy you would expect from a Conservative home secretary, not an allegedly progressive one."

On the basis of such a record, Mr Kennedy laughed off the idea of forming electoral pacts with Labour, even in marginal seats where a deal could help to keep out the Tories. "All this recent talk of electoral pacts between ourselves and Labour is so preposterous," he said. "We will be fighting Labour hard on civil liberties, highlighting the government's illiberal policies on asylum and law and order. It is our territory and we are deeply disappointed with Labour's record."

Mr Kennedy's speech was his most extensive statement on why he wants to distance himself from Labour. The Lib Dem leader has already abandoned meetings of a joint Lib Lab cabinet committee, set up by his predecessor Paddy Ashdown, because of Labour's failure to hold a referendum on electoral reform.

But he showed last night that he believes there is little scope for co-operation with Labour until the government adopts the sort of approach on civil liberties championed by the former Labour home secretary and Lib Dem grandee, Lord Jenkins. "No pacts, no deals - anything else would be betraying the cause we believe in," Mr Kennedy said.

The Lib Dem leader, who flirted with the Labour party as a university student in Glasgow, echoed the thinking of many leftwing critics of the government when he criticised the Labour leadership for abandoning its early roots.

"There are too many signs of the centralising, bossy and collectivist tendency that was at the heart of Old Labour," he said. "Unfortunately it seems to be part of New Labour. It's a travesty of what this Labour government could have been. A concern for liberty should not be alien to the Labour party. It was deeply rooted in the ethical socialism of the early part of the last century."

Despite Mr Kennedy's attack on the government, it is widely expected that Labour and the Lib Dems activists will reach informal deals on the ground in the hope of keeping the Tories out. Deals in seats such as Enfield Southgate, where Michael Portillo was unseated by Labour in 1997, would be a significant blow to the Tories.

fields.headline: It was Alastair Campbell who led an iniquitous panic
fields.standfirst:
Yes, Mandelson deserved his fall, yet I still find the affair troubling

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Yes, Mandelson deserved his fall, yet I still find the affair troubling
fields.body:
In politics it may be naive to talk about the rules of natural justice. Politics is a trade where reality is often defined by forces that have no logic, no reason and no justice whatever. Hundreds of ministers reach the end of the road without a chance to testify in their own defence before being pushed over the cliff. Peter Mandelson, in particular, can hardly expect much sympathy if he forgets that this has always been so. Many a reputation has been terminally damaged by his whispers.

It's also true that a party and government which he instructed in the mysteries of spin has often seemed, under his hand, the acme of evasiveness. That he should be caught out in an apparently terminal evasion is too sweet to miss. If Geoff Hoon had made the call to Mike O'Brien, who would even have asked a question? Having been evasive once before, in the Robinson affair, didn't Mandelson sacrifice a portion of the presumption of innocence? The rejoicing over his end is coloured with the unmistakable sense that you don't need to look closely at these events to know that he deserved it.

Yet I think it's troubling. Unless you take the view that politics is so rough a trade that natural justice should bother only blithering ninnies, especially when the victim of injustice is a high-octane politician with an explosive capacity for self-destruction, the Mandelson case must be reckoned an iniquitous misfortune. The story reveals not so much a decisive prime minister as an inner court in total panic - led in that direction not by Tony Blair but Alastair Campbell.

After all, what happened? Mandelson gave an answer to the Observer the weekend before last about his role in the Hinduja passport matter which did not tell the whole truth. He did not lie, but said his private office had been in touch with their oppos in the Home Office. It was only when Campbell told journalists on Monday that Mandelson had had no personal involvement whatever - a statement the minister had never made, either publicly or privately - that the world was substantively misled.

This stark claim was then followed by an equally stark contradiction, again through Campbell, to the effect that Mandelson had, after all, personally called O'Brien, the passport minister, a confession that carried the insinuation - in the eyes of a voracious media - that this was a passports-for-cash affair which Mandelson had been trying to cover up. This, again, strikes me as misleading. It is apparent that both accounts - the story of private office contacts as well as the story of a Mandelson-O'Brien call - are true, and until the content of these calls is known it is impossible to say which, if either, brought any improper influence to bear on O'Brien.

Since the fact of the personal contact between Mandelson and O'Brien was likely to be revealed anyway, via a parliamentary answer, it is hard to read an automatically sinister purpose into the half-truth Mandelson told. However, panic was by Monday evening setting in, and the epicentre of it was Campbell and his symbiotic relationship with the media: the media's appetites, their suspicion of Mandelson, their love of the kill, his fear of that, his fear of imminent self-contradiction, his own ready indulgence in the black-and-white clarities which is the only way the tabloid press reports the most subtle of political events.

Blair, I learn, did not favour the first story being changed. He thought an urgent inquiry into what he regarded as a stupid mess was the way forward. He also did not favour Mandelson going on television on Tuesday night, straight from several hours' wrangling with Northern Ireland politicians, and inadequately briefed on what the Home Office was saying about his call to O'Brien, or any other considered line to take. The call to do those interviews was Campbell's. At 10 minutes' notice, Mandelson did three of them, his jumbled syntax only adding to the confusion and, even more, to the public impression that he was being thoroughly evasive.

What had been created, in short, was an appalling muddle. The nuanced truth was replaced by contradictory starkness. No serious attempt was made to find out from Mandelson's officials their version of the events that the Home Office was determined to depict as keeping Jack Straw's and Mike O'Brien's faces clean. In the course of Straw's rush, quite properly, to own up to the Mandelson-O'Brien call being made, decisive importance was attached to it which closer investigation might have discovered - may still discover, through the Hammond inquiry - it did not merit.

The response to this muddle, however, was brutally decisive. Fear overcame justice to an extent which, even in rough old politics, has few precedents and, as far as the outcome was concerned, none that I can recall. Blair saw Mandelson, told him that the Home Office papers were evidence enough, and demanded his resignation. Campbell fluttered in and out, saying that the lobby journalists, awaiting their victim, could be delayed no longer. Lord Chancellor Irvine was called in, to give the execution his blessing, which he did without demur, and the verdict was pronounced.

Had any other minister been involved in this - see Keith Vaz - the entire effort of Blair and Campbell would have been to await the Hammond inquiry. It is a time-honoured device, and, where the facts are confused, a legitimate one. The inquiry might have concluded that Mandelson was indeed at fault. It may still discover that the minister for the dome was making offers and/or applying improper pressures. But at least all relevant witnesses would have been heard. The government would have been spared the twin embarrassment it now faces: both the destruction of one of its most prominent ministers and the evidence that it itself behaved with peremptory injustice.

Its answer will be political. We are close to an election, it will say, and can't afford to see this saga run on indefinitely. Peter is trouble, he is anyway "detached", he may even - the implication disgracefully runs - have slightly lost his marbles. Campbell also suggests that Mandelson was drifting from the centre of things, a quite laughable proposition to any official who is aware of the innumerable phone calls that have passed between Mandelson and Blair every week of every month, up to and including this one.

It's understandable, things having got to where they were last Wednesday, that this view was taken. But they didn't need to get that far. I think we should be fully aware that excessive respect for media passions was responsible for the importunate way in which the uninvestigated subtleties of this essentially minor affair were swept aside. This was due to the personality of Mandelson, a man who has attracted to himself a notoriety that makes him hated as well as perpetually suspected. Such reverence for the headlines is also, of course, an instinct dinned into New Labour by none other than P Mandelson. But the fact remains that he has been ruined, by a leader and his henchman, with other ministers gathering round, who needed his corpse more than they needed the truth.

Such reverence for the headlines is also, of course, an instinct dinned into New Labour by none other than P Mandelson. fields.headline: Murder most fowl
fields.trailText: The Pigeon Murders | Second Sight | The Real Stephen Hawking
fields.body:
Mark MacDonald can claim to be the world's least successful detective. Mark, who appeared in The Pigeon Murders (National Geographic), works for the American equivalent of the RSPCA and I feel he might have sneaked up on his quarry more easily if he hadn't been festooned with badges saying so. A cereal killer was at work in New York. Someone, as Tom Lehrer put it, was poisoning pigeons in the park. A thousand corpses were counted. The real total was clearly far higher.

It is customary in any detective series for the killer to get away with murder two or three times before our hero twigs him. But 1,000 corpses and counting...

Mark consulted an animal cracker. Dr Zee was an animal behaviourist whose real name, Zawistowski, was such that even New York had thrown in the towel. Dr Zee said it was like looking at ourselves in a feathery mirror. Pigeons are the creatures most like us. Most like Americans would be nearer the mark. You would be looking at a pigeon for some time before you were reminded of a violet by a mossy stone half-hidden from the eye. Pigeons are sociable, cheerful and overweight.

Late at night in his office, when the lights were low, Mark, who has clearly read Raymond Chandler, brooded moodily over his lack of success. "By no means am I putting this thing to sleep until I can walk through the door with a body."

Like Philip Marlowe, he tends to get entangled with dames. It is a sure sign of advancing years when a woman becomes dedicated to feeding pigeons. Pigeons are so touchingly grateful for their grub, and there is nothing like a clean plate to warm a mother's heart. This does, however, get the pigeon fancier into fairly constant rows with her neighbours. Mark interposed his badge-emblazoned body between a maidenly lady with looped hair like Jane Eyre, and a big bruiser in unflattering shorts. Their exchange was brief but animated. New Yorkers, like pigeons, tend to play out their lives in public.

Bruiser: "This woman is crazy. She's had me in the precinct six times accusing me of poisoning the pigeons, which I have not. She's nuts in the head." Maiden lady: "She's beaten me up four times. She's very dangerous. You can tell by the way she talks that she's not a nice person." Bruiser: "The ASPCA have asked her not to feed the pigeons in this block." Maiden lady: "She lies! She lies!"

Mark's sigh came from his substantial boots. "Ahhh! Never fails. Every time I come down here I gotta referee some boxing match or soap opera."

Had Ken Livingstone been aware of the passions roused by pigeons before went he went to New York, he would have packed a mac.

DCI Ross Tanner has problems of his own. Not only is he losing his sight but, at climactic moments, he gets a roaring in his ears and subliminal flashes of insight. In Second Sight (BBC 1) the daughter of a media mogul ("One of Tony Blair's inner circle") wakes up on the eve of her wedding to find herself drenched in her murdered fiancé's blood. Tony will be simply furious. This is X-Files territory. It reminds me of Gerard's Cottage Flora. Which may require some explanation. Gerard, the Titchmarsh of his day, said among other wise things that "Far-fecht and dere-bought is best for ladies." They do not come any more far-fetched than Second Sight. The ladies will like it. Like sex, it's quite enjoyable if you remember not to laugh.

The Real Stephen Hawking (Channel 4) found itself somewhat short of stout sticks to beat him with. He seems to have all the attributes of a star: brilliant, attractive and tending to see things from the standpoint of the sun. The synthesized voice, alien, oracular, makes everything he says mesmeric. The programme did not mention that, when he left his first wife after 25 years, he married the wife of the man who devised his voice synthesizer. What he is not, as he cheerfully agrees, is Einstein.

His mother described the day she realised he had motor neurone disease. He was about 20. "He came back at Christmas and we went skating on the lake at St Albans. He fell down and couldn't get up. So we went and had coffee and then he told me." You can feel the crispness, the skitter of the skates, the hot coffee, the ice round the heart. It does not seem coincidental that Hawking became the world expert in black holes.

webTitle: Unilever reduces its stock in £700m deal

fields.headline: Unilever reduces its stock in £700m deal
fields.trailText: Oxo, the gravy granules synonymous with the traditional British sunday roast, are to fall into American hands as part of a €1bn (£700m) clear-out of brands by Unilever.
fields.body:
Oxo, the gravy granules synonymous with the traditional British sunday roast, are to fall into American hands as part of a €1bn (£700m) clear-out of brands by Unilever.

The gravy business is to be bought by Campbell Soup Company, the New Jersey-based firm which is the world's largest soup manufacturer.

Included in the transaction is Batchelors - the maker of Cup-a-Soup, noodles and canned vegetables - and a variety of Belgian, French and German food businesses.

The sale was forced on Unilever by the EC as a condition of its recent £14bn takeover of US group Bestfoods.

A Unilever spokesman said: "We recognised when we did the Bestfoods deal that there were areas of overlap. The sale of Batchelors and Oxo is an unfortunate consequence."

Invented by a German chemist in the 1840s, Oxo gravy granules were intended to bring the goodness of beef to underprivileged households. The brand is best known for the Oxo family which featured in a series of television commercials running from 1958 to 1999.

Campbell will inherit 1,300 employees at six factories across Europe. These include more than 800 staff at sites in Worksop and Ashford.

The deal doubles the size of Campbell's European operations to just under $1bn (£650m). A spokesman for the US company said: "This is a major step forward for us. We're clearly very interested in growing these brands."

Campbell is built around condensed soup, which is particularly popular in the US. The firm has been keen to obtain more powdered products, which are characteristic of the European sector.

As evidence of its record of enhancing brands, Campbell pointed to its purchase of Homepride cook-in sauces six years ago. It ran into some flack at the time from a Labour MP, who tabled a Commons motion calling for a boycott of its products following the loss of 130 jobs at a Homepride factory in Cumbria.

Unilever recently said it wanted to streamline its business from 1,600 brands to 400 well known names. Its purchase of Bestfoods included Knorr soups, which the company said had "more international reach" than Batchelors.

Among the other businesses in yesterday's deal were Irish sauces firm McDonnells, French mayonnaise maker Lesieur and German pasta sauces company Raguletto. The transaction is subject to EC approval.
