webTitle: Relatives gather aid as UK steps up relief effort

fields.headline: Relatives gather aid as UK steps up relief effort
fields.trailText: In an underground car park of the Shree Swamimarayan Hindu temple in Harrow, north London, 250 volunteers gathered yesterday to sort through a mountain of donated clothes and blankets.
fields.body:
In an underground car park of the Shree Swamimarayan Hindu temple in Harrow, north London, 250 volunteers gathered yesterday to sort through a mountain of donated clothes and blankets.

It was a scene mirrored across Britain. Women and girls gathered at long tables to separate piles of saris, children's outfits, men's shirts and trousers, while men stacked up the sacks of clothing.

In parliament yesterday, the international development secretary, Clare Short, announced that the government was making £10m available to help deal with the Indian earthquake. Ministers have agreed to draw on the government's reserves to support the emergency relief effort.

Three aircraft carrying 1,200 tents and other shelter items from the government's emergency stockpile in Staffordshire will fly out from Britain.

A fourth will be dispatched from Ostend, carrying 10 sets of trauma equipment and plastic sheeting.

"Organisation by the Indian government is good, but international help is needed to ensure that all who survived the earthquake but have lost everything are provided with healthcare and other basic essentials," Ms Short said.

At the Harrow temple, volunteers were preparing to fly to Gujarat to assess the damage for themselves.

They are also negotiating with the Indian government to have to donations airlifted to where they are most needed.

The temple's vice president, Valji Dabasia, said: "We're separating out all the warm clothes and blankets and we are arranging an airlift. All the people are sleeping outside now and although it is very hot during the day, it is only five or six degrees at night.

"I'm very proud of the response from the public. We started collecting donations on Saturday and by Sunday night this whole car park was full of clothes. The people here are all from the Kutch district. It will affect someone's brother or someone's sister.

"We are sending a team from here to investigate what is going on - many people here want to know if their families are dead or alive."

The temple volunteers want to raise £100,000 for the relief effort and Mr Dabasia has estimated that they are already more than halfway to their target. One volunteer, Nisha Katani, 15, said she was proud to take part. "My dad's family is from there. I've given some of my jackets and T-shirts. I don't mind because it's going to a good cause."

But there was also anger that the media had failed to make the disasterits top priority. "Yesterday I turned on the television and the first headline was about Mandelson and the Hinduja brothers," Rama Gopal, 41, said. "I think it is disgusting when you think of the number of British citizens in India at the moment.."

At the Shree Swamimarayan in Woolwich, east London, a similar relief effort was under way. "It's been a worrying time but there's a lot of optimism as well," said a spokesman, Bhaven Patak. "People say no news can be good news. Three or four members of the temple are going out as volunteers. They will answer the specific questions that we have about specific families and assess what we need to here."

Mr Patak said there had been particular horror at damage caused to temples in Bhuj. At one 200-year-old temple, one of three intricately carved towers collapsed. At another, female worshippers were killed by falling masonry.

He urged Britain to do more. "A lot of our members donated between £200 and £500 initially. Now they have raised that to between £2,000 and £2,500. The British government should now promise a lot more than they initially promised."

webTitle: Australia introduces moonlit races for virtual punters

fields.headline: Australia introduces moonlit races for virtual punters
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Three stretches of the Australian outback will soon resound to the thunder of horses and the scamper of greyhounds racing through the night on racecourses uniquely dedicated to internet betting.
fields.body:
Three stretches of the Australian outback will soon resound to the thunder of horses and the scamper of greyhounds racing through the night on racecourses uniquely dedicated to internet betting.

Punters will not be allowed at the trackside of the remote strips, now being built at Waikerie, Millicent and Port Augusta, in South Australia. The horse and greyhound races will be held under floodlights in front of television cameras beaming the late-night action live over the internet, just in time for British gamblers to place an early morning wager.

The A$30m (£11m) scheme is the brainwave of John Hodgman, who became frustrated by the TV coverage of racing while working in sports television production five years ago.

His company, Teletrak, will stage races on straight courses, enabling the overhead and trackside cameras to stay much closer to the action than they can during public races on circular tracks.

The company says the darkness will produce close-up images ideal for digital com pression and live transmission on the net. The time difference means the races will reach Europe in the morning, when there is currently little live race action to bet on.

The South Australian government approved the development last month, and contractors have just finished the earth-moving stage for a 700m dog track and a 1,600m trotting track at Waikerie.

Teletrak plans to hold the first greyhound and trotting races - in which horses pull light carts - by the end of the year. Thoroughbred races will start shortly afterwards.

"It won't be so much like the charge of the light brigade, more like drag racing," Richard Law, Teletrak's South Australian development manager, told the newspaper the Australian.

Three Australian states refused to have the sites, and the South Australian Democrats led opposition to the scheme in parliament.

"We've had a dramatic expansion of gambling opportunity within South Australia, with no real government responsibility for the consequences of that," their parliamentary leader, Mike Elliott, said.

Although local people will not be able to watch the races at the tracks, the greyhound and trotting races will "create an enormous local attraction" and encourage more gambling in the state, he said.

The meetings are just the latest in a long tradition of wacky races in a country renowned for its love of sports betting. Australia's 16-track camel racing circuit is thriving: the prizemoney for the races, including the Arab Emirates-funded Sheikh Zayed Cup in Sydney, is worth more than A$100,000 (£37,000).

Cane toad contests are big business in north Queensland, where the giant toads are painted and raced. There is a regular lizard race in south Queensland, and Derby, in Western Australia, holds an annual cockroach race.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: ING plans huge job cuts
fields.body:
ING plans huge job cuts

ING Barings is today expected to announce plans to cut its 2,500 City workforce by as much as a half as it scales back its investment banking operation and centralises in its Amsterdam headquarters.

The announcement is expected to help alleviate the cloud which has been hanging over the City since ING, which rescued Barings in 1995, admitted last year it was conducting a strategic review of its business. The Dutch bank is expected to sell its US investment banking operation to its rival ABN Amro.

Disney to shut internet site

Walt Disney yesterday said it was closing its internet portal business Go.com with the loss of 400 jobs.

The entertainment company will also dissolve its online tracking stock, Disney Internet Group, which will be converted into ordinary shares of the parent group in March. The Disney Internet Group has lost around $1.5bn since it was set up in 1998.

Disney said it would take a hit of $790m related to the write off of intangible assets and a further $25m to $50m against job losses and fixed assets.

M&S appoints creative chief

Marks & Spencer's attempts to reinvent itself were accelerated yesterday with the appointment of Yasmin Yusuf in the new role of creative director of clothing.

Ms Yusuf, who will start in April, is joining the troubled retailer from the Warehouse group, where she has been managing director from 1996.

Old English hit by flood costs

The operator of traditional pubs Old English Inns issued a profits warning yesterday, saying that 30 of its outlets had been hit by damage or disruption after last year's floods.

The firm said insurance claims could take a year to settle, and it would be liable to pay an excess of about £10,000 on each of the pubs affected.

The setback sent Old English Inns' shares down 5.5p to 88p. It came as the company was beginning to rebuild its credibility in the City, following a series of profit warnings two years ago.Most of the pubs affected were in the Midlands and the west of England.

Hutchings in dismissal talks

Lawyers acting for Greg Hutchings, the former Tomkins chief executive, have opened talks with the engineering group aimed at securing a compensation package estimated at £5m.

Mr Hutchings left under a cloud last October following allegations that he had acted improperly by making personal use of company houses and jets, charges he always denied.

Mr Hutchings is claiming wrongful dimissal and breach of contract by the company. His lawyers say the report into his activities undertaken for Tomkins by Ernst & Young clear Mr Hutchings of any breach of contract or illegality.

Factory shuts

Pifco, the maker of Russell Hobs toasters and kettles, has announced its factory in Lichfield, Staffordshire, will close tomorrow with the loss of 150 jobs.

webTitle: Scotia administrators back cancer drug appeal

fields.headline: Scotia administrators back cancer drug appeal
fields.trailText: Biotechnology company Scotia Holdings has called in administrators less than a week after a devastating decision by European medical regulators to reject its treatment for head and neck cancer, Foscan.
fields.body:
Biotechnology company Scotia Holdings has called in administrators less than a week after a devastating decision by European medical regulators to reject its treatment for head and neck cancer, Foscan.

Accountants Ernst & Young were appointed yesterday to try to salvage the business, which is likely to run out of cash by the end of March.

Scotia, with 130 employees, is the biggest casualty yet in Britain's biotech industry. Three years ago it was worth more than £500m.

Despite the delicate finances, the administrators are likely to press on with an appeal to the European Medicines Evaluation Agency over Foscan, which cost more than £30m to develop. Joint administrator Andrew Wollaston said: "If the company's going to survive, it may be sensible to appeal. I think we've got enough cash to see us through an appeal."

Scotia has between £6m and £7m cash. To see through an appeal, which could take months, it is likely to have to cut outgoings or raise funds through disposals.

Assets include a business researching lipids - fatty molecules - in Nova Scotia, Canada. It also has "weight loss" food ingredient, Olibra, licensed to US food company General Mills, which is working towards putting it in breakfast cereals.

Analysts believe it may be possible to raise money by selling these operations. However, Scotia has convertible loans of £50m which must be repaid unless its share price reaches 340p by 2002. The shares were suspended at 18.5p last week.

Mr Wollaston said there was "every chance" of the company surviving, and that there had already been expressions of interest for parts of the business.

webTitle: Widow loses £114,000 payout over drowned husband / no byline

fields.headline: Widow loses £114,000 payout over drowned husband / no byline
fields.trailText: A widow lost the £114,200 damages she was awarded after her husband drowned in front of their children when the appeal court ruled yesterday that he should have known of the dangers.
fields.body:
A widow lost the £114,200 damages she was awarded after her husband drowned in front of their children when the appeal court ruled yesterday that he should have known of the dangers.

Lord Justice May said that if the award had been allowed to stand, "no swimming" notices would have to go up around every pond, reservoir, waterway and coastal stretch in the country to avoid liability.

The judge, sitting with Lord Justice Schiemann and Lord Justice Latham, allowed an appeal by the National Trust against a ruling that it was responsible for the death of Kevin Darby.

He took his wife, Diane, and four of his children to the trust's Hardwick Hall in Derbyshire on a hot day in August 1997. Mr Darby, who was 44, swam to the centre of one of the five ponds while his children paddled at the edges.

Lord Justice May said visitors to the hall often swam in the pond and Mr Darby was a regular visitor who played a game of "hidey boo" in the 10 feet of water to amuse his children. But after five minutes, he called to his wife who "knew he was in trouble", said the judge.

Another visitor found him under the water after 15 minutes, but Mr Darby died a few days later in hospital without regaining consciousness.

Mrs Darby, of, Bramley Vale, Derbyshire, who has five chil dren, was awarded the damages at Derby county court after an assistant recorder found that the trust had breached its duty of care to visitors.

The recorder said the trust had failed to provide adequate warnings and had failed to provide life-saving equipment at the pond. But Lord Justice May said: "The risks to competent swimmers using this pond were perfectly obvious. There were no special risks which the National Trust should have been aware of.

"Notices saying 'no swimming' would have told Mr Darby no more than he already knew."

webTitle: Chief quits as Cammell Laird fights for survival

fields.headline: Chief quits as Cammell Laird fights for survival
fields.trailText: John Stafford, chief executive and architect of a renaissance at Cammell Laird yesterday resigned after his shipbuilding company plunged to a first half loss amid a crisis over a cancelled £51m contract.
fields.body:
John Stafford, chief executive and architect of a renaissance at Cammell Laird yesterday resigned after his shipbuilding company plunged to a first half loss amid a crisis over a cancelled £51m contract.

A slimmed down board of the Birkenhead-based group is talking to Royal Bank of Scotland about a bridging loan which it needs in place by the end of April if the company is to survive. The future of the company has been in question since Italian shipowner Costa Crociere abruptly cancelled a contract for a midship section for a cruise vessel.

Results released yesterday showed the initial impact of the Costa crisis on Cammell. A £7.7m interim profit last year turned into a £3.5m loss in the six months to October 31. The interim dividend has been lowered compared to last year's 0.25p.

Mr Stafford has been replaced in the short-term by finance director Jon Schofield in one of several changes designed to "ensure the optimum development and focus of our international operations".

Mr Stafford resigned from his £124,000 job without compensation though he remains a 25% shareholder and will have a continuing, although unpaid, role as a consultant.

The former Grant Thornton accountant bought the Cammell name from VSEL in 1995 and combined it with his own ship repair business before floating the shipbuilder on the stock market three years ago.

Cammell soon became a stock market darling but its stock has fallen from a year high of 147p to 10p in recent months after the City took fright at a foreign investment strategy followed by the Italian debacle. Last night the stock ended the day up 3.5p at 15.5p.

Juan Kelly, chairman of Cammell, said the non-delivery of the Costa Classica would have a significant impact on financial results for the full year. Well-placed sources said the figure was likely to be around £34m.

The company restated its strategy of becoming an international business with yards in Marseilles, Portland in Oregon and Gibraltar.

Despite its immediate financial troubles, the longer term trading position looked bright with an order book standing at £41m.

Cammell said it was still negotiating with Costa about the cancelled contract and said it may take legal action.

The UK company is also waiting to see whether the government will improve financial guarantees that would bring a contract for two cruise ships to Birkenhead.

fields.headline: One fine day
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow and tomorrow are bound to be worse, moans Donald Hiscock
fields.trailText: Tomorrow and tomorrow are bound to be worse, moans Donald Hiscock
fields.body:
We all have good days and bad days at work. My last good day was in February 1996, so there was no reason to expect anything more than the usual frustrating experience when I turned up at college yesterday.

The first unusual thing was that I found a parking space. It was actually on the college site where I was to start teaching. Usually we have a park and run scheme, which means leaving the car on a patch of wasteland and dashing for the shuttle bus that connects the college sites all over town.

The bus is driven by Brian, a retired physical education lecturer who must have spent the better part of his teaching career moaning at students for forgetting bits of their kit as he drove them to away fixtures. Now Brian gets his kicks by putting the shuttle bus into spaces tighter than the principal's staffing budget.

But I missed all that yesterday morning. I had found the one unreserved parking bay outside the administration building. I parked next to Murray Whelk's new Audi, tossed my Hillman Imp key fob nonchalantly into the air and entered the building in a state of curious calm.

I was early. I was able to saunter along the corridors. I can't remember the last time I did any sauntering on the college premises. I stopped to read a notice or two and then bumped into my mate Colin from maths.

"Hello," he said cheerily. It was at this moment that I began to suspect that things were not right.

"How are you?" I inquired before I could stop myself.

"Good news. It's arrived." He had a glint in his eyes. "My new trundle wheel." Colin rattled off its features. I heard the words "digital", "self-cleaning" and "envy" several times before I left him in personal elation as he wandered the corridors only too willing to share his news with those too slow to avoid eye contact.

I found myself with 10 minutes to do some lesson preparation, but I decided that this would spoil that freshness of delivery for which I am sure I am admired by my students.

I got to the classroom early. I made another attempt to clean the whiteboard. The previous week an evening class lecturer in English language had used the wrong sort of pen. It would be at least a fortnight before someone came to clean away a list of anal synonyms. My class had got used to me trying to write the key themes in Hamlet in the spaces between "hole" and "butt" and the like.

I had a good lesson. Everyone turned up and handed in their assignments, including Roxanne. This was, again, another moment when I began to suspect that things were not right. I was even able to conduct a serious discussion on Hamlet's relationship with Ophelia. Hey, I was on a literary roll.

At the end of the lesson Roxanne asked for clarification of the essay title I had written on the board. From where she was sitting it looked like: "How far do you agree that Hamlet is a mad arse?" Of course what I had really written was "Is Hamlet a bum?" And everything went well for the entire day. So it is with trepidation that I depart for college this morning. I can't believe that I can have two good days in a row. If there are patterns in life, I reckon I have got five years to prepare for the next one. Have a good day.

fields.headline: Learn...dog grooming
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
What a lovely cut! How kind . . . but I'm actually trying to let my hair grow.

Not you, the dog. Oh right. Yes. I did it myself.

That's clever. Well, I'm a dog groomer.

Fascinating. What does that entail? Generally grooming involves bathing, shampooing, drying, clipping and brushing. Different breeds, and especially show dogs, may require specialist skill. We look carefully at teeth and ears and treat any parasites.

What do you need for the job? A love of animals is a basic requirement plus knowledge of breeds, patience, good customer-care skills and eye for detail.

What qualifications can you train for? The main one to work towards is City & Guilds 775 in dog grooming. You usually need about 18 months' experience with an established groomer to start the course. Do ensure that tutors for this course already hold this qualification, plus preferably an advanced dog-grooming diploma. Some appropriate NVQ qualifications are currently being developed for people already working with a groomer.

webTitle: Job opportunities in the new post-16 order

fields.headline: Situations vacant
fields.standfirst: There are lots of jobs on offer in the new post-16 order, but people don't seem to want them, reports  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: There are lots of jobs on offer in the new post-16 order, but people don't seem to want them, reports Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Amid the frantic preparations for April 1 and the new landscape in post-16 education, an awkward north-south divide is opening up.

Put simply, there are not enough people to staff the new learning and skills councils in the south of England and the midlands, and there are too many candidates for the equivalent jobs in the north.

The obvious solution - persuading the surplus personnel from the north of England to migrate south to fill the vacancies - has hit equally obvious snags.

Many people are reluctant to uproot their families. And property prices in the south of England add a major disincentive to movement.

The problem stems partly from the government's responsibility to re-employ 5,700 people who are losing their jobs in the dismantling of the old order - the 72 Training and Enterprise Councils, the Further Education Funding Council and those bits of the Department for Education and Employment which fitted in with this.

Under the Tupe (transfer of undertakings, protection of employment) regulations, those 5,700 have first bite at the new posts in the Learning and Skills Council and in the 47 local learning and skills councils which are due to be in operation on April 1.

The problems which the transitional managements face are, firstly, that there are only 4,700 jobs available in the new system - 500 at the Coventry headquarters and the rest spread around the 47 local councils. And, secondly, there are too many people entitled to Tupe transfer in the north for the numbers of new jobs on offer.

A spokesman explained: "We have about 1,000 more people than expected at the end of the day.

"However there are about 700 vacancies across the south, the midlands and at the national office which we can't currently fill."

He said that there was no question of the £50m, which ministers have repeatedly estimated as the total efficiency saving to be achieved by the learning and skills reforms, being put at risk in reaching a solution to the imbalance. Those driving the transition were also adamant that there will be no redundancy payments for staff who choose to leave rather than take up a vacancy.

Otherwise those running this vast and immensely complicated transition aim to treat those affected by the problem with sympathy, the spokesman stressed.

"We've given a fairly broad undertaking that there will be no compulsory redundancies.

"There will be surpluses of staff in some areas, but we will carry that surplus over an indeterminate time and hope it will be resolved by natural wastage."

He added that relocation packages are on offer to try to coax people to migrate. And there will be money available to people whose journeys to work are significantly increased.

Everyone entitled to Tupe had to fill in a "job matching" form briefly describing their current job. The aim was to slot people into suitable new positions, and most people were soon matched, said the spokesman.

It was hoped to make the bulk of the transfers by the end of January.

"The process is about ensuring that people are happy about the matching process and where they are going to be."

On Friday an "intensive" campaign advertising the remaining vacancies was launched on internal computer networks throughout the organisations. And this week a national and local media advertising campaign will begin to try to fill the southern vacancies externally.

webTitle: A last-ditch attempt to sort out lecturers' salaries

fields.headline: Pay crisis
fields.standfirst: Francis Beckett on a last-ditch attempt to sort out lecturers' salaries
fields.trailText: Francis Beckett on a last-ditch attempt to sort out lecturers' salaries
fields.body:
Time is running out for a solution to the further education lecturers' pay problem. On Friday college principals meet in London to hear top managers from Derby Wilmorton, Sheffield and Guildford colleges outline a sophisticated scheme which, they hope, will look sufficiently like performance-related pay to satisfy the government and the hardliners among the college principals; and sufficiently unlike it to satisfy lecturers and their unions. Only then can the government's £50m allocated for pay be released.

The three principals have had discreet but unmistakable government encouragement. They have had secret meetings with lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks and top civil servant David Forrester, after Mr Forrester visited Wilmorton.

Pay is between 10% and 35% behind that of schoolteachers - and that's in the colleges which implemented last year's 3.3% pay rise. In other colleges the gap is even bigger. Guildford principal Lynn Sedgemore's search for a solution is motivated by her serious recruitment problems.

The main lecturers' union, Natfhe, held a pay conference last week at which, against the advice of their leaders, members demanded an immediate pay claim and negotiations before the end of January, and threatened industrial action beginning with a one day strike on May 1. When even the general secretary, Paul Mackney, the most effective leader the union has had for years, cannot hold the line, the warning signs are unmistakable.

"Our members clearly were saying, we've had four years of this government, we have been very patient, but now we have had enough" he says.

So it is vital that next week's meeting comes out with something that Mr Mackney can sell to his members.

The Association of Colleges is proposing a statement that staff "engaged with teaching and learning with students" should "have access over the next two years, according to each college's priorities, within the agreed guidelines, to about £800-£1000, where they meet the minimum criteria - possession of the appropriate qualifications, and evidence of continuing professional development".

A further £800-£1000 would reward teams or individuals demonstrating "their contribution to raising standards and supporting others". And an advanced lecturer pay grade would "recognise advanced practitioners".

Sue Dutton, the AoC's deputy chief executive, is adamant that this does not amount to performance related pay.

"It's not about divisive mechanisms - rewarding some not others. We strongly desire a system where all members of the teaching profession in further education can benefit from the new arrangements."

The Association of Colleges cannot intervene to try to put an end to some of the cruder performance pay schemes that have set lecturers against the whole idea. Leek College, for example, has managers mark lecturers on 36 performance criteria which include: "Contribution to cheerful atmosphere in college"; "interpersonal skills/ behaviour;" "customer care"; "cooperation"; "proactivity; " and "loyalty".

It's no coincidence, says Mackney, that Leek is one of the colleges which refused to pay the 3.3%, and that its principal, Tony Price, received a 14% increase last December on his £64,119 salary.

All of which leaves the three speakers at the conference with a formidable task. fields.bodyText: Time is running out for a solution to the further education lecturers' pay problem. On Friday college principals meet in London to hear top managers from Derby Wilmorton, Sheffield and Guildford colleges outline a sophisticated scheme which, they hope, will look sufficiently like performance-related pay to satisfy the government and the hardliners among the college principals; and sufficiently unlike it to satisfy lecturers and their unions. Only then can the government's £50m allocated for pay be released. The three principals have had discreet but unmistakable government encouragement. They have had secret meetings with lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks and top civil servant David Forrester, after Mr Forrester visited Wilmorton. Pay is between 10% and 35% behind that of schoolteachers - and that's in the colleges which implemented last year's 3.3% pay rise. In other colleges the gap is even bigger. Guildford principal Lynn Sedgemore's search for a solution is motivated by her serious recruitment problems. The main lecturers' union, Natfhe, held a pay conference last week at which, against the advice of their leaders, members demanded an immediate pay claim and negotiations before the end of January, and threatened industrial action beginning with a one day strike on May 1. When even the general secretary, Paul Mackney, the most effective leader the union has had for years, cannot hold the line, the warning signs are unmistakable. "Our members clearly were saying, we've had four years of this government, we have been very patient, but now we have had enough" he says. So it is vital that next week's meeting comes out with something that Mr Mackney can sell to his members. webTitle: The economic pitfalls facing agency lecturers

fields.headline: Out and down
fields.standfirst: The fate of Peter Astle should be a warning to all agency lecturers. By Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: The fate of Peter Astle should be a warning to all agency lecturers. By Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Getting the boot is always painful. Trying to soften the blow with silly euphemisms such as "letting go" and "downsizing" only makes things worse.

But the cruellest agony of all, according to Peter Astle, a 34-year-old former media studies lecturer and course leader at the People's College, Nottingham, is to be summarily dispensed with and no explanation given at the time, or afterwards.

When he was called into the office of a senior manager on August 31 last year at the end of the first student enrolment week and told his employment was terminated, he says he was taken completely by surprise.

Still reeling from shock, he asked the obvious question: why.

"He said to me: 'Look, we don't have to give you any reasons for this,' " Astle recalls.

The college insists that Astle did know why he would not get any more assignments. But Astle says that he repeatedly requested at the time, and subsequently, an explanation and has been told nothing and has had no chance to appeal.

He recalls: "I said to him: I don't understand, we've just had our best media studies results ever."

His students, he claims, were the first ever at the college to have gained their intermediate GNVQs in media studies.

"I said: 'why did you ask me back to help with enrolments.' He said: 'we don't have to talk about this.' "

Since then Astle says he has repeatedly written to the college seeking an explanation.

The gist of any skimpy replies he has had back, he says, is that the college simply doesn't have to tell him.

What has happened to him stands as a warning, he reckons, to thousands of further education lecturers in the same position - the thousands who get work in colleges via ELS, the Nottingham-based firm and biggest lecturing agency in the country.

In despair, Astle asked ELS why his 31 teaching hours a week and his job as course leader had been summarily axed by the People's College. The agency proved as unforthcoming as he says the college was.

"You are a self-employed contractor and are not employed by ELS or the college," Rachel Newman, ELS's operations manager told him by letter. "Therefore your references in respect of your ELS contract to 'dismissal' and your expectation of a college 'explanation' are not appropriate . . ."

Astle has been devastated. "It is a disgusting way to treat any individual and no college or agency should be allowed to get away with it.

"The effect is disastrous. How on earth can you get another job when your last employers sack you and refuse to give any reasons for their actions?"

He was asked to interview for a media studies teaching job by another college. "I couldn't go through with it because I was so depressed. This has affected my mental health."

The way he tells it, his situation sounds like a Kafka plot. The one thing Astle is clear about is that it is an abuse against him. If so, it is an abuse which the government could quite easily prevent happening to others. And it wouldn't need new legislation.

That was made clear at a conference of trade union lawyers in London yesterday. Simon Deakin, reader in economic law at Cambridge University, told the gathering that it had not yet caught the public attention that the Employment Relations Act 1999 gives government the power to confer rights on individuals who fall within a grey area of neither being employees nor self-employed. Whether the government is ready to use this power is another matter.

Astle was originally invited by a contact at the college to help with some teaching on a course. He was then told that he would have to come to the college via ELS.

A recent survey by the lecturers' union, Natfhe at the college reported that 81% of ELS staff there either found their own work or were offered work by People's College before being referred to the agency.

Astle says his hours were increased to 31.5 classroom teaching hours a week and he was made course leader in June 1999. In February last year he says he led a five-day trip of 18 students to Futuroscope, the multi-media park in France.

Astle willingly admits that he had no teaching qualification and little teaching experience. His background was as a practitioner in media. He had set up a university radio station and had worked in recording studios.

He found that he enjoyed teaching at People's College and decided to embark on a teaching qualification. He says that he was told he would continue teaching for the 2000/01 academic year.

The college principal, John Rudd, said that he uses agencies for all sorts of staff. About 120 lecturers a year are hired via ELS. Rudd said that it wasn't normal to explain to agency staff why they wouldn't be wanted again.

"If it was a temp in the office you might phone Office Angels and say: You send somebody else.

But because Peter was a teacher at the college for a period of time, that's the reason why it was explained to him personally."

He rejected Astle's assertion that nobody would tell him why he had been rejected.

"He wasn't dismissed. His assignment with the college had ended."

He asserts that Astle knew why he wasn't wanted for the new autumn term. The reasons "were to do with quality and they were to do with general management and performance which he showed when he was assigned to teach this course.

"In respect of that course the college received a damning report, in effect on the work of Peter Astle. If the college had not done an awful lot of work after the course had finished the students would have failed."

If Astle proved so deficient, why hadn't the college or ELS picked it up over 18 months?

Rudd said: "We've tightened up procedures with ELS staff. It's ELS's - the agency's - responsibility to ensure that the person is doing a quality job."

Richard Eve, ELS executive director, said: "We would have satisfied ourselves as to whether Mr Astle is suitably qualified."

Asked how Astle could appeal against or get an explanation for the college's summary action, Eve said there was a "fundamental misunderstanding" about the nature of employment of ELS lecturers.

"There's no dismissal at all because when the lecturer accepts the contract they know what the end day is."

Eve said ELS was not obliged to discuss it with Astle. "He's asked why he's been dismissed. His contract came up." Astle is still on ELS's books, Eve said.

Astle himself intends to take the college to tribunal for unfair dismissal and is consulting Natfhe. On Friday he received confirmation from the Inland Revenue that he was an employee, not self employed.

fields.headline: Coming to terms
fields.standfirst: It may suit schools, but a six-term year could devastate colleges, warns John Brennan
fields.trailText: It may suit schools, but a six-term year could devastate colleges, warns John Brennan
fields.body:
There has long been concern about the present pattern of the school year - the uneven lengths of terms and holidays, the stress imposed by the long autumn term, the concentration of examination and assessment into the hay-fever season in the final half of the summer term - and a desire to break away from a cycle which owed everything to the needs of an agricultural society and nothing to the information technology-led world of the 21st century. So the establishment by the Local Government Association of another examination of the scope for change - in the form of an Independent Commission on the Organisation of the School Year - was not a surprise. But the adoption by the commission in their report, The Rhythms of Schooling, of an evolutionary, not a revolutionary, approach to change may well give their recommendations a better chance of success than some of their predecessors.

In essence the commission proposes a new pattern of six terms, beginning in August and ending in early July. The pattern would be fixed, not variable with the changing date of Easter as at present. Breaks between terms would generally be longer than at present, with a slightly shorter summer break, and public examinations and assessment would be concentrated in term 5 - between April and June. Not only would that address some of the problems of the present pattern, it would open up the possibility of a post qualification admission system for entry to higher education, and ease many of the uncertainties of the present UCAS system. But there would, of course, be major issues to be tackled in restructuring the examination and assessment system, in changing the working patterns for teachers and other staff, and in winning parental acceptance.

So what might this mean for further education? The sector was not involved in the work of the commission and the report is silent on the implications for colleges. But, despite the much more varied pattern of college delivery, it seems inevitable that if schools moved to a pattern of this kind, most colleges would need to follow suit in respect of a considerable proportion of their provision. Not to do so would place colleges at a disadvantage in relation to transfer at 16- plus, would make joint planning and delivery for 14- to 19-year-olds problematic, inhibit other types of partnership activity, and increase costs by making coordination of transport provision much more difficult. To do so colleges could garner many of the benefits which would accrue for schools, and would need to tackle many of the same organisational challenges.

In addition, colleges would face some particular problems of their own. For example, the changed pattern would involve a reduction in teaching time between the start of the academic year and the beginning of external examinations - a very serious issue for one-year courses such as AS-level. Schools might hope to recover some of that by using term 6 of the new pattern to begin teaching year 11 students - but that could leave colleges at a severe disadvantage if students could not transfer until after the summer break. If courses were to begin in mid-August for 16- to 19-year-olds, the logistics of college operation may dictate that much adult provision would need to begin at the same time.

But would adults - and their employers - be willing to accept a new pattern? Alternatively will the rapid spread of information technology-based approaches to learning make the traditional pattern of terms and holidays an irrelevance?

The commission proposals have opened up a welcome new debate about how to modernise the traditional pattern of learning delivery. But unless the implications for colleges are properly recognised and effectively resolved, it will be difficult to win further education sector support for a new approach, however evolutionary.

Dr John Brennan is director of further education development at the Association of Colleges.

webTitle: The problems facing lone parents on degree courses

fields.headline: Thwarted ambitions
fields.standfirst: It's tough being a lone parent on a degree course - would you risk poverty for your family in the hope of boosting your earning power?  Claire Callender reveals a student underclass
fields.trailText: It's tough being a lone parent on a degree course - would you risk poverty for your family in the hope of boosting your earning power? Claire Callender reveals a student underclass
fields.body:
Only around 3% of lone mothers in Britain are in full-time education. But perhaps this is not surprising. Would you risk borrowing more than your annual income to finance your higher education, and the prospect of years of debt ahead of you?

These dilemmas face most lone parents if they want a degree to help them escape poverty and dependence on state benefits. Lone mothers are much less likely than other women to have any educational qualifications, including degrees. Their lower qualification levels help explain why they have the lowest economic activity rates of all women and why, when they do work, most are concentrated in low-skilled and low-paid jobs.

Consequently, lone parents are particularly reliant on social security benefits either to top up their low wages or as their main source of income. Their average annual income of £10,972 means that around three in five live in poverty while two thirds of children in one-parent families are poor.

A key route out of poverty for lone parents and their children, is educational qualifications. So if the government wants to meet its commitments to widening and increasing participation in higher education, lone parents are an obvious target group.

In our study, commissioned by the Department for Education and Employment, we surveyed a nationally representative sample of nearly 3,000 higher-education students about their income, expenditure and debt. We looked at the impact of the changes in student funding policies since 1995/6, and showed how the move from student grants to loans had led to a three-fold increase in full-time students' debt. With rising student debt, entering higher education is an increasingly risky invest ment decision for low income students. For most this risk will pay off.

However, when lone parents do take the risk, our survey found they are the most likely to build up high levels of debt, and experience financial difficulties while studying. These affect their performance and chances of completing their course successfully. This risk of failure may discourage prospective students from less advantaged backgrounds from borrowing the large sums of money now needed to get a university degree.

Our survey found that in 1998/9 lone parents studying full time had the highest average incomes of £9,139, compared to an average of £4,924 for all full-time students. Unlike other students, most of their income came from the student-support system, including student loans, and from social security benefits. Unlike other students, they could not rely ontheir family for help, or on wages from paid work.

Lone parents' comparatively high expenditure was because they had dependent children. For example, lone parents spent an average of £1,457 a year on both formal and informal childcare, nearly three times more than married/cohabiting students with children. They also incurred other extra costs because of their children.

Our study showed that all student lone parents owed £4,747 on average at the end of the 1998/9 academic year - double the average level of student debt. They had accumulated these debts because they relied heavily on student loans. They were also much more likely than others to supplement their income through commercial credit. Despite their high levels of borrowing, lone parents students had to economise the most. More seriously, 77% of lone parents felt that financial difficulties had negatively affected their academic performance, compared with 60% of all students, and they were far more likely than others to think about dropping out for financial reasons.

The government recognises the problems faced by lone parents. It has just released details of an imaginative new package, centred on a new childcare grant. All low-income lone parents, with children up to the age of 14, will be entitled to the grant to pay for formal registered childcare. They will receive a fixed proportion of their actual childcare costs of up to maximum of £100 per week for one child, or £150 for two or more children, payable over 52 weeks. This will enable many lone parents to get paid work over the summer vacation, and so reduce their debts.

In addition, an access bursary of £500 will be available for those not claiming the new childcare grant. This bursary recognises lone parents' particular reliance on informal childcare arrangements. It is discretionary, however, and not an entitlement like the childcare grant. In addition a new income-assessed grant of £500 is being introduced to help pay for travel, books and equipment. Together these welcome measures, and those already in place, will really help lone parents, and in the longer term may serve to contain their overall levels of debt.

Lone parents' financial concerns do not stop once they leave university - quite the contrary. Their student-loan repayments are based on their income on graduation. However, research shows that graduate mothers not living with a partner are less likely to be employed than graduate mothers living with a partner. And even when lone parents do work after graduating, their earnings are likely to be lower than other graduates. This means it will take them longer than more affluent students to pay off their debts.

Some of the changes this government has introduced to student financial support are very real improvements on previous policies. There is, however, a key problem with the reforms for all low-income students, not just lone parents - it's the re placement of maintenance grants with student loans. This change means that students from the lowest socio-economic groups end up with the largest debts and experience the greatest hardship, which make higher education a risky investment.

Prospective students, especially lone parents, may be deterred from going to university because of the sheer size of the debts they will accumulate along with concerns about paying off their loans. There is a real danger that the government's desire to widen and increase participation will be undermined by this radical change to student financial support.

In future, lone parent students will leave university with much higher debts because of the move from grants to loans. Assuming constant 2000/1 rates of student loans and an estimated commercial credit debt averaging around £700 a year, a lone parent starting university this academic year could leave three years later with a debt of over £15,000.

This is 50% more than lone parents' average annual income. Will lone parents be able to jump over this psychological barrier? Could you?

Claire Callender is professor of social policy and Martin Kemp is a researcher at South Bank University

 The full report - Claire Callender and Martin Kemp (2000), Changing Student Finances: Income, Expenditure and the Take-up of Student Loans among Full-and Part-time Higher Education Students in 1998/9, is available from DfEE Publications Tel: 0845 60 22260, price £4.95. It can also be downloaded from the DfEE website (www.dfee.gov.uk/research/ re_paper/RR213. PDF).

Further information on the new childcare provision can be obtained from the NUS Welfare Unit 020- 7 272 8900. Crown copyright is reproduced with permission of the controller of HMSO.

Hard times - but worth it, they say

As someone who worked for years in accountancy, Kim Broodie knows a bad financial situation when she sees one. "I'm used to earning money and now I don't have any," says the 39-year-old South Bank University student in the second year of an accountancy and finance degree.

Her eldest daughter, Ayisha, is feeling the lack of money more, she laughs, but Kim says that going to university herself is inspiring her children to aim for higher education. "I will have to work hard to get my degree before [Ayisha] goes to university."

Kim's youngest son, Kazeem, attends the university's nursery, but there are other childcare costs and Kim believes the government's promised childcare grant will help.

Rachel Hassan, 24, started her degree in social policy in September and is already finding it hard- going financially. Two people on her course have dropped out for financial reasons, she says. She has two children - three-year old Nieema and Ajeye, one year old this week - who attend the South Bank nursery, and she finds her student loan is eaten up entirely by childcare costs.

To make ends meet, she works part-time at a centre for homeless teenagers where she was a volunteer helper before starting her degree.

She left school without any qualifications and started a GNVQ course in health and social care when her first child was a baby. The government's New Deal for lone parents helped with the cost of travelling to college. Going on to the degree was a natural progression, says Rachel. Although things are tough now, she believes she will be able to get a better job as a graduate to pay off her student loan and provide for her family. "I'm enjoying the course and the children are enjoying the nursery - it keeps us busy anyway."

Donald MacLeod

We looked at the impact of the changes in student funding policies since 1995/6, and showed how the move from student grants to loans had led to a three-fold increase in full-time students' debt. With rising student debt, entering higher education is an increasingly risky invest ment decision for low income students. For most this risk will pay off. However, when lone parents do take the risk, our survey found they are the most likely to build up high levels of debt, and experience financial difficulties while studying. These affect their performance and chances of completing their course successfully. This risk of failure may discourage prospective students from less advantaged backgrounds from borrowing the large sums of money now needed to get a university degree. Our survey found that in 1998/9 lone parents studying full time had the highest average incomes of £9,139, compared to an average of £4,924 for all full-time students. Unlike other students, most of their income came from the student-support system, including student loans, and from social security benefits. Unlike other students, they could not rely ontheir family for help, or on wages from paid work. Lone parents' comparatively high expenditure was because they had dependent children. For example, lone parents spent an average of £1,457 a year on both formal and informal childcare, nearly three times more than married/cohabiting students with children. They also incurred other extra costs because of their children. Our study showed that all student lone parents owed £4,747 on average at the end of the 1998/9 academic year - double the average level of student debt. They had accumulated these debts because they relied heavily on student loans. They were also much more likely than others to supplement their income through commercial credit. Despite their high levels of borrowing, lone parents students had to economise the most. More seriously, 77% of lone parents felt that financial difficulties had negatively affected their academic performance, compared with 60% of all students, and they were far more likely than others to think about dropping out for financial reasons. The government recognises the problems faced by lone parents. It has just released details of an imaginative new package, centred on a new childcare grant. All low-income lone parents, with children up to the age of 14, will be entitled to the grant to pay for formal registered childcare. They will receive a fixed proportion of their actual childcare costs of up to maximum of £100 per week for one child, or £150 for two or more children, payable over 52 weeks. This will enable many lone parents to get paid work over the summer vacation, and so reduce their debts. In addition, an access bursary of £500 will be available for those not claiming the new childcare grant. This bursary recognises lone parents' particular reliance on informal childcare arrangements. It is discretionary, however, and not an entitlement like the childcare grant. In addition a new income-assessed grant of £500 is being introduced to help pay for travel, books and equipment. Together these welcome measures, and those already in place, will really help lone parents, and in the longer term may serve to contain their overall levels of debt. Lone parents' financial concerns do not stop once they leave university - quite the contrary. Their student-loan repayments are based on their income on graduation. However, research shows that graduate mothers not living with a partner are less likely to be employed than graduate mothers living with a partner. And even when lone parents do work after graduating, their earnings are likely to be lower than other graduates. This means it will take them longer than more affluent students to pay off their debts. Some of the changes this government has introduced to student financial support are very real improvements on previous policies. There is, however, a key problem with the reforms for all low-income students, not just lone parents - it's the re placement of maintenance grants with student loans. This change means that students from the lowest socio-economic groups end up with the largest debts and experience the greatest hardship, which make higher education a risky investment. Prospective students, especially lone parents, may be deterred from going to university because of the sheer size of the debts they will accumulate along with concerns about paying off their loans. There is a real danger that the government's desire to widen and increase participation will be undermined by this radical change to student financial support. In future, lone parent students will leave university with much higher debts because of the move from grants to loans. Assuming constant 2000/1 rates of student loans and an estimated commercial credit debt averaging around £700 a year, a lone parent starting university this academic year could leave three years later with a debt of over £15,000. This is 50% more than lone parents' average annual income. Will lone parents be able to jump over this psychological barrier? Could you? Claire Callender is professor of social policy and Martin Kemp is a researcher at South Bank University  The full report - Claire Callender and Martin Kemp (2000), Changing Student Finances: Income, Expenditure and the Take-up of Student Loans among Full-and Part-time Higher Education Students in 1998/9, is available from DfEE Publications Tel: 0845 60 22260, price £4.95. It can also be downloaded from the DfEE website (www.dfee.gov.uk/research/ re_paper/RR213. PDF). Further information on the new childcare provision can be obtained from the NUS Welfare Unit 020- 7 272 8900. Crown copyright is reproduced with permission of the controller of HMSO. Hard times - but worth it, they say As someone who worked for years in accountancy, Kim Broodie knows a bad financial situation when she sees one. "I'm used to earning money and now I don't have any," says the 39-year-old South Bank University student in the second year of an accountancy and finance degree. Her eldest daughter, Ayisha, is feeling the lack of money more, she laughs, but Kim says that going to university herself is inspiring her children to aim for higher education. "I will have to work hard to get my degree before [Ayisha] goes to university." Kim's youngest son, Kazeem, attends the university's nursery, but there are other childcare costs and Kim believes the government's promised childcare grant will help. Rachel Hassan, 24, started her degree in social policy in September and is already finding it hard- going financially. Two people on her course have dropped out for financial reasons, she says. She has two children - three-year old Nieema and Ajeye, one year old this week - who attend the South Bank nursery, and she finds her student loan is eaten up entirely by childcare costs. To make ends meet, she works part-time at a centre for homeless teenagers where she was a volunteer helper before starting her degree. She left school without any qualifications and started a GNVQ course in health and social care when her first child was a baby. The government's New Deal for lone parents helped with the cost of travelling to college. Going on to the degree was a natural progression, says Rachel. Although things are tough now, she believes she will be able to get a better job as a graduate to pay off her student loan and provide for her family. "I'm enjoying the course and the children are enjoying the nursery - it keeps us busy anyway." Donald MacLeod

webTitle: The results of an enquiry into equal opportunities at Cambridge Univeristy

fields.headline: Big boys' rules
fields.standfirst: Cambridge University dared to ask its staff if they felt they had equal opportunities. Now, reports Pauline Hunt, it has to act on the results - and change
fields.trailText: Cambridge University dared to ask its staff if they felt they had equal opportunities. Now, reports Pauline Hunt, it has to act on the results - and change
fields.body:
The "tough macho culture" at Cambridge is intimidating many of its staff, who see it as a stumbling block to progress towards equal opportunites. That culture is overwhelmingly white and male, and is perpetuated by the fact so many of the senior academics have little experience of other universities.

A new report canvassing the views of the 7,000 people on the Cambridge payroll reveals that many staff feel their work is undervalued by the university and criticise the lack of management and people skills among heads of department. It highlights "intimidation by culture rather than individual persons".

The report was commissioned by the university from Schneider-Ross, the equal opportunities experts. It canvassed all staff, whether cleaners or professors, to see whether they felt valued and fairly treated.

The aim was to take stock of the current position - Schneider-Ross says Cambridge has a good range of equal opportunities policies - and identify key areas for change.

The university is the first in this country to commission such an independent survey, and has pledged to take action on problems identified. "We are not doing justice to the talent we have at Cambridge if we take a 'sink or swim' attitude to career development," said vice-chancellor Sir Alec Broers. "I see it as vital we establish a more friendly and supportive environment for everyone."

Broers said resources would be found to implement the findings of the report. He acknowledged that it identified that "many of us with organisational responsibilities currently lack the necessary skills".

But he added: "The Cambridge culture has adapted and changed in the last 10 years. We've developed a highly successful entrepreneurial culture here - we can do the same with equality and diversity issues."

The report highlights the dilemma of one of the world's top universities, famous for its cutting-edge research, in its choice of managers. Many staff felt there was a conflict between the need to appoint eminent researchers able to attract vital research funds for the university and the need for people skills in running departments.

Cambridge gets more than 30% of its income from research and has always scored high in the national research assessments. But not everyone thinks this is an unmitigated benefit. "The Research Assessment Exercise has done more to hold back good practice in equal opportunities than any other thing," says one respondent. "Management skills don't influence Cambridge's standing; it's research that does," said another.

"Nobody seems to [care] whether people can teach or not," a third comments. "All that matters is how much research money you can bring in."

In all, 40% of the university's staff responded to the survey and two-thirds rated Cambridge University a good employer and felt they had been fairly treated and valued by their colleagues. They rated the university a desirable place to work.

But three-quarters of those who replied thought the university must move further towards equality of opportunity, mainly on moral grounds but also because without progress it would not be possible to attract and retain the most talented staff.

They see the biggest hurdle as that of the "closed" culture which needs to change if the university is to be seen as a more inclusive institution. "Other universities have had these things in place for years" is a comment quoted in the survey to reflect a general view: few people (only 12%) thought that Cambridge was good at learning from other institutions.

Schneider-Ross suggests that part of this problem could lie in the fact that 70% of the top academics (professors and readers) surveyed had a Cambridge degree, whether at the first or higher level, and nearly 40% of academics in the survey had been at the university for 20 years or more.

A third of the academics who put forward their views and who had a Cambridge degree had no experience of other universities. The report quotes a comment that the institution is seen as "insular and secretive - at least if you have been a student here you know the rules".

A reputation for excellence over the centuries, with many academics choosing to stay in the male-dominated university for most of their working lives, produces a distinctive culture which came under fire from staff, particularly those who could be seen as outsiders and who experienced feelings of exclusion.

"I sense that recruitment is fair. But what is not fair is the culture," was one comment highlighted to illustrate some of the problems.

Not surprisingly it found that male readers and professors were the most satisfied among the staff. As a group they were seen as somewhat "blind" to issues of equal opportunities.

"It is easy for those in privileged positions to assume that they are there because of their ability," reported one male academic. "Women are more aware there is an issue. Men don't think about it. It doesn't affect them," said one female academic.

Among British universities, Cambridge was late in offering women full degrees, and it has long had a problem with the percentage of women academics on its staff. They currently make up just under 15% of all Cambridge academic staff: only 19 of the 302 professors are women.

Two-thirds of female academics said they had experienced feelings of exclusion at some time, twice the percentage of male professors and readers with the same experience.

Schneider-Ross say the culture can only be changed by leadership. The report questions whether many department heads have the necessary people-management skills ito do this.

A third of the staff surveyed reported feeling unable to discuss the development of their career with their head of department, and nearly a quarter complained that bullying by managers had been a barrier to their career progress.

Some heads were valued by their staff - one boss was described as a "treasure" - but there was much criticism of management skills overall. "Our head has no skills in relation to managing people. That affects men as well as women," said one. Management training is available for heads, but attendance is voluntary and often not taken up. "Requiring people to attend training is anathema to Cambridge. They would probably say they didn't have the time," one person said.

The vice-chancellor says training must be a requirement in future. The university has already begun to introduce a scheme that will require all those involved in selection to have equal opportunities training. And such training will be given to all new managers. Schneider-Ross says ways should be agreed to hold heads of department accountable for their leadership and management skills.

The university does not monitor the ethnic background of academic staff but draws gifted people from around the world. Schneider-Ross found a strong acceptance of national diversity and survey responses came from staff of 33 different nationalities. But of those who identified themselves as from ethnic minorities - 171 of the 3,034 re sponses - three-quarters had felt excluded from Cambridge culture at some time.

Managing disability issues was an area of concern. Disabled staff felt most excluded, bullied and discriminated against. They felt on the whole that "at the central level you get action on disability. At the faculty level you get little understanding. You don't get a chance to discuss it properly with your head. There is little awareness."

Since the equality audit a disability resource centre has been opened and disability training begun. The remarks on disability reflect one key finding of the report, that not all heads of departments know, or act upon, central policies of the university.

Cambridge, for instance, has family-friendly policies which allow job sharing or a career break because of family responsibilities without loss of seniority. But the report highlights the low take-up: less than one in 200 academic staff works part-time.

"I have thought of working part-time but I have not dared mention it to anybody," was one comment.

The survey also noted a perception among academics that working part-time would be "held against them".

Over a third of all staff - and nearer half the female academic staff - saw being expected to work excessively long hours as a barrier to career progress. "They always have very big faculty meetings on a Saturday," commented one respondent.

Schneider-Ross express surprise that half the academic staff surveyed had no caring responsibilities.

Not everyone objected to long hours. "What are excessively long hours when you love what you are doing?" asked one. Many reported feeling valued by their closest colleagues, and many recorded the pleasure and intrinsic satisfaction they found in their work - although fewer than a third thought their work had the financial reward it justified.

Schneider-Ross saw a failure to implement the central job-appraisal system properly, and lack of support from department heads in career progress. Nearly half those surveyed saw promotion processes as a barrier to career progression. "You can't make head nor tail of what it takes to get an advancement," said one academic.

The report identified particular problems faced by contract staff - researchers appointed for a given period for a specific project - and who now outnumber academic staff with permanent jobs. The university has now begun to appoint people with responsibility for contract staff.

The consultants found the gulf in Cambridge University between academic and support staff reflected a national problem in higher education. Support staff reported a strong feeling of "us and them". "Assistant staff and academics are like oil and water - they don't mix" was one comment. Support staff felt they were seen as "inferior", even when they were well qualified graduates.

The Cambridge colleges, employers in their own right and not included in the survey, were seen as contributing to this "us and them" factor. Many academics have a college membership which provides a social network - but it is a world to which support staff hardly ever have access.

fields.headline: The big blunder
fields.standfirst: College mergers don't raise efficiency, they put up costs. Peter Kingston reports
fields.trailText: College mergers don't raise efficiency, they put up costs. Peter Kingston reports
fields.body:
The government's belief that some colleges would do better to merge into bigger structures is a recipe for expensive inefficiency, according to a leading analyst of the further education sector.

Doubling or trebling in size may bring cost benefits in college's central administration. But these are outweighed by the higher teaching costs and a deterioration in teachers' performance, according to Ben Johnson-Hill.

He reckons that the biggest colleges with budgets up to £30m could be well advised to go in the opposite direction of the current merger trend and subdivide into separate chunks.

Johnson-Hill, who has been analysing colleges' efficiency for a decade, claims to have developed an unrivalled technique for "benchmarking", or comparing them on a "cost per unit" base.

Two-thirds of the sector - 330 colleges - are on his client list and have been subject to scrutiny by his team, many of them several times.

He is extremely impressed with colleges' performance since incorporation in 1993. Few other sectors have experienced pressures such as convergence of funding, for instance.

"The further education sector is unique in that, through convergence of the level of funding, it has improved its productivity by 30% or so over the last eight years.

"This is remarkable for a bureaucratic sector - just imagine what the UK could do if the health service could improve its output per £1 of funding by 30%."

The sector is also unique for the purpose of his analysis in that it has a system of "unitised output". Every student, depending on the course, carries a unit of cash value. That enables the totting up of the value produced by each college and comparisons.

Until the demise of the British textile industries a decade ago, Johnson-Hill analysed the 14 sectors of garment manufacturing. Johnson Associates, the company he is MD of, switched primarily into education.

"I won't go into sectors unless there are a lot of similar businesses of reasonable size and they are under pressure to improve their performance."

His method is to strip down every cost in a college and store it in a database which enables it to be compared against similar colleges' costs.

"We can tell a £15m college, for instance, that its £400,000 telephone bill is four times more than we would normally expect."

He would typically show a college 25 areas where its costs are out of line with norms.

Johnson-Hill greatly admires the Further Education Funding Council for the unitised system. But he is suspicious of the taste for mergers which the council, soon to be disbanded, has latterly promoted.

This taste was also encouraged by the education secretary David Blunkett who last year spoke of the council becoming "proactive in encouraging mergers" and even making merger a condition of continuing funding for colleges in serious financial straits

Johnson-Hill's results show that as colleges grow from £3m-budget to £30m-budget size, central administration costs drop by 80 pence per unit, or 5% of total income.

But at the same time teaching costs on average rise by £2 per unit, or 12% of total income.

"You also have, what colleges don't see, a deterioration in the performance of direct labour, ie the front line teachers, because the management moves further and further away from them.

"All in all, the data does fly in the face of the popular theory that big is beautiful and that to merge will bring benefits of efficiency."

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: higher news
fields.body:
The third degree

 We are delighted to inform passengers that the University of Surrey has announced the identity of the world's first professor of airline food. Peter Jones is taking off from the Forte chair of hotel management in the school of management studies at the Guildford institution. He hopes to help improve the university's catering. It conjures up a picture of stewardesses pushing trolleys through lectures while the customers fall asleep.

 For all those fanatics of Inspector Morse, the grumpy police detective who exposed the renowned murderous activities of Oxford University dons until he was killed off last November, we have more bad news. Dexter's creator, Colin Dexter, is in fact a Cambridge man. The Cambridge graduate visited the university last week to help with a crossword being sponsored as part of science week in the Cambridge Evening Post.

 What has happened to the Council for Science and Technology, the much vaunted senior science advisory body for the government? Launched by luminaries such as Sir Richard Sykes, rector of Imperial College, Cambridge vice-chancellor Sir Alec Broers, and the recently departed chief scientific adviser, Sir Bob May, it last met in June while the three reports it conducted gather virtual dust on its website.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us at: donald.macleod@theguardian.com, lee.elliot major@theguardian.com

News: Life class

St Andrews University's royal appointment has paid off handsomely in by far the biggest increase in applications for degree courses among UK universities this year - but what is Kingston's secret?

The 'Prince William effect' - a 44% increase compared with last year is revealed in figures from the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service. Last year, the British Council reported a surge in interest in St Andrews from young women after HRH decided to enrol on an art history degree starting this autumn.

Other universities witnessing large increases include Kingston (up 15.9%). Universities which have seen the biggest falls in applications include Sunderland and three London institutions - Imperial, Goldsmiths and East London - all down by more than 12%.

By December 15, 2000, a total of 322,621 people had applied for university courses starting in autumn 2001 - up by 2,171 on the previous year.

Research news

Middle income

The perennial debate over how much funds should be skewed to the top rated research departments is hotting up again as the Research Assessment Exercise approaches. The elite academic club, the Royal Society, has urged the Higher Education Funding Council for England not to cut funds from mid-rated departments in the assessment.

Closer encounters

The Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council has taken on the brave task of getting life scientists talking to physical scientists and engineers. Funding is now available for summer schools to encourage collaboration as part of the council's life sciences interface programme. Applications by February 23, 2001. Email: prue.backway@epsrc.ac.uk

webTitle: Michael Brown defends JMU following an examiner's stinging attacks

fields.headline: Shambles? Shame on you
fields.standfirst: Michael Brown defends Liverpool John Moores University following an examiner's stinging attacks
fields.trailText: Michael Brown defends Liverpool John Moores University following an examiner's stinging attacks
fields.body:
All universities have come under the scrutiny of the media at some point in their evolution and Liverpool John Moores University is no exception. The university has grabbed its fair share of headlines, many highlighting the excellent initiatives and work of the staff and students but others portraying the institution in a negative manner.

One such story highlighted by the Guardian (January 16) concerned an examination paper presented to students in a highly unsatisfactory state. We cannot and did not defend what happened. The students will not be disadvantaged and an enquiry into this appalling incident is currently underway.

What followed, however, in the Guardian last week (January 23) was a completely unjustified and unprovoked attack on the university, which stemmed from comments made by an external chemistry examiner who was last under contract to the university three years ago. In this case, there seems to be no substantial charge to answer.

Subsequent examiners on the chemistry degree programmes and those who served alongside the examiner in question, have not raised any such issues and indeed have remarked upon the boards being "conducted in an exemplary manner".

It is true that certain quality system issues were discussed three years ago. Advice was, however, acted upon and the details were reported back to the examiner. Co-examiner, Dr Richard Brown, of Manchester University, has stated that: "There were some problems three years ago of a minor (and not exceptional nature) but the matters have all been dealt with and the problems have not re-occurred."

Students, staff, trades unions and external colleagues alike have been united and indeed, vociferous, in their shock at such an unjustified attack. I have also been inundated with letters of support expressing dismay at these very public comments.

That the Guardian linked these comments to an acknowledged error in one of 10,000 exam papers presented last semester to label the university "a shambles" is totally unacceptable and not the kind of uninformed article one would expect from the highly respected Education Guardian.

Professor Michael Brown is vice-chancellor of Liverpool John Moores University.

See our story on www.educationunlimited.co.uk/higher and judge for yourself.
