webTitle: Does it pay to choose a university with an eye on results?

fields.headline: A marked difference
fields.standfirst: Last year a third of Cambridge students graduated with a first, against only 10% at Durham.  Lee Elliot Major asks if it pays to choose a university with an eye on results
fields.trailText: Last year a third of Cambridge students graduated with a first, against only 10% at Durham. Lee Elliot Major asks if it pays to choose a university with an eye on results
fields.body:
The chances of getting a first-class degree vary dramatically from one university to another - even when they teach similar subjects and admit students with similar A-level grades.

Official figures for last year's degree results, exclusively compiled for the Guardian, raise further fears that degree standards vary enormously across the academic sector.

Just under a third of students graduating from Cambridge University last year received first-class honours, figures from the Higher Education Statistics Agency reveal (though the Cambridge figure reflects the division of degrees into two parts, which are separately graded). Over a quarter of students at Imperial College, London and over a fifth at Oxford University secured firsts.

Much lower proportions of graduates got firsts at the other old, research-led universities. At the University of York 12% of graduates got firsts, while only one in ten did so at at Sheffield and Durham universities.

Officials from Cambridge and Oxford put their success down to the academically gifted students attracted to the ancient universities. "Our admissions criteria are extremely high, and we are confident that our examinations are of high standards, and that students deserve the grades they get," said Sir Alec Broers, vice-chancellor of Cambridge. An Oxford spokeswoman said: "It is a reflection of the excellent teaching facilities at the university, and the quality of candidates."

The particularly high proportion of firsts at Cambridge is owing partly to a quirk in the university's degree awarding policies. The university does not, in fact, award different degree classifications: students simply receive a bachelor of arts degree. But 32% of graduates secured firsts in at least one of two sets of exams taken during their degrees. The university has yet to work out a formula which would produce a final degree classification comparable to other universities but meanwhile sits complacently at the top of the firsts league table. Even allowing for such anomalies, the large differences in degree results cannot be explained by the variation in the academic ability of the students enrolled. While 99.6% of students have higher than average A-levels at Cambridge, 90.9% are equally well qualified at, say, Sheffield.

Some argue that the figures cast further doubts that degree grades represent the same academic standards in different universities. "They suggest great variations in the quality of the teaching and learning experience," said Professor Geoffrey Alderman, vice-president of Touro College, New York, and formerly pro vice-chancellor for quality and standards at Middlesex University, "and great variations in standards applied in the same subject at different institutions, and the inability of the external examiner system to deal with this."

Last year the vice-chancellor of the University of York, Ron Cooke, sparked controversy when he wrote to York's external examiners about the relatively low proportion of firsts at the university. Many claim universities are under increasing pressure to award more first-class honours to improve their academic standing.

The degree results for new universities also show big differences in the proportion of firsts. In Scotland, Robert Gordon and Napier Universities last year awarded firsts to 9.6% and 9.3% of their graduates respectively. At Westminster and Hertfordshire universities meanwhile, 8.5% of students received first class honours. But only 5.4% of students at Sheffield Hallam, 5.2% at Manchester Metro politan, and 4.9% at Plymouth, were awarded first-class degrees.

Some of these differences reflect the different degree subjects. In general, more firsts are awarded in the scientific and mathematical disciplines where answers are more black and white compared with the arts and humanities. Getting lawyers to give firsts in some institutions is like getting blood out of stone; mathematicians, on the other hand, often appear to throw them around like confetti.

The more frequent firsts in science help explain why science institutions such as Imperial College, Umist and Cranfield award so many firsts overall. Yet the degree results are different for many institutions with similar degree subjects. Thefigures do not include graduates in medicine, dentistry and veterinary science, who do not receive degree classifications.

Universities with highest proportion of first-class honours

Cambridge 32%

Imperial College 26.3%

Oxford 20.5%

LSE 18.3%

Umist 17.5%

University College, London 16.8%

Open 16.4%

Cranfield 16.3%

Bristol 15.5%

Manchester 15.0%

Source: Hesa

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My daughter is dyslexic and needs to retake her A-levels to get the grades she requires for university. Can she get any funding for this?
fields.trailText: Leading experts advise on your problems
fields.body:
Sue Flohr
British Dyslexia Association

If your daughter is going to resit her A-levels at an further education college she will probably find there is a good learning support department to help her. There should be no cost implications as the college can apply for funding to cover any extra costs in her tuition through the Education Funding Council. If your child is still at school, schools have a duty to offer as much help as possible to children with dyslexia.

Another option is to pay for a private tutor - we can offer advice for people considering this, and a local dyslexia association may be able to supply the names of specialist teachers.

You'll find public libraries have two reference books which may help: Grants for Individuals in Need and The Educational Grants Directory. Try also to get an exciting piece of software called Wordswork, which will help your daughter find the best way to study. When she is ready to apply for university, Dorothy Gilroy's book Applying to Higher Education for Dyslexic Students is worth a look.

For more information call the BDA Helpline on 0118-966 8271.

Martin Sissons
Skill, the National Bureau for Students with Disabilities

If your daughter is at school, she probably has a Statement of Special Educational Needs which involves support from her school. If she is at a FE college, it should meet her needs, usually by providing special facilities such as computer resources. Colleges can get extra funding for this.

Your daughter is entitled to free further education until she reaches 19 (18 in Scotland). If she is older, colleges may decide to let her study without paying fees. They are likely to let her finish a course she's started, perhaps by resitting exams, and are also more likely to let her carry on free if she's progressed more slowly than usual because of learning difficulties.

Problems can arise if dyslexia is suspected, but has not been identified by a full assessment, although this should be arranged by your school or college (once she's left learning she'll find little financial support for any dyslexia assessments, which cost more than £200). Many people pay for these themselves, but you may be able to go to grant-making organisations and trusts for help.

If she does a degree or HND, cash help may be available from the Local Education Authority, through the Disabled Students' Allowances.

Skill can be contacted on 0800-328 5050 (voice) or 0800-068 2422 (text), between 1.30pm and 4.30pm Monday to Friday. On the internet: www.skill.org

Coming next

There are two local primary schools I would happily send my child to (she is now three). Both are over-subscribed. Meanwhile, the school nearest my house is dreadful. I won't hear whether she has a place in one of my preferred schools until a few months before she is due to start. If I don't get a place when she is four, should I: a) move house; b) accept a place at the "bad" school but keep her on the waiting list for the "good" one; c) keep her in nursery until she's five in the hope a place comes up?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Each week we ask leading experts to advise. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020 7239 9933 or e-mail to education.letters@theguardian.com

webTitle: On the board: The diary of a parent governor

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
No meeting of the governors has yet taken place this term. Officially, at least. However, my daughter has had a playdate with her friend Natalie; and Natalie's mother, Judith Evans, is a governor. So we are also able to share gubernatorial deliberations. And over a better class of biscuit, too.

I am grateful to Judith, a personnel director by day, who (as I had been) was elected unopposed last term: her election means that I have been able to pass the baton of the greenest governor.

Governors are assailed by an ever-more demanding workload these days. I can barely keep up with the minutes of meetings, let alone the stream of newsletters and bulletins. But, crucially, I did not know about the workload when I agreed to be nominated.

More salient is parental passivity: as Mrs Mills, the deputy head, related last term, the school had once advertised a public meeting about sex education and the school's teaching policy. What subject could more reliably guarantee a packed audience? The meeting had to be cancelled due to lack of interest.

I've seen this now from both sides. My friend on the PTA, Susie, is constantly complaining about the school's paternalistic managerial attitude, essentially uncommunicative and non-consultative. But I can see that the management team's attitude is: "We've tried consultation, and nobody's interested; either parents trust us, or they just don't care, so we're going to do what we were going to do in the first place."

So, like me, Judith has been the electoral beneficiary of the generalised parental apathy. Unlike me, however, she is clearly a powerhouse. It emerges that she has already spent a morning touring the school, meeting her designated classes and being briefed by the head on finances. She is a one-woman task-force - a fact that the head, Mr Richardson, seems to recognise, since he has already drafted her onto the finance committee.

"It's a pretty big enterprise, isn't it?" I ask idly. "What's the annual budget?"

"Oh, about a million and a half," she replies breezily. Clearly, the school is a pretty small enterprise in her experience. "You know what, though: the amount of money the school gets is dependent on the number of pupils. If the school's not full, it's losing income."

I did know this, in fact. But any smugness is momentary, as the implication of what she's saying sinks in.

"But you don't mean the school has unfilled places?"

"Yes, that's exactly what I mean."

"But that's absurd. It's really hard to get a place."

"What happens is that in May people confirm they want a place, but then their children never show in September - presumably because they've taken up a place elsewhere."

This news makes me uneasy, and not only because some parents are apparently choosing other schools ahead of ours. The issue of unfilled places actually arose at the first governors' meeting last term. We were told that all the parents of missing children had been given a two-week deadline to respond before their places were offered to the next parents on the waiting list. We felt that this was too generous - which parent of a child without a school place would still be calmly waiting in mid-September to hear from our school? - and the head agreed to speed up the procedure.

The matter had not been revisited since, because, I think, we assumed that all the places had been filled. But apparently not. If the school and, indirectly, our children were now suffering from reduced financial resources as a result of bureaucratic delays, we ought to know. I make a mental note to ask when the admissions committee will next meet. At last, I am a governor with a mission.

webTitle: Melissa Benn on her father's decision to move her to a comprehensive school

fields.headline: Child of a dream
fields.standfirst: Tony Benn's decision to move his children to a comprehensive school was branded a 'collective sacrifice'.  Melissa Benn says she felt only lucky
fields.trailText: Tony Benn's decision to move his children to a comprehensive school was branded a 'collective sacrifice'. Melissa Benn says she felt only lucky
fields.body:
When I first walked my elder daughter through the gates of our local primary I felt something approaching awe. Here, 10 minutes from our home - eight if you run, and we are always running - is a school containing children from every social background, religion and nationality. Like so many large inner city primaries, it is housed in a formidable Victorian building: there is a large intake of refugees, not enough playground space and a chronic teacher shortage. Oh, and it is also a wonderful school. (If you don't believe me, ask Ofsted).

But walking through those gates I also felt a primitive sense of recognition. For as a child and teenager I, too, raced to schools just minutes from my home which contained an extraordinary mix of class, nationality and religion ; 26 languages were spoken at my secondary school.

Resources were an issue even backthen, in the pre-inflationary 70s. And then, too, the question of middle-class participation in the great state school experiment was a big deal for the pundits, politicians and policy-makers.

But I am the product not just of a state school but a comprehensive education. It was, and remains, a crucial distinction. Comprehensives were first introduced as the answer to an insidious system that divided children up by apparent ability before they were even teenagers and consigned large sections of young people to a no-hope future, educationally speaking. In contrast, the comprehensive school opened its doors to all in the neighbourhood, the able and apparently not so able, the well off and the not so well off. In doing so, it was an important first lesson in democratic citizenship. And a comprehensive education has a particular feel to it, an openness and excitement that I can still recall more than 20 years on.

But, as a special conference convened this week, will ask: how will the comprehensive ideal survive into the 21st century? Anxiety over the future of comprehensive schooling is particularly acute under this government, which, in its unerring support for parental choice has, many claim, accelerated the introduction of more subtle forms of selection. And in its unending search for electorally popular ideas the government continues to put forward depressingly old-new initiatives such as this week's announcement on vocational training for the 14 plus, which will once more divide children at too early an age, this time in the name of so-called technical know how.

I did not start out in state schools. Like so many children of Labour politicians in the 60s, my brothers and I began our education in the private sector. My parents, Tony and Caroline Benn, decided to move us all to state schools around 1963 on the grounds that it was hypocritical to back comprehensives for everyone else and then educate your own children privately. In some people's eyes, this made us four children a collective sacrifice, a living social experiment. We felt only lucky.

Our nearest comprehensive was Holland Park, which cynics so enjoyed deriding as a showcase comprehensive and therefore a place of privilege. (If I had a pound for the number of times people have said to me, "Holland Park? Oh that wasn't a real comprehensive!" I could have paid for a year of private schooling, easy.) Holland Park was one of the first purpose-built comprehensives in the country but it was also, by the time I got there in the late 60s, a large rumbustious institution, which drew in a small, albeit highly publicised, section of the middle class who lived around the school. Some of these, like my mother, Caroline, became passionately committed to both the school itself - she was governor of Holland Park for 35 years - and the wider comprehensive cause.

My brother Hilary remembers the strangeness of arriving at Holland Park for the first time after attending Westminster preparatory school, where he and my eldest brother Stephen had been usefully designated as Benn I and Benn II. He can still remember how huge the school buildings looked to him and the strange sound of so many boys - and girls - laughing and running and talking in the vast playgrounds.

It remains virtually impossible to talk about class in this country without sounding pious or sentimental. Lets just say this: class distinctions are not erased in a comprehensive. If anything they become sharper. In this sense, it is rather like the best of city living. All one learns is how to coexist and get a kick out of the proximity of so many kinds of difference.

You will also learn useful things about yourself. For instance, should you live in a good-sized house with a garden you will understand, as my daughters are now coming to understand, just how privileged you are. I remember the surprise and an odd sense of shame I felt at my own ignorance when I saw one of my classmates, who often came to school without shoes, dropped off at school in the caravan in which she lived. Each school creates its own kind of world but a comprehensive has a better claim than most to represent the whole of the world outside, and that is an education in itself. Anyone who has been through a comprehensive wouldn't dream of trying to be a Ruler of Men, a Master of the Universe. The Universe is there, all around you, with its own volatility and vitality, its own plans.

But what about standards? Well, there were brilliant teachers, there were teachers who could bore you into some extra curricular reading. (I first read Lucky Jim in the back of one particularly tedious sixth form course.) There were teachers who had trouble controlling classes, there were teachers who could capture your attention just in the way they entered a room.

In some ways, it was a much less conformist, more politicised era: we wrote essays on free schools, spent a lot of time in the art room, ran school assemblies, played enthusiastically in the orchestra and like most middle class children in state schools got the requisite O-levels, A-levels and, later, degrees and further degrees.

But as a parent, I am acutely aware of how different things are now from the 70s. For those of us who still want to live the comprehensive dream for our children it is getting much harder. Parental choice has meant the introduction of what is, in effect, hidden selection. Education, particularly in the inner cities, has come to resemble a minefield where the aim seems chiefly to negotiate your child's safe passage through the system.

As a result, anxiety about education has reached almost fever pitch. I have been at three- year-olds' birthday parties where the parents sit, chomping crisps and swapping information about the local secondary schools with all the intensity of Pokemon obsessives.

There obviously is a genuine dilemma here. In some boroughs the local school will amount to a sink school which does not represent the true mix of talent and type in that locality, a school which has for one reason or another lost hope. But what parents do not realise is how often this is the result of education policy, the price of parental choice, rather than the failure of one headmaster, one set of teachers or a particular local authority. This isn't personal, it's politics.

Results in Scotland, which adopted a completely comprehensive system in the 70s, show that pupils actually thrive under such a system, which in effect removes the right of politicians to create schools for the specially gifted or create special places for special children, as New Labour plans to do. And on recent results, comprehensive Cheshire outperforms selective Kent on every achievement indicator available.

But let's not get too gloomy. There remain many schools, even within inner cities, that we can still call more or less comprehensive. Here, pupils get good enough results which is all that exams should be about anyway; a statement of intent, a window on to the next stage of learning. Changes to the national curriculum have, to some extent, allayed middle-class anxiety about achievement. Certainly, a bright six-year-old today seems incredibly literate and numerate compared to when I was a child.

What remains, as ever, is anxiety about social mixing. This is partly an age-old middle class fear of the underclass, partly a wish to educate one's children with other children of the same background and partly a pretty simple kind of snobbery that uses education as a way of keeping one's children separate from most ordinary children. But for that, there are always private schools.

But in those schools that retain a genuine social mix, there exists the same kind of excitement that I remember from my school days. I see something of the same spirit in the teenagers I know at these schools; a lack of fear, an absence of arrogance, a genuine openness to other people, other experiences.

I daresay there are still some kids playing the cello as loudly and enthusiastically as I once did and slopping loads of red and green paint on giant grey rolls of paper in some airy art room. I hope so.

webTitle: Can football help boys draw level in the classroom?

fields.headline: Girls 1, boys 0
fields.standfirst: Can football help boys draw level in the classroom?
fields.trailText: Can football help boys draw level in the classroom? By John Crace
fields.body:
Who'd be a bloke these days? If you haven't got Anthony Clare telling anyone who'll listen that you're in crisis, then you've got the media misreporting that young male suicide is on the increase. But for all the myths of male disadvantage, there are some unavoidable, uncomfortable truths. Boys do take longer than girls to develop both their fine-motor and cognitive skills (whether the difference is genetic or developmental is still up for grabs, but the results are indisputable). And, according to the education department's own figures, boys lag significantly behind girls in early literacy skills - especially in writing - and the attainment gap widens to 17% when they come to study English at secondary level.

None of which will come as any surprise to parents with children of both sexes - not least if your eldest child is a girl, as the chances are you have spent years trying to reassure yourself that your son and heir isn't actually dim and that you're not a bad parent, as he steadfastly refuses to take more than a passing interest in books that your daughter could read for herself at the same age.

The bad news is that some psychologists believe the situation could get worse. "Girls have a more finely tuned sense of wanting to please others," says Oliver James, author of Britain on the Couch, "and they generally make more effort to get things right. The current move towards marking courses by continuous assessment rather than exams, at which boys have traditionally performed better, plays into their hands and we're in danger of stigmatising boys as failures long before they've left school."

Steve Biddulph, author of the best-selling Raising Boys, believes the situation has become critical. "The classroom has become a battleground for survival with only two goals - getting girls to achieve and boys to behave," he says.

The best means of achieving these goals has proved elusive, however. Various ideas to engage boys in learning have been flung around, with a few common themes cropping up. After all, if they're not interested in school, what are they interested in? The answer, say many, is football.

David Blunkett launched Playing for Success, a national initiative run in association with football clubs and the local education authorities, to establish out-of-hours study support centres for underachieving children at key stages 2 and 3. Kids find football far more interesting than classwork, went the theory, ergo if you give numeracy and literacy a soccer flavour then you can fool/encourage them to spend more time learning.

Others have followed. Letts has just published key stage 2 numeracy and literacy workbooks linked to Manchester United and Liverpool. Nike has launched Nike FC, a mixture of football training and cross-curricular activities for use in schools, and the English and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) has produced Howzat, a similar mix of physical education and classroom resources for key stage 2. The publishers are understandably sensitive to any accusations of sexism - all stress that their materials are designed to appeal to girls as well as boys - yet all admit that their resources are aimed primarily at boys.

One man who is not surprised by the move towards sport-led education is Robert Powell, headteacher of Blurton High School in Stoke-on-Trent. "Many of the children have low aspirations and low levels of achievement," he says, "and I was brought in to the school in 1997 with a brief to raise standards." Recognising that there was little enthusiasm for classroom literacy and numeracy work, Powell devised a series of games for lunchtime and after-school clubs revolving around anything from snooker to cricket to the TV gameshow Blockbusters. When he heard about the Playing for Success scheme he was one of the first to get involved. Which was just as well, because Stoke City were relegated from the first division within weeks of joining the scheme and would have been ineligible thereafter. "Even though the scheme was primarily aimed at key stage 2, I wanted to be part of it," Powell continues, "because I knew that many of the underachieving children in the city would eventually come to Blurton High and become our problem.

"The Sats results from the participating schools have improved and the youngsters really seem to enjoy learning in that environment. One comment I got from a child was particularly telling. He said, 'I enjoyed that; it wasn't a bit like school'."

The Manchester United and Liverpool workbooks - Arsenal is to follow - are direct offshoots of Playing for Success. Their content is, as you might expect, resolutely glossy and upbeat; in particular, there are no questions of the "If David Beckham is paid £100,000 per week, how long will it take him to earn the money to buy seven Ferraris?" variety.

If the club workbooks are more aimed at the "sons and fathers bonding over homework" market, Nike and the ECB have targeted schools. Nike has demonstrated its product in over 50 schools in London and Manchester since its launch in November and the ECB hopes eventually to get Howzat into all the UK's primary and secondary schools. "Even though it is free, no school will use it unless the teachers understand it and are behind it," says David Leighton, primary schools development executive for the ECB. "So we are concentrating most of our efforts on making teachers aware of what it is about."

Initial responses to all these publications have been overwhelmingly positive, but their success raises a fundamental question. Getting boys to raise their academic standards through sport is all very well, but does it not also reinforce the macho belief system that physicality is in and learning is uncool?

Powell acknowledges the problem but believes the advantages far outweigh the disadvantages. "Research has shown that boys often feel it is only OK to be academically successful providing they are good at sport," he says. "Those who are academically able but not particularly sporty often get teased. If you can reduce the influence of the 'learning is girly' school of thought by encouraging the less academically able to take an interest, you don't just raise the standards and self-esteem of underachievers; you also improve those of the more able."

So where will it all end? Last year, the RAF produced a classroom CD-rom that presented a series of maths problems in a format that was presumably designed to make students think, "I'll sign up immediately". One of the "missions" focused on bombing an enemy target. Even Powell might reckon that was a bridge too far.

fields.headline: Oxo mum stirs the pot
fields.trailText: The idea of Oxo under US ownership is "bizarre", according to Lynda Bellingham, the actress who spent 16 years playing a food loving housewife in television commercials for the famous gravy granules.
fields.body:
The idea of Oxo under US ownership is "bizarre", according to Lynda Bellingham, the actress who spent 16 years playing a food loving housewife in television commercials for the famous gravy granules.

Ms Bellingham and her fictional husband and children were scrapped by Oxo in 1999 on the grounds that it is increasingly rare for British families to sit down together for a home cooked meal. She said yesterday that this cultural change had its roots in the US.

"We learnt the idea of TV dinners, and of not bothering to cook, from the Americans. The basic art of cooking doesn't exist over there."

Ms Bellingham, at present starring in the ITV drama series At Home With the Braithwaites, believes that the decline of home cooked meals is a tragedy: "People like everything ready made all the time - it's very sad. People are incapable of even crumbling an Oxo cube."

She has fond memories of the award winning commercials which began, with different actors, in the 1950s: "A lot of viewers really enjoyed them. It was like a soap opera."

webTitle: Judges endorse Europe's view of plastic flowerpots

fields.headline: Judges endorse Europe's view of plastic flowerpots
fields.trailText: Eurosceptics had a field day yesterday after the high court in London declared that plastic flowerpots counted as packaging under an EU directive and ordered a nursery in Hampshire to recycle them.
fields.body:
Eurosceptics had a field day yesterday after the high court in London declared that plastic flowerpots counted as packaging under an EU directive and ordered a nursery in Hampshire to recycle them.

The ruling by Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, and Mr Justice Newman could also affect many other businesses.

Sir Teddy Taylor, the Conservative backbencher and secretary of the Europe Reform Group, said the directive put an unfair burden on companies such as Hillier Nurseries which had not complied.

"This makes the European commissioners look like Flower Pot Men," he said "They should be dumped in a compost heap."

He added that he had written to Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, calling on the government to protest about this "flood of useless directives and to invite Eurocrats to take a running jump".

Robert Oulds, campaign director of the Eurosceptic Bruges Group, agreed: "This is typical - people in Brussels are deciding our regulations and are just interfering with the criminal justice process. It's a total waste of resources when our courts should be trying real criminals."

Under the packaging regulations, which were introduced in March 1997, companies with a turnover of £2m which produce packaging exceeding 50 tonnes must pay for a proportion of the waste to be collected and recycled.

Business leaders accused Whitehall of being "over-zealous, impractical and bureaucratic" in interpreting the directive and the confusion over what constituted packaging led to yesterday's test case.

Hillier Nurseries, of Romsey, was charged last year with failing in 1998 to register under the regulations and not taking reasonable steps to recover and recycle packaging waste.

The company was also accused of not furnishing a certificate of compliance. Lyndhurst magistrates threw out the case.

But yesterday the high court ruled that it should be sent back to the magistrates with a direction to convict on each offence and impose a penalty. The environment agency stressed that only larger firms were affected by the directive and said it was necessary to tackle the growing problem of disposing of waste in Britain.

The court's ruling on the regulations was welcomed by Daniel Wiley, solicitor for the environment agency, which brought the case.

"The ruling confirms that our interpretation of the regulations was the correct interpretation from the start," he said. "Although on one level this case is about flowerpots, it is also about plastic and the disposal of plastic.

"If this decision leads to increasing the volume of plastic that comes under these regulations we are very pleased.

"It means that less waste material will be disposed of in landfill sites and more will have to be recovered and recycled."

But Tim Mason, of Hillier Nurseries, said: "For legislation to be so complicated that it takes two years debate and court action to reach a conclusion, surely it must be poor legislation."

"Although on one level this case is about flowerpots, it is also about plastic and the disposal of plastic. "If this decision leads to increasing the volume of plastic that comes under these regulations we are very pleased. "It means that less waste material will be disposed of in landfill sites and more will have to be recovered and recycled." But Tim Mason, of Hillier Nurseries, said: "For legislation to be so complicated that it takes two years debate and court action to reach a conclusion, surely it must be poor legislation."

fields.headline: Zimbabwe report
fields.standfirst:
Bombs are mightier than presses, for now

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Who will rid me of this turbulent press? If the thought was not expressed in Robert Mugabe's entourage, the Zimbabwe president's henchmen - who last week had besieged the offices of the Harare Daily News - picked the suggestion up somewhere close to the throne. In a carefully planned attack by experienced bombers, the paper's printing plant was wrecked early on Sunday.
fields.body:
Who will rid me of this turbulent press? If the thought was not expressed in Robert Mugabe's entourage, the Zimbabwe president's henchmen - who last week had besieged the offices of the Harare Daily News - picked the suggestion up somewhere close to the throne. In a carefully planned attack by experienced bombers, the paper's printing plant was wrecked early on Sunday.

The protocols through which newspaper-government relations are conducted in this country matter - see above - but they pale before the picture we printed yesterday showing two Daily News editors standing in front of the wreck of their rotary press. For them freedom to report and comment in newspapers is not a vanity of writers, but a bolster and precondition of democracy. Freedom of public dissent, which the Daily News represented, is no affectation of affluence, but a means of securing the good and honest government on which, in turn, economic progress depends - however the ownership of land is distributed.

On the face of it the bombing of the Daily News is another instance of intimidation by Zanu-PF to maintain Mr Mugabe's position and its hold on power. Perhaps the death of Laurent Kabila made Zimbabwe's government even more fearful of awkward questions about its role in Congo and the regime's private interests, pointing its thugs to seek to silence a vehicle of public information.

Our Zimbabwe correspondent quoted Trevor Ncube, the editor and publisher of another Harare paper, saying that the Mugabe government had explosive weapons, but in the end the pen would be mightier than the sword. For Zimbabwe the end may only be reached after further violence, economic degradation and tyranny. Zimbabwean journalists who do seek to speak truth to power can at least take comfort from knowing their pens - and rebuilt presses - will be needed to remake their country as a law-abiding, plural and prosperous state.

fields.headline: Sir Alistair Grant
fields.standfirst: Dynamic businessman who built Safeway chain
fields.trailText: Sir Alistair Grant, who has died of cancer aged 63, was one of the key characters in the Guinness affair in the 1980s, when his company battled for control of the giant Distillers whisky company, and the driving force behind the Safeway supermarket chain.
fields.body:
Sir Alistair Grant, who has died of cancer aged 63, was one of the key characters in the Guinness affair in the 1980s, when his company battled for control of the giant Distillers whisky company, and the driving force behind the Safeway supermarket chain.

Although advertising was probably his principal love, he spent most of his career in the food industry. It began in what was then classic fashion, as a management trainee at Unilever, the grocery giant that provided a generation of marketing managers for British business.

Towards the end of his career, Sir Alistair became one of the great and the good of the Scottish business scene, first as chairman of the brewer Scottish & Newcastle, then in the same role at the Bank of Scotland. Until then, his Scottish links were more muted and, like many in the business world, he was opposed to devolution. In fact, he spent most of his life in England after his family moved from East Lothian to Bradford when he was a boy.

After national service in the Royal Signals, Grant opted, in 1957, to join the Unilever training scheme instead of taking up a place at Edinburgh University, where he had planned to study English. He stayed for six years, becoming manager for one of the group's dried pea brands. Never one to take business too seriously, he always regarded that role with typically dry humour, describing himself as a rather unsuccessful pea salesman.

Tiring of selling peas, Grant then moved to another great British marketing company of the time, the J Lyons group. But he stayed for only a couple of years before following his interest in the liveliest element of the marketing profession by joining an advertising agency.

This might have been his ideal career, but an advertisement in 1968 for a job with the Fine Fare supermarket chain seduced him back into the food industry, and began a key partnership which was to last for nearly 20 years with the entrepreneur James Gulliver.

Gulliver was then running Fine Fare, a subsidiary of the flour and foods conglomerate Associated British Foods. He chose Grant as marketing director, and although the two Scots made an unlikely team - Gulliver was an abrasive wheeler-dealer impatient to create something for himself, whereas Grant was a suave, thoughtful manager, more interested in running businesses - between them they built what became the giant supermarket chain, Safeway.

In 1972, they left Fine Fare and, with a third Scot, David Webster, set about building their own food group, Oriel Foods. It was typical of Gulliver's style that he sold Oriel to a US conglomerate, then repurchased it a few years later at a substantially lower price. By 1983, Gulliver's group had become Argyll Foods and ranged across food manufacturing and retailing, with the acquisition of the Lo-Cost and Presto chains.

Retailing became the ultimate focus of the business, but only because of defeat in 1986 in the acrimonious battle with Guinness for the Scottish whisky group Distillers. Argyll's attempted takeover was typical of Gulliver's brashness and ambition. The Scotch maker was a pillar of the country's business world and, while its performance had been miserable, it was much bigger than Argyll.

Distillers reacted with horror to the notion of being acquired by a grocer, and was forced to seek salvation through a deal with Guinness. Its shareholders were almost evenly divided between the two offers, however, and, in its desperation to win the battle, Guinness engaged in what was later judged to be an illegal but successful operation to shore up its share price. Argyll lost the battle for Distillers, and it was little consolation to receive £100m compensation from the victor after details of its illegal activities emerged.

The battle also led to the end of Grant's partnership with Gulliver, who was revealed to have over-claimed his education at Harvard Business School. Gulliver departed, leaving Grant to take over the chair of the group.

Foiled in its attempt to become a major drinks company, and floundering in the wake of Sainsbury, Tesco, and Asda, Argyll faced a dilemma which was solved when Safeway's US parent decided to sell its British operation in 1987. So far as Grant and his colleagues were concerned, this was an opportunity they could not afford to miss, and they paid a handsome price to join the supermarket elite.

For the next 10 years, Grant led Safeway (the company name was changed in 1996) as it struggled to keep up with the market leaders. He was knighted in 1992 and took a number of industry posts, including the chairmanship of the biotechnology and biological sciences research council from 1990 to 1998 - the period when genetic modification of foods emerged as a major issue.

Unlike many businessmen, he always had outside interests. He enjoyed hunting, shooting and fishing, was a great book-lover and amateur artist. However, when he handed over the Safeway chair to Webster in 1997, finally moving back to live in Scotland, he had no intention of devoting himself wholly to these pastimes.

As well as his business roles, he was a director of the National Museum of Scotland and a trustee of the National Heritage Memorial Fund. Only in 1999, when illness began to hamper his activities, did he step down from the most demanding roles.

Grant is survived by his wife Judi, a farmer's daughter whom he met during his spell at the Batchelor's pea factory in Sheffield and married in 1963, and their daughter and two sons.

Matthew Alistair Grant, businessman, born March 6 1937; died January 22 2001

fields.headline: Myroslav Lubachivsky
fields.standfirst: Symbol of the Ukrainian church that Stalin could not destroy
fields.trailText: The Ukrainian prelate, Cardinal Myroslav Lubachivsky, who has died of pneumonia aged 86, lived through many vicissitudes, none more dramatic than his return to his native land on the eve of Palm Sunday, 1991, following 53 years of exile.
fields.body:
The Ukrainian prelate, Cardinal Myroslav Lubachivsky, who has died of pneumonia aged 86, lived through many vicissitudes, none more dramatic than his return to his native land on the eve of Palm Sunday, 1991, following 53 years of exile.

In the practical sense, this call came too late. He was already 77, and faced the task of rebuilding the Greek-Catholic Church (as the Ukrainian Eastern-Rite Catholic Church now officially called itself), which had been the largest religious community to be liquidated in Stalin's Soviet Union.

Nor was his welcome, although ecstatic, unqualified. Already in place was Metropolitan Volodymyr Sterniuk, who had suffered decades of imprisonment in solidarity with his people, and had then moulded the shape of the church as it moved from the catacombs to legality in 1989. But the returning cardinal, a man of humility and warmth, was content to allow his role to be mainly symbolic, remitting the practical details to others, particularly as his health declined.

Lubachivsky was born in Dolyna, Galicia, on the eastern extremity of the Austro-Hungarian empire, just before the outbreak of the first world war. The region subsequently came under Polish rule, then suffered Soviet invasion in 1939, German occupation in 1941, and re-conquest by the Red Army as the second war reached its climax.

Lubachivsky had gone abroad in 1938, after his initial theological education in Lviv, to do postgraduate study in Innsbruck. In the event, his "temporary" absence became more than half a century of exile.

A worse shock than the political fate of his homeland was the abolition of his church in 1946 at the so-called Synod of Lvov. At gunpoint, the terrified clergy - many married after the tradition of the Eastern Rite - were threatened with imprisonment and reprisals against their families unless they voted to abolish their church and be absorbed into the Moscow-dominated Russian Orthodox Church.

Lubachivsky's ministry was therefore to exiled Ukrainians until recent years. He undertook medical as well as theological studies in wartime Rome and began his pastoral and administrative work in the United States, where he served the Ukrainian community for more than 30 years. He was variously in Philadelphia, as secretary to the Ukrainian Archbishop, Cleveland, Michigan and Wisconsin, including a year's break back in Rome for further study. Much of his work was as a teacher, both in seminaries and schools, and he took American citizenship in 1952.

One of the early acts of Pope John Paul II, in November 1979, was personally to consecrate Lubachivsky in the Sistine Chapel, as Ukrainian Archbishop of Philadelphia. A year later, there was a recall to Rome. A synod of exiled Ukrainian bishops - no one, of course, could attend from Ukraine itself - elected him coadjutor to Cardinal Slipyj, the head of the church, who had lived in the Italian capital since his sudden release from prison and exile from the Soviet Union in 1963. In 1984, Lubachivsky was the only possible successor to Slipyj after his death, and the next year he received the red hat.

Lubachivsky found some aspects of his new administrative and diplomatic role less comfortable than his teaching and pastoral work. There was controversy, for example, over whether he should adopt the title of patriarch, as many of his flock wished him to do. In fact, he went along with the Vatican's cautious line on this, and his loyalty to the Pope was unwavering, which caused tensions among those Ukrainians who felt that their church was being marginalised.

The question over whether the Vatican considers there to be a long-term future for the Eastern-Rite Catholic Church, with its very different traditions, is still unresolved, but Lubachivsky insisted, for example, that there should be no ordination of married men outside Ukraine. He travelled to greet his scattered flock in those years, including a memorable visit to Keston College in Kent. Those who received his framed tribute for their defence of his persecuted church will not forget his charm and warmth.

This was already becoming a time of uplift for all Ukrainians, as their church emerged from underground. It regained legal status on the very day of Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to the Pope in December 1989, and Lubachivsky was able to send his first direct instruction to the newly- enfranchised believers:

"As head of the Ukrainian Catholic Church, I call upon our faithful in Ukraine to avail themselves of their rights and begin to register our congregations with the authorities as soon as possible." It was a historic moment.

The subsequent return of church property by the Orthodox to the Catholics was a fraught process, with many local conflicts, but the cardinal acted throughout with restraint and dignity; a firebrand might well have stirred up emotions to the point of bloodshed. The Pope had not accepted Luba- chivsky's offer to resign at 75 in 1989, and he lived out the rather muted years after his return to Lviv with dignity and humility, a man always ready to offer spiritual advice from his sickbed.

Myroslav Ivan Lubachivsky, cleric, born June 24 1914; died December 14 2000

fields.headline: Sylvia Scaffardi
fields.standfirst: Feisty spirit whose energy helped to launch the civil liberties movement
fields.trailText: Sylvia Scaffardi, who has died aged 99, co-founded the Council for Civil Liberties (which became the National Council for Civil Liberties and is now Liberty) in February 1934, with her lover Ronald Kidd, with whom she lived for 14 years until his death. For the time, such an arrangement was unorthodox, but then Sylvia never cared a fig for convention.
fields.body:
Sylvia Scaffardi, who has died aged 99, co-founded the Council for Civil Liberties (which became the National Council for Civil Liberties and is now Liberty) in February 1934, with her lover Ronald Kidd, with whom she lived for 14 years until his death. For the time, such an arrangement was unorthodox, but then Sylvia never cared a fig for convention.

Born out of the reactionary climate of the mid-1930s, the council was to be a militant arm in the struggle for democratic rights. As Sylvia wrote in her book, Fire Under The Carpet (1986): "Democracy as a slogan to rally support had only recently acquired respectability." And she quoted Ronald Kidd: "Conservatives almost unanimously did not bother to disguise their dislike of and contempt for democracy, but since the [first world] war they have paid lip service to the principle."

More specifically, Kidd, who became the council's first general-secretary, EM Forster, AP Herbert, HG Wells and Sylvia were among those who decided to act as observers on the hunger march of 1934, confirming the presence of police agents provocateurs; there was evidence to suggest that the police had played this role in a similar march two years earlier. Kidd decided that a permanent body of observers was necessary, and the council's inaugural meeting - attended by Claud Cockburn, Edith Summerskill and Geoffrey Bing, among others - was held in the crypt of St Martin-in-the-Fields.

With the marchers due in London, and the home secretary warning the public off the streets, a letter from the council appeared in the Manchester Guardian and the Times. It announced the formation of the council "in view of the general and alarming tendency to encroachment on the liberty of the citizen".

From the start, celebrities from every walk of cultural, intellectual and progressive Britain joined up: from AA Milne to Bertrand Russell and Havelock Ellis. Sylvia and her "darling Ronald", living in their Soho garret, became the centre of this world, immersed in politics and their work for human rights. At the beginning, Sylvia, with no accountancy training, acted as treasurer; soon, she became assistant secretary, a post she held for eight years.

In her long life, she took on a variety of roles: an English student at the Royal Holloway College, then based in Surrey, in the early 1920s, a repertory actress with the Lena Ashwell Players (and Laurence Olivier), then a spell as a civil servant, before becoming a teacher in a secondary modern school at the Elephant and Castle, south London. She was a lifetime humanist and a Green party activist. In her early 80s, when her back gave out and she could no longer do her gardening, she became a writer.

Her first book, Fire Under The Carpet, documents the origins of the fascist movement in Britain and the anti-semitism of the 1930s. Her second, Finding My Way, is the story of her childhood up to the formation of the Council for Civil Liberties.

When Ronald died in 1942, Sylvia could have scuttled back to the bosom of her large, warm Anglo-Brazilian family, the Crowther-Smiths, in Surrey. They had moved from Sao Paulo to England in the 1910s so that the children could get a "proper" education; Sylvia herself became the reluctant head-girl of a boarding school in Eastbourne. Her English father had gone to Brazil to make his fortune and fallen in love with the daughter of wealthy, progressive landowners.

Her grandmother had set an example in Brazil - the family were the first to free their slaves before emancipation; she herself was a well-known writer and communist sympathiser. Sylvia never forgot the richness of the land of her birth.

After Ronald's death, she worked for 10 years as a commissioning editor at the Ministry of Information, but the cold war made her position untenable. "The sensible course was never right for me," she wrote when she went into teaching, at the age of 52. There she met my mother, Molly Parkin, then a 21-year-old art teacher, who heard Sylvia shouting: "Has anyone had the misfortune to teach the little cunts in 4c?"

Sylvia married John Scaffardi at the age of 56, and her time with this small, gorgeous, hunchbacked Italian Cockney were the happiest of her days, living in their lovely house in Carshalton, Surrey, with a huge garden and wood. When he died in 1971, at first she wanted to die too. Instead, she was to begin to write.

With the publication of her first book came public recognition and interest. There were television and press interviews. Two years earlier, in 1984, the National Council for Civil Liberties had celebrated its 50th anniversary. Sylvia was there. Through it all, she was humorous, philosophical, fascinated with new faces and serious about political dangers.

In her late 80s, she joined the Green party, and never stopped being an astute observer of what Britain had turned into under Margaret Thatcher and the Tories. She was a hard reviewer, but with an encouraging beam and a lively, self-mocking humour. She gave me critiques on all my work from degree theses to novels. She was the best-read person I knew, and I am lucky enough to say she was my godmother. Her brain never stopped, although her body gave out in later years. Her cultured voice could still produce a shocking stream of expletives, and her radical views often shocked people - but her warm Brazilian energy won them round every time.

Sylvia Scaffardi, campaigner and teacher, January 20 1902; died January 27 2001

Her first book, Fire Under The Carpet, documents the origins of the fascist movement in Britain and the anti-semitism of the 1930s. Her second, Finding My Way, is the story of her childhood up to the formation of the Council for Civil Liberties. When Ronald died in 1942, Sylvia could have scuttled back to the bosom of her large, warm Anglo-Brazilian family, the Crowther-Smiths, in Surrey. They had moved from Sao Paulo to England in the 1910s so that the children could get a "proper" education; Sylvia herself became the reluctant head-girl of a boarding school in Eastbourne. Her English father had gone to Brazil to make his fortune and fallen in love with the daughter of wealthy, progressive landowners. Her grandmother had set an example in Brazil - the family were the first to free their slaves before emancipation; she herself was a well-known writer and communist sympathiser. Sylvia never forgot the richness of the land of her birth. After Ronald's death, she worked for 10 years as a commissioning editor at the Ministry of Information, but the cold war made her position untenable. "The sensible course was never right for me," she wrote when she went into teaching, at the age of 52. There she met my mother, Molly Parkin, then a 21-year-old art teacher, who heard Sylvia shouting: "Has anyone had the misfortune to teach the little cunts in 4c?" Sylvia married John Scaffardi at the age of 56, and her time with this small, gorgeous, hunchbacked Italian Cockney were the happiest of her days, living in their lovely house in Carshalton, Surrey, with a huge garden and wood. When he died in 1971, at first she wanted to die too. Instead, she was to begin to write. With the publication of her first book came public recognition and interest. There were television and press interviews. Two years earlier, in 1984, the National Council for Civil Liberties had celebrated its 50th anniversary. Sylvia was there. Through it all, she was humorous, philosophical, fascinated with new faces and serious about political dangers. In her late 80s, she joined the Green party, and never stopped being an astute observer of what Britain had turned into under Margaret Thatcher and the Tories. She was a hard reviewer, but with an encouraging beam and a lively, self-mocking humour. She gave me critiques on all my work from degree theses to novels. She was the best-read person I knew, and I am lucky enough to say she was my godmother. Her brain never stopped, although her body gave out in later years. Her cultured voice could still produce a shocking stream of expletives, and her radical views often shocked people - but her warm Brazilian energy won them round every time. Sylvia Scaffardi, campaigner and teacher, January 20 1902; died January 27 2001

webTitle: Children 'should be freer to roam internet'

fields.headline: Children 'should be freer to roam internet'
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Children should take a "surfing proficiency test" at 11 to allow them a freer ride on the information superhighway, a leading thinktank said today.
fields.body:
Children should take a "surfing proficiency test" at 11 to allow them a freer ride on the information superhighway, a leading thinktank said today.

Students who passed should be allowed less restricted access to the internet than schools presently allowed, according to a report by the Institute of Public Policy Research.

Damien Tambini, a research fellow at IPPR, said the test would help students learn "how to respond to meeting strangers in chat rooms and how to get the most out of the net". Pupils could take an exam after a one week course in the summer holidays, just like the cycling proficiency test.

"We want to stress that it is not a completely negative test - it would also be about making sure that children are aware of what they can find in positive terms," said Mr Tambini. "For example, information that could help them with their schoolwork. At present, they are not learning this in their classes - school computers filter out too much information."

He said parents had too little awareness of their responsibilities for child's computer use. In 1999, only 18% of internet users had heard of the Internet Watch Foundation, which is responsible for internet regulation.

The government should also have tough penalties for internet porn barons who deliberately target children, Mr Tambini argued.

The call came in Communications: Revolution and Reform, which has a preface by the culture secretary, Chris Smith. The IPPR has close links with Labour.

The idea received a sceptical response from John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association.

Dr Dunford said: "A proficiency test as a passport for unsupervised use of the internet would simply give [children] even more knowledge of how to find sites that they shouldn't be seeing."

fields.headline: Bush pushes his luck
fields.standfirst:
Florida findings should give him pause
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Florida findings should give him pause
fields.body:
George Bush has been in effusive mood this past week, his first in office, shaking hands, slapping backs and turning on the charm. His sense of wonder at his White House surroundings would be almost touching were it not as tacky as the redecorated Oval Office's peaches-and-cream colour scheme. "Today everything is so promising and new," he told his assembled staff. "My hope is that the day will never come when some of us take this honour for granted." Mr Bush acts like a man who can hardly believe his luck. An awful lot of American voters cannot believe his luck, either.

As a painstaking Washington Post analysis of election records in eight Florida counties has now established beyond reasonable doubt, the state's voters were disenfranchised last November in extraordinarily large numbers by inadequate, antiquated balloting machinery and misleading procedures.

The intention of 45,608 of them was to vote for Al Gore, while 17,098 backed Mr Bush. But all these ballots were declared invalid due to double or multiple-punching. A separate investigation, into the notorious Palm Beach dimpled chads, found Mr Gore should have benefited from a net gain of 682 votes. Mr Bush was officially declared the winner in Florida last month by a margin of 537 votes.

This ruling, fixed in stone by the Supreme Court when it halted all recounts, handed him the presidency over which he now unctuously gloats. But it does not take a mathematical genius to work out that the will of the Floridian (and thus the national) electorate was thwarted, the outcome was an avoidable travesty, and it is Mr Gore who by right should be picking out drapes in the west wing.

Nothing fundamental is going to change now, it seems. Under America's odd rules, it is all too late. Some states may modernise their voting systems; Mr Gore is embarking on a teaching career. Move on, say all those smirking Republicans. But is it really too much to ask Mr Bush to show a bit of humility in the face of this hard evidence that Florida was a shaming, fixed-up farce?

His very first initiative as president was to rescind US funding for family planning groups providing abortion advice overseas. He simply has no mandate for such crass, divisive, ideologically driven steps. And is it too much to ask opposition Democrats in Congress to stop fawning over the new man? Most Americans did not want Mr Bush. Their voices must be heard.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: According to the usual timetable, it is about now that we must turn to the Routledge Lexicon of Political Cliche for the one about knowing the whereabouts of the corpses.
fields.body:
 According to the usual timetable, it is about now that we must turn to the Routledge Lexicon of Political Cliche for the one about knowing the whereabouts of the corpses. However in this case, purely for variety, we prefer another ghastly analogy, seeing him as the leader of a rogue former Soviet Republic - let us call it Mandikastan - just released from Moscow's yoke. Bless his heart, he has every nuclear code in his briefcase and could vaporise the region at a moment's notice. The questions, then, are why Mr Tony and Alastair are encouraging everyone all the way down to Bomber Short to rubbish Mandy with no apparent concern for the consequences? And which of the silos will he activate first when finally his temper goes entirely? From what we gather, that temper is wearing very thin indeed. And while it's not for us to speculate, you do begin to wonder about his memory being jogged about, for example, the finer details of the Bernie Ecclestone affair. We shall see, we shall see.

 The Oval ward Labour party wishes to congratulate IPPR think-tank director Matthew Taylor for his Newsnight performance the night Mandy went. Rubbishing the notion of an electoral impact, Matthew argued that what really worries High Command is voter apathy. The party must motivate the activists who attend branch meetings, he argued, and make sure they're out there knocking on doors. "We at Oval ward Labour party couldn't help wondering if this is the same Matthew Taylor," writes its treasurer, "who has not attended a branch meeting in living memory, hasn't even been to a social, and certainly hasn't been helping knock on doors to identify potential voters in the run-up to the election." Poorest of shows.

 A fond farewell to Rizla Rosie Boycott, who leaves the Express finally with £250,000. Let me make it clear once again that the Spare Rib founder only stayed so long after bungling pornster Richard Desmond bought the group from concern for her staff. Loyal to a fault, that's Rosie. We're just waiting to hear what proportion of her pay-off Rosie is contributing to those of her staff (not forgetting the website workers) sacked with almost nothing.

 Attempts to have alopecian Sun editor David Yelland sectioned over his rampaging memory loss (he can no longer be relied on to remember to turn off the gas) gather pace. Since the appeal here last week, we have been contacted by psychiatrists and social workers all of whom are willing to sign the necessary forms to put him away. Mirror editor Piers Morgan, keen to keep his old mate out of the straitjacket, has offered to fund a brief stay at the Priory, but frankly we think things may have moved too far for that. More tomorrow.

 On similar territory, after reading his explanation ("the crocodile ate my prep, honest it did, sir") in the Worthing Guardian as to why he couldn't vote either way on the hunting bill, my colleague Marina Hyde rings Peter Bottomley to ask if he is feeling quite all right? "If Matthew Norman wants to ask me about my health," replies poor Bumley, "he can call me himself." Marina says that she wants to know. "If Matthew Norman wants to ask me about my health, he can call me himself." On hearing the mantra for the tenth time, Marina's patience goes. "Where... is... your... carer?" she asks. "Could I speak to your carer?" This is too much, and the last we heard Bumley was demanding to talk to the editor. Oh dear.

 Louche gay icon Baroness Young attracts more cheeky innuendo by the day. When the saucy old haddock went on to the Today programme yesterday to make some parodic complaint about the morning-after pill, Sue McGregor couldn't resist it. "Do you think you are going to get your way in the Lords later today?" Ooh, yer Ladyship!

fields.headline: Sushi and coke - the new world of Anna Karenina
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: When Anna Karenina first appeared in Russia, Fyodor Dostoevsky put aside his feelings of rivalry towards Leo Tolstoy to declare the novel a "perfect work of art".
fields.body:
When Anna Karenina first appeared in Russia, Fyodor Dostoevsky put aside his feelings of rivalry towards Leo Tolstoy to declare the novel a "perfect work of art".

More than 120 years later the Moscow publishers of a new version of the book felt this was no longer the case, arguing that it was long-winded, somewhat dated, and in desperate need of a few pictures to lighten the prose.

So they have sought to please the modern reader by transforming the novel into an 80-page cartoon strip with lurid illustrations that owe more to Judge Dredd than Tolstoy. And to make the drama more immediate, the artists have jettisoned the backdrop of late 19th-century high society in favour of 1990s Russia.

Anna and Vronsky's liaison no longer develops in salons and ballrooms but sushi bars and strip clubs, alongside characters who cut lines of coke with their credit cards and send billet doux in the form of text messages.

Tolstoy's exposé of the moral disorder seeping through Moscow and St Petersburg's aristocratic circles has become a satire on the vacuous lives of rich post-Soviet New Russians.

The book's appearance has met with disgust in the literary community. The daily newspaper Izvestiya invited teachers, librarians and critics to a debate on the merits of such a venture, and most voiced their firm disapproval.

Critics are distressed by the loose interpretation and aghast at the reduction of nuanced dialogue to speech bubbles.

Anna Karenina does not beguile men with "the expression of utter sweetness in her charming face". The cartoonists, Valery Kachaev and Igor Sapozhkov, have turned her into a Russian Lara Croft, seen mainly in a negligee. By the end of the book she has become a depraved drug addict.

Her husband, Alexei, has been updated from a senior government official into a sinister oligarch. Vronsky's appearance has been modelled on that of John Travolta.

Ilya Tolstoy, the novelist's great-great-grandson, expressed polite dismay last night. "I can't believe that this is a serious project," he said. "I hope that our children will not start studying literature using this kind of material."

But the comic's author, Katya Metelitsa, insisted that she was inspired by admiration of the novel.

"People in Russia simply aren't used to the genre of cartoon strips, which is why there's been such a fuss," she said. "Most of the words are taken straight from the book. I think Tolstoy would have approved."

webTitle: Why can't we have a top woman judge?

fields.headline: New Zealand has one, and so has Canada. Why can't we have a top woman judge?
fields.trailText: Yesterday the sheer maleness of the British judiciary was highlighted yet again. For the first time, a woman judge sat on the Privy Council's judicial committee - the body that hears appeals from the courts of some Commonwealth countries and decides legal disputes arising from devolution.
fields.body:
Yesterday the sheer maleness of the British judiciary was highlighted yet again. For the first time, a woman judge sat on the Privy Council's judicial committee - the body that hears appeals from the courts of some Commonwealth countries and decides legal disputes arising from devolution. But was this judge British? Of course not. The Privy Council is made up of our own law lords and a few judges of equal seniority from other countries. But as no woman has ever reached the House of Lords as a law lord, none from this country has been on the Privy Council. New Zealand, by contrast, has a woman chief justice, Sian Elias, and it is she who has the hugely belated honour of being the first female judge on the Privy Council. Her judicial brilliance is spoken of in hushed tones in upper legal circles, and it turns out that she was born in Britain, of Welsh and Armenian parentage. It's not just New Zealand (which was the first country to give women the vote, in 1893) that has a woman chief justice. Canada has one too, in the equally respected Beverley McLachlin. What's wrong with us here?

In Richard Dehmel's poem, Verklärte Nacht ("Transfigured Night"), which was the basis for Schoenberg's masterpiece, a woman confesses to her companion that the baby with whom she is pregnant is not his. He forgives her, and accepts the child as his own." I do not usually use the word unprecedented, but I'll bet that this is the first time a High Court judge - the hitherto uncelebrated Mr Justice Stanley Burnton - has begun his judgment with references, in the first sentence, a) to a Nietzsche-influenced German poet who won the Iron Cross in the first world war and b) the Austrian composer and inventor of the atonal 12-note system (though I should add - which is not in the judgment - that Transfigured Night is tonal rather that dissonant). I haven't had such a cultural shock since Lord Hoffmann introduced into one of his judgments the concept of Schrödinger's Cat (no, I'm not going to explain the principle; sufficient that you know that S. was big in wave mechanics) but he didn't do it in the first few words, as Burnton did. I fear we may be on the verge of a wave of judicial intellectualism. It will soon become impossible to read a judgment without recourse to several encyclopaedias. Today a slight reference to Verklärte Nacht, tomorrow an entire judgment in German. Where will it stop?

I forgot to mention that the judicial ei-kopf (t te d'oeuf, egghead,) Burnton was giving his ruling in the case of the man suing his lover for the eight years' worth of money he'd paid out in raising their son, who, he then discovered, had been fathered by another guy, a fact which the woman had omitted to reveal. I feel a whole new area of law coming on. Should not all fathers now take blood tests to confirm - or not - their alleged paternity? Even if only a small percentage find that their paternal assumptions have been misguided, their litigation should keep several dozen lawyers in Tuscan villas for some time. Incidentally, the Lord Chancellor's Department wishes the polymath judge to be referred to, unusually, by his first name as well, as Mr Justice Stanley Burnton. That suggested to me that there's another judge called Burnton, from whom the saintly cultured one needed to be differentiated. But there isn't. Rigorous investigation finally unearthed the reason. There's a judge called Burton, and neither the press nor the legal profession can, it seems, be trusted to tell the difference between them without the help of a first name.

There's another nomenclatural story this week. The chap inquiring into the Mandelson Hinduja passport issue is Sir Anthony Hammond QC, a former Treasury Solicitor. But everyone knows him as Wally Hammond. "I wonder why", a colleague mused. What a cultural gulf that demonstrates. There was a time when Wally Hammond, one of the greatest ever English cricketers, was as nationally known - and not just to sports-lovers - as, say, David Beckham is today. But how quickly national heroes are forgotten. I'm sure my colleague now represents the vast majority in never having heard of him.
