webTitle: Ethnic minorities in the police force

fields.headline: Falling behind in the race
fields.standfirst: As forces struggle to attract ethnic minority officers  Clare Dyer reports on the Sikh policewoman who claims she was hounded out of her job by colleagues
fields.trailText: As forces struggle to attract ethnic minority officers  Clare Dyer reports on the Sikh policewoman who claims she was hounded out of her job by colleagues
fields.body:
London's royal parks are a haven of peace and greenery from urban rush and traffic fumes, a lunchtime refuge for stressed office workers. Pepe Kaur often stops off for a brief visit to St James's Park, which many find an oasis of calm. Her forays there, however, bring on palpitations and panic attacks. She goes with a psychotherapist, one of three mental health professionals treating her for post-traumatic stress disorder.

The visits are part of her therapy. Kaur claims that her illness, which is so severe that she once blacked out during an anxiety attack and woke up in hospital, is the result of her time as a probationer in the Royal Parks Police. She went on sick leave last July and has not worked since.

Her tale of how her colleagues allegedly ostracised her, compiled a dossier of false or misleading allegations against her and delayed coming to her aid in potentially dangerous situations leaves her in tears. The parks police are contesting Kaur's claim of race discrimination and victimisation against the force. An employment tribunal which is due to hear her case next April will decide whether her claims are true. Her solicitor, David Tyme, from the south London firm Fisher Meredith, says: "We do anticipate that some se nior officers will be giving evidence in support of her."

The police force has brought in an outside consultant to carry out an inquiry. "We have appointed an independent ACAS-recommended investigator to look into all aspects of the allegations and cannot comment until the investigation is completed," said a spokesman. Kaur's story suggests that it may take more than well-intentioned high-level recruitment initiatives before police forces in Britain manage to attract and retain enough black and Asian officers to mirror the diversity of the communities they serve.

The embarrassing revelation this month that the Met's 218 new "ethnic minority" recruits included 214 whites from such places as Ireland, Canada and Australia tells its own tale. Forces around the country are struggling to meet targets for black and Asian recruitment. There are proposals to merge the Royal Parks Police into the Met, and Kaur, born in Birmingham to a Sikh family, could have helped boost the figures.

She says it was always her dream to join the police. At 18 she was told by a Met recruitment officer to go out and get more experience of life and they'd welcome her back. Five years ago she had a daughter. In 1999 she passed assessments by both the Met and the parks police, but chose the latter to fit in better with her family responsibilities. With a white partner, she says she had never experienced racism and never expected to find it in the police.

But to Patrick Franklin, a black detective sergeant in the Met who has just ended an 18-month stint as national coordinator for the National Black Police Association, her story is a familiar one. Tough men have also shed tears in his room at the Home Office as they told of their experiences.

Has he encountered racism himself in nearly 19 years in the Met? "Oh, God, yes. Many times I thought of giving it up." Few blacks and Asians join the police, and those who do are much more likely than their white counterparts to leave.

A study of eight police forces carried out in late 98-early 99 by the Home Office's own policing and reducing crime unit found that retention figures for ethnic minority officers had deteriorated over the previous four years, while those for whites had improved. Ethnic minority officers were twice as likely as whites to resign and two to three times as likely to be dismissed. If they stayed, they took longer to obtain promotion or posts outside mainstream uniform policing.

The study concludes that the difference in the career patterns, according to the definitions used in the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, "is enough in itself to conclude that institutional racism has played a part in defining the careers of ethnic minority officers".

Only 20% of those interviewed for the study did not see race or racism as a problem during their careers: 60% had had negative experiences with some real or perceived impact on their careers, while another 20% reported experiencing "different" treatment but felt their careers had not been hampered. The interviewers were told bluntly: "Racism is part of the 'canteen culture'."

For another study, this time independent of the Home Office, Ellis Cashmore, professor of culture, media and sport at Staffordshire University, interviewed black and Asian officers in five police forces in the aftermath of the 1999 Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence. Interviewees believed that "persistent habitual racist practices by white officers serves as the most formidable impediment to recruitment," the report concluded. Ethnic minority officers felt they were subjected to racist abuse as a way of "testing" them.

Kaur alleges that her colleagues regularly excluded her, leaving her to patrol alone even at night. Fellow officers explained delays in answering calls for urgent assistance by claiming they couldn't understand what she was saying over the radio - she has a slight Birmingham accent with a south London overlay.

"'Urgent assistance' is the highest level of urgency," explains Franklin. "When you get that, you chuck your burgers or whatever away. It could be a life-threatening situation." Though only a probationer and on her own, Kaur had to confront a suspect carrying a stick. On another occasion she jumped out in front of a black cab and tackled a suspect unaided as he tried to leave the cab, sustaining severe bruising to her arm.

She says she looked for her colleague, but he was nowhere to be seen. "They never directly said to me 'black' or 'Paki' or whatever, but when you walk in the room they move away and they giggle." She alleges that one colleague made disparaging references to her "smell". Her notebook, in which she was recording her work experiences, went missing from her coat pocket. Later she found under a chair a necklace her daughter had made for her and which she had used as a bookmark.

The final straw was the day last July when she came on duty at 6 am. She says she had asked a colleague to ring her and tell her what time she was down on the list to go on security patrol. She came back to the station at 7.30 to discover she should have been on patrol at 7. "It was 7.30 and I was not on my ground. If an inspector from Hyde Park had come down and seen that I wasn't there I would have lost my job instantly.

"I got very, very upset. I ran upstairs and I confronted him. He said there were enough people out there. I said to him 'I asked you to tell me and you didn't tell me'. He didn't answer. I went downstairs and cried my eyes out. You feel so hurt and you just can't take it any more. And I thought I just can't carry on like this. I remember standing there at guard change, because it was time to do guard change, and you're supposed to be a strong officer standing there with all these crowds. And I'm standing there with tears coming down my face."

Afterwards she told the inspector. He handed her a brown envelope containing allegations made by her colleagues accusing her of bad time- keeping, failing to come to their assistance when summoned and incorrect paperwork. "It was all false," she says. "When I opened that brown envelope I said to the inspector 'I can't take it any more. This is the end. I've fought and I've fought for my job.'"

Her solicitor, David Tyme, observes: "It's obviously of great concern that allegations like these can be made, in particular in the current climate when every effort is being made to attract officers from ethnic minorities."

fields.headline: Take five: the daily news quiz
fields.trailText: Each weekday, we set five questions based on events in the news. All you have to do is come up with 25 correct answers by the end of the week and post them to us. The sender of the first correct entry out of the hat receives a £100 Electronic Gift Card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com)
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on events in the news. All you have to do is come up with 25 correct answers by the end of the week and post them to us. The sender of the first correct entry out of the hat receives a £100 Electronic Gift Card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com)

B1 Which organisation did the former intelligence officer Richard Tomlinson work for?

(a) MFI (b) MSF (c) MI5 (d) MI6

B2 Where did Tomlinson train?

(a) Havana

(b) Moscow

(c) Langley, Virginia

(d) Portsmouth

B3 Tomlinson was commissioned to build an alias for use in Russia. Thus Alex Huntley was born. Where was "Huntley" educated?

(a) Eton

(b) Scorton

(c) Repton

(d) Girton

B4 What was the codename of the first head of Britain's secret intelligence service?

(a) C (b) M

(c) Q (d) X

B5 How much did the secret intelligence service's HQ at London's Vauxhall Cross, which was completed in 1995, cost to build?

(a) £247m

(b) £547m

(c) £847m

(d) As if we'd tell you . . .

fields.headline: Bush embraces evangelical agenda
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush handed the religious wing of the Republican party one of its most coveted prizes yesterday when he announced plans to place church-based groups and preferences at the centre of his social policies.
fields.body:
President George Bush handed the religious wing of the Republican party one of its most coveted prizes yesterday when he announced plans to place church-based groups and preferences at the centre of his social policies.

He announced the formation of a White House office of religion-based community initiatives and said he would instruct five key federal departments, including justice, education and labour, to create their own internal offices to work with community religious groups.

"Compassion is the work of a nation, not just a government," he said after meeting more than 30 religious leaders and activists for a White House discussion, the first of several this week.

His plans were immediately attacked by groups dedicated to maintaining the separation of church and state, but they are unlikely to come under mainstream political assault from the Democrats, many of whose leaders share Mr Bush's general perspective.

Mr Bush does not want the new office to be taken as evidence that he is on an evangelical crusade. Yesterday's meeting was attended by Jewish and Islamic leaders as well as Christians, and presidential advisers told the media that the man he wants to head the the new office, Professor John DiIulio, would take a pragmatic rather than an ideological approach to his work.

"Government will never be replaced by charities and community groups," Mr Bush declared. "Yet, when we see social needs in America, my administration will look first at faith-based programmes and community groups, which have proven their power to save and change lives. We will not fund the religious activities of any group, but when people of faith provide social services, we will not discriminate against them."

The new office is expected to be in a position to distribute billions of dollars to social service and other activities organised by "faith-based" groups, many of which make adherence to a fundamentalist evangelical Christianity a condition of the programmes they offer.

Yesterday's announcement is a victory for a group of advisers close to the president whose philosophy of "compassionate conservatism" masks a determination to place evangelical Christianity at the heart of social policies, particularly those concerned with criminals and the poor.

The most important of them, Marvin Olasky, was at yesterday's White House meeting. His theories lie behind much of what Mr Bush said afterwards, though Mr Bush's assistants were anxious to play down that fact. Professor Olasky is the author of Compassionate Conservatism, a book for which Mr Bush wrote an introduction last year.

Prof Olasky sees the role of "faith-based organisations" as being to convert those with whom they deal into active believers. "Marvin is an evangelical Christian and Bush is an evangelical Christian," Prof DiIulio told an interviewer last year.

The Olasky book describes his doctrine as "a fully fledged programme with a carefully considered philosophy" that "will have to cross a river of suspicion concerning the role of religion in American society".

Yesterday's meeting was attended by several other evangelical Christian activists who share this agenda.

Among them was Charles Colson, the disgraced former Nixon administration official who now heads an organisation called the Prison Fellowship Ministries. Its aim is to see "that God's kingdom will be manifested as the redemptive grace and peace of Jesus Christ [and] experienced by those impacted by crime".

fields.headline: Sympathy for the devil
fields.standfirst: We've been getting the child-murdering Medea wrong for centuries, argue actress  Fiona Shaw and director  Deborah Warner . She isn't warped - she's perfectly normal
fields.trailText: We've been getting the child-murdering Medea wrong for centuries, argue actress Fiona Shaw and director Deborah Warner . She isn't warped - she's perfectly normal
fields.body:
Fiona Shaw's dressing room in the Queen's Theatre, London. Shaw and director Deborah Warner have just returned from an interview for Woman's Hour.

Deborah Warner: It's interesting that you can go on Woman's Hour and the first question asked is: "Is it your intention to make Medea sympathetic?" It suggests that in 2,400 years she has never been seen as sympathetic. Which is a bit of an oversight in performance history.

Fiona Shaw: The iconography is so against her. The myth of Medea is of a screeching, vengeful creature.

Warner: Previous performances make us have dangerous misconceptions about so many of these heroines. Think of when we did Hedda Gabler and how we discovered that the essence of Hedda was that she was a coward, a weak woman. We had to break through 100 years of performance history and the desire of so many actresses to play strong female roles. Here it is even harder. You have a 2,400-year-old stone to crack to get at the fossil within.

Shaw: What you are saying about people in a weak position is interesting. Audiences can identify with weakness. I think the Greek playwrights knew that. That they could entice the audience into an emotional debate about failure and dealing with being a failed person.

Warner: What's so surprising is that we are surprised by that. It leads back to our misplaced image of Medea as a strong, wilful, witchy woman who slaughters her children. In fact she spends the play struggling to find the strength to do the deed.

Shaw: Necessity provides the final push because she knows that if she doesn't kill the children, someone else will and far more savagely. I am interested by the connection between somebody's capacity to kill a child and their capacity for romance. The idea of romantic love corrupts Medea - it corrupts us all. We love the idea of someone who is prepared to give up life for another. We heap praise on couples who we perceive as being romantic.

Warner: Ah, but what happens when Posh and Becks come to grief? What is it about our society that makes us idealise the notion of romantic love?

Shaw: The idea of romantic love goes hand in hand with our sentimentalising of children. We say we put them first, but we don't. We are narcissistic in the way we love.

Warner: The children are not the centre of Medea and Jason's world. Medea and Jason are. There is a vanity about that.

Shaw: But Medea isn't a warped person. She is very normal.

Warner: She is. She loves Jason, the children, and her house. She is the happy housewife of Corinth. But there is an abnormality that must be spoken about. Her passion for Jason is so great that she murdered her brother for him. That's why when Jason wants to trade her in for a younger model, it is so devastating for her. She has given up everything for him. It is what ties them together. From the moment she killed her brother, Jason was never going to be able to just walk away from her.

He can't afford to see it like that. He believes in his argument that if he marries Creon's daughter they will get this thing called security.

Shaw: Oh yes, he believes it but he doesn't have the self-knowledge to realise what it means for Medea.

Warner: He won't or can't take on board her broken heart.

Shaw: There is part of him that just wants to start again and part that wants it all to be all right.

Warner: He wouldn't be the world's first man to think that he can have a new wife while the old one and their children are in the background.

Shaw: Surely part of the problem is that he has replaced domestic happiness with political ambition. What's that line of the Chorus? "A man tired of domesticity goes out." Domesticity is tiring, at least for men it is. That's the difference between the sexes, between Jason and Medea. What Medea mourns is her lost domestic life - for her it was a golden life.

Warner: Yes. The challenge is getting a modern audience to really understand what banishment will mean to Medea. We've lost touch with the idea. We know about refugees, we can imagine what it might be like to be awoken in the early morning by a knock at the door, marched off to Heathrow and put on a plane, but it is hard to capture just how terrible banishment would be for Medea.

Shaw: The whole thing is a challenge.

Warner: I think it is the most exacting thing I've ever done. It is unbelievably tough for the cast. It is like a piece of music. The top C has to be played at precisely the right moment or the whole thing crumbles. If you don't hit the right notes then the audience never understands why she kills the children.

Shaw: She just becomes an oddity.

Warner: More than that. If you fail to offer a reason why she does it, how necessary it is for her to kill them, it becomes pornography. There is a huge gap between her saying "die children" on page three and her actually doing it on page 49. The massive misunderstanding that has derailed this play in the past is the belief that what she says at the beginning is what she does at the end. They are two completely different things. The tragedy of Medea is that in the end, because of the other choices she makes, she has no choice but to kill her sons.

Shaw: This play reminds you of the terrible things we say casually to each other. Like: "If you don't come in from the garden I'll kill you." We excrete language. The play closes the gap between the part of you that flies off and our civilised selves.

Warner: But it's not about revenge. It is never about revenge, although it plays with the idea of revenge when she sends the bomb to the palace. I've thought about her killing the children in terms of recently documented cases of parents killing their children, often during divorce proceedings. But what comes closest is a photograph I once saw. It was of two dead little boys laid out with white blindfolds over their eyes. Standing by them was a ruddy-faced German housefrau who had been a committed Nazi supporter and the Nazis had lost. She had killed her own children and apparently, after the photographer left, she killed herself. I can't get the image out of my mind.

 Medea is at the Queen's Theatre, London W1 (020-7494 5040), until April 14.

Domesticity is tiring, at least for men it is. That's the difference between the sexes, between Jason and Medea. What Medea mourns is her lost domestic life - for her it was a golden life. Warner: Yes. The challenge is getting a modern audience to really understand what banishment will mean to Medea. We've lost touch with the idea. We know about refugees, we can imagine what it might be like to be awoken in the early morning by a knock at the door, marched off to Heathrow and put on a plane, but it is hard to capture just how terrible banishment would be for Medea. Shaw: The whole thing is a challenge. Warner: I think it is the most exacting thing I've ever done. It is unbelievably tough for the cast. It is like a piece of music. The top C has to be played at precisely the right moment or the whole thing crumbles. If you don't hit the right notes then the audience never understands why she kills the children. Shaw: She just becomes an oddity. Warner: More than that. If you fail to offer a reason why she does it, how necessary it is for her to kill them, it becomes pornography. There is a huge gap between her saying "die children" on page three and her actually doing it on page 49. The massive misunderstanding that has derailed this play in the past is the belief that what she says at the beginning is what she does at the end. They are two completely different things. The tragedy of Medea is that in the end, because of the other choices she makes, she has no choice but to kill her sons. Shaw: This play reminds you of the terrible things we say casually to each other. Like: "If you don't come in from the garden I'll kill you." We excrete language. The play closes the gap between the part of you that flies off and our civilised selves. Warner: But it's not about revenge. It is never about revenge, although it plays with the idea of revenge when she sends the bomb to the palace. I've thought about her killing the children in terms of recently documented cases of parents killing their children, often during divorce proceedings. But what comes closest is a photograph I once saw. It was of two dead little boys laid out with white blindfolds over their eyes. Standing by them was a ruddy-faced German housefrau who had been a committed Nazi supporter and the Nazis had lost. She had killed her own children and apparently, after the photographer left, she killed herself. I can't get the image out of my mind.  Medea is at the Queen's Theatre, London W1 (020-7494 5040), until April 14.

fields.headline: US rehearses space battle
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The US air force has completed its first major war game set in space, where attack satellites and lasers fought computer hackers and space planes in a simulated struggle reflecting the Pentagon's growing belief that the key battles of the 21st century may be fought in orbit.
fields.body:
The US air force has completed its first major war game set in space, where attack satellites and lasers fought computer hackers and space planes in a simulated struggle reflecting the Pentagon's growing belief that the key battles of the 21st century may be fought in orbit.

About 250 military and civilian experts spent last week at the air force's space warfare centre in Colorado rehearsing a showdown set in the 2017 between two major powers: blue (the US) and red (a thinly disguised China), which has threatened a small neighbour (probably Taiwan).

According to the Washington Post the computerised confrontation involved complex manoeuvres which stopped just short of a missile attack.

The Pentagon is taking the possibility of a military struggle for control of space increasingly seriously. The new defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, believes that national security in space has not been given enough prominence in military planning.

The view of the battlefield provided by military satellites in the 1991 Gulf war and the Kosovo air campaign in 1999, demonstrated how important space has become to US dominance. But it also showed how vulnerable that dominance may be to enemy counter-measures, such as attack satellites or ground-based lasers.

On day three, the Post reported, the two sides focused on the use of commercial satellites owned by third countries. The game's organiser, Robert Hegstrom, said that dealing with third-party commercial providers would l be a priority for CincSpace" - the US commanders for space operations.

Major-General Lance Smith, who took part in the war game, said it showed that the "space theatre" could offer opportunities to resolve crises without loss of blood.

"Space could allow us to demonstrate to an adversary how we can hurt him militarily and economically without actually carrying it out, and force him to negotiate," he said.

"It may allow a face-saving dimension for the enemy which we hadn't thought about before."

fields.headline: 'Puffy' in court
fields.standfirst: Rapper's gun trial begins
fields.trailText: One of America's best-known rappers and music producers, Sean 'Puffy' Combs, went on trial yesterday accused of illegal gun possession and bribery in the wake of a violent incident in a New York nightclub.
fields.body:
One of America's best-known rappers and music producers, Sean 'Puffy' Combs, went on trial yesterday accused of illegal gun possession and bribery in the wake of a violent incident in a New York nightclub.

One of his musical proteges is charged with attempted murder. The case packed the Manhattan courtroom.

Mr Combs, 31, known for his flamboyant style and his relationship with the actress and singer Jennifer Lopez, sat quietly in court with his co-defendants, wearing a business suit, white shirt and a silver tie, as the assistant district attorney, Matthew Bogdanos, opened the case against him.

He told the jury that witnesses would testify that they had seen Mr Combs fire a gun in a crowded Times Square nightclub on December 27, 1999. Mr Combs is not accused of shooting anyone and the bullet from his gun is said to have hit the ceiling.

The incident is alleged to have started after a man bumped into Mr Combs and spilled his drink. There was an altercation during which the man supposedly taunted him.

The court would also hear that Jamal 'Shyne' Barrow, 21, had opened fire with a semi-automatic gun, missed the man with whom Mr Combs was having the argument and hitting three bystanders. He is charged with attempted murder and assault.

The three people who were hit are suing the defendants for $100m (£68m) in a civil suit.

"Witnesses will say they saw the muzzle flash," said Mr Bogdanos of the shot allegedly fired by Mr Combs who ihas pleaded not guilty. "It appears that Mr Barrow fired three times and Mr Combs once."

Mr Combs, whose empire includes Bad Boy Records and Sean John clothes, was arrested after fleeing the nightclub with Jennifer Lopez and jumping 11 red traffic lights before he was stopped. Ms Lopez was questioned at the time but has not been charged with any offences.

Mr Combs could be jailed for up to 15 years in jail if convicted. He is being defended by Johnnie Cochran, who successfully defended OJ Simpson on charges of murdering his wife.

Mr Bogdanos said Mr Combs's driver, Wardell Fenderson, while sitting in a sports utility vehicle, saw the rapper leave the club, climb into the back seat and slip a gun into his waistband before re-entering the club.

Mr Combs allegedly offered Fenderson $50,000 to say the gun was his.

Mr Combs's bodyguard Anthony 'Wolf' Jones, 34, is also charged in connection with the incident.

fields.headline: All in the mind
fields.standfirst: Lolita is at her most seductive when she can't be seen, says  Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Lolita is at her most seductive when she can't be seen, says Michael Billington
fields.body:
Vladimir Nabokov's Lolita has always seduced adapters. Stanley Kubrick and Adrian Lyne both made films of the novel. Edward Albee hacked a Broadway play out of the book and there was even an Alan Jay Lerner musical, which mercifully expired in Boston. Now the great Italian director Luca Ronconi has staged a four-hour Lolita at Milan's Piccolo Theatre, using a translation of Nabokov's original screenplay for the Kubrick film. The result is visually stunning. It also leaves you feeling that Nabokov's novel eludes its most ardent pursuers.

Ronconi's approach is undeniably serious. He and his adapter, Ugo Tessitore, clearly understand that Nabokov's novel is not about paedophilia, but about the confrontation of European experience and supposed American innocence, and about the author's own love-affair with the English language. At the same time Ronconi tries to re-create the visual texture of the novel and its evocation of suburban American towns. But there is a contradiction here which Ronconi never fully resolves. His version tries to be "literary" and "cinematic" at the same time; but, in the contest between the word and the image, the latter inevitably wins.

In a technical sense, Ronconi's production is astonishing. Anyone who remembers his promenade Orlando Furioso, with its simultaneous performance of multiple scenes, will know he has a genius for theatrical motion. Here the stage is in constant revolution. Live action is synchronised with video images. Furniture passes across the stage as if on a conveyor belt. And there are endless levels of reality so that Humbert Humbert is shadowed by a Nabokovian narrator and there are two Lolitas on stage: an American-speaking nymphet, and another representing both her Italian voice and her sadder, older self.

The result is like an encounter between Proust and Monty Python. The Proustian element stems from the adoption of the novel's form of a confessional memory. And Python comes to mind because Margherita Palli's designs are influenced by the animations of Terry Gilliam. At best, the Proustian and Pythonesque elements magically combine, as when the hand of the adult Humbert reaches out to touch the projected image of his first love, the 13-year-old Annabel, whose premature death provoked his tragic obsession.

But the visual information overpowers the narrative. When, for instance, Humbert and Lolita first take to the road and arrive at a swank place called The Enchanted Hunters, everything is out of scale: the human figures are dwarfed by giant doors and even the purple bedroom is dominated by a king-size bed. The reference to Alice in Wonderland is wittily appropriate: in Nabokov, as in Carroll, the nymphet becomes the decadent's obscure object of desire. But you are more conscious of the bed and the visual allusion than you are of the irony of the situation: that Humbert's nervous prevarication is overcome by the matter-of-fact sensuality of Lolita herself.

That, in itself, raises the delicate question of the story's sexuality and, to be fair, Ronconi handles it with great discretion. He makes it clear that Nabokov's story is partly about the myth of childhood innocence: the younger Lolita, played by Elif Mangold, lolls teasingly on the lawn in her sun-specs and shorts, is seen getting her leg over a boy at summer camp and escapes with Humbert's doppelganger, Clare Quilty, clamped to a gigantic telephone receiver.

In general, Ronconi plays down the sexuality in order to make a larger point, that Lolita symbolises the American experience which eludes the sophisticated European emigre. That, however, merely highlights the difficulty of adaptation. In Nabokov's book Lolita is both a nymphet and a literary device. In one famous scene the hero achieves orgasm while she plays on his lap and bites an apple. In print, Nabokov makes the point that Humbert is excited by the Lolita of his imagination; if played on stage, which thankfully it is not, the scene loses its linguistic subtlety. The corporeality of the theatre is at odds with the multivalent nature of Nabokov's novel, one that constantly exists on the levels of both realism and verbal arabesque.

What one is left with in Milan is a visually audacious but over-strenuous attempt to encompass the Nabokov screenplay. You can admire the technical skill with which it is done, but the evening confirms the need to respect integrity of form. Ronconi offers a theatrical version of a screenplay derived from a novel. It has an imagistic brilliance but it can match neither the fluid rhythm of film nor the linguistic density of fiction. It offers a dazzling illustration of the novel but in the end Nabokov remains as elusive as Lolita - "light of my life, fire of my loins" - was to Humbert Humbert himself.

 At the Teatro Strehler, Piccolo Teatro, Milan until March 4. Box office: 00 39 02 72 333 222.

webTitle: Lie back and think of profits

fields.headline: Lie back and think of profits
fields.standfirst: Advertising is everywhere: on  the small screen, the big screen, the street, in the news and in   our faces. But what do we really think of it? A survey published last week revealed that most women are turned off by the images on offer. To find out more, we asked four to keep an ad diary for a day
fields.trailText: Advertising is everywhere: on  the small screen, the big screen, the street, in the news and in   our faces. But what do we really think of it? A survey published last week revealed that most women are turned off by the images on offer. To find out more, we asked four to keep an ad diary for a day
fields.body:
Oona King, Labour MP

7.30am I feel it's a bit early to watch Angela Rippon doing high-leg kicks in a micro-miniskirt, so switch off the TV. It's not fair to have a go at Angela, she's just having "a bit of fun". A talented older man would be able to continue a "serious" news career, but the talented Angela does the knickerbocker routine. Is it what she wants? Maybe, but that begs the question, why? The answer is probably a lifetime of stereotyped images. Before switching off, I see an ad for the new Peugeot 607 and ask myself what a woman's half-starved, semi-naked body has to do with a V6 engine.

Midday Another journey, another billboard and this time it's alcohol - cognac. The ad reads: "Rules? I make them up as I go along." It shows a very beautiful woman, silk dress slit to the crotch, oozing sex and availability. Again, this implies she's yours so long as the price is right. There's no getting away from it: members of my gender are portrayed as whimsical whores, no matter what the product. That is the one rule that never changes. And the one product used to sell all others is the female body.

New crime statistics show that, though overall crime is down, violent crime is up. More women being attacked. I'm an old-fashioned type who thinks crime against women is linked to media portrayals of pouting, lusting females who say no but mean yes. And even if they say yes but mean no, who cares? After all, like a car, a woman is a ticket to ride.

11.30pm Driving home after a late vote, I spot a billboard with Claudia Schiffer spread across it, advertising the "new look" Citroën Xsara. The poster reads: "Travel in a safer world." Would women be safer if they bought a Citroën Xsara? Would recordedincidents of rape fall? Obviously not, but then the point isn't to make women feel safer, it's to make men feel safer. And of course the ad doesn't have a direct link to rape. It's just one of a million daily messages telling us the most important thing about a woman is her body. And if you haven't got a woman's body to hand, go and grab one.

Midnight Arrive home. Try to wind down by watching TV. As my partner is Italian, we have Italian cable TV. Every single show includes the obligatory semi-naked attractive women prostrating themselves before the semi-ugly male presenter. I finally realise what's driving me nuts: it's not the naked women, it's the imbalance. If for every naked woman I saw a naked man, I'd be happy. And if for every semi-naked male presenter there was a semi-ugly female presenter, I'd be even happier.

At my constituency surgery earlier in the week, one woman showed me her wrists where she'd slit them. Another sobbed quietly about her forthcoming eviction. She will be on the streets, her life is in ruins, yet she clutches her lipstick like a security blanket. The lipstick, the make-up, the concealer: we know it's a mask, but most of us are suckers. Whether we like it or not, at some level we're trying to conceal the fact that we're not Claudia or Naomi or Kate. And until it's all right for us not to be - the same way it's all right for men not to be Brad or Bruce - then I will remain irritated by the sight of Sophie Dahl with her legs apart as I drive to work.

Tamzin Outhwaite, EastEnders actor

7am On my way to work, I spot a McDonald's ad which reminds me that I haven't eaten yet. I don't crave McDonald's, but I increase my speed, hoping I can grab a bacon sandwich and a coffee before work.

10am While browsing through Elle, I spot an Oasis ad with a healthy-looking girl in red lying on the grass with shiny, scarlet tomatoes all around her. She is smiling with her eyes closed, looking ecstatic. All I can think is how I need to eat more fruit and veg. I don't think: "Must rush to Oasis to buy some new clothes."

8pm Go to meet friends for a drink and am amazed to see new flats on an area that used to be a park. A billboard on the corner reads: "Stunning landmark development capturing the Islington lifestyle with Armani-suited concierge, air-conditioning, gym, parking." Could an Armani suit on a concierge really be a factor in the huge decision to buy a property? The thought that someone would be impressed by this makes me sad.

11pm Late-night ads always appear more interesting and after a long day, I am relaxing in front of the TV when I see one for Secret Satin. It consists of many flashing images of hunky, built-up men, leaving me wondering what the product is. I wait and wait, and eventually it appears. It is a deodorant and an English rose-like girl gives a sexy look. That's it? Is the message that if you wear Secret Satin you can be with men like this? Or is it that this type of man will wear you out and Secret Satin is the only way to stay dry? I resign myself to the fact that sex sells.

Straight out of one mood, into another as the next commercial has a really positive vibe. Funny how a two-minute ad can make you feel part of something big, united with the world. There is poetry displayed over beautiful lakeland images and it could have brought a tear to my eye - but now I'm staring at a direct debit sign. I know it's all about money but I can't help feeling uplifted. Conned but uplifted.

Juliet Soskice, St Luke's ad agency

7am Wake up. Put telly on. I was one of those kids brought up in the 70s by book-reading parents who didn't see the point of having a TV, especially as it contained "rubbishy adverts". The upshot is that I have become an adult obsessed by TV and by advertising.

7.05am Cup of tea. The Big Breakfast has some great ad breaks and I'm disappointed when people are snobby about advertising. Without it, there'd be no Channel 4 and your Weekend Guardian would cost you a fiver. And advertising is so often a part of the entertainment experience - would Vogue be better without all the beautiful photos selling beautiful stuff ?

7.20am Leave for gym. On my way, I pass the bus stop where there's an ad for a gentlemen's club (lap-dancing, I presume) called Spearmint Rhino, with a strangely dated photo of a pouting woman with collagen lips. It looks inappropriate, even pathetic, at this time in the morning in the cold. It'll look even stranger in an hour when the bus stop is crowded with mums, kids and OAPs. And it's offensive - of course. Unfortunately there are plenty of ads that are crass, but if you choose never to look, you're closing your eyes to something vibrant and telling about our culture.

8.30am Get to work at St Luke's, where I am marketing and new business director. The creative director is Kate Stanners, one of only two women creative directors in the top 30 London agencies. Advertising is a great business for a woman to be in, but I am terribly aware that while women organise, administrate, plan, run and direct, hardly any of us actually writes the ads. It's a great shame.

1pm At lunch I sit with a copywriter and planner - both women - and we talk about ads we like. The consensus is that creative departments often do brilliant "bloke" ads. Think of the "wobbly belly" Reebok or Tango ads, which are great if you are a bloke and great if you aren't. But why is it that only 17% of copywriters and 14% of art directors are women?

3pm R4's Today programme rings to ask if someone can go on to defend the latest IKEA ad, featuring a naked tattooed man, as it's been voted most hated ad of the year by one magazine and best campaign of the year by another. We are all delighted because advertising should be provocative and insightful, treat people intelligently and create debate. Any ad that ridicules or upsets people who don't deserve it is rarely good advertising.

7pm To pub for quick drink. Going home, I pass the Spearmint Rhino ad again and remember a poignant quote in last year's major report by Debbie Klein into women in advertising. On the lack of women in creative departments, an unnamed creative director said simply: "Just think. Who knows what great ads we could be making?" Increasingly, I think we're missing a trick.

Arabella Weir, author and comedian

4am Woken by screams of 19-month-old son. Feel sure his upset is caused by the ad we spotted yesterday for Holmes Place gym, the place to be for people hoping to lead a leaner, fuller life. He is on the chunky side and may be feeling the subtle pressure of those ads. After all, the woman emerging from the pool does seem to have everything: a good figure, lots of friends, health and a blue swimming costume. Who could ask for anything more?

7.30am Three-year-old daughter insists she must have "grittelly" (read glittery) bra top and nail polish. As am currently not working as a stripper, am puzzled to fathom where such glamorous apparel has been espied. "From the TV." Naturally, where else?

9am Childminder arrives, carrying tabloid newspaper. Feel irresistible urge to flick through it. Predictably contains article in which women are referred to as "having really taken care of themselves by losing masses of weight" in what seems an unfeasibly short space of time - assuming Class A drugs have not been involved. Feel writer is pointing finger at self as being fat, lazy old bag who doesn't care enough about the love of a good man and looking good in an imitation Chanel suit to starve herself.

10am Can't put paper down, can't do work, can't get dressed. Am locked in heroin addict-like frenzy, convinced I must phone the "calls will cost £92 per minute and should last no longer than eight years" line to learn how I, too, can look like Vanessa, Carol etc.

11.40am Have happily parted with £124. Now in proud possession of address to which I can write off for factsheet. Within days I will look like Vanessa - oh joy. In preparation for new me, decide to visit local gym.

12.10pm Am crushed as see huge poster of woman in blue swimsuit who belongs to Holmes Place and has a great figure. If she looks like that already, what's the point in me going?

12.45pm Having decided gym holds no future for me, have large coffee and heavily mayonnaised sandwich in bar. Flick through glossy mag and am assaulted by image upon image of thin, gorgeous women, all with posh three-wheeler prams, as far from our food-encrusted buggy as their glistening new Land Rover Discovery is from our beaten up old VW.

1pm Hope to find cheer in afternoon TV. Futile endeavour: every woman in an ad, be it for a car, beer, low-fat meal, even a sodding nappy, is a size 10 and wearing high heels to hang out the washing. She, the ads make clear, is a perfect mother and I am a grubby, hefty peasant. Look forward to day when a man's testicles have as much relevance to the selling of a car as a woman's body appears to today.

8pm Collapse in front of TV and am invited to reward myself for being me with chocolates and wine as advertised. Soon slip into welcome coma.
fields.bodyText: Oona King, Labour MP 7.30am I feel it's a bit early to watch Angela Rippon doing high-leg kicks in a micro-miniskirt, so switch off the TV. It's not fair to have a go at Angela, she's just having "a bit of fun". A talented older man would be able to continue a "serious" news career, but the talented Angela does the knickerbocker routine. Is it what she wants? Maybe, but that begs the question, why? The answer is probably a lifetime of stereotyped images. Before switching off, I see an ad for the new Peugeot 607 and ask myself what a woman's half-starved, semi-naked body has to do with a V6 engine. Midday Another journey, another billboard and this time it's alcohol - cognac. The ad reads: "Rules? I make them up as I go along." It shows a very beautiful woman, silk dress slit to the crotch, oozing sex and availability. Again, this implies she's yours so long as the price is right. There's no getting away from it: members of my gender are portrayed as whimsical whores, no matter what the product. That is the one rule that never changes. And the one product used to sell all others is the female body. New crime statistics show that, though overall crime is down, violent crime is up. More women being attacked. I'm an old-fashioned type who thinks crime against women is linked to media portrayals of pouting, lusting females who say no but mean yes. And even if they say yes but mean no, who cares? After all, like a car, a woman is a ticket to ride. 11.30pm Driving home after a late vote, I spot a billboard with Claudia Schiffer spread across it, advertising the "new look" Citroën Xsara. The poster reads: "Travel in a safer world." Would women be safer if they bought a Citroën Xsara? Would recordedincidents of rape fall? Obviously not, but then the point isn't to make women feel safer, it's to make men feel safer. And of course the ad doesn't have a direct link to rape. It's just one of a million daily messages telling us the most important thing about a woman is her body. And if you haven't got a woman's body to hand, go and grab one. Midnight Arrive home. Try to wind down by watching TV. As my partner is Italian, we have Italian cable TV. Every single show includes the obligatory semi-naked attractive women prostrating themselves before the semi-ugly male presenter. I finally realise what's driving me nuts: it's not the naked women, it's the imbalance. If for every naked woman I saw a naked man, I'd be happy. And if for every semi-naked male presenter there was a semi-ugly female presenter, I'd be even happier. At my constituency surgery earlier in the week, one woman showed me her wrists where she'd slit them. Another sobbed quietly about her forthcoming eviction. She will be on the streets, her life is in ruins, yet she clutches her lipstick like a security blanket. The lipstick, the make-up, the concealer: we know it's a mask, but most of us are suckers. Whether we like it or not, at some level we're trying to conceal the fact that we're not Claudia or Naomi or Kate. And until it's all right for us not to be - the same way it's all right for men not to be Brad or Bruce - then I will remain irritated by the sight of Sophie Dahl with her legs apart as I drive to work. Tamzin Outhwaite, EastEnders actor 7am On my way to work, I spot a McDonald's ad which reminds me that I haven't eaten yet. I don't crave McDonald's, but I increase my speed, hoping I can grab a bacon sandwich and a coffee before work. 10am While browsing through Elle, I spot an Oasis ad with a healthy-looking girl in red lying on the grass with shiny, scarlet tomatoes all around her. She is smiling with her eyes closed, looking ecstatic. All I can think is how I need to eat more fruit and veg. I don't think: "Must rush to Oasis to buy some new clothes." 8pm Go to meet friends for a drink and am amazed to see new flats on an area that used to be a park. A billboard on the corner reads: "Stunning landmark development capturing the Islington lifestyle with Armani-suited concierge, air-conditioning, gym, parking." Could an Armani suit on a concierge really be a factor in the huge decision to buy a property? The thought that someone would be impressed by this makes me sad. 11pm Late-night ads always appear more interesting and after a long day, I am relaxing in front of the TV when I see one for Secret Satin. It consists of many flashing images of hunky, built-up men, leaving me wondering what the product is. I wait and wait, and eventually it appears. It is a deodorant and an English rose-like girl gives a sexy look. That's it? Is the message that if you wear Secret Satin you can be with men like this? Or is it that this type of man will wear you out and Secret Satin is the only way to stay dry? I resign myself to the fact that sex sells. Straight out of one mood, into another as the next commercial has a really positive vibe. Funny how a two-minute ad can make you feel part of something big, united with the world. There is poetry displayed over beautiful lakeland images and it could have brought a tear to my eye - but now I'm staring at a direct debit sign. I know it's all about money but I can't help feeling uplifted. Conned but uplifted. Juliet Soskice, St Luke's ad agency 7am Wake up. Put telly on. I was one of those kids brought up in the 70s by book-reading parents who didn't see the point of having a TV, especially as it contained "rubbishy adverts". The upshot is that I have become an adult obsessed by TV and by advertising. 7.05am Cup of tea. The Big Breakfast has some great ad breaks and I'm disappointed when people are snobby about advertising. Without it, there'd be no Channel 4 and your Weekend Guardian would cost you a fiver. And advertising is so often a part of the entertainment experience - would Vogue be better without all the beautiful photos selling beautiful stuff ? 7.20am Leave for gym. On my way, I pass the bus stop where there's an ad for a gentlemen's club (lap-dancing, I presume) called Spearmint Rhino, with a strangely dated photo of a pouting woman with collagen lips. It looks inappropriate, even pathetic, at this time in the morning in the cold. It'll look even stranger in an hour when the bus stop is crowded with mums, kids and OAPs. And it's offensive - of course. Unfortunately there are plenty of ads that are crass, but if you choose never to look, you're closing your eyes to something vibrant and telling about our culture. 8.30am Get to work at St Luke's, where I am marketing and new business director. The creative director is Kate Stanners, one of only two women creative directors in the top 30 London agencies. Advertising is a great business for a woman to be in, but I am terribly aware that while women organise, administrate, plan, run and direct, hardly any of us actually writes the ads. It's a great shame. 1pm At lunch I sit with a copywriter and planner - both women - and we talk about ads we like. The consensus is that creative departments often do brilliant "bloke" ads. Think of the "wobbly belly" Reebok or Tango ads, which are great if you are a bloke and great if you aren't. But why is it that only 17% of copywriters and 14% of art directors are women? 3pm R4's Today programme rings to ask if someone can go on to defend the latest IKEA ad, featuring a naked tattooed man, as it's been voted most hated ad of the year by one magazine and best campaign of the year by another. We are all delighted because advertising should be provocative and insightful, treat people intelligently and create debate. Any ad that ridicules or upsets people who don't deserve it is rarely good advertising. 7pm To pub for quick drink. Going home, I pass the Spearmint Rhino ad again and remember a poignant quote in last year's major report by Debbie Klein into women in advertising. On the lack of women in creative departments, an unnamed creative director said simply: "Just think. Who knows what great ads we could be making?" Increasingly, I think we're missing a trick. Arabella Weir, author and comedian 4am Woken by screams of 19-month-old son. Feel sure his upset is caused by the ad we spotted yesterday for Holmes Place gym, the place to be for people hoping to lead a leaner, fuller life. He is on the chunky side and may be feeling the subtle pressure of those ads. After all, the woman emerging from the pool does seem to have everything: a good figure, lots of friends, health and a blue swimming costume. Who could ask for anything more? 7.30am Three-year-old daughter insists she must have "grittelly" (read glittery) bra top and nail polish. As am currently not working as a stripper, am puzzled to fathom where such glamorous apparel has been espied. "From the TV." Naturally, where else? 9am Childminder arrives, carrying tabloid newspaper. Feel irresistible urge to flick through it. Predictably contains article in which women are referred to as "having really taken care of themselves by losing masses of weight" in what seems an unfeasibly short space of time - assuming Class A drugs have not been involved. Feel writer is pointing finger at self as being fat, lazy old bag who doesn't care enough about the love of a good man and looking good in an imitation Chanel suit to starve herself. 10am Can't put paper down, can't do work, can't get dressed. Am locked in heroin addict-like frenzy, convinced I must phone the "calls will cost £92 per minute and should last no longer than eight years" line to learn how I, too, can look like Vanessa, Carol etc. 11.40am Have happily parted with £124. Now in proud possession of address to which I can write off for factsheet. Within days I will look like Vanessa - oh joy. In preparation for new me, decide to visit local gym. 12.10pm Am crushed as see huge poster of woman in blue swimsuit who belongs to Holmes Place and has a great figure. If she looks like that already, what's the point in me going? 12.45pm Having decided gym holds no future for me, have large coffee and heavily mayonnaised sandwich in bar. Futile endeavour: every woman in an ad, be it for a car, beer, low-fat meal, even a sodding nappy, is a size 10 and wearing high heels to hang out the washing. She, the ads make clear, is a perfect mother and I am a grubby, hefty peasant. Soon slip into welcome coma.

fields.headline: Scotland confirms care charge divide
fields.trailText: Britain is set to have a two-tier system of care for the elderly within 15 months after the Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, confirmed yesterday that he would abolish personal care charges north of the border.
fields.body:
Britain is set to have a two-tier system of care for the elderly within 15 months after the Scottish first minister, Henry McLeish, confirmed yesterday that he would abolish personal care charges north of the border.

The commitment followed a weekend of wrangling over whether the executive had really set itself on a collision course with Westminster by pledging to abandon the charges.

But yesterday Mr McLeish said he could be no more explicit. "We are embarking on a process which will have as its destination the implementation of free personal care," he said.

He later added: "There will be no backsliding."

The executive is working towards a programme which aims to ensure that as soon as April 2002 any elderly person living north of the border will be entitled to free personal care, which covers things like washing and cooking. But elsewhere in the UK this benefit will remain means tested and only nursing care will be free.

Downing Street yesterday ruled out any policy reversal for England and Wales and denied the move north of the border was an embarrassment. "The fact different decisions are made is not an accidental consequence of devolution," said a spokeswoman.

But pressure groups said yesterday's Scottish announcement would be used as ammunition to force amendments to the health and social care bill, currently on its way through Westminster.

"It is patently ridiculous that we are now going to have a situation where an elderly person living a few miles across the border will be up to £350 a week worse off in terms of paying for their care," said a spokeswoman for Age Concern England.

The abolition of personal care charges was a key recommendation of a recent royal commission, chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland. But it was initially rejected by the administrations on both sides of the border as too costly and of disproportionate benefit to better-off pensioners.

When he took over from the late Donald Dewar, Mr McLeish made it clear he wanted to implement the Sutherland proposals in full.

By the middle of last week Mr McLeish backtracked on the issue and the executive announced it planned only to make the means testing system used to calculate who is exempt from personal care charges more fair.

The move was widely interpreted as recognition that there was opposition to implementation of Sutherland not just from Westminster but within Mr McLeish's own cabinet.

But after Labour's Liberal Democrat coalition partners threatened to rebel and vote with the Scottish National party on the issue, the executive was forced to make an emergency statement to the Scottish parliament. The wording of that statement was ambiguous, however, and it was not until yesterday that Mr McLeish categorically committed the executive to Sutherland's recommendation, going further than many had predicted. "We are embracing the principles of Sutherland in full," he said.

Some analysts have predicted that the abolition of personal care charges in Scotland will lead to an influx of wealthy pensioners, anxious to protect their savings, from south of the border.

A spokesman for the Scottish executive said a committee led by the health minister, Malcolm Chisholm, would be looking at cross-border issues.

Jess Barrow, of Age Concern Scotland, dismissed the idea of a mass migration.

"This is Scotland, not Florida," she said.

webTitle: Five-year-old choked to death after 'incompetence at dental surgery'

fields.headline: Five-year-old choked to death after 'incompetence at dental surgery'
fields.trailText: A five-year-old girl died after a routine operation to extract a tooth because of the incompetent and improper actions of a dentist and an anaesthetist, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A five-year-old girl died after a routine operation to extract a tooth because of the incompetent and improper actions of a dentist and an anaesthetist, a court was told yesterday.

Karla Selley died in hospital in August 1999 after a visit to the Towngate dental surgery in Leyland, Lancashire.

Dentist Michael Lane, 42, of Bolton, Greater Manchester, and anaesthetist George Vanner, 67, of Bilsborrow, Lancashire, deny charges of manslaughter at Preston crown court.

Howard Bentham QC, prosecuting, told the jury that Karla choked to death on blood, mucus and debris after having her tooth removed, because of a catalogue of errors by the two men.

Mr Bentham said that Karla, of Leyland, had been taken to the surgery by her mother, Tracey, on August 9 to have a baby tooth removed.

He said that because of a previous unhappy experience when Karla had a tooth removed, it had been agreed that she would be given a general anaesthetic.

"The operation was completed very quickly and it was uneventful in its early and middle stages," he said.

"The tooth was removed without problems but as Karla was coming round from the anaesthetic, problems arose. From these problems she died."

Mr Bentham said a hospital had not been notified about the operation, as was normal. Her mouth was not swept with suction before the tooth was removed as it should have been. The court heard she was not hooked up to an electrocardiagraph machine or a pulse oxymeter to monitor her heart beat and reactions while she was unconscious and her mouth was not swept for a second time after the extraction of the tooth to remove debris, mucus and blood.

In addition there were only three people present in the room during the operation rather than four as was usual.

Following the removal of the tooth, Lane left the room against regulations, Mr Bentham said. "It's at this stage that problems began to be apparent. Karla coughed, she pushed against Dr Vanner and she changed colour."

Mr Bentham added: "The dentist should have been in the room at that stage, but he was not. He returned very quickly then because Karla was obviously in trouble and breathing resuscitation began."

These attempts, the court heard, were described by one witness as "hopeless". Mr Bentham said that if this had not been the case, Karla's life could still have been saved.

He said Karla was given an electric shock which was much too large for her weight and although this did not lead to her death it was an example of the "competence" of the resuscitation technique used on the little girl.

The court heard there was no adrenaline at the surgery and when the resuscitation team arrived they noticed Dr Vanner was unable to locate a suitable vein to inject with the adrenaline they brought.

He said that a postmortem examination showed Karla had a "peculiarity" of the heart but it was the crown's case that this was not responsible for her death.

"It is our case that the anomaly of her heart did not cause her death. That her death was caused by obstruction of the airway, that the airway should not have become obstructed if these two professional men were acting competently and properly, but that even if it did, had they been adequate and competent in the art of resuscitation she could have been held back from the danger she found herself in."

The case continues.

webTitle: We are stardust - perhaps - says Nasa

fields.headline: We are stardust - perhaps - says Nasa
fields.standfirst:
Discovery 'implies life could be everywhere in the universe'

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Nasa scientists have fashioned some of the fabric of life - in the conditions of deep space.
fields.body:
Nasa scientists have fashioned some of the fabric of life - in the conditions of deep space.

Laboratory experiments have delivered some of the complex self-assembling compounds necessary to make living cell tissue.

The research, reported today in the Proceedings of the US National Academy of Sciences, confirms that life on Earth could have been kick-started by molecules from the freezing cold emptiness between the stars. Their experiments yielded structures like the membranes that hold cells together, and protect them from the outside world.

"Scientists believe that the molecules needed to make a cell's membrane, and thus for the origin of life, are all over space. This discovery implies that life could be everywhere in the universe," said Louis Allamandola, who led the research.

The idea is at least 2,000 years old. The Roman poet Lucretius proposed a universe swarming with the seeds of life, and 100 years ago the Swedish chemist Arrhenius - who also predicted the greenhouse effect and global warming - proposed the notion of panspermia: that the chemistry of life existed in space. Astronomical research steadily confirmed the presence of vital chemicals such as water, alcohol, methane, formaldehyde, hydrogen cyanide and many others in the atmospheres of distant planets and in interstellar clouds, and then found even more complicated hydrocarbons and amino acids in meteorites from space.

But life on Earth began at least 3.8bn years ago, and the leap from organic chemistry to self-replicating organism is so huge that the astronomer Sir Fred Hoyle proposed that life might have been delivered by a passing comet.

A team from the astrochemistry laboratory at the Nasa Ames research centre and from the University of California at Santa Cruz replicated the freezing vacuum of space in the laboratory and filled it with am monia, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and methanol to form a thin ice. They then exposed this ice to the harsh ultraviolet radiation that would blast such a brew in space.

"Sure, we expected that ultraviolet radiation would make a few molecules that might have some biological interest, but nothing major," said Dr Allamandola. "Instead, we found that this process transforms some of the simple chemicals that are very common in space into larger mol ecules which behave in far more complex ways. Ways which many people think are critical for the origin of life, the point in our history when chemistry became biology."

The next step is to confirm that such molecules actually exist in space. A Nasa space probe called Stardust is already on a 2bn mile journey to an encounter with a comet called Wild-2. It will rendezvous with the comet beyond the orbit of Mars, sail through its dust tail at 13,000 mph, catch fragments of the primordial material of the solar system and bring them back to Earth in 2006. This might provide researchers with a clear picture of how stardust became not only planets, but the creatures on them.

"Every year more than a hundred tons of extraterrestrial stuff falls on the Earth, and much of it is in the form of organic material," said Scott Sandford, one of the experimenters.

"In the early life of our solar system, before the debris from its formation was fully cleared away, these materials were deposited on the Earth in far greater quantities than we see today."

fields.headline: 'He destroyed my family. I can never forget'
fields.standfirst:
Israelis are going to elect Ariel Sharon next week - despite his bloody history

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Nawal Abu Rudeinah's childhood ended on Thursday September 16 1982 when she was seven years old and a minor war hero called Ariel Sharon was Israel's defence minister.
fields.body:
Nawal Abu Rudeinah's childhood ended on Thursday September 16 1982 when she was seven years old and a minor war hero called Ariel Sharon was Israel's defence minister.

On that day the 24 members of Nawal's family had crammed into a room near the entrance of the Sabra and Shatila refugee camps, in the southern suburbs of Beirut. In the lanes outside Israel's Christian Lebanese allies - armed and trained by Israel and under Mr Sharon's command as minister - were slaughtering hundreds of people.

The following day Nawal's mother crammed a rag into her daughter's mouth to silence her. From the darkened shelter the girl heard the screams of her cousin as she was raped and killed by the Lebanese militiamen and the death rattle of her uncle who had tried to save her.

On Saturday the surviving family members were discovered. The men were taken off to be shot, and Nawal was marched away at gunpoint, stepping over the corpses in the doorway. One of the dead was her father, with the cleaver that killed him embedded in his skull. Another was her pregnant sister, Amal, whose belly was slit open.

"As we were walking, we kept looking around, and saying: 'Who is this? Oh look, this is Mohammed, and this is Ahmed'," Ms Abu Rudeinah says. At least 800 - and as many as 2,000 - people had been killed over three days.

For years it was unimaginable that Mr Sharon, who shares the blame for the deaths, could ever lead Israel. But time, and the four-month uprising in the West Bank and Gaza, have wiped out the stain of his bloody personal history, and next week, barring a miracle, Israelis will elect him their prime minister.

Visiting a West Bank outpost this month, Mr Sharon gazed out over the Jordan valley and beyond, to Iraq and Syria. "Israel is surrounded by enemies," he said. "The Jews have one tiny country where they have the right and the power to defend themselves."

The comment might have been true 20 years ago, but since that time it has signed peace agreements with Egypt and Jordan, and started negotiating with the Palestinians.

But after the intifada, which most Israelis see as a Palestinian betrayal, many Israelis are inclined to agree with him. People are yearning for an uncomplicated warrior who will promise them security, and nobody embodies that better than Mr Sharon.

"If I could get my hands on him, I would kill him," says Ms Abu Rudeinah. "He destroyed my family. I can never forget that, or anything that happened that day - the way I had to step over the bodies, and the bodies lying everywhere in the street. I hope God strikes down Sharon, and whoever had a hand in the massacre."

"My great fear is that he has a lifelong penchant for grand strategic designs that go completely awry and that prove disastrous for Israel, says Joseph Alpher, a former director of the Jaffee Centre for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University.

"This is his record. I listen to his statements about wanting to bring peace, and being more capable than [the prime minister, Ehud] Barak to bring peace, but he presents no reasonable or logical plan for doing so."

The first time Mr Sharon put one of his "grand designs" into action was in 1953, when he commanded Unit 101, a force charged with retaliating against Palestinian raiders. After the brutal killing of a woman in central Israel, Mr Sharon and his men blew up at least 45 homes in the West Bank village of Kibya, then under Jordanian control. Sixty-nine people were killed, half of them women and children.

Abroad, the operation caused outrage; in Israel it made Mr Sharon into something of a hero. Unit 101 was expanded, and Mr Sharon led other reprisal attacks in Jordan, Egypt and Syria.

Mr Sharon left the army for politics in June 1973. He was recalled later that year to command the Israeli forces which eventually crossed the Suez canal, and helped turn around the 1973 war.

In the rightwing Likud party he became was a champion of the militant Jewish settlers. But in a sense he was marking time until his defining moment: Lebanon.

In October 1981, two months after becoming defence minister, he ordered the army to prepare a war plan and within months it was in Beirut. But the following year the massacre at Sabra and Shatila brought his career crashing down.

Mr Sharon remains defiant about the massacre. Last week he told the Tel Aviv chamber of commerce: "What happened in Lebanon, which we didn't have any connection to or anything, was that Christian Arabs killed Muslim Arabs and as a result of the atmosphere of hysteria in Israel I was forced to leave my post."

But he has faced such questions only once during this election campaign. The new Sharon, as constructed by his handlers, is a grandpa in blue jeans cuddling baby goats at a farm in the Negev desert.

The idea is to make him more palatable to centrist voters who feel betrayed by Mr Barak's failed efforts to bring peace. "Even those voting for Sharon do not trust him entirely," says Yossi Verter, a columnist for the liberal news paper Ha'aretz. "Deep down, they think he is an extreme rightwinger who never voted for any peace plan.

According to Mr Sharon, now is not the time to talk about peace. He proposes a series of interim accords that freeze the amount of territory under Palestinian control, and make no concessions on Jerusalem. He says he will not negotiate with the Palestinians until the intifada ends.

"Sharon is in effect killing the Israeli and Palestinian peace process not in terms of refusing to talk, but by refusing to offer anything," Mr Alpher says.

Others say Mr Sharon is more nuanced. Last week he sent his son and a lawyer to a secret meeting in Vienna with Mr Arafat's money man, Mohammed Rashid.

Mr Rashid controls the millions of dollars that flow in and out of the coffers of the Palestinian Authority, and is believed to be a principal stakeholder in its biggest earner, a glitzy casino in Jericho.

But in Beirut, and in the Arab world beyond, Mr Sharon can never be rehabilitated.

In Sabra and Shatila, a walled-off field heaped with rubbish serves as the mass grave of the militiamen's victims.

Yamama Abdullah's hus band and four of her children are buried there.

If you ask her or Ms Abu Rudeinah who was to blame for the massacre, they say "Sharon". Dozens of people claim to have seen Mr Sharon on the roof of a nearby block of flats, watching the killing through field glasses.

And the thought of Mr Sharon becoming Israel's prime minister brings the horror flooding back.

"Oh God, no, not Sharon," says Ms Abdullah. "If Sharon comes that means war - not only for the Palestinians but for all the Arabs."

webTitle: Students to revive spa town's fortunes

fields.headline: Students to revive spa town's fortunes
fields.standfirst: University of Derby will breathe new life into Buxton
fields.trailText: Buxton, a once fashionable spa whose waters were taken by the gentry as a remedy for a variety of ills, has found a wonder cure for its own economic strife.
fields.body:
Buxton, a once fashionable spa whose waters were taken by the gentry as a remedy for a variety of ills, has found a wonder cure for its own economic strife.

Local councillors, who have struggled to reverse a decline which has lasted for a century, are celebrating the imminent arrival of the University of Derby in the town centre.

The university already has an outpost on a windy hill on the edge of Buxton. But plans will be finalised this week for the university to take over two of Buxton's - and Britain's - finest buildings and import 2,500 students to a new and elegant Peak District campus.

"Students may not be rich but they spend every penny they have in their pockets - and more besides," said Andrew Uprichard, deputy leader of High Peak borough council.

The council cannot believe its luck. The economic and social impact on Buxton, a place with an ageing population and few job opportunities, has yet to be fully assessed. But the university has attracted £80m to the local economy in Derby each year since it was created in 1992.

"The university's plans have won almost universal support," added Mr Uprichard. "Everyone sees the bringing in of a significant number of students as the injection of life that Buxton needs."

Councillors dream of new bars and restaurants and the revival of fortunes of Spring Gardens, the principal shopping street now dominated by charity shops. "Many people are already making investment decisions in anticipation of the students coming to town," said Richard Tuffrey, the council's conservation manager.

This week the university will formally acquire from NHS Estates, at the knockdown price of £100,000, the former Devonshire Royal hospital, built in 1789 by John Carr of York as a circular stable block for the horses of spa visitors.

The complex became a hospital and was given a steel roof with glass cupola in 1881. Now listed grade II, it boasts a dome which is 154ft in diameter, bigger than those of the British Museum, St Peter's in Rome, the Capitol in Washington and the duomo in Florence.

It also has an amazing acoustic quality which attracts visitors who cough, snap their fingers and whisper to each other round the walls.

"One of our challenges will be to retain the dome's wow factor," said Roger Waterhouse, the university's vice-chancellor. "The challenge will be to create an atmosphere that respects the learning function but also maximises access for the public."

Present plans suggest a variant of the British Museum's reading room, a mix of learning and cafe sociability, a place to meet and exchange ideas. As part of the £8.5m scheme, former wards will be converted to lecture theatres and new uses will be found for 13 other buildings on the site. The first students should arrive in September 2002.

The university will also cure a Buxton headache and give a boost to the local tourism economy by moving into The Crescent, a Georgian range of hotels and lodging houses built by John Carr to accommodate spa visitors. It is listed grade I but has been empty for 15 years.

Following the closure of a hotel in the mid 80s, the building rapidly declined until it was jointly acquired by the High Peak and Derbyshire county councils.

Emergency repairs made the exterior wind and waterproof but the interior, including a magnificent ballroom used variously as a hospital and a library, was untouched.

But in December a trust formed by the two councils submitted a £10.9m bid to the heritage lottery fund as part of a £15.5m restoration scheme. The councils have found a preferred developer and The Crescent will become a four-star training hotel managed by the university's new international school of tourism and hospitality management: 69 guest bedrooms (with bathrooms having running Buxton spring water), 25 student bedrooms, two restaurants, conference spaces and spa and fitness centre. It should open in 2003.

"We are planning a renaissance of the core of 18th and 19th century Buxton," added Professor Waterhouse. "We know we have the ability to breathe new life into the town. Buxton will feel different. But the scheme will also have a cultural impact on the town, which should have a great future as a centre for the arts."
