fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hit-and-run driver spared jail
fields.body:
Hit-and-run driver spared jail

A hit-and-run motorist who drove to a pub two miles away with the body of his victim on his car roof was spared jail and given 160 hours' community service yesterday. Wakefield magistrates court accepted that Craig Gant, 29, of Wakefield, had been traumatised by the incident and had not driven on to evade the consequences.

Couple escape gun attack

A couple escaped unharmed after three shots were fired at their home in the nationalist Ardoyne area of Belfast yesterday. The loyalist paramilitary group, the Red Hand Defenders, claimed responsibility.

Sewage hits water supplies

Radioactive sewage has been overflowing into the river Misbourne in Buckinghamshire causing the closure of local drinking water boreholes, the environment agency revealed yesterday. It said the problem, caused by heavy rain, was not dangerous.

Brittle bone pill launched

A once-a-week pill, Fosamex, that helps prevent post-menopausal women developing brittle bones was launched yesterday. Osteoporosis affects one in three women, and up to 12,000 women die each year after hip fractures due to osteoporosis.

Boxer faces jail over assault

Former world heavyweight champion boxer Herbie Hide, 29, was yesterday warned that he could be jailed after being convicted of punching and kicking a civil servant in a Norwich nightclub in May. He will be sentenced at Norwich magistrates court on February 28.

Beatles top 'rich list'

Sales of the Beatles greatest hits package, called 1, helped them top a pop "rich list" with earnings of £55m in the past 12 months, say researchers for Heat magazine. U2 were second, earning around £50m, and Sir Elton John third with £35m.

Revenge more sweet for women
Nearly two-thirds of women would seek revenge if they were betrayed by a partner, compared with just under half of men, according to a survey for Bella women's magazine .

British Library papers on net

Details of more than 10m documents from the past 500 years are to be made available on the internet through an initiative launched yesterday by the British Library. The British Library Public Catalogue, available through www.bl.uk, holds one of the world's biggest reference collections.

Cell death inquiry

Police are investigating the death of a man suffering from hypothermia who was held for nine hours in a police cell. The unnamed 34-year-old was arrested in Leicester early on Sunday and died at Leicester royal infirmary.

End of the road - at last

One of Britain's longest running and most expensive roadworks was finally completed yesterday at a total cost of £125m. Work on the mile-long Avonmouth Bridge, near Bristol, began in June 1995.

10 hurt in factory blast

Ten factory workers were last night recovering in hospital after an explosion at a ceramics plant at Clydebank, near Glasgow.

None was seriously hurt. They suffered burns and the effects of inhaling solvents in the blast at Thor Ceramics.

Stick-up

Booklets of self-adhesive stamps were yesterday on sale for the first time. They could eventually replace the old-fashioned gummed postage stamps.

Goat guard

Northumberland Wildlife Trust is seeking a ranger to look after a herd of 75 wild goats on its nature reserve at Whitelee, near the Scottish border.

webTitle: Portrait of Swift comes to light

fields.headline: Portrait of Swift comes to light
fields.trailText: A portrait of Jonathan Swift, said to have been a gift to his housekeeper, has gone on display for the first time.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy  Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A portrait of Jonathan Swift, said to have been a gift to his housekeeper, has gone on display for the first time.

The former dean of St Patrick's cathedral in Dublin was known for his ferocious satires, including Gulliver's Travels, and A Modest Proposal, which suggested the unwanted children of poor Irish people might be used as delicious meals for the rich.

However, he was kind to his servants leaving several of them bequests in his will. Most portraits of the writer show a stern man. But one which is now at Marble Hill house, in Twickenham, south-west London, by Irish painter Francis Bindon, shows a relaxed man, wearing a cap on his own long grey hair instead of a wig.

Swift, typically, was not happy with the result. "I have been fool enough to sit for my portrait at full length by Mr Bindon," he wrote.

A handwritten note on the back of the 18th century canvas says that Swift left it to his housekeeper, a Mrs Ridgeway. After Swift's death she married the sexton of St Patrick's, Henry Land, which gives some authority to the separate note which says that the plain looking frame was made from timbers from the cathedral - St Patrick's was restored on several occasions in the 18th and 19th centuries. The painting was sold in 1835 and was in the hands of private collectors for many years.

It was spotted alongside a portrait of Swift's protege, John Gay, author of the Beggar's Opera, in the stores of a London gallery by English Heritage's head of collections, Julius Bryant.

The gallery owner, Philip Muld, was able to negotiate a long loan from the private owner for both pictures to Marble Hill house, a house which both men knew.

The house was built by Henrietta Homoney, a royal mistress, with the money with which the Prince of Wales pensioned her off.

She was a friend of many of the writers who lived or stayed in Twickenham, including what was then one of the most fashionable outskirts of the city, including Horace Walpole and Alexander Pope.

webTitle: Letters: Legal aid solicitors present their case

fields.headline: Legal aid solicitors present their case
fields.trailText: Attorney general Lord Irvine's principal private secretary, Debora Matthews, describes the purpose of the reform of criminal legal aid as being to ensure a quality-assured service and provide good value for money for the taxpayer (Letters, January 25).
fields.body:
Attorney general Lord Irvine's principal private secretary, Debora Matthews, describes the purpose of the reform of criminal legal aid as being to ensure a quality-assured service and provide good value for money for the taxpayer (Letters, January 25).

Remuneration for this work has increased only once in eight years. All practitioners now have a quality assurance "franchise". Most are frequently called out at night and at weekends. Value for money has never been greater. Yet the government is now trying to impose on the profession a new contract that has been described in independent legal advice as unfair and one-sided.

It includes unilateral provision for the government to change major terms and additional bureaucratic quality assurance measures of dubious worth.

Even now, the likely remuneration under the contract is unclear. The Law Society has advised firms not to sign it; and no business organisation could sensibly be advised to do so. This, and not the salaried defender service, is the immediate problem in the reforms.

LAPG and others involved in negotiations are working hard to agree a fair contract in order to avoid a potential crisis in the criminal justice system. Otherwise there may be no solicitors available in the courts and police stations from April 2.
Richard Miller
Acting director, Legal Aid Practitioners' Group
richard@lapg.co.uk

fields.trailText: You highlight the challenge of Lib Dem MSPs securing free personal care for Scotland (Report, January 27). The decision turns the spotlight on the plans Labour is driving through Westminster. English health ministers are promoting the meanest possible scheme of free nursing care. If a nurse provides your care it will be free. But if a care assistant provides the same care, it will come with a price tag.

webTitle: Bigger payout 'still not enough' for machete girl

fields.headline: Bigger payout 'still not enough' for machete girl
fields.trailText: An eight-year-old girl who was scarred for life four years ago in a machete attack at a teddy bears' picnic had her compensation award almost trebled yesterday.
fields.body:
An eight-year-old girl who was scarred for life four years ago in a machete attack at a teddy bears' picnic had her compensation award almost trebled yesterday.

However, the decision by the Criminal Injuries Compensation Appeal Panel was criticised by her lawyers, family and local MP who said it had not gone far enough and highlighted the inadequacies of the existing tariff scheme.

Francesca Quintyne was one of three children and four adults injured when a schizophrenic ran amok at St Luke's school in Blakenhall, Wolverhampton, in July 1996.

Last year she was awarded £8,100 for her injuries but her parents have been fighting to have the compensation increased ever since. Yesterday, the panel agreed to raise the amount to £23,625, a decision which has prompted the parents of two other victims to announce they would also be seeking legal advice about increased compensation.

Francesca was slashed in the face by Horret Campbell. Her jaw was fractured and her earlobe cut off. The panel accepted evidence from her barrister Cherie Booth QC last week that Francesca has symptoms of post traumatic stress disorder but did not make an award for future treatment of her physical injuries.

The girl was also awarded another £2,500 for future psychological therapy plus £750 for severe facial scarring and £375 for fractures and other injuries which needed operations. Ms Booth, who acted for nothing after meeting the girl's mother two years ago, had urged the four members of the panel at central London to raise the payout to the £80,000 maximum.

Francesca, from Tipton, West Midlands, was seeking a £20,000 award for psychological damage and further funds to ensure she could have private health care. The panel reserved its decision until yesterday to weigh up the trauma suffered by Francesca under its tariff scheme. The panel said Francesca could appeal for more if the scarring needed further treatment than was covered by the current award.

Her mother, Sheridon Quintyne, said: "We never asked for the earth. We wanted what was fair. How can £750 for the scarring be called fair?

Campbell was jailed for life in 1996 after being found guilty of seven counts of attempted murder.

Tom Jones, of Thompson's solicitors, who presented Francesca's appeal, said the appeals panel went to the limits of the scheme but it was not enough.

"The message it gives is that if you are the innocent victim of an attack by a madman your injuries are worth less than if you are injured in a car crash."

This decision exposed a "grossly unfair system" which the government must radically reform as it had pledged to do before the last general election, Mr Jones said.

Francesca could also need extensive plastic and reconstructive surgery to try to reduce scarring. Under the current system, the victim gets 100% of the tariff for their most serious injury, 10% for their second and 5% for the third.

Lisa Potts, the nursery nurse awarded the George Medal for shielding children at the party, said: "Every time Francesca looks in the mirror she is reminded of that dreadful day."

Last night Mrs Saba Malik and Mrs Surinder Chopra said both their children were still suffering mentally and physically four years after the attack and pledged to fight for more compensation.

Reena Chopra got £6,000 after receiving cuts to her face. Ahmed Malik, who suffered a broken skull and cuts, was awarded £6,250. "Ahmed received just £6,250," Mrs Malik said. "Francesca's parents were right to appeal against their daughter's award. We want to do the same for our son."

fields.trailText: In a report headed Little Rock firm with Clinton links rescued HLS [Huntingdon Life Sciences], page 20, Finance, yesterday, we should have made it clear throughout that until recently the key lender to HLS was Royal Bank of Scotland and not Bank of Scotland. They are two distinct organisations.
fields.body:
In a report headed Little Rock firm with Clinton links rescued HLS [Huntingdon Life Sciences], page 20, Finance, yesterday, we should have made it clear throughout that until recently the key lender to HLS was Royal Bank of Scotland and not Bank of Scotland. They are two distinct organisations.

Pat Arrowsmith has asked us to make it clear that, contrary to the impression we may have given in an article, Perverting the course of justice?, pages 14 and 15, G2, January 22, she was not tried and acquitted with others in the 1970s of inciting troops to disaffect. She was the sole defendant in a separate trial for incitement to disaffection, was convicted and sentenced to 18 months in prison.

In a report headed £4.5bn on offer to revive rail service, page 13, January 25, we said, "Tourists pouring off the Channel ferries or approaching London on Eurostar from Paris or Brussels have expressed their shock at seeing such a rundown station [Clapham Junction] at the southern gateway to the capital". None of these services goes to or through Clapham Junction.

Microsoft have asked us to say that, contrary to what we stated in Get ready for a pager on steroids, page 7, Online, January 25, Bill Gates does not possess a BlackBerry pager.

In our survey of prisons (the best and worst), page 7, G2, yesterday, we placed Portland young offenders' institution "on a remote Devon peninsula". It is in Dorset.

The Olympic cox Rowley Douglas became Edith Douglas in the birthdays column, page 24, January 27. This was an editing error which deprived Edith Cresson, the former French prime minister of all but the merest hint of her birthday. She was 67. Apologies to both.

The home of the Brontë family is Haworth, not as it appeared on page 11, Saturday Review January 27, Howorth.

Homophone corner, from an article headed Farewell, focus groupie, page 22, Comment, January 27: "The people cleaning out Peter Mandelson's offices at Labour party headquarters had a bit of a shock when they unlocked the stationary cupboard."

webTitle: More friction over the Middle East

fields.headline: More friction over the Middle East
fields.trailText: After all the transparent half-truths and distortions which have been written on the Israel-Palestine issue in recent months, by supporters of both sides, we might have thought that every idiocy had now been aired.
fields.body:
After all the transparent half-truths and distortions which have been written on the Israel-Palestine issue in recent months, by supporters of both sides, we might have thought that every idiocy had now been aired. That would have been to underestimate the inventiveness of David Hirst (Israel's survival is far from assured, January 27).

To liken the foundation of Israel to the accumulation of overseas colonies by European powers is breathtakingly absurd. The "conquistadors" in this case were dispossessed refugees who had managed to escape the genocide in Europe and to breach the British blockade, and who were joining an established Jewish community. They were forced to leave behind them 6m who, far from dreaming of the riches of empire, would have been content simply to find a land in which they were permitted to stay alive.
Tim Wright
Huddersfield
thwright@talk21.com

David Hirst's warning of the dangers now facing Israel, as it prepares to make a decisive turning into what may prove to be a cul-de-sac of history, should be obligatory reading for all European leaders as well as for President Bush. A European initiative could begin to build the international pressure required for a historic compromise, based on the results of a UN fact-finding mission.

This would reveal, among other things, the true extent of the concessions already made by the Palestinians and the need to treat Jerusalem ("the holiest of cities") as a matter of global concern (perhaps as an autonomous "international city of peace").

To suggest that such a historic compromise "must, if necessary, be imposed by force", as Hirst does, is surely unrealistic? But Israel's intransigence does suggest the need for some form of sanctions to be applied.
Prof David Seddon
University of East Anglia

David Hirst claims Israel is the only surviving European settler colonial state. Has he forgotten the US, Canada and Australia? Maybe the lesson for the Zionist state is that if you do a thorough enough job of eliminating the indigenous population, people will forget that you are a settler state.
A Dawar
Cambridge

webTitle: Letters: Why it's not a gay thing

fields.headline: Why it's not a gay thing
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams's verbal assault upon Peter Mandelson, (It's a gay thing, January 27) depends upon the assertion that homosexuals of a particular period are marked by the same negative characteristics and behaviour.
fields.body:
Hywel Williams's verbal assault upon Peter Mandelson, (It's a gay thing, January 27) depends upon the assertion that homosexuals of a particular period are marked by the same negative characteristics and behaviour.

The conviction that present-day homosexuals, unlike their heterosexual counterparts, are inherently unreliable, dishonest and self-destructive, unfit to do anything more than act, make dresses, cut hair and decorate shop windows, flourished in the age of gay witch-hunts - the 50s. Self-loathing homosexuals of Mr Williams's sort might well cling to a belief in such stuff.

But by publishing an article dependent upon this discredited, malign claptrap, complete with tasteless references to "bare-backing, "one man's bitch" and "the shifty fudge-packer", the Guardian becomes the transmitter of a form of homophobia more virulent than anything published by the tabloid press.
Nicholas de Jongh
London

Hywel Williams gratuitously inserted a paragraph about Gavin Young into his nasty, confused, illiterate ("truistically"!) article. I wrote the obituary of Gavin Young which you published last Monday (January 22). I did not mention homosexuality because, despite 40 years as, first his editor and then his colleague and friend, I never regarded it - unlike Mr Williams - as relevant to his work as a foreign correspondent and author.

Mr Williams evidently trades on his own homosexuality. Why should that give him the licence to make casual assertions (two days after the funeral) about the private life of a brave and admired man - or you to publish them?
Michael Davie
London

For 20 years, a senior civil servant, I fought openly for equal gay rights. These include recognition that sexuality has nothing to do with competence or reliability, and is irrelevant to nearly all work. The idea that gays are by culture chancers and deceivers - more than heterosexuals - is rubbish.

All of us make slips we live bitterly to regret. Decent folk then give us a hand up, not a kick. Mandelson has done much for his country and I hope he can one day continue his work, with the support of his life's partner.
Ian Buist
London

Mandelson is the scapegoat for the public's dislike of the deceitfulness and hypocrisy in British politics. And there lies the bitter irony: his ability to cut through the humbug and speak as he finds has contributed to his downfall.
Richard Salmon
London

Thank you for your accurate insights into Mandy. I have become a specialist in self-harming behaviour, especially anorexics and self-slashers, and can readily confirm your points from my clinical experience.
Dr Bob Johnson
Consultant psychiatrist, special unit, C-wing, Parkhurst prison

At least I understand one bit of it, namely the reference to Methodist dullness, where clearly he is out of his depth.
Rev Dr Timothy Mark
(Methodist minister) Doncaster timothy.mark@eggconnect.net

Homophobia thinly disguised as political commentary? It's OK, the author's gay.
Aine Duffy
London Aine.Duffy@tandf.co.uk

What a splendid, original, brilliant piece! Boy, is he ever going to take the heat off me this week!
Julie Burchill
Brighton

fields.headline: Memorial to humanity
fields.trailText: In the wake of this country's first Holocaust Memorial Day it might be well to remember that these events are more successful as vehicles for secular reconciliation or quasi-religious redemption than as devices for the understanding and explanation of what will always remain political phenomena (Comment, January 29).
fields.body:
In the wake of this country's first Holocaust Memorial Day it might be well to remember that these events are more successful as vehicles for secular reconciliation or quasi-religious redemption than as devices for the understanding and explanation of what will always remain political phenomena (Comment, January 29).

It was heartening, therefore, to hear the prime minister refer to democracy at the event at Westminster Hall, because it acknowledged that the most formidable barriers to genocide are to be found not in sentimental forms of community based on our "common humanity", but in political and legal institutions and social structures capable of having a constraining effect on human passions.
Charles Turner
University of Warwick sysat@dredd.csv.warwick.ac.uk

I would like to suggest two achievable steps which this country could and should accomplish before the next Holocaust Memorial Day.

Firstly, the UK should ratify the statute of the international criminal court. This treaty has been ratified by 37 nations so far and needs a total of 60 ratifications to enter into force: the UK should be in that number.

Secondly, UK involvement in the torture trade should be outlawed. Torture is perhaps the most extreme form of persecution and is still practised in over 60% of the world's nations. Amnesty International estimated that over 6,000 torture victims sought asylum in th UK in the last year alone. It is now illegal to export torture equipment from the UK, but individuals from the UK can still legally act as brokers in the torture trade: this must be outlawed.
Dr Martin Juckes
Oxford
juckes@atm.ox.ac.uk

fields.headline: Models for prostitution
fields.trailText: Those who live in areas afflicted by kerb crawlers will welcome the name and shame campaigns by police in Manchester and Merseyside (Crackdown forces out prostitutes, January 29).
fields.body:
Those who live in areas afflicted by kerb crawlers will welcome the name and shame campaigns by police in Manchester and Merseyside (Crackdown forces out prostitutes, January 29). But no one suggests this will put an end to prostitution. Brothels were legalised in the Netherlands last autumn. The intention is to curb the exploitation of women, protect minors, and safeguard public health. It is a sensible, mature approach which the government would do well to emulate.
Chris Davies MEP

Mobiles may be one reason people use phone boxes less (Phone boxes near the end of the line, January 29), but the phone card is another. Not long ago, you put the card in, dialled and spoke to the person. The last £3 card I bought involved having to wait for and then listen to a voice instruction, then being told how much money was left on the card and its expiry date - all an absolute waste of time. The card also failed to work in the first three phones I tried.
Simon Lawton Smith
London

You suggest (Leader, January 29) that now Mr Mandelson has been described as "slightly detached", it may be said of a future politician: "I'm afraid he's becoming a bit of a bungalow." Been there, done that. In the valleys of south Wales, if a man is known as Dai Bungalow, it means that he hasn't got much upstairs.
Rhys Williams
Lampeter, Dyfed

These shiny CDs (Letters, January 29), exactly compatible with my budgie's perch, provide him with hours of interactive games, and thus me with endless chirpy music.
Rick Collet
Maidstone, Kent

Why does the front cover of No Logo (Letters, Janaury 29) have TM at the base of its title design?
Doug Devaney
Brighton

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Norway | Austria | Montenegro
fields.body:
Racist killing shocks Norway

The suspected racial murder of a black teenager has led to a debate in Norway on whether to ban neo-Nazi groups.

Benjamin Hermansen, 15, was stabbed in a district of Oslo on Friday. Five suspects linked to a neo-Nazi group have been arrested and a sixth is sought. Culture minister Ellen Horn said yesterday the government should consider a ban on neo-Nazi groups. AP, Oslo

Heater theory in ski-train fire

The fire which engulfed a funicular ski train in Austria in November, killing 155 people, may have been caused by a fault in the heating system, according to an investigator.

The expert told the weekly magazine Profil that he supported two theories of the cause of the blaze in Kalprun: a defective coil in the heating system and ski-clothing placed over a radiator. Kate Connolly, Berlin

Fatal blast in Montenegro

At least one person was killed yesterday in an explosion that brought down a three-storey building in Berane, northern Montenegro. Reuters, Podgorica

fields.headline: Jailed French terrorists' hunger strike gains support
fields.trailText: One of the founders of Action Directe, once France's most feared terrorist movement, entered the seventh week of a hunger strike yesterday as leftwing politicians and human rights groups began a national campaign for more humane treatment for the group's jailed leaders.
fields.body:
One of the founders of Action Directe, once France's most feared terrorist movement, entered the seventh week of a hunger strike yesterday as leftwing politicians and human rights groups began a national campaign for more humane treatment for the group's jailed leaders.

Jean-Marc Rouillan was convicted in 1988, with Georges Cipriani, Nathalie Ménigon and Joëlle Aubron, of more than 50 attacks, including the assassination of the then Renault chairman Georges Besse, who was shot by the two women outside his flat in 1986, and of General René Audran.

Sentenced to multiple terms of life imprisonment, the four have spent most of the past 12 years in solitary confinement in high-security jails and are all now suffering from physical and mental breakdown, the campaigners said. Aubron is also on a hunger strike, which began on January 8.

"The government cannot allow this situation to continue," said Nicole Borvo, a Communist member of the French senate.

"The Action Directe four need medical care, visiting rights, transfers to jails meant for long-term detainees. These are not exorbitant demands. If they are not granted, someone quite soon is going to die in prison."

Artists and intellectuals have joined the campaign, backed by the Communist and Green parties. "They being treated with almost unimaginable inhumanity," said the film-maker Yves Boisset.

"What's the sense of it, for people who so clearly represent no threat whatsoever to anyone?"

Ménigon, a revolutionary communist who co-founded Action Directe in 1979, has had two heart attacks, is paralysed on her left side and suffers from severe speech problems, the campaigners said. Cipriani, the group's Tunisian-born treasurer, has lost most of his teeth, is "barely aware of who or where he is", and has refused psychiatric help.

The product of a lost generation of young idealists, Action Directe was the inheritor of Germany's ultra-left Red Army Faction, with which it eventually merged, and the Italian Red Brigades. It lasted only eight years but engaged in a particularly bloody struggle against the French military-industrial complex.

Opposed to France's policy in Africa, property speculation, arms production and big employers, its largely symbolic early attacks focused on targets such as ministries and corporate headquarters. But its suspected 30-odd members were later held responsible for a number of murders, including two policemen and a gendarmerie general.

Rouillan, the son of a teacher from southern France, was first convicted of terrorist activities in Spain when he was 17. He has said his hunger strike is intended to ensure that his former colleagues get medical attention, and that he himself is transferred to a detention centre nearer his family.

He has asked not to be fed intravenously should he lose consciousness.

"What's happening here is simply not acceptable," said Henri Malberg, a Communist MP.

"A man is putting his life in danger, and what he is asking for any normal state could sort out with three letters and four telephone calls. This may be deeply embarrassing for the Socialist government, but if someone dies it will be a lot worse."

fields.headline: On the web
fields.trailText: Food chains | The Gothic
fields.body:
 Food chains

An introduction

www.science.org.au/nova/039/039box02.htm

Suitable for older KS2 pupils

As an Australian Academy of Science site, it's not directly linked to our national curriculum but it's still helpful. Covers the transfer of energy from one animal to another and loss of energy through body heat. Links to Science Education, Primary Investigations and Sample Lessons are worth a look.

Activities

www.clickteaching.com

Suitable for KS1/2 pupils

Select Science, then Animals and Habitats, where there are several activities depending on your children's age (eg, for year 3 there is a cut and stick activity about a simple food chain). For years 4 and 5 select Teaching Food Chains for a sample lesson which includes all the essential vocabulary. You can also download a wall display, which uses a lot of ink but provides very clear material.

The food pyramid

www.alienexplorer.com/ecology/topic4.html

Suitable for KS2 pupils

A US site, so American animals are used as examples, such as beavers, moose and groundhogs along with the more familiar mice, rabbits and deer. Children could be asked to come up with British examples. Just a pity that advertising by the site's sponsor is so persistent.

Lesson plans

www.alternativeparenting.com/lesson_plans/3_through_6/ science_nature/web_of_life.htm

Suitable for KS1 pupils and teachers

A simpler American site offering a lesson plan suitable for KS1. One practical activity shows how every living thing is dependent on everything else.

Resources for teachers

web1.si.edu/sites/educate/ troprain/foodchai.html

Suitable for teachers

The introductory information is quite clear. Select Creating Food Chains and Food Webs for some lesson ideas.

Jim Merrett

 The Gothic

The Literary Gothic

www.litgothic.com

Suitable for teachers/KS5 students

An exhaustive list of Gothic authors, accompanied by several rare works available as e-texts. Useful resources include concise and readable definitions of Literary Gothicism, Romanticism and Victorianism, as well as a useful page entitled "Elements of the Gothic Novel".

Monsters

www.wsu.edu/~delahoyd/monsters.html

Suitable for KS3/4/5 students and teachers

A strange site detailing the literary and cinematic appearances of various monsters. As well as a small picture gallery, an interesting essay on monsters in the Middle Ages is featured.

The Gothic Literature Page

members.aol.com/iamudolpho/basic.html

Suitable for teachers/KS5 students

A good bibliography, some decent essays (including a brief survey of criticism on the Gothic) and an impressive resources page make this site amongst the best of its type available. This site is particularly strong on the writing of Ann Radcliffe.

Fortean Picture Library

www.forteanpix.demon.co.uk/fsubind.html

Suitable for KS3/4/5 students and teachers

This collection of striking images could form the basis of an investigation into what makes a monster for younger students, or, with older students, how a society's fears are translated into monsters. Ghosts, giants, aliens, yetis and dragons are all represented

The Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy

www.utm.edu/research/iep

Suitable for teachers/KS5 students

Students interested in the theoretical framework of the Gothic (Kant, terror, horror, the sublime), could be directed here as part of independent research. Equally useful for teachers hoping to brush up on their technical vocabulary.

The Gothic Novel

www.academic.marist.edu/faculty/gothicno.htm

Suitable for KS4/5 students and teachers

Best suited to work with 19th and 20th century texts (with an attempt to address the Gothic theme in contemporary fiction), although its Dictionary of Sensibility is a particularly handy way into the imagery of Gothic texts.

Lyndsey Turner

webTitle: The first of a series of schools taking part in the dream school competition

fields.headline: Pupil power
fields.standfirst: This month we launched a competition, asking children to design their dream school.  Claire Phipps visits the first of a series of schools that are taking part
fields.trailText: This month we launched a competition, asking children to design their dream school. Claire Phipps visits the first of a series of schools that are taking part
fields.body:
Ask any child to describe their dream school, and chances are they'd have something to say about teachers. The teachers at Kilmorie primary school in London are lucky: they would at least be part of their pupils' ideal school. But there are some ground rules.

"Teachers need to interact with you," explains Holly, 11. "A teacher should be funny," chips in Vicki, nine, "but they have to teach you, too."

And what they say counts. Class councils, from reception age upwards, mull over and decide the issues for representatives to take to the weekly school council meeting. Acting head Ken Johnson - Ken to the children - sometimes attends; often, though, he leaves the children to get on with it.

Council members have complained about drivers parking on the yellow lines outside the school. They've contributed to the school's bullying policy. And this month they played a crucial part in recruiting a new headteacher by compiling a wish-list for the ad.

"Kind . . . playful . . . respects children . . . not posh," were their top criteria. And who better to ask, says governor Jane Hinnrichs. "It seemed obvious - the children would see him or her every day," she explains. "They know the rules of the school, because they've helped draw them up, and they know the sort of thing they want."

And on April 25 they'll be able to demonstrate exactly what they want. Kilmorie will be - for one day only - in the hands of the children as part of a project, along with schools in the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Portugal, to design a school day.

"I've tried not to say no to anything," says Ken. "Their plans so far have been quite thoughtful and focused, and much more practical than you might expect."

Plan A, explains Huy, 11, is to "have different teachers teaching different activities in different rooms." Teachers would enthuse about their favourite subjects - art, literacy, maths, music - while children pop in and out. The school intends to submit the plans, ideas and discussions for the children's day in charge for Education Guardian's The School I'd Like competition (see details below).

And in case this all sounds far too sensible, the children have other ideas. Huy would like a high-tech school, Holly to be closer to the seaside. Vicki wants water slides in the playground. But this is a school council that knows its limits. Still, if you don't try... As Ken puts it: "A lot of schools think children can't make a contribution - because they haven't asked them."

To enter the competition: Email education@theguardian.com or write to Education Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER for an entry form. Visit www.educationunlimited.co.uk for more details.

The prizes: The winner in each of the three categories (primary; years 7-9; years 10-13) will receive £10,000 of Toshiba ICT equipment and Microsoft software for their school.

To see your school featured here, contact the above address.

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: Fireman Sam | Investigating Christianity
fields.body:
Fireman Sam (The Productive Play Company, £17.01 + VAT, www.prodplay.co.uk) Age 4-7yrs

This cross-curricular package introduces pupils to various skills via 10 activity modules, 30 levels of play, activity sheets, a workbook and worksheets. The animations and narration suit the pupils well, engaging and motivating them. Once they have completed certain activities, pupils are promoted to the next level of training with more complicated tasks. The program is well designed, with a clear, intuitive navigation. The Fireman Sam icon can be clicked to remind the user what to do next. Although aimed at the mainstream classroom, it has real value for special needs pupils.

Investigating Christianity (Heinemann Educational, New version £52.50 + vat) Age KS4

This package supports the teaching of GCSE full and short courses in Christianity and Christianity perspectives. The quality and depth of information are comprehensive. The title offers text and picture sources as well as automated and relevant links to the Bible that would be difficult to reproduce in textual form. There is a good resource section, which allows pupils to test their knowledge, though the format is more that of an encyclopedia. The software is accessible, although weaker students would find language levels difficult. The pictures and virtual tours are excellent.

Read a full evaluation of these programs at www.teem.org.uk

fields.headline: Tracey goes to the seaside
fields.standfirst: A £7m Turner centre for Margate?  Ian Martin has an alternative suggestion
fields.trailText: A £7m Turner centre for Margate? Ian Martin has an alternative suggestion
fields.body:
Can art revive the seaside? Kent County Council thinks so - and it is to commission a new £7m arts centre at Margate dedicated to the work of JMW Turner. A Victorian painter's turbulent seascapes at the heart of a 21st-century economic regeneration programme . . . oh dear. Turner may have been the father of modern painting, and undoubtedly has a local connection (he lodged in Margate during the 1830s) but: a) he has been dead for some time and is therefore non-controversial; b) art galleries the length of Britain are already full of his stuff; and c) Tracey Emin comes from Margate.

How much more interesting it would be if Tracey, rather than Turner, were at the heart of this initiative. The aim of the project, after all, is to raise the resort's profile and attract tourists. Margate, once Kent's gateway to the sea, is now little more than a catflap at the end of the A28.

A combination of Spanish package holidays and the evaporation of local industry locked the town into decline, despite regular Northern Soul weekenders and more en suite bedrooms. If anyone can put the town back on the map, it's the Bed Girl. The confessional meta-narrative running through her work is: "I Grew Up In Margate And Someone's Going To Pay For It." If someone's got £7m, now's their chance. Contemporary art should engage, or at least enrage, the viewer. Who needs another architect-designed art box?

The design competition for the Turner Centre is launched this week. Ominously, the assessors are looking for something that "not only works in its own terms, but also enhances the quality of the setting - a building that works as architecture and urban design . . ." Contextual, then, but in the "urban grainy" style championed by Lord Rogers rather than the vernacular "coastal sandy" look.

If this architectural competition runs true to form, at least one of the proposed five shortlisted design teams will resign in a huff. The winning scheme will be damned as an eyesore by the local press and given a horrible nickname. It will turn out to be more expensive than thought and will be redesigned in consultation with local authority bores.

Nobody knows the perils of assessing architecture better than Tracey Emin. She was one of the judges for last year's RIBA Stirling Prize and shared her robust views with Channel 4 viewers, notably on Norman Foster's widely acclaimed Canary Wharf underground station (summary: "Who done this? Fucking Hitler?").

Margate needs to get Tracey back and let her loose on something Mighty Real. Who can forget Every Part Of Me's Bleeding, the reconstructed beach hut she sat in with her pants off? Imagine a grand projet involving, say, 365 new beach huts strung out along the prom!

The artist in residence could live and work for a day in each, leaving behind poignant little tableaux as she goes (empty vodka bottle, pants, etc). At the end of the year you've got Kent's first ever mile-long confessional art piece! Plus some perfectly serviceable beach huts.

You can vote for Turner or Tracey for Margate at www.martian.fm/artnews.htm

fields.headline: School report
fields.standfirst: Intel Computer Microscope
fields.trailText: Intel Computer Microscope
fields.body:
Intel Play QX3 Computer Microscope (www.taglearning.com Tel: 01474 537886)
Price £89.95
Age/ability range KS1-3

The manufacturer says: Connects directly to a computer to capture magnified images, record live video or even make time-lapse movies. Use it on field trips, for science investigations, and to record scientific evidence.

Sharon Dale, IT co-ordinator, Whirley Primary School, Cheshire, says: "I used it with a year 6 class, the right age group for the product. Younger pupils would have needed very structured input. It took me an hour to familiarise myself with the basics. The maker's instructions assumed a certain level of IT literacy. The class really enjoyed it. They learnt about magnification and looked at images projected on to a computer screen. I like the fact that you can save your own images to look at. The microscope could be taken off its stand and pointed [at objects], but the children found it difficult to focus the lens when used in this way (though they still enjoyed fiddling around with it!). It was at its most effective next to the computer where it gave incredibly clear detail. It's a unique product that is reasonable value for money given the cost of a standard microscope."

Curriculum links

Science KS1/2/3: Ideas and evidence; Investigative skills. Good cross-curriculum application with use of computer.

webTitle: Notebook: 700,000 ready to rumble in Orange alert

fields.headline: 700,000 ready to rumble in Orange alert
fields.standfirst:
Punters' instinct is alive and well

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Notebook: Punters' instinct is alive and well
fields.body:
As far as the immediate future is concerned, the flotation of Orange promises a stock market rumble the intensity of which has not been witnessed in recent times.

Take the headline facts. France Telecom needs to sell around 13% of its mobile subsidiary, carrying an indicative price tag of £5.5bn, into a hostile investment environment in which telecom industry valuations have plummeted over the past 10 months and where some sector pundits are already talking about the mobile business going "ex-growth".

To achieve this it has lined up a bruising team of investment banks - led by Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, Morgan Stanley and Société Générale - covering all the main institutional and retail markets in London, New York and continental Europe.

Analysts have been leaned upon so they add their numbers up in the right way; private client stockbrokers have been given juicy commission deals to make sure they foist stock on their clients; and the media, meanwhile, has been saturated with advertising.

On the other side are the big institutional investors and the smaller, albeit vocal, investment banks not included in the fees fest. The professional investors, not surprisingly, want to get this newly floated stock as cheaply as possible, and they already seem to have had some success in talking the price down - the indicative offer range of 733p-860p, valuing all of Orange at just over £40bn, is about a third of earlier predictions. But success breeds confidence, and the institutions know that there is plenty more mobile paper due to be printed by everyone from Deutsche Telecom to BT over the coming months. It is indeed a buyers' market.

In the case of Orange, the oh so reluctant buyers' position has been strengthened by the opacity of the Orange flotation document - drawn up in accordance with the Commission des Operations de Bourse regulations, since the primary listing will be in Paris.

This 360-page tome gives us none of the usual titbits associated with London offers - such as how much the chief executive trousered last year - and is instead structured so as to fuel suspicions of market conspiracy.

Yesterday, for instance, it emerged that the fine print contained news that Mobilecom, the German mobile reseller, enjoys an option to dump some of its shares on Orange - and, with this being a Commission des Operations de Bourse document, there was not enough detail to judge the real importance that should be attached to the matter.

In turn, all this has encouraged some particularly violent research coverage from those few analysts in London without a conflict of interest.

T ake Terry Smith, for example, the Collins Stewart hard man who made his name in the City defacing artificially enhanced balance sheets from firms such as Grand Metropolitan. On his proprietary valuation model, Quest, Orange is 70% overvalued and, even taking the most flattering forecasts from the syndicate selling banks, his figures suggest investors might get a better return from 10-year European government bonds.

Putting it all together, "I hope it is clear why the title of this piece is 'No Rhyme or Reason'," Mr Smith's research concludes. "There is no reason to invest in these shares, and Orange is one of the few words in the English language that does not rhyme with any other."

Compare all this, however, with the fact that, by the close of play last night, at least 700,000 would-be retail punters had registered their interest in having a flutter on Orange. The market as a whole may have tanked last year. Dot.commery burnt innumerable fingers. But the speculative instinct of the British public is clearly live and well.

The betting is that ordinary punters believe that this is a stagging opportunity in the style of the Thatcher-era privatisations. During that period, assets were sold cheaply for political reasons; now assets are being sold at a discount as a market imperative.

Given the fact that retail investors are being offered a 5% discount to the regular offer price, some of the down side risk is already covered. Simultaneously, there is an assumption - or hope - that the institutions will be so successful in talking down the price that Orange's syndicate banks will be forced to set the issue towards the lowest end of its indicative range.

Indeed, there is already evidence of this move. The "grey market" spread on the closing price of Orange after the first day's trading - February 12 - has slipped from 790p-810p last week to 785p-805p last night, according to financial bookie IG Index.

This scenario is reinforced by a general belief that France Telecom just cannot allow the issue to flop.

The repercussions would be just too great to contemplate - for the market as a whole as well as the mobile business itself.

The offer closes on February 8. We will return to the matter, offering firm investment advice, before that deadline.

fields.headline: BBC Phil/ Tortelie
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating ***
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall
Manchester
Rating:***
fields.body:
Brahms was not a composer to let a scherzo stand in the way of a serious piece of music. He didn't allow one so much as a look-in in any of his symphonies, and they are a rarity even in his chamber music. When he let his hair down and included one in his Second Piano Concerto, it was so un-scherzo-like that even he had to joke about it - "a tiny wisp of a scherzo" was his ironic description to a friend.

This concerto is a massive undertaking for any pianist. Nelson Goerner was up to the challenge: I counted a grand total of two wrong notes, and they were only split octaves, not proper mistakes. Nothing was taken for granted: each return of the first movement theme was a moment worth waiting for.

Goerner has the imagination to allow phrasing and pacing to absorb the strain, so that he never reaches the point where getting louder seems the only way of maintaining tension. Though intense, even the dark, elemental scherzo was never violent, and his ability to suspend all sense of time in the dreamlike adagio, partnered by Peter Dixon's cello, was spellbinding. Finally putting gravitas aside, Brahms allows his Gypsy themes to dominate the finale: Goerner toyed with each, holding it up to the light and letting it sparkle.

Bartok's Concerto for Strings, Percussion and Celeste is, as with Brahms's Concerto, a work written at the height of its composer's mature powers. Experimenting with what he called "melodic chromaticism", Bartok created one of the most haunting opening movements ever composed. The dark, twisting fugal theme has an inchoate, primeval quality which intensifies with each entry. However, a slight raggedness in the BBC Philharmonic's strings marred this movement, which never felt really secure. A little more bite would have given the piano part the sadistic glitter it needed in the brittle allegro.

The adagio fared better, its ghostly stalking theme atmospherically coloured by swirling piano, celeste and harp. The chromatic opening theme, gradually unfurling throughout, blossoms in the dance-like finale, which was exuberantly performed.

fields.headline: Feathers
fields.standfirst:
Lyric Hammersmith
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Lyric Hammersmith
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Imagine The Right Size crossed with contemporary dance and you'll have some idea of the field of operation of Giorgio Rossi, a performer and choreographer who has been described as "the clown prince of Italian dance".

Rossi's award-laden theatre-dance show, which arrives in London as part of a ground-breaking mini-season of work for adults and young people called The Catch, is certainly different from the overly literal work for the not-yet-grown-up that is often produced in this country. But for all its infectious good humour it remains as light and insubstantial as a feather.

On a bare stage, three men and three women play out a series of what appear to be friendship and courtship rituals. Whether they are adults playing like children (as I surmised), or children mimicking adults (as my young companions insisted), hardly matters, for the pleasure is all in the game: the teasing, flirting, loving, longing, losing and, on occasion, lying, that takes place in all human relationships. These people are like feathers being constantly blown hither and thither against each other, drifting in and out of relationships.

At its best, the show is a bit like being tickled all over with passages of slapstick interspersed with the most joyous dancing. At one moment the hair of two women becomes living wigs for the two men, who then speak with their mistresses' voices; at another the performers become a carriage and horses. Maybe something to do with love and marriage going together like a horse and carriage. Who knows? Certainly, at the end feathers fall across the stage like confetti. These stage pictures dissolve into wonderfully precise and uninhibited dancing that can be cheeky one minute and absurdly lyrical the next.

This is all enjoyable enough, but the show only ever skates the surface of real emotion and the physical comedy is never sufficiently eloquent to cross the language barrier. I got the distinct impression of an audience that, as the show continued, became increasingly polarised by age and knowledge of French and Italian: adults seemed to love and engage with it, while children became increasingly puzzled, only perking up whenever there was a rude or slapstick moment.

There might be deeper meanings but I never got them; and when a woman plucks a dark feather out of a man's hair and cryptically declares "You are a black swan", you begin to think that the piece isn't just stunted but pretentious. However, you will forgive this company anything once they start to dance, and perhaps that is what they should stick to.

The Catch season continues until March 10. Box office: 020-8741 2311.

webTitle: Can I cut it without a degree?

fields.headline: Can I cut it without a degree?
fields.trailText: 30 January: I am on the foundation year of a four-year engineering course but I am wondering if I have done the right thing.
fields.body:
The problem

I am on the foundation year of a four-year engineering course but I am wondering if I have done the right thing. Last year I started another course, but found it was not right for me. I am now worried that I am not cut out for education.

What has the working world got to offer a person with a foundation but no degree?

The solution

Actually, I think your real question is not "what has the working world got to offer a person with a foundation but no degree", but "what do you want out of your working life?" You have stumbled from one inappropriate course to another, and are now not even sure if you want to study at all. I think you need to step back and undergo some deep self-analysis in order to really discover who you are and what will make you happy before you can start to think effectively about changing direction.

Use this process as a guide:

 First of all, you need to know yourself. You need to identify your skills, talents, strength and weaknesses. Not just academic ones, but things like organisational skills, the ability to work under pressure, the ability to get on with people, enjoyment of taking things apart or building things, etc. You will need to look back over your life so far and pick out experiences that you enjoyed or excelled at, and those that you didn't.

 Once you really know yourself, you should start to think about what might make you happy. Would you prefer a well-paid job to a very satisfying one? Are you bothered by what the status of a job and what other people think about you? Do you want to work with people or are you happier with machines?

 Finally, you need to match your skills and desires with a suitable job or profession. Once you have done this, you will have to find out what it takes to succeed in this profession - whether vocational or academic training is required - and decide whether you are able and willing to undertake this.

Of course, this three-step process is not easy and takes some time. It is very hard to do on your own, but there are a number of places that can help. First of all, visit your careers office at the university and ask for one of their computerised vocation tests. This will help you go through each of the three stages then match your answers with some suitable professions (some of which may not require a University education). Borrow or buy What Color is Your Parachute?' - an excellent book that will help you sort yourself out. Once you know what you want, you will be more motivated to do what is needed to get there and will stop stumbling around in the darkness searching for what cannot easily be seen.


 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

Advice given to this problem should only be regarded as a guide based on the limited information provided by the letter-writer. No responsibility can be taken by Dr Mann for any outcomes following advice given.

fields.headline: LSO/Pappano
fields.standfirst:
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Barbican
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
With Antonio Pappano poised to take over at the Royal Opera House, his London appearances are very much in the limelight. Any conductor looking to impress potentially critical audiences could hardly do better than work with the London Symphony Orchestra. Few orchestras would have been able to tackle this programme and bring it off, but the LSO's line-up of high-calibre soloists and strong ensemble players managed it impressively.

It started with a skilfully shaped piece evoking great atmosphere despite the simplicity of its writing - Arvo Pärt's Cantus in Memory of Benjamin Britten. Phrases given to each of the string sections repeated, diverged and regrouped, while a single bell cut through the ever-intensifying swathes of sound.

During Prokofiev's First Concerto, violinist Alexander Barantschik played with deliberate care, seeming to be concerned that we should not miss a single note Prokofiev wrote. Although he eschewed physical histrionics in favour of a textbook stance, his actual playing grabbed and held the attention. He relished the spikiness of the opening movement's second theme, while the scherzo glittered with brittle strength.

There is tenderness in this concerto too, but a real emotional connection with the audience remained elusive. Next time they play together perhaps Pappano can persuade Barantschik to wear his heart on his sleeve now and then.

Barantschik returned after the interval to lead Shostakovich's Symphony No 10. Here the wind players came into their own. Every principal had a lengthy, finely coloured solo, and the pianissimo clarinet duet towards the end of the first movement was especially rewarding. The huge span tested and ultimately proved Pappano's judgment - the lines and ideas seemed to grow organically from one another, building almost inconspicuously to a scintillating climax.

The final major-key allegro of the symphony can sound like a compromise, written to keep the Soviet authorities happy, but in the LSO's riotous interpretation it might have been the sound of Shostakovich dancing on Stalin's grave.

fields.headline: Gary Potter Quartet
fields.standfirst:
Lawrence Batley Theatre
Huddersfield
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Lawrence Batley Theatre
Huddersfield
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The acclaimed jazz guitarist Gary Potter brought his Gypsy-inspired Django Reinhardt review show to Yorkshire and amazed a devoted crowd with a ferocious display of instrumental prowess.

Far from being a swarthily charismatic Gypsy, Potter is an amiable, plump-faced Liverpudlian, whose cheeky smile and jokes about stealing plectrums from guitar shops mark him as a prosaic and proudly mischievous Scouser. His guitar playing is another matter, stylistically taking in several continents andevoking the woodsmoke and flickering embers of impossibly distant outdoor firesides.

While rhythm guitarist Nils Solberg, best known for his work with Bryan Ferry, maintained a relaxed but rock solid foundation of snaking chords, and award-winning violinist Christian Garrick tugged on our heartstrings, Potter sweated and strutted his stuff, applying every technical trick he has ever learned to every solo and eliciting appropriate gasps of wonder.

Far more than just a jazz stylist, he worked his fingers ever faster to reveal a dazzling array of influences - country twangs, blues string-bending and Spanish classicism - and a considerable debt to the two great Charlies of bop, Parker and Christian. And, of course, Django was all-pervasive.

There is more to Potter than speed alone. He frequently hit passages of refined and colourful lyricism while consistently maintaining a bell-like purity of tone. However, he was prone to self-indulgence, throwing a million notes into the third measure of every solo; 20 seconds into the first number he had already given us his all. His hard work was initially quite thrilling, but he might consider pulling back occasionally and offering up the odd surprise.

While Potter huffed and puffed, often with staggering results, Garrick serenely revealed himself to be the exquisite musician of this ensemble. His playing had all the natural heart-warming exuberance of children at play; and although the guitar made us all gape and shake our heads in wonderment, the violin simply made us swoon.

fields.headline: Nabucco
fields.standfirst:
Coliseum
London
Rating:****
fields.trailText:
Coliseum
London
Rating:****
fields.body:
English National Opera is marking the centenary of Verdi's death with a revival of Nabucco, his first masterpiece and the work that brought the composer to stardom when premiered in 1842.

David Pountney's staging was first unveiled during last year's Italian opera season, when the vast scaffolding of Stefanos Lazarides's multi-purpose set engulfed the auditorium. Pountney has reworked it so that it fits into the rest of the season's repertoire. The divisions between stage, orchestra and audience are blurred, with only the first violins playing in the pit and the rest of the musicians grouped on platforms round the set. The conductor weaves his way among the soloists. The chorus sing from gantries projecting into the auditorium or materialise in the theatre's tiers. Given that Nabucco is partly about the transcendence of divisions - religious and political - the metaphor is telling.

Pountney, bravely, has also attempted to underscore the gulf that now inevitably separates us from the opera itself. Nabucco's initial success was partly due to its tacit equation of the experience of the exiled Jews in Babylon with that of the Italian nation, smarting in internal exile as armies of occupation tramped across it. Verdi briefly and terrifyingly posits the idea of genocide as the outcome of anti-Semitism, but draws back in sincere optimism by effecting the moral and spiritual redemption of its would-be perpetrators. History has horrifically proved him wrong, as Pountney reminds us by relocating the work in the 20th century.

Verdi prefaces each act with Old Testament quotations. Pountney has them spoken in Hebrew by children. We are reminded that man has failed the humanitarian vision that triumphantly reasserts itself at the end of the opera.

Pountney also centres on the Lear-like relationship between Nabucco and his daughters - the monstrous, illegitimate Abigaille and Fenena, loving but tough, like Cordelia. The performances here don't always do the roles justice. Bruno Caproni's Nabucco is beautifully sung and affecting as he passes through madness to redemption, though he is not frightening enough as the racist bigot in the earlier scenes. As Fenena, Claire Weston is happier than she was in the unfortunate staging of the Verdi Requiem last year, but she still squalls when her voice is under pressure.

On the other hand, Lauren Flanigan's Abigaille remains a terrifying, acutely observed study of the insanity of power, while Alastair Miles's Zaccaria - noble, fervent, vocally spectacular yet genuinely spiritual - is second to none.

Conductor Michael Lloyd drives the score with tremendous electricity. Pountney's placing of the performers, though dramatically powerful, has musical drawbacks in that the balance between soloists, chorus and orchestra occasionally comes unstuck.

In rep until February 23. Box office: 020-7632 8300.
fields.bodyText: English National Opera is marking the centenary of Verdi's death with a revival of Nabucco, his first masterpiece and the work that brought the composer to stardom when premiered in 1842. David Pountney's staging was first unveiled during last year's Italian opera season, when the vast scaffolding of Stefanos Lazarides's multi-purpose set engulfed the auditorium. Pountney has reworked it so that it fits into the rest of the season's repertoire. The divisions between stage, orchestra and audience are blurred, with only the first violins playing in the pit and the rest of the musicians grouped on platforms round the set. The conductor weaves his way among the soloists. The chorus sing from gantries projecting into the auditorium or materialise in the theatre's tiers. Given that Nabucco is partly about the transcendence of divisions - religious and political - the metaphor is telling. Pountney, bravely, has also attempted to underscore the gulf that now inevitably separates us from the opera itself. Nabucco's initial success was partly due to its tacit equation of the experience of the exiled Jews in Babylon with that of the Italian nation, smarting in internal exile as armies of occupation tramped across it. Verdi briefly and terrifyingly posits the idea of genocide as the outcome of anti-Semitism, but draws back in sincere optimism by effecting the moral and spiritual redemption of its would-be perpetrators. History has horrifically proved him wrong, as Pountney reminds us by relocating the work in the 20th century. Verdi prefaces each act with Old Testament quotations. Pountney has them spoken in Hebrew by children. We are reminded that man has failed the humanitarian vision that triumphantly reasserts itself at the end of the opera. Pountney also centres on the Lear-like relationship between Nabucco and his daughters - the monstrous, illegitimate Abigaille and Fenena, loving but tough, like Cordelia. The performances here don't always do the roles justice. Bruno Caproni's Nabucco is beautifully sung and affecting as he passes through madness to redemption, though he is not frightening enough as the racist bigot in the earlier scenes. As Fenena, Claire Weston is happier than she was in the unfortunate staging of the Verdi Requiem last year, but she still squalls when her voice is under pressure. On the other hand, Lauren Flanigan's Abigaille remains a terrifying, acutely observed study of the insanity of power, while Alastair Miles's Zaccaria - noble, fervent, vocally spectacular yet genuinely spiritual - is second to none. Conductor Michael Lloyd drives the score with tremendous electricity. Pountney's placing of the performers, though dramatically powerful, has musical drawbacks in that the balance between soloists, chorus and orchestra occasionally comes unstuck. fields.headline: Equitable price hit as bidders cry off
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The potential price of troubled mutual insurer Equitable Life slumped further yesterday as bidders for the business that was once valued at £5bn continued to walk away. City sources warned last night that Equitable might now fetch little more than £300m after AMP, the Australian insurance group, became the latest to pull out of talks.
fields.body:
The potential price of troubled mutual insurer Equitable Life slumped further yesterday as bidders for the business that was once valued at £5bn continued to walk away. City sources warned last night that Equitable might now fetch little more than £300m after AMP, the Australian insurance group, became the latest to pull out of talks.

Only Eureko, an alliance of European insurers, remains - although it was far from certain last night that it had any intentions of formalising a bid.

Equitable closed its doors to new business last month after Prudential refused to table a formal bid for the group amid concern about the true size of its bill for guaranteed annuities. Hopes of a sale were rekindled when policyholders began talks about putting a cap on the guaranteed annuities, which the law lords ruled had been unfairly cut.

Equitable is now trying to lure potential bidders by ringfencing the guaranteed annuities, so allowing bidders to buy the customers, brand, sales force and back office. It insisted last night that it was hopeful that a sale of the operation could still be completed.

fields.headline: Ian Pace
fields.standfirst:
Duke's Hall
Royal Academy of Music
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Duke's Hall
Royal Academy of Music
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
The statistics of Ian Pace's world premiere performance of The History of Photography in Sound, by Michael Finnissy, are mind-boggling. The piece is five and a half hours long, and its five books took Pace an entire day to perform at the Royal Academy. None of the 11 separate "chapters" is shorter than 15 minutes and the longest, at 75 minutes, lasts the same time as a Mahler symphony. Book four alone is a vast, two-hour structure.

The touchstone for enormous piano pieces, Kaikhosru Sorabji's Opus Clavicembalisticum, clocks in on a recent recording at a whisker under four hours - a mere minnow in comparison with the scale of History. Finnissy's main rival for the crown of longest non-repetitive piano piece is La Monte Young's The Well-Tuned Piano. Young's ongoing project now lasts roughhly six hours in performance.

The scale of History is monumental, both in length and the physical and technical difficulties the work poses for an interpreter. In accepting the herculean challenge, Pace - long one of Finnissy's closest collaborators - ensured his status as one of the most adventurous pianists of his generation. Yet the main feature of the music, and the performance, was the opposite of the heroic grandiosity you might expect from such a self-consciously huge piece. History expresses instability, ambiguity and crisis.

Writing a "history" in sound is, in a sense, an impossible task. Music is not capable of expressing the kinds of information needed for such a history, nor the reproductive accuracy of photographs or films. But from the titles and dramas of individual movements, Finnissy's purpose becomes clearer. North American Spirituals, a chapter from the second book, is a critique of the horrors of slavery. The music begins with the spiritual tunes themselves, which gradually become distorted by unpredictable, hysterical outbursts. This is a music of innocence corrupted and perfection disfigured. Here, as elsewhere, Finnissy uses photography as a metaphor for the violence of cultural appropriation.

Quotations from Beethoven, Bach, Berlioz and Wagner appear throughout as ciphers for spirituality, love, death and vanity. But Finnissy's range is much wider than the western tradition: Vendan African songs are prominent in book four, as are Moroccan and Berber folk songs; Indian ragas and 1940s pop songs appear in Book 2. Everywhere there is allusion and critique.

Finnissy explores the tyranny of power in Parents' Generation Thought War Meant Something, the devastation of colonialism in Unsere Afrikareise and the emptiness of capitalism in Kapitalistisch Realisme. Representation, he seems to be saying, is always political.

Paradoxically, this endless ambivalence produces a music that is full of dramatic contrast and virtuosic spectacle. The chapter Alkan-Paganini that opens the third book is even more jaw-droppingly pyrotechnical than anything by Alkan or Paganini.

Pace's strength and conviction were magnificent. Yet there were many passages where his performance seemed more like interior monologue than public event. Although Finnissy's music is one of all-encompassing complexity, it needs vibrant characterisation to come to life. But with the glitter of Etched Bright with Sunlight, the final part of History, Pace - and his devoted audience - had completed a remarkable journey of discovery.
